sentence: "I wanted to be brave for these girls": Sunshine is on the verge of joining the national gymnastics team and going to the Olympics, when she loses focus, careens off balance, and falters
Dreams nearly in her grasp shift to distant phantoms as she realizes she is pregnant
Shaken, fearful, desperate, and determined not to lose her rightful place on the national team, Sunshine searches the underground of the city for abortifacients
Abortion and even divorce are illegal in the Philippines, so Sunshine has few options and few people she can trust
Just then a mysterious young girl appears in the darkness and crowded streets with knowledge of Sunshine's heart that surprises her and touches her deeply
"I wanted to be brave for these girls," said Maris Racal (Sunshine) "who have no one else to turn to
" Racal is intrinsically believable in her role
In the conservative religious culture of the Philippines and with the lack of access to reproductive support, many girls are in crisis
The issue is relatable and timely not just in the Philippines, but in many other countries including, unfortunately, our own
At this world premiere screening at the Toronto International Film Festival, director Antoinette Jadaone said she got the idea for an imaginary friend from the film Jojo Rabbit
As part of her film research Jadaone interviewed girls who had abortions
She hopes the film sparks conversations and change, that it is part of the solution for the country, and helps girls in such situations make their own decisions
An honest, genuine and raw moving story
: I've seen this movie at the cinema alone last night and truly I can say that this is absolutely a genuine heartfelt cinematic experience movie
The story is really an eye opening for everyone especially for the young teenage women out there

It was really sad and heartbreaking story for a young athlete who had a dream to do good in gymnastics in the olympics but struggled in the process because of getting pregnant and doing an abortion in order to do so

One of the best part in the movie wherein I cried and felt bad for the main lead actress was her motel scene, where there is quietness of being alone but all you can hear is the noise of the train running in the background
This scene was very raw and sad to watch especially the time when she struggled so hard to abort her baby just to make sure that she can continue with her dream in the gymnastics
Overall this movie, definitely can be a great contender at the Oscars International Film Feature especially by how cinematic, and compelling the story was
I love how the movie tackled a controversial topic that everyone needs to hear and be open about
Maris Racal and her eyes in this movie is seriously a gem, such an amazing and effective best actress of this generation
This is the sunshine the country needs in today's climate

It was Jadaone's courage that popped in my head when the title card flashed, a very Filipina name that connotes brightness and warmth - two things the film was not intended for, two things the titular character deprived of

Sunshine is a story of every Sunshine, a Filipino woman vulnerable to systemic injustice and oppression; a story no one could have been told better than a Filipino woman herself - and a fearless and intelligent one at that
From reproductive health and general health care system to conservatism, Jadaone's care and spirit championed
Her personification of one's conscience was beautifully done

Perfect execution: Directed by: Antoinette Jadaone Written by: Antoinette Jadaone

SUMMARY

A teenage gymnast, training to compete in the Olympics, is derailed when she discovers she's pregnant
In the Philipppines, where abortion is illegal, she risks everything to end the pregnancy
After surviving a near-fatal scam abortion pill, she finally succeeds and finds closure in a vision of her future child giving her her blessing

RATING

S

Sunshine is absolutely perfect filmmaking
A simple plot - so simple that it risks being stale, but isn't
- that is executed with perfection and nuance
Sometimes the hardest things to get right are those that are the simplest
Superb casting
A Powerful 10/10 Film That Tells the Truth: This 2024 Filipino film follows a teenage gymnast, Sunshine, whose Olympic dreams are suddenly derailed when she finds out she's pregnant
What unfolds is a raw, deeply emotional journey through shame, societal pressure, and the painful reality of having no legal access to abortion-something many women across Asia still face today
The film doesn't sugarcoat anything

It shows exactly what's wrong with restrictive abortion laws in many Asian countries-how they silence girls, punish ambition, and force life-changing decisions on those who are still children themselves
The movie itself is honest, hard-hitting, and emotionally devastating in the best way
Maris Racal's performance was absolutely stunning
She carries the entire film with a performance that is real, raw, and unforgettable
Sunshine should be shown in classrooms, government offices, and households
It's that important
It sparks urgent conversations about women's rights, bodily autonomy, and the price of silence
Sunshine is one of the most courageous and necessary films to come out of Southeast Asia in recent years
It holds up a mirror to society and forces viewers to face uncomfortable truths
Anyone who thinks film can't change minds hasn't seen this one yet
This is not just a good movie-this is essential cinema
A masterpiece
One of the most important Filipino films: "Sunshine" is not just the greatest Filipino movie I've seen but one of the most important Filipino films of all-time
This film deals with controversial topics in our society, abortion and teen pregnancy
A week of national tryout for the gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal) finds out that she's pregnant
Conflicts arise as she has to decide what to do next
In between life and dreams, what's the most significant between the two
The film is unconventional at best
This is not your usual and average Filipino drama you'll see
It's a character study about a teenager who is on the down side of her life
We follow her journey through this life and see a glimpse of her life dealing with her problem
Maris Racal defines this film as Sunshine
Her acting here is brilliant
She's perfect for this role
Jennica Garcia surprised me
Her character as Sunshine's sister marks
What she said to Sunshine near the ending, though it's common, is like a punch to tears
I ended up loving her character
Jennica Garcia deserves an award for being the best supporting actress for this role
Another cast that standout is Rhed Bustamante and Xyriel Manabat both deserve a recognition for their role
Blurring between reality and fantasy, mostly this film is realistic in portraying the whole theme thanks to Direk Antoinette Jadaone directions
Also, the cinematography is the best
Overall, "Sunshine" is a women's movie
It's timely, affecting and brave to its theme
It doesn't spoon feed
It will make you immersed and think
It's worth an experience
This is a rare Filipino movie I've seen
I'm glad and proud watching this in cinema
After watching "Sunshine", it leaves me with a question, "Is abortion a choice if your greatest dream will compromise
Sunshine is the collective experience of many Filipina: We watched Sunshine yesterday, July 24, during the block screening at SM Megamall
I had seen the trailer beforehand, so I knew we were in for something bold, something necessary
But I wasn't prepared for how deeply it would sit with me long after the credits rolled
I didn't cry while watching the film, but once it ended, I found myself overwhelmed
The weight of Sunshine doesn't hit all at once - it lingers, it settles
And it stays
At its core, Sunshine is the story of a woman taking control of her body in a society that keeps telling her she isn't allowed to
It's not simply about one choice, one moment, or one woman
It's about the collective experience of many Filipinas who navigate a system that consistently fails to hear them
Antoinette Jadaone's direction doesn't shy away from discomfort

She faces it head-on, inviting the audience to confront the silences we've learned to live with - about abortion, reproductive rights, the stigma around sexuality, and the lack of access to informed sex education in the Philippines
Sunshine is timely, urgent, and painfully real
It gives voice to the cry of our generation, echoing the need for progressive reforms that protect women and children
The film challenges its viewers not just to empathize, but to act
As a viewer, I left the cinema not only moved, but also awakened
Sunshine isn't here to entertain
It's here to disturb, to provoke, and to push us into uncomfortable yet necessary conversations
To my fellow Filipinos: let's not turn away
Let's create spaces where women can speak freely, where choices about their bodies are met with compassion, not judgment
Let's demand that our lawmakers stop treating reproductive health as taboo
To filmmakers and storytellers: keep telling these stories
We need more films like Sunshine-bold, unapologetic, and grounded in truth
The personal is political, and cinema has the power to move both heart and policy
Let Sunshine be a beginning
Let it be a spark
And let's keep the conversation going
Sunshine - A Raw and Eye-Opening Film: Sunshine is truly an eye-opener
It bravely tackles real issues that so many young adults-and even kids who are just stepping into their teenage years-are silently going through
The film dives deep into the realities of early pregnancy, abortion, and the emotional and social weight that comes with them
What I really hope is that parents take the time to watch this film
Not just to be aware, but to feel that urgency-the need to guide and talk to their children about these sensitive but important topics
It's a conversation that can't be delayed anymore
What stood out to me the most was how real and raw everything felt
I didn't leave the cinema feeling happy, but I did feel relieved
I felt the pain, the heartache, and the struggle that Sunshine went through-but I also saw the strength in her journey
The story is complete
It gives you everything from beginning to end, no shortcuts, no sugar-coating
I loved the film
I honestly want to watch it again-not just for the story, but for the emotions it stirred up and the awareness it brings
This film matters

It perfectly captures and delivers the message it intends to relay
Just beautiful

Moves you even if you yourself cannot directly relate, and that is where the magic proves itself

Sunshine: The performances are outstanding, with the lead actress delivering a raw and emotional portrayal of Sunshine's struggles
The supporting cast adds depth to the story, particularly the little girl, who brings a sense of wonder and curiosity to the film
One of the most striking aspects of "Sunshine" is its refusal to provide easy answers
The film presents a realistic portrayal of the complexities surrounding reproductive choices, leaving viewers to ponder the moral implications
Still processing
This film stays with you
: Maris Racal delivers an incredibly raw and grounded performance
You feel her tension, her fear, her hope and the heartbreak that comes from making an impossible decision
She doesn't ask you to agree with her character
She just asks you to understand
And that's powerful
Direk Tonet Jadaone has once again proven her gift for telling stories that cut deep
This film doesn't shout, but it lingers
It haunts you in the quiet moments
It reflects a reality many would rather not see one where shame is louder than support, and judgment comes faster than help

Responsibility is Also a Choice: The film Sunshine, directed by Antoinette Jadaone, presents a deeply emotional and socially relevant story that challenges how Filipinos view teenage pregnancy, abortion, and womanhood
It is a complex and sensitive topic, especially in a country that is deeply rooted in religion and traditional values

As a viewer and as someone who is pro-abortion, I strongly believe that abortion should be legalized-not to promote recklessness, but to ensure safe healthcare for women who are placed in impossible situations
What makes Sunshine powerful is how quietly but painfully it reflects reality
The film does not exaggerate emotions; instead, it shows how fear, confusion, and pressure from society weigh heavily on young women
It highlights how judgment often speaks louder than understanding
In many cases, the girl is seen as the only one responsible for what happened, while the systems meant to protect her fail
In the Philippines, many people argue that illegalizing abortion teaches responsibility
But isn't choosing abortion also a form of responsibility
Knowing that you are not ready-emotionally, financially, or mentally-to raise a child can already be an act of maturity
We openly preach safe sex, yet we deny women access to safe abortion
This contradiction puts women's lives at risk
For me, this issue is not about the rights of a fetus alone-it is also about the rights of a living woman
In my own view, if my mother had gotten pregnant in her teenage years while still chasing her dreams, I would rather not be born than be the reason her future was taken away
I would not remember it, I would not suffer from that decision-but at least she would have lived the life she wanted
That, too, is a form of love and sacrifice
Another harsh reality the film touches on is how society treats teenagers who experience early pregnancy
Many say, "They enjoyed it," or "They wanted it
" But a child or a teenager needs guidance from responsible adults, not condemnation
Blaming them does not fix the problem
This is not about tolerating impulsive behavior-it is about educating both girls and boys, teaching accountability, protection, and respect
Sunshine makes you realize that judgment is easy, but compassion is rare
The film reminds us that behind every controversial situation is a scared, confused young girl who still deserves empathy and protection
Overall, Sunshine is a brave and emotionally heavy film that forces us to confront one of the most uncomfortable issues in Filipino society
It does not give easy answers, but it asks the right questions
For me, the film strengthens the belief that abortion should be legalized-not to promote irresponsibility, but to protect women, save lives, and give them the freedom to choose their own future
True responsibility does not come from punishment and shame, but from understanding, education, and safe choices
Sunshine is not just a movie-it is a mirror of our society and a challenge to our beliefs
A Missed Opportunity to Stick the Landing: I had been waiting a long time to watch Sunshine, especially since I never got the chance to see it on the big screen
So, when it finally arrived on Netflix, I was so excited, only for that excitement to fade the longer I watched
The premise is undeniably compelling: a young gymnast discovers she's pregnant just as her lifelong dream of reaching the Olympics is within reach
It's a setup filled with emotional stakes and potential for a powerful, character-driven story
But instead of exploring her dedication to the sport, the film shifts almost entirely to her pregnancy and her attempts to deal with it
I kept waiting for scenes that would show her fighting for her dream, intense training, the pressure of competition, the physical and emotional toll of gymnastics, but those moments never really come
The narrative focuses more on side characters and subplots that feel unnecessary and, frankly, uninteresting
I couldn't help comparing this film to other international athlete biopics that portray the grit, passion, and relentless work behind the journey
Sunshine had all the ingredients to deliver that kind of inspiring story, but it simply doesn't stick the landing
Overall, I'm disappointed
With a stronger focus on the athletic journey and the challenges of balancing an unexpected pregnancy with Olympic ambitions, this could have been a much more compelling and memorable film

This film truly highlights how anti abortion is violence against women: While the subject is powerful and brave and the acting excellent, the execution and cinematography are weak, marring what could have been an excellent film

The hospital scene where the evil "Jesus" Dr
Berates the propagandist for attempting an abortion absolutely enraged me because it is so accurate as to how women are treated
I think the film would have been better if it has put more emphasis on Sunshine's sister who supported and helped her

All that said, this is a powerful and timely film about an important subject
I applaud all those involved for having the courage to show the evil at the heart of Filipino culture, and for daring to stand up against the "pro life" machine

Dreams nearly in her grasp shift to distant phantoms as she realizes she is pregnant
Shaken, fearful, desperate, and determined not to lose her rightful place on the national team, Sunshine searches the underground of the city for abortifacients
Abortion and even divorce are illegal in the Philippines, so Sunshine has few options and few people she can trust
Just then a mysterious young girl appears in the darkness and crowded streets with knowledge of Sunshine’s heart that surprises her and touches her deeply
“I wanted to be brave for these girls,” said Maris Racal (Sunshine) “who have no one else to turn to
” Racal is intrinsically believable in her role
In the conservative religious culture of the Philippines and with the lack of access to reproductive support, many girls are in crisis
The issue is relatable and timely not just in the Philippines, but in many other countries including, unfortunately, our own

This is a film of two parts
This film is part compelling drama, with a strong lead performance from the young actor and a powerful examination of the treatment of women in the Phillipines
This film is also part surrealist, but in a way that I feel undermines the strengths of the film
There is a young girl who appears at various points throughout the film; her identity is left to interpretation
However I feel that this apparition weakens every scene she's in
You'll have this powerful understated drama and then this wise-cracking girl appears to swear at you
It is clear that they couldn't even make her fit throughout the film because she disappears for at least half an hour in the middle
The filmmaker said this was the original core concept of the film and I understand that, but I feel that the film moved beyond the need for this character
I will say that I found the final interaction between the girl and our protagonist quite touching
Maybe if the girl was more understated it could have worked better

I do want to mention that it was really lovely to be in the TIFF audience for this one; the Filipino community was so passionate about this film and it was the longest and most involved Q&A I'd ever seen
It's really inspiring to see how beloved it was

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichés and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines — which is prohibited in the constitution itself — Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge
Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy

With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (it’s obvious when no one else interacts
While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of women’s rights in the Philippines, Jadaone’s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message

Filipino movies ranged from Hallmark style romances, repetitive action movies and cheesy low budget horror (although Shake, Rattle and Roll did slap)

Switching between goofy magic realism, teenage coming-of-age clichés and a gritty look at the reality of trying to get an abortion in the Philippines — which is prohibited in the constitution itself — Sunshine is a heartfelt story with an angry edge
Maris Racal stars as the wonderfully-named Sunshine Francisco, an aspiring gymnast whose potential tryouts at the Olympics are derailed by an unexpected pregnancy

With no officials to turn to, she is forced to search the black market, where she is followed by a strange young girl (Annika Co) who appears to be a figment of her imagination (it’s obvious when no one else interacts
While the film certainly draws awareness to this issue of women’s rights in the Philippines, Jadaone’s cornier tendencies overwhelm the message

Antes que nada he de decir que la la cinematografía de Pao Orendain en Sunshine es un deleite: sus planos capturan la ciudad de manera natural, con un lenguaje de cámara preciso que da vida a la historia con una sencillez bella y efectiva
A través de una mirada profundamente realista, Antoinette Jadaone narra la historia de una adolescente atrapada en una sociedad que niega la libertad de la mujer sobre su cuerpo
La película muestra de manera sutil pero poderosa el conflicto interno de la protagonista, atrapada entre sus deseos, su futuro y las estrictas normas y creencias impuestas por su entorno

El guion, que entrelaza la historia con la presencia de una misteriosa niña pequeña que persigue a Sunshine, ofrece una reflexión sobre cómo las cargas y creencias sociales se transmiten de generación en generación; subrayando la continuidad de esas presiones a lo largo del tiempo

What sets ‘Sunshine’ apart is how writer-director Antoinette Jadaone roots the film in the Philippines’ conservative culture, shaped by Catholicism and its influence on public policies
While some moments may feel a bit heavy-handed, Jadaone delivers an earnest take on the tension between religious values and societal realities, while occasionally poking fun at certain hypocrisies
Another unique aspect of ‘Sunshine’ is how it weaves in magic realism

This creative approach, which is like a mix of Taika Waititi’s ‘Jojo Rabbit’ and Celine Sciamma’s ‘Petite Maman’, might not be for everyone; nevertheless, it enriches the discourse and keeps the narrative from feeling simplistic

Early in this coming-of-age sports drama from Antoinette Jadaone, we see Maris Racal as the titular character, twisting and turning her body gracefully like a professional who's been doing this routine all her life
Right there and then, I told myself silently that this is going to be the best and most unforgettable performance of her career
In the film, she plays Sunshine, a dedicated young gymnast preparing for her team’s upcoming tryouts for the Olympics
But days before their tryouts, she discovers that she is pregnant
Now she must embark on a desperate and risky journey to fight for her dream

Penned and directed by Antoinette Jadaone, this is definitely one of her strongest works and one that truly stands out amongst all the films in her sprawling filmography, thanks to its solid script paired with equally confident direction

Her works, which are reminiscent of the late Marilou Diaz-Abaya, albeit with a more modern flair, are always centered around fully fleshed-out female characters who, while at times flawed, go through a transformative journey (case in point: directing That Thing Called Tadhana, Beauty in a Bottle (2014), Never Not Love You (2018), Alone/Together (2019), and Fan Girl (2020))
And this latest one is no different

Here, we follow a young woman faced with the burden of her unplanned pregnancy in a country like the Philippines, where abortion is illegal under all circumstances and has no exceptions, even in cases of rape, incest, or when the woman's life is at risk
It's honestly a pretty daunting task to write a story like this given its themes, let alone actually make one and release it in a highly conservative, mostly Catholic country like the Philippines
Yet Jadaone successfully completed the film without sacrificing her vision
The film manages to bravely portray the burden brought by unwanted pregnancies to women while men get a free pass in this patriarchal society designed by and controlled by men
It also paints how religious people can't help but keep shoving their beliefs on others instead of minding their own business
Most importantly, the film discusses the importance of a proper health care system in a third-world country like ours, which is run by capitalism and corrupt government officials
Instead of providing safe and accessible procedures like safe abortion for women, we have a country forcing them to find unsafe means on their own, endangering their lives in the process
Performance-wise, the film is packed with numerous talents, so not a single shot in the film is put to waste
Both Meryll Soriano as Sunshine's coach, Eden, and Xyriel Manabat as her best friend, Thea, are effective
Elijah Canlas nails the gaslighting asshole of a boyfriend, Miggy, while Jennica Garcia is simply brilliant as Sunshine's sister, Geleen
Other noteworthy turns include Rhed Bustamante, Juan Miguel Garcia, Angeli Bayani, and Piolo Pascual in a cameo role as Miggy's father
A young Annika Co also shines with her role as the young girl constantly nagging Sunshine
But the film will definitely not work if not for the career-best portrayal from its lead, Maris Racal, who delivers a tour-de-force performance as Sunshine herself
One can really feel and see the dedication she had for such a demanding role, physically and emotionally
Her performance really pulls you into the film and won't let go until the emotionally charged third act, making it one of the best local female performances I've seen this year so far
The film also boasts some great visuals thanks to Pao Orendain's slick camerawork and incredible music courtesy of Rico Blanco—a first for the singer-songwriter
Overall, this latest film from Antoinette Jadaone is one rollercoaster of emotions that is buoyed by a daring and electrifying performance from Maris Racal
It's a poignant, gripping and thought-provoking journey of a woman coming to terms with her own inner conflicts
It's already halfway through the year, but this is already the best Filipino film of 2025 in my opinion
Trust me, you will not be prepared for how powerful this film is
This is the best Filipino film I've seen so far
It follows a gymnast whose dreams are challenged by an unexpected pregnancy
Because the Philippines are incredibly Catholic, abortion is illegal and hard to execute
Will she give in to the pressure of keeping the child, will she seek medically unadvised procedures, or will she get help from others who understand her situation
The film explores the pressures that religion and misogyny place on young women - pressures that unfortunately appear to still be widespread in today's world
Watched as a representative of UP Cinema
It's a brave take on one of the most controversial issues in Philippine society ever
Maris Racal is soooo good
Direk Tonet is on Fan Girl mode: things get quite tense and harrowing

Claustrophobic, not just in how the frame is composed in several scenes, but in how it shows the extent in which the malignant structure of self-righteous patriarchal conservatism has done palpable harm to women and children everywhere
The film uses its central plotline to weave a rich tapestry of people and places that paint a picture of how this corrupted structure affects the titular protagonist, as well as the people around her
The tone possesses a gradually ratcheting anger at the oppressive status quo, going for the throats of its targets with at times bleak satire, or crushing nightmarish realities
This indignation, however, is ultimately fueled out of immense compassion
The film never really downs itself in hopelessness as it actively claws for hope, and never loses sight of Sunshine's agency through it all
Maris Racal's humane, scrappy performance is the total anchor of this film, carrying the heaviness with determination impressively

Although the breadth of the screenplay's scope is the film's biggest strength, there is some messiness in terms of scene-by-scene progression, and the more metaphorical/allegorical stuff doesn't fully coalesce with the film's more tangible arcs
Still, its willingness to take an approach both upfront and delicate to its central topic proves to be a burning, driving core towards a cathartic final endpoint
Meaningful, impassionate stuff
I am averse to making comparisons to Brocka, but here we are
You see it in this film's Manila, a hysterically cruel city that somehow maintains its kindness in its edges
Here we are, at the claws of light, a sliver of sunshine cutting through the darkness
Sunshine makes a lot of bad decisions, but that's all she has
This is a nation of bad decisions, especially when it comes to the plight of young women
And she has to weave through these apathetic streets to find the kindness that exists in spite of the cruelty
The film uses a device that I found tenuous at points, though I do think it works out in the end
It's just that the film is so good at depicting the casual reality of these characters and the city that surrounds them that I found the break from it a little distracting

The film is transcendent when it just shows us what this city is: a place where a churchyard is where you go to find abortion drugs, a city where a motel is hesitant to give you a room if you're alone, a place where a person charged with caring for you might also take it as an opportunity to shame you for your choices
At the heart of this is Maris Racal, who delivers what might be the performance of a lifetime
A lot is asked of the young actress, who is made to mask the rage of generations of women and put on the facade of someone who is pretending that all this will pass without incident
It is sadness and worry, but also the prevailing need to show the world that everything is okay
She gets ample support from the rest of the cast, with Jennica Garcia in particular embodying the spirit of this film in its most crucial moments
There were several moments watching Sunshine where I find myself saying, "yes
" Yes, because I was agreeing with what the movie was saying
Yes, because it was showing me a Manila that felt right
Yes, because Racal was really nailing something
Yes, because the music just swelled at just the right moment
There will be much talk about what the movie says, what it argues in the face of a society that often feels immovable
But here we are
Here it is
All I can say is yes
“Mahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas

”No matter how matriarchal, modern, or progressive we claim to be, women here are still shackled by outdated norms, patriarchal laws, and the belief that their bodies and their choices are not truly their own
Sunshine confronts these hard truths with unflinching honesty
The quiet desperation of having limited options
The shame bred by religious and societal expectations
The resilience women are forced to summon simply to survive
Maris Racal delivers a tour-de-force performance
I’ve loved her since Marupok AF, but here, she transcends
She carries the film with depth and vulnerability, her portrayal of Sunshine equal parts fragile and fierce
She’s matched beautifully by Jennica Garcia, whose turn as her older sister is quietly powerful
In her hands, sisterhood becomes a form of motherhood, a reminder that parenting can come from places we least expect
Sunshine hopes to be a catalyst for reproductive rights, choice, and change
And at its core, it’s a love letter to every Filipina who has ever had to fight for her rights and a light in the dark
Go see it

Phenomenal drama that explores so many aspects of abortion and the various aspects of living in a deeply religious society where it is illegal
Maris Racal is truly astounding as the title character
Cinemaster FJ Calvario says:In 2022, the government of Cuba had undertaken a bold move
It ratified a revision of its Family Code which redefined the “family”
It was no longer defined by only biological ties but also by relationships based on love and mutual support
This revised code is a radical piece of legislation, expanding the rights of women and children and recognizing same-sex marriages and adoption
It is a watershed moment for a country once colonized by Catholic Spain whose religious policies defined what was and wasn't allowed in society
In another corner of the world, the government of the Philippines continues to enforce the same religious norms set by Spain
Unlike Cuba, the Philippines has a long road ahead of itself in dismantling colonial legacy
A road perhaps may be paved by radical films such as Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine
A pioneer of the dialogue-driven hugot films of the 2010s, Jadaone is best known for her screenplays that blended comedy and romance
However, beginning with 2020’s haunting thriller Fan Girl which tackled male idolatry in the Duterte era, she seems to be on a sociopolitical streak in her directorial efforts
Her latest drama Sunshine now examines a woman’s decision to abort her pregnancy in a country where it is illegal and heavily stigmatized by the influential Catholic Church
At the heart of the film is the eponymous protagonist Sunshine (played by Maris Racal), a gymnast who dreams to compete for the Olympics
We first see Sunshine practice her routine in a stunningly directed scene showcasing well-paced editing and choreography
The pulsating electronic score by Rico Blanco is the cherry on top
He embodies his inner Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross who coincidentally scored another sports film released the same year as this one
Her character’s Olympic ambitions remind me of the great women athletes in our country who have been making waves for their international achievements
I see in her the Olympic gold-winning weightlifter Hidlyn Diaz and the Wimbledon-competing tennis player Alexa Eala
But this dream of Olympic glory and national pride may not be realized if Sunshine decides to continue her pregnancy

We spend much of the film following her as she navigates through her personal relationships with her family and friends, her boyfriend, her gymnastics coach, and a mysterious girl who questions her decision to abort
It’s quite a cast really
Maris Racal makes the film as Sunshine; she plays her with steadfast determination
Bubbling behind Racal's eyes is great fear and tragedy
Xyriel Manabat does a lot with silent glances as Sunshine’s best friend Thea who begins to distance herself from her pregnant friend
Elijah Canlas epitomizes the upper class douchebag as Miggy the boyfriend, frequently speaking in straight English and hilariously offloading responsibility to his girlfriend

Annika Co as the mysterious nagging girl manages to be cute, annoying, and threatening in the same scene (although her character’s inclusion in the film is questionable and counter-intuitive, well intentioned as it is)
Jadaone’s dense screenplay is riveting in its timeliness, empathy and boldness

The struggle of Sunshine in choosing between her career and an unwanted pregnancy recalls last year’s controversy around another athlete the Olympic gold winner Carlos Yulo who feuded with his mother over the latter’s misappropriation of his hard earned money
The discourse around the Yulo issue saw the clashing of cultures, the divide between conservatives (who viewed the athlete as an ungrateful son) and progressives (who championed Carlos’s autonomy)
I expect the same discourse around Sunshine’s decision in choosing herself to unfold in Facebook comments sections once the film gets widely released in the country
It takes a cold heart not to be moved by Sunshine’s struggle for bodily autonomy
Jadaone situates her protagonist in the working class environs of Manila
It is a landscape defined by neglect and economic difficulties
Sunshine’s mother and father are nowhere to be seen, leaving only Sunshine and her siblings to fend for themselves
Sunshine meets a young girl who is also in need of money for her own abortion, having been raped by her own family member
Miggy refuses to share the burden of Sunshine’s pregnancy and keeps his distance
Beyond her words, Jadaone’s images (courtesy of cinematographer Pao Orendain) strikingly capture urban oppression
There is a great shot of Sunshine praying behind the grills of a church, visualizing the struggle between Catholic faith and personal freedom
There’s another great shot where a lone Sunshine is again framed behind a window of a motel beside a train line, highlighting how isolating her struggle can be
Who would want to give birth to a child into a world of constant struggle amidst economic hardship and social stigma
The screenplay brilliantly reimagines what a family and society could be
In the place of a mother and a father, Sunshine has two mother figures: her sister Geleen (played by Jennica Garcia) and her coach Eden (played by Meryll Soriano)

Where other films would fixate on the familial tension between a parent and a child, this film is refreshingly optimistic in envisioning a family that supports and respects each other in their decisions, even with a decision as controversial as abortion
Sunshine’s supportive, orphaned family challenges the dominant Filipino imagination of the family (a father, a mother, and children)
There is a wryly funny dialogue exchange in a Catholic hospital scene between Geleen and a conservative doctor where the former defends Sunshine by pointing out the doctor’s religious hypocrisy
Jadaone’s screenplay beautifully emphasizes the solidarity between women
Beyond interactions within her family, we see Sunshine helped by a kind doctor (played by Angeli Bayani) and, in turn, she helps a young pregnant girl (played by Rhed Bustamante)
Even in an unjust male-dominated world, the film shows hope in the kindness among women
I have read reviews comparing this film to works of Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya
Perhaps, they are not far off

What Jadaone achieves in this film is the start of an honest conversation about women’s bodily autonomy in our society, much like what Brocka and Abaya have done in their social dramas during the Second Golden Age of Philippine Cinema
Time will tell how impactful Sunshine will be on legislation regarding abortion and other aspects of women’s rights
The Philippines, society and state, has a long way ahead to embrace progressive ideas, unlike for our fellow ex-Spanish colony Cuba
I suspect this film will trigger backlash among conservative audiences
God, imagine the online discourse and private message chains from concerned parents
But I do hope that close minded people would be moved by a film as empathetic as Sunshine
Watch Sunshine exclusively in SM Cinemas starting July 23

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is a powerful, intimate portrait of a young gymnast who discovers she’s pregnant just days before her Olympic tryouts
Rather than using the pregnancy as a dramatic twist, the film treats it as a deeply human moment—one that forces Sunshine to confront her identity, future, and agency as a young woman
Jadaone’s direction is sensitive and grounded, allowing the story to unfold with quiet urgency and emotional truth
The film bravely highlights the invisible struggles women face when ambition and reality collide
Through layered characters and subtle symbolism, Sunshine reveals how choices—especially for women—are rarely simple, often shaped by expectations and silent pressures
Maris Racal delivers a standout performance, capturing Sunshine’s vulnerability and strength with nuance
The final scene is restrained yet powerful, offering a deeply satisfying end
Sunshine is a brave, necessary film that speaks volumes about the difficult choices women must make in a world that rarely makes space for them

As in Fan Girl, the best thing about Jadaone’s filmmaking here is how she leverages unreality to create an immersive, tactile, and real subjective experience

The film is not just set in Manila, but Sunshine’s Manila, at times hypocritically prim and tragically seedy, both just different modes of alienation borne from the conservative milieu that devalues and abandons the marginalized among us, here particularly young women

It’s a potent text not because it presents clear answers—although its allegiance to its protagonist is never uncertain—but because it paints the sort of full and rich portrait of a woman’s life that the society it portrays cannot seem to imagine for the women in it
Very good
Sunshine is a powerful, empathetic, and important film that bravely confronts a topic still considered taboo in the Philippines
As someone born and raised in the country, I found it both courageous and deeply resonant
It’s not just what the film is trying to say, but how it says it and, that stands out
They did it with care, nuance, and emotional clarity rarely seen in local cinema
Premiering internationally was also a smart and strategic move
It speaks to how difficult it still is to have open conversations around abortion back home

The truth is, stories that challenge long-held cultural or moral beliefs often need recognition from abroad before they’re embraced locally, a reflection of our lingering colonial mindset and deeply rooted conservatism
I truly hope Sunshine finds its audience in the Philippines
It deserves to, it needs to
Until we confront the systems that silence stories like these
Film this bold will remain the exception, not the norm
And for that alone, I commend Jadaone
We need films like Sunshine—not just to provoke, but to create space for real change

During the film's duration, I felt like I was drowning
I was drowning with Sunshine in the chaos of Manila's unsafe milieu
As she traverse the limited and unfair choices, the feeling of helplessness associated with the ticking time bomb inside her is tactile

I felt restrained from the very beginning until the penultimate scene because every obstacle she goes through, she can't show weakness; she has to show up with a brave face because of the programmed noise in her head; which was generated by the years of social norms put upon every woman's shoulder
One of the most profound and sensitive moments I found deeply moving was when Sunshine said, "Hindi po ako buntis, coach", yet her eyes was swelling with tears

She can't believe that this is the only truth she is forced to deal with, that everything she has worked for will end in a whim, and that the choice wasn't even deliberately made by her; mirroring the many women in the Philippines who undergo teenage pregnancy, who also don't have a safe choice for their bodies, and for their dreams
As I sit and bask in her story in the cinema, my tears kept falling even in the most simplistic emotions
Maybe that's what happens when you feel like you've already lost the battle even if you haven't started to face it it yet
Maybe that's how it feels to be in the losing end of the decisions made by the very society that should be protecting you
Maybe this is how it is to step in the shoes of every woman in the Philippines, and at the very least, it's only a feeling I can imagine

in search of a way to undo it, she crosses paths with a strange girl who mirrors her fears, thoughts, and silence
what follows is a quiet unraveling of control, shame, and choice

Sa Pilipinas, ang mga tulad ni Sunshine ay pinipilit habulin ang liwanag kahit paulit-ulit silang nilulunod sa dilim
Alam naman nating lahat: illegal ang aborsyon sa bansang ito
Pero kailanman, hindi ito makakapigil sa aborsyon
Ang nagagawa lang nito ay itulak ang mga babae sa delikado, hindi ligtas, at hindi kontroladong paraan
At ipinakita sa atin ng pelikulang ito kung gaano ka-mapanganib iyon

Mula sa pagbebenta ng pamparegla sa mga black market hanggang sa mga hilot na hindi naman ginagawa ng propesyonal—lahat ‘yan ay repleksyon ng desperasyong hindi nila ginusto, kundi bunga ng sistemang patuloy silang pinapabayaan
Pero hindi lang aborsyon ang laman ng pelikulang ito

Binuksan nito ang mas malawak na usapin—bulok na healthcare system, paniniwalang relihiyoso na ginagamit panlaban sa kababaihan, incest, rape, teenage pregnancy, pressure bilang atleta, takot sa kahihiyan, at moralidad na tila laging nakasandal sa pananakit ng babae
Pinakita ng pelikula ang buong paligid ni Sunshine—pamilya, paaralan, simbahan, coach, kaibigan, doktor—at kung paano sila naging bahagi ng problema o ng solusyon
At sobrang tamang-tama lang na sa Maynila ito kinunan
Sa Morayta, Recto, at Quiapo—mga lugar na malapit sa University Belt, kung saan maraming estudyante ang nakakaranas ng hindi planadong pagbubuntis
Mga lugar rin ito na kilala sa underground na kalakaran—mula sa pekeng dokumento hanggang sa black market na pampalaglag
Realidad ito ng maraming kabataan, at pinili ng pelikula na hindi ito pagtakpan
Wala itong pa-plot twist
Walang engrandeng eksena
Pero ramdam mo ang bigat
At naipaabot niya ang mensahe nang malinaw sa masa, sa bawat Pilipinong kailangang mamulat
Hindi para mangumbinsi, kundi para magpasimula ng pag-uusap
Pag-uusap na maaaring maging tulay tungo sa legalisasyon—o kahit dekriminalisasyon—ng aborsyon sa bansa natin
Sobrang husay ni Maris Racal
Para siyang talagang gymnast
Lahat ng galaw may kahulugan
Lahat ng tahimik na sandali, may sigaw
Kudos sa choreographers—dahil bawat routine, may sariling kwento
Si Sunshine ay isa lang
Pero napakarami pang katulad niya
Iba-iba man ang dahilan, iisa ang dapat malinaw: ang desisyon ay dapat laging nasa babae
Sa katawan nila
Sa buhay nila
Hindi kailangan ng pelikula ng sagot
Pero may lakas ito para magtanong
At sa isang bansang takot harapin ang tanong, sapat na iyon para tawaging rebolusyonaryo
Sana ang Sunshine na ito, maging sinag ng panibagong simula

The best Filipino film I’ve seen so far this year
Raw, relevant, and worth talking about
Set in Manila: masikip, mainit, mabaho
The film captures it so well that you can almost smell and feel it
Beneath that heat and heaviness is a quiet story of sacrifice
It powerfully portrays the struggles of women in a deeply patriarchal society
Young women are expected to give way, to carry the weight, to make the harder choice
While men are often free to walk away, women are left at the crossroads, torn between duty and ambition, between what they want and what they are told they should become
Its honest portrayal of everyday hardship, mixed with strong feminist themes, feels like it is channeling both Lino Brocka and Marilou Diaz-Abaya
The film also reflects the quiet hypocrisy we see in everyday life
No one is truly exempt
People speak of values, yet live with contradictions
The film shows us these double standards in a way that makes you reflect
Maris Racal is so, so good as Sunshine
The rest of the cast is just as strong
Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Rhed Bustamante and the rest of the casts are all remarkable
I also appreciate how even the crowd and background extras were credited at the end
It speaks volumes about how everyone involved was valued
And what a story it is
Raw, relevant, and worth talking about
Sunshine is not just the best Filipino film I have seen this year
It is one that dares to ask difficult questions and sit with uncomfortable truths
Brave and thought-provoking, it will likely spark conversation after the ending credits
Some of the choices in the film may feel morally difficult, and not everyone will agree with them
But the real question is, who are we to decide what is right for someone else
Are we even in their place to judge
More than anything, Sunshine reminds us to be kind
To live with empathy
To listen, to pause, and to try to understand before we judge
Just like these past few days, the rain has not stopped
For some, it is a blessing
For others, it feels like a never-ending trial
But in the middle of it all, we wait for the same thing: Sunshine
Sunshine that reminds us that after the storm, healing begins
And slowly, we rise

ChoicesSunshine makes mistakes and will make mistakes
People will question why she is pregnant at a very young age
And it was clearly hers and her boyfriend’s choice to be unprotected
And when she decided to tell him she was pregnant, both of them had to make choices
But when legal options run out for Sunshine and the only choice she can make is to abort through illegal means, she puts her own life at risk
But it is also in making a choice that Sunshine finds herself
God’s Gift Sunshine leaves a jeepney with the words God’s Gift
She walks towards Quiapo church and asks for forgiveness, and outside the church there is a market selling religious things, but also potions that “induce menstruation”
A medical professional preaches God at Sunshine’s bedside after her “medicine” fails her
And it says a lot about the structures surrounding young women with unwanted pregnancies
Later on in the film, we see the impact of these structures on them
They are forced to make decisions that risk their lives
Full of GraceMaris Racal is perfect at portraying Sunshine’s physicality and character

Her performance will make you believe she’s an Olympian who can take the spotlight and get everyone’s attention, a sister who learns how important it is to make her family proud, but most importantly, a dreamer who understands her young age is the right opportunity to change the world around her
I will never feel the exact same way as Sunshine experienced, but as a male audience, the film still allows me to put myself in Sunshine’s hard and difficult situation
The film is able to open eyes, and hopefully the audience willingly opens their eyes to Sunshine

There’s a lot to unpack in Sunshine, but let me begin by saying this: Maris Racal owns this character
There’s no other actress who could have pulled off Sunshine the way she did
She embodied every bit of the character so completely that Maris disappears—you’re not watching Maris as Sunshine; you’re watching Sunshine herself
Her performance is quietly powerful and emotionally charged, grounded in rawness and empathy
But this film isn't just carried by Maris alone
Alongside her are Annika Co, Jennica Garcia,and Rhed Bustamante, who play pivotal roles in deepening Sunshine’s story
In many ways, their characters are Sunshine—reflected through different lenses
Through themes of mental health and teen pregnancy, the film constructs a layered portrait of girlhood under pressure
It's raw, empathetic, bold, and unafraid
It doesn’t flinch from the truth, nor does it romanticize the pain
What Sunshine does best is handle a very sensitive subject in our country with sincerity and urgency: the ongoing struggle for bodily autonomy
It quietly and firmly illustrates the emotional toll of being a young woman in a society that refuses to let her decide for herself
And worse, how these conversations remain taboo
Every silence in the film is so loud
The pauses, the stillness, the unspoken—Sunshine knows that some of the loudest screams come from what isn’t said
The film allows space for emotion to breathe, for truths to sink in, and for viewers to truly feel the weight these girls carry
The producers behind Sunshine had to fight to get this film seen—not for profit, but because these are stories that matter
They pushed forward to open a much-needed conversation on bodily autonomy and reproductive rights
And it’s 2025—yet these issues are still being dismissed, invalidated, or worse, treated like they’re myths
In truth, they are not up for debate
They are basic rights that every woman deserves
I only hope that in the years to come, we won’t need another Sunshine just to get people to listen

Direk @tonetjadaone’s pragmatic approach to storytelling moves the soul
Although far from being perfect, the film delivered where it mattered most - clarity in messaging and a vision compelling enough to leave emotional resonance to spectators
This film on female reproductive health boldly centers the female gaze, offering a fresh and unflinching take on the realities that many Filipinas face

It attempts to break the glass ceiling of deeply rooted Filipino norms and challenges the culture shaped by religion, stigma, and silence around topics like abortion, sex education, and women’s health
Direk Tonet Jadaone masterfully captures the struggles of the protagonist, whose aspirations are put on hold after she discovers she’s pregnant
The film follows her journey, portraying how a woman navigates the weight of societal expectations in a culture that often leaves little room for personal agency
Cinematically, it’s far from your typical Filipino cliché
The pacing is tight, the cinematography is visually compelling, and each scene is deliberate, drawing the viewer into the emotional and social turmoil the character endures
The film allows us to witness how Sunshine finds resilience amidst adversity, all while shedding light on the layers of deprivation and injustice a Filipina can experience in a patriarchal society
More than just a narrative, the film leaves an impact

It sparks important conversations about our broken systems—the stigma surrounding reproductive health, the taboo nature of sex education, the inaccessibility of contraceptives, and the criminalization of abortion
It confronts how society often reduces women to objects of pleasure or vessels of reproduction, without regard for their mental or physical well-being
Ultimately, this is a film about empowerment
It’s a powerful reminder that women can dream for themselves, stand their ground, and rise above a system designed to keep them down
Thought-provoking and timely, it’s a testament to Direk Tonet Jadaone’s bold storytelling and her commitment to stories that matter

This movie is arguably one of the best films of the year
It feels incredibly real because it reflects life in the Philippines, where women's rights are acknowledged but often support a male-dominated system and the patriarchy
"Sunshine" tells the story of many women living in the Philippines
In this country, discussions about sex and sex education are frequently considered taboo
Many people talk about sex negatively, treating it as something sinful rather than educational
As a result, issues like teenage pregnancy are primarily viewed as public health problems
Furthermore, while there is a law aimed at protecting women from violence, it forces victims of sexual abuse to carry any resulting pregnancy to term, even in tragic circumstances such as r4p3
With abortion being illegal in the Philippines, many women find themselves in difficult situations
Those facing unplanned and unwanted pregnancies may have to consider unsafe options, which can threaten their lives
Women's rights must prioritize the well-being and choices of women, not men
The self-righteousness and views of certain religious groups should not dictate whether abortion is legalized
Women must have the power to make choices about their bodies
"Sunshine" is a story of hope, second chances, and pursuing dreams
It hopes for a better society where women are not scrutinized for claiming rights over their bodies
This movie is a bold and significant step for film in the Philippines, as it represents the experiences of many women in the country
We must continue the conversation and let this film be a part of the movement advocating for better women's rights
Without a doubt, Maris Racal brought life to her character, Sunshine
Her outstanding performance solidifies her status as one of the best actresses of this generation

“gets ko na”the physical representation of sunshine making peace, letting go of her guilt, and getting complete reassurance in her decision, all in the form of the child she once detested, but in the end, loved, was honestly beautiful

there is so much love and strength with the child in understanding sunshine’s dreams and circumstances, and how society was truly set against them; two females who were young girls at the end of the day
in a way, it reminded me of the popular thought prompt, “if my mother didn’t have me, what kind of life would she have had

” it’s a bittersweet thought at first, but there is such genuine love and understanding in seeing your mother past her caregiving responsibilities and wanting to witness her thrive as an independent woman with goals and ambitions, even if it meant losing your existence
however, there is also so much love and strength with sunshine deciding what would be best for both her and for the child, even if it hurt

sunshine loved the child enough to recognize that she didn’t deserve to be brought into such a cruel world, not when her own mother was still navigating through it, barely managing to survive the horrors she was dealt with
she knew she wasn’t ready at all and she didn’t want her child to bear the brunt of it, given what she herself has went through

there is love and strength in choosing yourself, recognizing your weaknesses, and acknowledging that both you and your child deserve the best version of yourself; one that has wholeheartedly lived her dreams and life despite societal expectations and harsh realities and one that is ready to help her child to do just the same
despite all odds, naintindihan nila yung isa’t isa
and out of love, for both themselves and for each other, they both let go
every time sunshine makes a decision, i just find myself nodding, quietly saying, “gets ko
” because i do
i was shaped by the streets of metro manila, grew up near churches where pampalaglag or pamparegla are sold right outside
i've had my own sunshines— close friends, a relative, a classmate — people i care about who’ve gone through the same thing
and watching this film, i saw myself in geleen, thea, the kid, and ariana
you just want your sunshine…

Sunshine is an aspiring Olympian
She is two weeks away from performing in the qualifying round
She has won numerous gold medals in local and Asian competitions, making her an ideal candidate for an Olympic gold
But everything changes when she discovers an unwanted pregnancy
In a male-dominated, conservative, church-leaning country, who can help Sunshine achieve her dreams
Jadaone's latest picture is a gritty coming-of-age sports drama that tackles a sensitive yet realistic portrayal of the struggles women face when the government and society turn their backs on them
It is a claustrophobic journey that dims the shine of its lead character even before she sees the end of the tunnel
The film offers a timely and relevant discussion on gender roles, sex education, the health care system, body autonomy, female rage, and empowerment
At its center is Maris Racal, who plays the titular character with grace, bareness, and nuance
She embodies the sunshine amidst a dirty, hypocritical, careless, and immovable society that becomes a character of its own
This is supported by the film’s striking eye for cinematic framing of the ragged city of Manila
I love how the film handles the core of its subject: should Sunshine get an abortion and continue chasing her dreams, or take the baby and live a life she is not prepared for
I love how the women characters come together to help each other against the oppressive weight of our patriarchal society
And when Sunshine finally makes a decision, I don’t think the film wants you to agree or disagree with her
It wants you to ask why she had to be in this position in the first place
It wants us to notice the shoulder-to-shoulder crowding in public maternity wards

It wants us to see the hypocrisy of a society where black markets for abortion operate in the shadows of churches, and why a woman still cannot make a decision about her own body without judgment from everyone around her

Sunshine is a statement
Raw, delicate, and bold
It presents a social commentary on themes rarely explored yet deeply prevalent in the Philippine context
It dares to be radical
It dares to draw the line
When does the sun finally shine in a morally gray cloud of social disapproval
As linear and straightforward as the film appears, beneath it lies a complex character study — fearlessly told, thematically sharp, and emotionally unsettling
Antoinette Jadaone writes for women, and in a cinematic landscape like ours, we need more voices like hers
I was initially worried about where the story would go, but it was brave enough to take the harder path
This is Maris Racal's best performance yet — nuanced and quietly powerful
But it was Jennica Garcia who stole every scene she was in
She was the emotional anchor, the tearjerker
Some casting choices outside the leads, however, fell short
Certain scenes and narrative decisions could have landed harder with stronger performances or more fitting direction
That said, the editing needs work
The presence of a stunt double in certain scenes is obvious, breaking immersion
While the film’s visuals hauntingly capture a side of Manila we rarely see on screen, the sound design lacks polish
These flaws are noticeable but not deal-breaking
Still, this film succeeds in doing what few others do: it makes you ask what is ethical and what is not
It invites reflection
And when a film draws that line clearly for society to see, perhaps that’s when the sun truly begins to shine

Sa bawat eksena ng pelikula ni Antoinette Jadaone, iisa ang tinig na umaalingawngaw — tinig ng babae
Hindi lang basta karakter ang mga babae, gaya ni Coach Eden mapa hanggang kay Doc Helena; sila’y haligi, saksi, at sandigan
Maging ang mga ina sa maternal ward, tahimik man o may tinig, ay larawan ng kababaihang nagtutulungan, nagkakapit-bisig sa gitna ng unos

Sa mundong kinahon ng patriyarka, binubuksan ng pelikula ang mata natin sa lakas ng kababaihan — lakas na hindi lang para sa tahanan o pamayanan, kundi para sa paghubog ng mas makatarungan at pantay na lipunan
Sa mata ng kamera, dama ang panawagan: bigyang saysay ang katawan at karapatan ng kababaihan
Dahil sa mundong nararapat, walang Sunshine, walang Menggay, ang kailangang manahimik sa sakit
Walang babaeng kailangang dumaan sa dilim ng unsafe practices para lamang maramdaman ang kontrol sa sariling buhay
Sa mundong nararapat, ang babae’y hindi takas, kundi ganap — may tinig, may kapangyarihan, may laya

Obviously im not a woman so I will never fully understand the lived experience of a woman but just like sunshine, I am someone who made regrettable decisions in the past
Someone who’s also eager to make it right
At least for me
But sometimes it’s hard to do the right thing when you have so many people telling you what to do, or when you don’t have the resources to do so
It’s hard to drown out the noise in your head when everything around you is so loud
Sometimes you don’t even need someone to tell you what to do at all, because you already know
Sometimes all you need is someone to be by your side
Something to make you feel like youre not alone
A text message from a friend
A hug from a sister
A pair of compassionate eyes of a stranger
Despite feeling alone in her whole ordeal, Sunshine was held together by the women she encounters
From the child, her sister, the cashier at the motel, the doctor at the hospital
I was lucky enough to have my own community lift me up at a time when I thought i was done for
It’s because of them that I’m still here, and that I still keep going
“Mahalin mo si sunshine, kahit ano pa siya, kahit ano pang nagawa niya”, said my friend
Indeed, we are all just people in need of community to get us through
In need of compassion
In need of empathy
Someone to say “kakampi mo ko dito”
Sometimes having someone sit through it with you is enough
And yes, gets kita, Sunshine

The film has a sense of urgency about it, presenting the drama with so much eagerness, firm convictions, and intense sentiments nearly to the point where it devolves into cheap propaganda for a cause with which I happen to agree ideologically

It was too on the nose and constantly going for shock value that it was draining to follow, brazenly provoking the audience to feel for a horrible social reality but instead of pointing it out with a nod and a commentary, it was trying so hard to make them feel bad about those situations
Not in a good way because it is one of those things that breeds frustration rather than empathy for the protagonist

At some point, Sunshine simply disappeared, becoming a vessel for the audience to put their shoes on since she is subjected to so much oppression, losing any semblance of agency as it is all about how messed up her social reality has become

It's the same problem I had with war films and other poverty porn, where it ignores developing the protagonist in favor of escalating the situations in front of her and throwing every miserable conflicts imaginable at her

To be fair, the protagonist as a vessel had an aspiration, a threatened dream that was about to be broken, and the idea of her interacting with all these women, smoothly transitioning from the one who needed help to the one who provided help, clearly distinguished the film from those with a typical point-of-view character

Those moments of empowerment and camaraderie with other women may have eased the tension and made it feel more hopeful than the premise implies, but it also falls into the trap of caricaturing other characters for the sake of cheap sensationalism

It also felt betraying that so many things transpired that the gymnastics was set aside for so long, and I would hope that it was more of an escape than a hardship because no joy was displayed during those routines except for the last act
I would say that the sport was not seamlessly wedded to the character, since it could have been any sport or dream, and the film would still be effective

The magical realism element is essentially what I detest about the film, because it could have lingered in the loneliness and allowed the audience to connect with the character through subtlety, but it had to be filled with hypothetical conversation that hits the audience on the head to explain the themes and demonstrate the unspoken dilemmas in the present predicament

It could be interpreted as a mean to communicate guilt, a process of forgiving oneself and empathizing with other women, or as humanizing the fetus inside the body, which I'm not sure how to feel about that ideologically

It's also tonally odd, which is a Philippine cinema branding at this point, but it's always convenient to use a child for humor, and it reduces the overall tone of what's happening to the main character

It was just too telegraphed at times, and I was hoping to let the sequences play out and use more silence because those are the scenes I enjoy when the protagonist is alone and burdened by her situation

The upward momentum of a film that begins bleakly will always impede any form of storytelling because it must outdo itself, building emotions that are overwhelming every ten minutes to the point of monotony
In fact, I can't recall the chronology of the film even though I saw it yesterday, but I do remember every segments and the emotions it was going for

It actually came to the point of absurdity in the third act, when one character emerged, followed by a terrible circumstances, followed by even more bleak information and an unsettling confrontation, which would undoubtedly disturb anyone

And then there was a cameo in which the small theater collectively whisper and giggle a bit as a result of being taken off guard, which again felt awkward because it always has to make a joke after every other miserably effective scene
Not letting the moments breathe for a while

It can even be tonally confusing at times, with scenes that is either attempting to be comical or unsettling as some of the dialogue was just satirical and they incorporate some triggering monologue ala Vincentiments, but they also made the film lighthearted, which I am not sure is a good thing

I suppose I want my abortion movies to be more thought-provoking and full of sociological nuances rather than funny and emotional, because it can be too loose for its sensitive subject matter, but it was heartfelt and that was good
I'm making it seem like I hate this film when than I don't because it was terrific and entertaining, but it's just that I'm not sure if those are the things I want to take away from this film
I have to say though that it had a very good filmmaking mechanics

I heard they tried to hide the camera in public scenes to make the setting appear more authentic, and I was expecting long takes because it was another Filipino film about a protagonist wandering around which they did not employ at all, but I kind of like what they did here, from the shot composition and coverages to the way they were edited together

The only criticism I had regarding the filmmaking was the noticeable stunt double in the gymnastic routines, as well as how the emotions in the close-ups did not match those in the wide shots whenever they intercut them together
I suspect no one grins when doing gymnastics since it is a serious performance by meticulous athletes rather than by an exuberant victorious person, as the film claims at the conclusion
It's just a little quibble, but I commend the filmmaking overall and even the rough cuts were fantastic
Definitely the best-directed Filipino film I've seen in quite some time, I can say that with confidence
Ung after niya ikuwento ung kuwento niya in the most perfect way and in a language na she knows best, she asks (dares, almost) "Naiintindihan mo naman ako di ba

Sunshine is a powerful, no-frills story set in the gritty, chaotic streets of Manila
It follows a young gymnast whose future gets shaken when she finds out she’s pregnant
Antoinette Jadaone tells this story the way she does best—letting silence, glances, and small gestures speak louder than words
No drama for drama’s sake
Just raw, real moments
Maris Racal delivers a stunning performance
This film tackles numerous points that need to be discussed

It provides a comprehensive overview of the different systemic issues that our country is not addressing, ranging from the double standards imposed on women to the societal barriers that make it difficult for women to meet these standards
It is an irony between what society wants for women and how society sets up women to fail to meet these standards
That's where the "bullsht-ery" comes in, as this film successfully sends it to its audience

I want to say a lot of things about this film, on how it provides a good argument, on how it provides a good piece of reality that is not glorified nor romanticized and on how it gave us something that will not just be left on the cinema, but to be talked about in the streets and on the media

I really understand the fear of the production of showing this in the Philippines, but I believe that strong and brave films like this are what we need, to not just start conversations but to challenge the views we have as individuals and as a collective
This is the kind of film that everyone needs to watch, as it will definitely afflict the comfortable and comfort the afflicted
No words, but pure awe of everything about this film
Definitely the best work of both director Antoinette Jadaone and actress Maris Racal
And it's weird for me to have a good rewatch feeling on these kinds of movies, but I believe I will be rewatching this film again (once the storm settles and subsides)

Antoinette Jadaone has always been one of the few Filipino filmmakers I deeply admire, not just for her craft, but for the way she tells women’s stories with empathy and nuance
Her work has always felt personal, films like Alone/Together, Fan Girl and now Sunshine, might just be my favorite Filipino film released this year so far
I remember seeing the trailer last year and wondering if it would even get a proper release here
It tackles such a taboo topic, one that many in this country still refuse to even speak about
That’s why I admire Jadaone so much
She’s chosen to talk about what others won’t
In a predominantly Catholic nation where abortion is criminalized, even in cases of rape or incest, Sunshine feels like an act of courage
I’ve always been pro-choice
I grew up surrounded by the whole “abortion is murder” narrative, from relatives, from my old Catholic school run by nuns
But even as a kid, it never sat right with me
I never saw it as a sin
And now that I’m studying to become a doctor, that belief matters even more to me, because women deserve healthcare that doesn’t judge or shame them
Sunshine affected me on a personal level because of that
It reminded me why I want to do this
It’s not a perfect film
Some might find the pacing fast or feel like it didn’t say enough
But to me, the point isn’t perfection
What matters is that it exists
It dares
It’s a film that opens doors, uncomfortable ones, sure, but necessary
I really hope it’s not the last of its kind

Maris plays Sunshine with so much empathy that it permeates outside the screen, her win is our win, her disappointment is our disappointment
Through the streets of Manila to the corners of her room, we get to hold hands with her and be a confidant
I like how it positions the audience as part of this journey, not as the usual bystander
One sequence that stood out is the one from the inn to the hospital - Maris lets herself be consumed by Sunshine, almost as if the creeping is part of the routine itself
The messaging gets confusing in the middle but ultimately ends in a tender moment of acceptance and determination
I’m just happy films like this finally exist in our country

In a Q&A with writer-director Antoinette Jadaone that I was lucky to attend, she was asked how she braced for the potential backlash of this film from Filipino audiences given our mostly conservative background
Her answer resonated with me deeply: As a writer, Jadaone believes her primary duty is to stay loyal to her characters
If her character's arc demands visiting unnerving and controversial depths, she is not afraid to take the plunge - regardless of how viewers might perceive it
Her earlier work, Fan Girl (2020), already painted a similar picture, albeit a bit spottily
Jadaone takes her boldest steps yet in her latest work, Sunshine (2024), by tackling abortion, a highly contentious subject in the country, with both sensitivity and grit

This entry is unflinching in its commentary, taking us to the most harrowing places women can be in a nation where sexual abuse is prevalent, abortion is illegal, and healthcare fails the underprivileged
Sunshine, our protagonist, is a skilled gymnast, but even she can't leap over patriarchy, tumble past outdated laws, or cartwheel her way out of the conservative society and system

In one scene, Sunshine waits along a street choked with tricycles, behind the railing of a pharmacy counter - she is jailed in and by this wretched city, made a criminal for wanting to make a choice that should be her right
But this film's Manila is more than just Sunshine's prison
It's a breathing character, trailing her around from scene to scene
Always in the backdrop but never invisible
Never speaking but always loud
A passing MRT train rattles the windows of a shabby motel
A crammed jeepney bounces to the bass of a local rap song
Grimy streets teem with hustling vendors and weary residents
Sunshine makes her choices, but her choices are only as good as this bleak, brutal city allows
Maris Racal delivers a phenomenal performance, portraying our protagonist with nuance and raw intensity
She is backed by a stellar ensemble - Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, and Elijah Canlas - each breathing life into characters that are authentic and vital to the film's message
The sequences are daring, the story beats sometimes violent, but always necessary
The music elevates it all, with a standout Challengers-esque score underscoring the gymnastic scenes
This film is not without its faults though, with excessive cursing (seriously, again in a Project 8 work
), somewhat awkward acting, and some unpolished plot points, but these are forgivable given how effective the complete work is
Sunshine may very well be Direk Tonet's finest work yet - and rightly so
It stands as one of the most important Filipino films in the modern times

i thought that the choice to portray the unborn fetus as a grown, conscious being was counterintuitive at first, but then i realized the film was only trying to meet its conservative audiences halfway in their beliefs
then i thought it was a stroke of genius: of course, the only way to convince someone to change their mind is by explaining it in the terms they understand, through their perspective of the world
but then it also alienates this very audience by demonizing them in the film
while it successfully empathizes with the horrors of being a woman in the philippines, there is a lack of nuance, a dichotomy of good vs
evil, that might be more harmful than helpful in the grander scheme of things

(there are also so many scenes where maris racal’s quiet yet powerful performance should have been enough, but the beauty of the moment is ruined by the “child” voicing out sunshine’s thoughts, spoon-feeding the audience
