i loved it and i think everyone should still watch it in spite of its flaws
As someone who is always online, I often encounter issues that are difficult to discuss, to the point where I sometimes become desensitized and think, 'ahh shit, eh ganyan talaga that's life

' I knew that the main topic of this movie is abortion, and after watching the movie as a woman and a Filipino, I was reminded na hindi kasi abortion 'lang', there are so many layers to it, may it be sexual education, healthcare, and the patriarchal society we…
The tone set by Sunshine over Jadaone's previous film, Fangirl, is way different
The urgency of survival is apparent and how it clashes with the film's thematic journey, like Paul Soriano's Thelma
Though Sunshine tends to get the feel of guerrilla direction, it is a combination of the director's experiences in mainstream and her indie roots
Meaning, we get to see well-lighted scenes and less usage of shake cam
Sunshine unpacks a lot of society's ills and inequalities
Patriarchy, discrimination in the medical field, inhumane laws, and glaring social class issues that don't benefit those without that much
In a country where religion reigns, or so they say, the film easily relays problems with well-made sequences and heartbreaking results
Jadaone knows the voices of her characters, and it tells a distinct topic with passion and wit, giving the audiences a rollercoaster of emotions
One thing that makes this film unique is the inclusion of a fantastic element
It somehow references, or a styling of, what they had in Death Note anime or Big Mouth to make it more accurate
And such symbolism as Sunshine's conscience made it relatively easier to tell the film's narrative
It was smartly added, and it didn't make the audience unintelligent
The technical are overwhelmingly great
The use of lighting in urban areas, especially those scenes shot at night, is worthy of a picturesque view of the marginalized reality
We rarely see such strong shots in film
The options to use close-ups for intensity of emotions and certain decisions to make the scenes with Mariz Racal's gymnastic performance were made with careful efficiency
And the sound editing was just on point
It is technically the protagonist's in-ear audio being shared with the viewers
Jadaone's casting is really one for the books
An appreciation to Mariz Racal's graceful bookend performance
The representation is exactly what we need to see from young adults, especially in the situation of what is happening to her character
The conflict-bearers really made the sequences memorable, and it made you think of the situations presented
These aren't farfetched ideas shown in the film
Most of them are realistically sound and Piolo Pascual's short stint really is just something for us to gasp about
And we also get to see Jennica Garcia and Elijah Canlas' supporting roles to complete the ensemble
Les we forget Annika Co's strong personality
I guess we have another star made by the director
And regarding Meryll Soriano being part of the film
It made me remember how she did a similar role back in 2010, as Lizette in the Mark Meily film, Donor
Sunshine displays what needs to be said in a society when abortion is considered a taboo topic
A possible eye-opener to the current status quo

Sunshine Francisco played by Maris Racal, is a teenage gymnast dreaming of getting in the Olympics, got pregnant by accident, and must face the moral dilemma of choosing between her dreams and keeping the baby
Maris Racal carried the film to pitch perfection and rawness
She takes you in and makes you feel her struggles
Her facial nuances and physical vigor makes her the right choice to play the titular role, in what could be a role of a lifetime
Director Antoinette Jadaone's never been more sure and absolute of her vision here
The film stands as an audacious statement in a country full of naysayers when it comes to the sensitive and controversial subject matter: abortion
The ending really made me shed a tear, in response to understanding why women do what they do
Though the film is not without its flaws
I sometimes felt the script and characters could have been more seamlessly sewn, and not just coming out of nowhere, making it feel a bit unnatural
Nevertheless, this is an essential film that needs to be seen by a wide audience
It didn't provide the answers, but this is what a filmmaker does best: to start conversations, to challenge the status quo and make us reflect our own beliefs and morals
support local films, local music, local products, and local boys

I was honestly scared that the film might take a turn…
Every time I visit Quiapo Church, I’m always amused by the chaos outside its gates
Right beside vendors selling rosaries, crucifixes, candles, and bottles of holy water, there are stalls hawking pamparegla and other herbal concoctions said to “regulate” missed periods
The juxtaposition is striking
Sacred and taboo, salvation and cycle, side by side like it’s the most natural thing in the world
It’s absurd, hilarious, and deeply Filipino
I always find myself thinking, someone should write a story, play, or movie out of this contradiction
With Sunshine, it finally feels like someone did
Fearlessly and with heart
It’s not exactly about Quiapo, but it carries the same beautiful mess of contradictions
Faith and survival, morality and body, dream and disappointment
It dares to talk about reproductive health care in the Philippines without flinching, but it’s also about more than that
It’s about the right to choose
Not just over one’s body, but over one’s future
It’s about women tired of being told to wait, to settle, to stay silent
And finally daring to want more
What makes it powerful is its quiet grace
It doesn’t preach
It listens
To the unspoken shame carried by women
To the whispers exchanged in tricycle/jeepney rides and neighborhood clinics
To the dreams that keep getting deferred by the weight of economy, expectation, and morality
Sunshine is a film that sees women
Not as symbols or martyrs, but as people
Technically, it’s a marvel
The cinematography captures the real Manila
Not the sepia-toned or shadow-drenched “poverty porn” we’re so used to
No extra lighting or artificial grime smeared on walls for the sake of grittiness
No “designing poverty
” The production design feels lived in, never overworked
Every detail feels honest
If I have only one criticism, it's that the magical realism elements could have been woven in more seamlessly
But even that doesn’t take away from the film’s quiet power
Then there’s the acting
Maris Racal delivers the role of a lifetime
Raw, honest, and quietly devastating
Jennica Garcia, whenever she’s on screen, shines
Her presence is magnetic, and together, their chemistry feels lived-in and true
In every sense, Sunshine is a landmark film
It should be our Oscar submission for next year
And if there’s any justice, it should sweep every local award
It’s not just a movie
It’s a mirror
One we’ve long needed in a country as patriarchal and hypocritical as ours
The kind of mirror that’s often hard for Filipinos to look into, but impossible to ignore
Reproductive rights
Mag-thank you kayo kay Papa God dahil sa pelikulang to
Some films entertain you
Sunshine confronts you
When the credits rolled, no one moved
No one spoke
It was that rare kind of silence
Not awkward, but sacred
As if we had all just witnessed something painfully true and didn’t quite know what to do with ourselves
Because Sunshine isn’t just a movie
It’s a question
A confrontation
Directed with clarity and deep compassion by Direk Tonet Jadaone, Sunshine doesn’t soften its message or try to make it more palatable
It’s brave
It’s loud in its honesty
It doesn’t ask for permission to be angry or tired or vulnerable
It simply is, and that’s why it hits the way it does
And yet, somehow, even with all its emotional weight, Direk Tonet’s signature humor still finds its way through
There are moments—unexpected but perfectly timed—when the entire cinema bursts into laughter
It’s sharp, it’s honest, and it never feels out of place
Maybe Direk Tonet makes us laugh because she knows we’ll cry eventually
Or maybe that’s just how we are as Filipinos, finding humor even in the heaviest moments, because sometimes, it’s the only way we know how to carry the pain
What makes this film even more powerful is how it gives voice to things we often overlook
As someone who isn’t a woman, I know I can’t fully grasp the weight of that experience
But this film opened a window for me
A clear, honest glimpse into a reality I will never live, but need to see
Much of that power comes from the performances
Maris Racal, as Sunshine, delivers the most vulnerable and grounded work of her career
Her pain is quiet, but it radiates
You feel it in the way she holds her breath between words, in the weight behind her gaze
Jennica Garcia, as her sister, is just as affecting
Her stillness, her softness, the way she listens
She becomes a reflection of what the film asks of us: to pause, to witness, to respond with care
There’s a moment near the end that stuck with me
Sunshine asks, “Gets mo na ba ako
”And while it’s said to the person in the room, it felt like she was looking straight through the screen, asking us, the viewers
And like that person beside her, I hope we all have the courage to say: Yes
We see you
We understand
Please, Direk Tonet, keep making films like this (inutusan pa nga)
Keep telling stories that hold space for women to be everything—loud and quiet, strong and hurting, tired and brave
Stories that make people feel seen

isa sa sentro ng pelikula ang reproductive health at aborsyon

isang maselang usapin sa isang bansang ilang siglo nang sadlak sa ideolohiya ng katolisismo, isang bagay na pilit pumipiit sa mga batas na dapat ay nagsisilbi sa lahat ng pilipino at hindi sa iilan lamang
sobrang pait makita ang depiksyon ng mga batang babaeng nais lamang kumawala sa tanikalang hindi naman sila lamang ang may gawa, ngunit sila lamang ang nagdurusa
nanliliit na sila sa lipunang mababa ang tingin sa mga batang ina, nanliliit pa sila sa sistemang iniwanan silang mag-isa—sabi nga sa pelikula, krimen ang aborsyo

Andami kong napanood na Filipino films lately
Sunshine (2024) would be a perfect double feature with Eliza Hittman's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) as they both tackle similar topics but with a stark difference in privilege and access
where the latter becomes a story of sisterhood and compassion, as two girls cross state lines to get access to healthcare, Sunshine offers no such respite to our eponymous protagonist
in here, what Sunshine wants is not even a matter of choice, it is something that she is forced to bear
all alone as her confidants succumb to the stigma of her dilemma, Sunshine takes to the streets of Manila in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy
the plot moves along while the audience is served scenes of what i believe to be one of the better cinematic depictions of modern Manila
the first few minutes almost feel like an entirely different film (one i would have particularly liked more) until the plot takes a peculiar detour
in all of its realism and poignancy i found a particular element in its storytelling very out of place and oftentimes distracting
while the ending made me understand why those choices were made i just don't think a semblance of Magical Realism is the perfect vehicle for a message as heavy as this one

while i think the point that: "an entire generation of Filipino women being forced to reckon with their unborn children as if the choice of abortion is something that has to be explained, and in turn, be understood
" is a step in the right direction for this nation's pro-choice discourse, the delivery just felt like it was bordering into Diary of an Unborn Child territory
with that being said, i still thoroughly enjoyed Sunshine and i would still highly recommend it

Perhaps my favorite element of this new project from Antoinette Jadaone is the contrast between morality and sin as personified by the hawker who sells abortion pills behind figures of saints beside Quiapo Church, which is arguably the most popular place of veneration among Catholic Filipinos throughout the country
Beyond that, I’m struggling to seek nuance and proper closure
What sets this work, aside from the palpable gentleness toward the female main character, apart from the many stories about abortion out there
It’s worth noting, however, that stories about women are told by women, just like what Jadaone manages to deliver here
I believe (cis) male filmmakers, no matter how genuine their intent is, cannot tell stories about women because women’s danas, the distinct Filipino word for experience, is not men’s danas

Sunshine is going to be an eye-opener for a lot of people here in the Philippines
It doesn't just raise awareness, it confronts the daily injustices Filipino women face just for being women
This should kickstart long-overdue conversations about reproductive rights, no matter how uncomfortable they may be
Maris Racal gives a career-defining performance as Sunshine
She fully captures the vulnerability, resilience, and quiet strength of her character
She feels heartbreakingly real
The supporting cast also pulls its weight, with Jennica Garcia standing out in a big way
What I really appreciated is how the film frames everything through the lens of a deeply Catholic country
The Sto
Niño statues being sold next to illegal abortion pills and the Christmas lights in the maternity ward stick with you
They are not just background details, they feel like commentary
Birth and suffering are made sacred here, even when they come with pain, even when they are not wanted
Sometimes it feels like the film is about to lean into pro-life messaging, with "what if" hypotheticals and future-president guilt trips
But instead of reinforcing those ideas, it pulls them apart
I didn't expect it to handle such a taboo subject with this much care
Subtlety is completely thrown out the window at times, with some characters written like Facebook comment sections come to life
They are loud, caricature-like, and clearly meant to provoke
But the sad truth is that people like that exist
Without getting into spoilers, the film isn’t trying to decide what’s right or wrong
It’s more interested in what it means to be understood
So with that, we thank God for Sunshine

The moments when our titular character, Sunshine, was hopeless and lost, the first thought that came to mind was: Thank God I’m not a woman
And as soon as I thought it, I recognized how privileged it was to even have such a thought
How easy it is to be a cis man
And because of that, I’ll never truly understand how a woman feels
But this is precisely what the film accomplished—it made me feel
Direk Tonet’s writing and direction are potent and hard-hitting, while Maris’ performance is just as powerful
For a film that exudes a seemingly hopeless atmosphere, with no end in sight to the world’s harshness, Maris’ Sunshine shone like a light at the end of the tunnel
I hope the future is kinder to women, and I hope I get to contribute to paving the way for that future to become a reality

I still remember when Direk Tonet shared the concept of Sunshine back in 2021 at a workshop I attended
Everyone knew it was risky, yet the story had to be told
It wasn’t a question of “how” but “when
”Fast forward to today, Sunshine finally lives and receives its well-deserved spotlight
It’s easy for some to dismiss it as “just a film about abortion”
When in reality, it’s a gritty portrayal of thousands of Filipinas—all the dreams and lives lost, the could haves and what ifs
The fact that this film exists (in this political and social climate) is already a miracle
It being one of Direk Tonet’s masterpieces is just a bonus

A film that paints a very real, raw, uncomfortable, and deeply moving picture on what it is like to be a Filipino woman with a dream, a mistake, and an agency that is being challenged by those around her—even by herself
It does this through depicting scenes all pointing towards the state of reproductive healthcare in the Philippines, and all those who are affected by it
Its characters are what makes the film so moving
Of course, Maris Racal does a stunning job portraying Sunshine and the character’s emotional complexity
Every character, though, has a purpose and reflects Filipino realities accurately
Perhaps the most special characters are what the film uses as a device to move the story along
At first, I felt unsure of it, but by the end of the film, it was very effective
This is a type of story that I feel, and hope, most Filipinos get to see
It is highly relevant as much as it is good
The narrative, linear structure of the film lends to the experience of the casual spectator; it builds up and comes crashing down

is one that will stick with me for a while

For a couple of years, I've lived and roamed in the kind of Manila Tonet has painted for us: busy and dirty streets of Recto and Carriedo overflowing with people trying to make ends meet, the filthy motels of Avenida filled with horny, exploitative men who need them, and the whispering neighborhood all around the tight grid-like system such as Tondo, Blumentritt, San Lazaro, Laon-Laan or Dapitan watching, staring, looking for something to make time pass

Under the watchful eyes of this condemnatory city stands a rather bright-eyed Sunshine, a young female student-gymnast trying to secure her spot in athletic competitions such as the Olympics and SEA Games
Her hard work and dedication have reflected in her routine, and her coach is confident in her skill in making it to the national team
But all of her dreams of soaring global recognition have been put to risk when one day, she discovers she is with child
What's heartbreaking about this piece is that this film is about a young woman working day and night fighting for a country who doesn't fight for her
This is a country where a woman needs to make unnecessarily drastic measures just to live a life she works hard on achieving
This is a country built on guilt and shame, yet a country proudly branded for its resilience
This is a country that veiled its dirt and its scum with the cloak of catholic morals and self-righteousness
This is no place for a sun to shine on
It's easy for me to believe in this film, because it is a true story
This is a biography, not of Sunshine and not of Tonet

This is a biography of Philippines in modern day, and for decades this has been told time and time again from the works of Lino Brocka, Ishmael Bernal, and Brillante Mendoza, to works of Kip Oebanda, Ramona Diaz, and now Antoinette Jadaone

For years filmmakers like them have hoped for a brighter future, hoped for people to open their eyes and unveil what is hidden in plain sight, and Tonet, in this incredible feat, making the movie ticket as cheap and as accessible as it can be, is reaching out to us saying "This is my country
Look and see
The moment Sunshine opened, I felt like I was already there in her world
That’s one of the things I’ve always admired about Direk Tonet Jadaone: how she builds these quiet, lived-in spaces that don’t just exist for her characters, but completely pull you in
You don’t just watch the story unfold, you feel it with Sunshine

What stuck with me the most is the way the film builds this deeply uncomfortable paradox: a country that loudly declares abortion is murder, yet leaves no room for safe options, quietly allowing dangerous pills to be sold under the table
The contradiction isn’t even subtle, it’s the whole point
Being a Filipino is already hard, but being a woman in the Philippines
It's brutal
The film doesn’t sugarcoat anything, it throws you straight into the brokenness of it all, from healthcare to shame culture to just… surviving
As the story unfolds, you’re taken on this intense ride with Sunshine, a girl trying to make sense of what she’s going through while the world around her offers no real answers
It forces you to confront your own biases
You start to ask yourself: what would I do in her place
What’s the “right” choice, really, when you’re trapped in a society that only ever gives you wrong ones
Menggay’s story hit like a gut punch
It’s the kind of pain that’s so real, but we never talk about because we’re scared to
Menggay isn't just another casualty, at the end of it all -- she's still a kid
What I love most about the storytelling is that it doesn’t preach
It makes you think, it makes you question -- but in the end, it reminds you that it should all boil down to what Sunshine feels is right
What she knows is best
It gives her that agency, that voice, something this world so often tries to take from girls like her
I've always been a fan of Maris Racal, and I agree that this is her best project yet
She didn’t need to go big; her silence already said everything
And I loved how the film used gymnastics as this quiet metaphor of control, performance, and discipline all while her personal life spirals into uncertainty
It’s so smart
And I have to say: the cinematography
Of course, the gym scenes were beautifully shot, we all expected that - but it was the motel scenes that floored me
There was something about how those moments were framed that just hit harder
Like everything was raw, exposed, still
And what really stayed with me, long after the credits rolled, was this one feeling: at the end of it all, our dreams, they’re always for the younger versions of ourselves
We fight, we keep going, because we hope they’d understand
That if we ever had to explain why we chose what we chose, they’d look at us and say, “gets kita
”But the question that lingers is: are we, is this world ready for a story as brave as Sunshine

There’s no denying Sunshine matters - it speaks to harsh truths and tackles its themes with care and emotional honesty
The film had a timely subject, sincere writing, and phenomenal acting - Maris Racal was stellar, while Jennica Garcia delivered with quiet power
But I struggled with certain elements, particularly its attempt at magical realism
The presence of the imaginary child felt clunky, tonally jarring, and out of sync with the otherwise grounded narrative
Frankly, the character felt unnecessary - the film had already evolved past the need for her
The story had power, and I wish it had trusted its own strength without the added flourish
Ultimately, I admired its purpose more than loving its execution

I walked into the cinema with so much expectation—and Sunshine delivered more than my expectations
This is a landmark film
A humanizing, soul-stirring, and bold piece of cinema that dares to speak truth in a country that often prefers silence and compliance

In a nation as conservative and deeply religious as the Philippines, Sunshine dives headfirst into the conversations we often whisper about, especially around the elderly and religious individuals—abortion, reproductive health, sexual abuse (WITHIN the family), and the religious hypocrisy that surrounds them
One of the most powerful moments for me was when she prays to God in the middle of an abortion attempt: “Lord, tanggalin Mo lang ’to, babawi ako sa lahat-lahat
” That line alone—honest and devastating—is a statement that cuts deep into the Filipino moral paradox
Maris Racal carried this film on her own, brilliantly
No awkward or cringey moments—just pure, intentional acting that hits you right in the gut
This is easily her most brilliant and mature performance to date, and I am hungry for more
Also, just to share my theory: I don’t think the kids she sees represent a “mother figure” version of herself
To me, they were the babies’ little angels, quietly watching over their mothers, protecting them, forgiving them
I laughed, I wept, I cursed out loud inside the cinema
PUTANGINANG PILIPINAS TO
We need to see this
Sunshine deserves every bit of international acclaim it’s been getting—and more
And most of all: the Philippines is ready
Filipinos are ready for this conversation, for this kind of truth-telling, for this kind of art
More than a film, it’s also a wake-up call
Never doubted you, Maris Racal

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is a powerful and unflinching examination of the ongoing issue of teenage pregnancy in the Philippines, anchored by a stunning breakout performance from Maris Racal

The film transcends a simple narrative, offering a poignant and necessary critique of a society grappling with deeply entrenched religious and political views that often leave young women isolated and without agency
Through its raw and unapologetic storytelling, Sunshine doesn’t just present a problem
It takes a stand and demands that we, the viewers, confront it alongside its protagonist
Where the film truly excels is in its unflinching depiction of the societal and systemic failures that trap young women like Sunshine

The Philippines has the second-highest rate of teenage pregnancy in Southeast Asia, and a 2023 survey by Save the Children Philippines revealed that more than 500 adolescents become mothers each day, some as young as ten years old
Sunshine masterfully illustrates the intense personal isolation behind these numbers by using the accessible medium of sports

I have a love-hate relationship with the Philippines
My country has it all, a strong historical background and culture, beautiful agricultural sights
The Philippines shines in so many ways
This country is easy to love, but it’s also easy to hate

On the other side of the spectrum, the Philippines is plagued with corruption, deeply oppressive religious standards, and many more hateful traditions and mindsets that continue to affect the Filipino people
The bare minimum is oftentimes glorified as the best that society could do for itself in the Philippines, but is to settle for less to settle for enough
This is the question that Sunshine raises
In a country that struggles to stand for its women, Sunshine did what many movies could not, it fearlessly depicted what was real and happening in our country
It showed the pure, unfiltered realities of a young, adolescent woman facing an unwanted pregnancy
The film doesn’t hold back

From the infamous ‘motel scene’ to the different women we follow in the film, direk Antoinette Jadaone fearlessly portrays the dangers a woman has to go through just to gain autonomy over their body, hopes, and dreams
Upon a second watch (this time with my mom and my cousin), I noticed something about the way Sunshine (Maris Racal) progresses in the film
She starts off as quiet
When she finds out she is pregnant, she only tells her boyfriend and her best friend
When she’s worried or angry, she conceals her emotions
She is held back
She is chained
As the film progresses, she slowly finds her footing, first through the infamous ‘basag windshield’ scene, and then through the numerous situations she finds herself stuck in
There is a scene near the end of the film
Sunshine is practicing her routine
She is emotional, and she’s made up her mind
As she ends her routine, the ribbon falls around her body, chaining her
She has a heartfelt conversation with ‘bata’ and she breaks free from her chains, which directly leads to the ending
Nothing is holding her back, she won’t settle for less, she has had enough
There is a scene in the film between Thea (Xyriel Manabat) and Sunshine
They are at a school canteen, eating separately from each other, but through their eyes, through the way they are looking at each other, you know that they are in support of one another
In a country that fails its women, they are forced to support each other in silence
Listening to my mom’s thoughts and reaction to Sunshine was the best part of my experience with this film
A woman who is somewhat religious, understanding why someone would want an abortion
An emphatic moment between my mom, me, and all the Sunshines in our country
The irony of watching a film entitled Sunshine during tag-ulan season is an irony that’s hard to look past, but I think this film couldn’t have come at a better time
We are settling for less
The streets are flooding, and the women in our country struggle to find the healthcare they deserve
We are chained and we are held back
When will we break free
When will we have enough

We are in a limbo
So much of Philippine cinema, especially that which makes the rounds in local and international film festivals, is stuck churning out “groundbreaking” firsts
Because our cultural discourse is so behind, our filmmakers are tasked not only with telling stories, but also with inventing the stories to be told
They’re required to stake out new thematic ground, not in service of aesthetic evolution, but simply to keep up with the global conversation
The cost of this is a cinema that often feels overburdened with didactic intent and undernourished in emotional and formal rigor
In a particularly polarizing gesture, Jadaone introduces a hallucinated child character, a device that indirectly echoes Jojo Rabbit (2019)
But this choice results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the film’s emotional center
What was perhaps intended as farce to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour
It’s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the film’s pro-choice sensibility
In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on
It circles back into the age-old “when does life begin
” debate—a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare
The film doesn’t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, literalizes it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics

What’s more revealing than the film itself is the discourse surrounding it: a ubiquity of gender-essentialist and bioessentialist defenses, as if any critique of any form is automatically a threat to representation
That instinct: to guard a film’s cause rather than evaluate its craft just proves how far behind we are as a nation in talking about gender politics in filmmaking
The refusal to embrace genuinely revolutionary tactics, whether in politics or art, has kept us coasting on the optics of progress ever since

While the narrative might feel familiar to some, its power lies in its unflinching, raw depiction of a story deeply grounded in the realities of the Philippines

Sunshine isn't afraid to show what it truly means to be a woman in the modern world
In a society where your choices are often shamed, imposed, or forced into the very core of your identity, Sunshine remains steadfast in her decisions
We are too unforgiving towards women—too critical, too much of everything
And for a 19-year-old girl simply wanted to chase her dream, who are we to shame her for the choices she takes pride in
The film is heavy, filled with thrilling sequences and beautiful picturesque cinema that adds an insightful edge to its narrative
It doesn't shy away from the realities of living in Manila, where everything is muddy, dreary, and dried in irony

It reminded me at different tangents of Black Swan and Manila in the Claws of Light—a woman haunted by the consequences of her actions while navigating Manila's streets with weary kindness and understanding

In a country where a uterus can feel like a prison, Sunshine breaks through the silence with a scream
This is not just a film—it’s a rebellion against a system that punishes Filipinas for daring to survive

What a fearless and necessary filmz Sunshine dares to confront a brutal reality in a country where abortion remains illegal and where women’s rights are often reduced to whispers—silenced by false morality and systemic neglect
Antoinette Jadaone’s storytelling isn’t just intimate; it is a searing indictment of how the state and even the healthcare system fail Filipinas
This film reminds us that every choice a woman makes is shaped by power structures that shame her, control her body, and turn compassion into judgment

Through Sunshine’s journey, we see how being a woman in the Philippines means living in a constant struggle for autonomy—ang hirap maging babae, pero mas triple ang hirap ng mga babae dito sa Pilipinas
Sunshine is not just a movie; it is a mirror held up to a society that polices women’s bodies while abandoning them in their most vulnerable moments
It’s a rallying cry for the Sunshines, Theas, Helenas, Geleens, and Edens of this country—voices we must hear, stories we must protect
May this film be the turning point for our generation: progressive, pro-women, and unapologetically pro-choice
Thank you to the entire Sunshine team and SM Cinemas for making this powerful narrative accessible by lowering ticket prices
This is cinema with a purpose

Sunshine takes us by the hand in a bustling Quiapo that's full of hypocrisy, contradiction, and a brutal system on women and their bodies
It's a random odyssey of a woman trying to take back what is her's in an unforgiving conservative society
In the film's opening moments, we see an ambitious athlete confused and paralyzed with the news of her untimely pregnancy
She's scared and she's prolonging the agony of confronting the inevitable
One thing that some people may ask is, why doesn't she immediately ask anyone for help
Doesn't she have a family
Why is she trying to deal with such a serious problem on her own
Is this the society that we've grown into
Where a young woman is so afraid and paralyzed to get any help that she risks her life trying to deal with it on her own
The answer is a resounding YES
We are living in a country where dominant beliefs and religion are shoved down in women's throats even if it means giving up their dreams
Where young women are scorned and defined by their mistakes instead of being educated and getting a strong support system
Most egregiously, we live in a society that stigmatizes and punishes women but tolerates the very system, and actions that led to their unwanted pregnancies
That is the society that Jadaone perfectly paints in this harrowing film
Jadaone uses Quiapo as the backdrop to tell this story as she blends elements of neorealism and magic realism
This film has a great sense of place as Sunshine roams around a Quiapo that hides hypocrisy underneath its Catholic cathedral
Jadaone goes full Brocka mode through these scenes as she showcases different communities and people through a neorealist lens
That's why I found the film's surrealist tendencies to be a little bit jarring
Sunshine encounters a kid that appears only through her consciousness and it really makes you wonder if this type of storytelling fits the themes that Jadaone is exploring
It just runs the risk of making it too melodramatic and undercutting its authenticity
But what keeps it from going off the rails is her unwavering compassion and understanding of Sunshine's plight
Direk Tonet did mention in the Q&A session after that she swore that she was gonna hold Sunshine's hands and be by her side through every turbulence she'll face while writing this movie
In the film's third act, the neorealist and magic realist narratives just blend into a powerful, poignant, and profound moment while Sunshine practices her routine one last time
I think this is a film that our country desperately needs right now
It's bound to spark debates and fruitful discussions about abortion, reproductive health, and women's right
Some may disagree with what Sunshine ended up doing, but at least this is a film that ignites a discussion for these taboo topics
I will never know how it feels to be a woman in an unfairly conservative country
But this film rings with so much vitality, bravery, and honesty that I just cried by the end of it
This is so damn close to being a masterpiece

Maybe most ingenious about Sunshine is its willingness to accept the decision to abort likely also involves a negotiation with the unborn child, maybe even a plea for forgiveness—less from God, because getting that would be easy, and in fact Sunshine gets it out of the way early on, but more from who the child would have been
For the film indeed that is the longer battle, and it affords Sunshine a long array of events that could make the explaining easier
She sees her dilemma reflected in the city's decay, her choice—which she readily makes—put into perspective, rounded out, by another girl's inaccess to that choice
Very carefully, and backed by research, Jadaone dissects what that choice may mean for women like Sunshine in a developing city like Manila, where dreams are scarce and their fulfillment even rarer
Sunshine's choice is an act of self-determination, in a world where that's seen as vulgar, irreverent: that is clear
But to what should reverence be owed, in any case
Sunshine argues it's simply a matter of priority
When Sunshine chooses her dream—which she's been carrying in her womb longer than she's known her unborn child's ghost—we empathize with her, as does the ghost
That shows the film’s executed its heavy work

If there’s anything that is uniquely Filipino in terms of interior design, it’s the green walls
It generally evokes feelings of tranquility and harmony, but Jadaone’s latest film flips it around to signify chaos and dysfunction

The color is almost everywhere, it’s inescapable: the walls of the protagonist’s home, the sterile and hostile clinic spaces, even the motel where the film’s lead almost died, comparable to the grip Catholicism has on the Philippines
While they say there’s a separation between the church and the state, it’s barely upheld in practice, as they hinder human rights that could save thousands of lives
And yes, I am talking about abortion laws, or the lack thereof here in my country
Jadaone’s Sunshine addresses the huge elephant in the senate, as it depicts the life of its titular lead (Maris Racal), whose life is turned upside down due to a sudden news of her own pregnancy
It’s easy to blame women like Sunshine for getting pregnant
After all, she’s presented as a domineering figure in her sport, even bound to compete in the Olympics, and she technically practiced unsafe sex, but not every case of unwanted pregnancy is like that

There are multiple shots where Sunshine is physically separated by a fence-like barrier: be it the metal gates in the church, the ever-stretching horizontal jeepney rails, or the cold and black window frames, that subtly signal how Filipinas are imprisoned by their surroundings

Almost every gratingly infuriating, thought-provoking, and ludicrous dialogue circles back to one simple question: why is it that women are the ones penalized and restricted on matters that could jeopardize their own health and safety, especially in pregnancies caused by rape and incest

While watching, I was constantly reminded of a film with similar thematic points, that of Hittman’s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, and how women need to be discreet, travel thousands of miles, and suffer in silence over matters that should be openly discussed and not considered taboo or immoral
If anything, I think this film is being highly censored in the Philippines, as the movie review board slapped an R-16 rating on a film that should be watched by teenagers
How can we avoid teenage pregnancies when our government avoids talking about practicing safe sex to the right demographic
Not everyone gets a happy conclusion like Sunshine did, so I hope that this film sparks a necessary conversation about women’s rights outside of the walls of movie theaters
Jadaone’s Sunshine is truly one of the Philippines’ best releases of the year so far, in both its themes and execution, and a must-watch for all types, especially men and the religious-alike
Written immediately after screening, Journal app, revised, and posted, July 25th

We watched Sunshine yesterday, July 24, during the block screening at SM Megamall
I had seen the trailer beforehand, so I knew we were in for something bold, something necessary
But I wasn’t prepared for how deeply it would sit with me long after the credits rolled
I didn’t cry while watching the film, but once it ended, I found myself overwhelmed
The weight of Sunshine doesn’t hit all at once — it lingers, it settles
And it stays
At its core, Sunshine is the story of a woman taking control of her body in a society that keeps telling her she isn’t allowed to
It’s not simply about one choice, one moment, or one woman
It’s about the collective experience of many Filipinas who navigate a system that consistently fails to hear them
Antoinette Jadaone’s direction doesn’t shy away from discomfort

She faces it head-on, inviting the audience to confront the silences we’ve learned to live with - about abortion, reproductive rights, the stigma around sexuality, and the lack of access to informed sex education in the Philippines
Sunshine is timely, urgent, and painfully real
It gives voice to the cry of our generation, echoing the need for progressive reforms that protect women and children
The film challenges its viewers not just to empathize, but to act
As a viewer, I left the cinema not only moved, but also awakened
Sunshine isn’t here to entertain
It’s here to disturb, to provoke, and to push us into uncomfortable yet necessary conversations
To my fellow Filipinos: let’s not turn away
Let’s create spaces where women can speak freely, where choices about their bodies are met with compassion, not judgment
Let’s demand that our lawmakers stop treating reproductive health as taboo
To filmmakers and storytellers: keep telling these stories
We need more films like Sunshine—bold, unapologetic, and grounded in truth
The personal is political, and cinema has the power to move both heart and policy
Let Sunshine be a beginning
Let it be a spark
And let’s keep the conversation going

Walang Sunshine sa mundong patas
Hindi ko mapigilang ihalintulad ang Maynilang ipinapakita ng Sunshine sa Maynila na kung saan nakilala si Lino Brocka
Amoy mo ang malamayang usok ng mga sasakyan at hindi mo na ito kailanman malabas sa iyong sistema
Mahapdi ang tirik ng araw sa balat
Ramdam mo ang pawis sa balikat ng bawat kasalubong na para bang ramdam mo na rin ang bitbit nilang bigat
Rinig mo ang ingay ng mga umiiyak na sanggol sa kapitbahay at pati ang nakabibinging busina ng tren na dumadaan sa Avenida
In a Quiapo churchyard, abortion pills are sold right across the “abortion is a sin” signages

In a cramped hospital, the doctor who preaches their kind and merciful God is the same one who will shame you until you are forced to say I’m sorry, God, repenting a thousand times not to a benevolent being, but to a woman in a coat
Four women, round bellies squeezing against each other, share only two small hospital beds
Hundreds more in that one tiny room, some whose dreams never saw the light of day
I’ve had two girls already
You’re so lucky that your child is a boy
The horrifying realization that 13 isn’t even the youngest of them
Hindi mabait ang mundo, at mas lalong hindi sayo mabait ang mundo kung babae ka
But sometimes, it takes just a sliver of warmth to remind you that you are not alone
The kind that comes from the ate sa botika who hands you a pregnancy test without judgement
The kind that comes from your best friend texting they love you right when you don’t know if you’re making the right choice
Or the kind that comes from the gentle caress of a young girl bleeding out, telling you she does not want to die in the back of a police car
How you can sense that the fear in her voice is also the one that crept up on you days before, as the motel lady put you in tricycle telling the driver to hurry to the hospital
I’ve always found the word “ate” to be a strong signifier of the tight the bonds between Filipina women
We may not know each other, but we know that we carry similar burdens
Call a woman ate and their heads turn with instinct
The film does not only show you the grim, unrelenting, cruel Manila that takes (and claws) more than it gives
Nor does it exclusively show you the girlhood that was stolen from you by the capitalistic and patriarchal structures so deeply embedded in society
Yes, it shows you that
It does not hold back from showing you how tiresome it is to clean the poo of a newborn or how much more easy it is to find empathy in illegal markets than it is in public institutions
Yet, what it also shows you is that whenever you feel like a lone speck of light in the dark, just call an ate
Ask them for help
Rest on their shoulders
You are all each of you has
The film itself does its job of telling an important story beautifully

One of the key narrative devices may be a bit too on the nose for some viewers, but I find that it adds a sort of tangibility and gravity to the story that otherwise would have been missing some heart and soul without it
Tonet’s directing is sharp and focused on such visceral and visual contradictions

Nanay ba kita

Gut-wrenching and brave, Sunshine speaks truth with honesty and feminine rage in a heartbreaking story of womanhood, a character study that puts a young woman, an aspiring Olympian in the most harrowing ordeal — pursue her dreams or let go of it, continue her pregnancy or terminate it

In a country where traditions and conservatism plague our sociopolitical landscape, and at a time where the world at large is being corrupted by right-wing fundamentalists, Sunshine stands with a strong pro-choice message; that women should have the rights to bodily autonomy despite the patriarchal structures that harp on religious preachings in which our women have to pay social costs or worse, their own lives and safety
At the center of it is Sunshine, played by the brilliant Maris Racal whose tenacious yet delicate character work put so much layers to a heartfelt protagonist
In the first 10 minutes alone, Racal delivered a string of unbridled emotions, from being flushed with regret, anger and desperation, she grew with intensity, defiance and vulnerability

Her resolve is one of strength and a moving emotional core that’s unshakeable while being present in every turn in Sunshine’s dilemma in which we met the most colorful and textured cast of unusual characters
Even with Racal’s stellar lead performance, every supporting actor also put on a remarkable stamp that not only served their scenes but also the entire story

From Jennica Garcia to Annika Co to Elijah Canlas to Meryl Soriano to Xyriel Manabat to Angeli Bayani to Rhed Bustamante to Piolo Pascual, it’s perfectly casted and Jadaone made sure that they deliver a well-calibrated turn for Sunshine’s story

A chilling and entrancing dissection of womanhood, the film shifts gears as a sports movie to a melodrama injected with some satire, absurdity, and a mystical element, it’s full of inspired creative choices that are in full concerto

With its spectacular cinematography and production design from drab and somber interiors with a hint of natural light or sometimes depressing fluorescent light, to neon-tinged urban areas where chaos lingers just around the corner while also capturing Sunshine’s extraordinary close-ups behind window railings that cage her or framed by her vibrant pink ribbon; its outstanding sound design that puts Sunshine’s inner turmoil at the center of a noisy Manila and blends a surrealist element to its heart; and a formidable original music that juxtaposes Sunshine’s personality from her life as an gymnast to her personal life
Sunshine is an urgent film that needs to be seen and heard, there’s power in its universality and Tonet Jadaone’s feminist voice soars with an elevated storytelling

Beaming with Filipino sensibilities and humour, its melodrama is used with beautiful intent while being grounded and playing with raw emotional reactions from the cast, and levity and grit in its screenplay
And as cliche as it sounds, it’s a totally different Jadaone that made this movie
There’s maturity that put her titular character at the center of a well-crafted film but there’s this restraint we haven’t seen before that refined the story’s message without ever being didactic

Undoubtedly, her best film yet, an opus that cements her place as an important voice in Philippine cinema but also a landmark film that tackles subject matters that only a handful of Filipino filmmakers have touched on

An absolute achievement in today’s climate of Filipino cinema, there’s power in its tone and its themes — a protest that exposes controlling hypocritical men and medical professionals, and an interrogation of a systemic inequality full of government’s shortcomings in giving proper care and support for unwanted pregnancies, in a place where poverty and overpopulation have been a decade-long problem

But also in Sunshine, we found hope and her light in confronting her reality while finding women who helped and listened to her, a kind of feminism that celebrates sisterhood even in the most horrifying circumstance in a woman’s life
With high hopes, this should spark a conversation about women’s struggles and rights

In light of the overturning of Roe v Wade in the US, akin to Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Sunshine’s story is real and rampant in the PH, and as disturbing as it sounds, unsafe abortion have been killing 1 in 3 Filipinas each day

Too often, films about abortion fall into the trap of emotional manipulation, when they push a specific agenda, reducing a complex issue to a simplistic, black-and-white narrative
But Sunshine rises above that pattern

Instead, the film offers a nuanced portrayal of the struggles (and even rage) experienced by women who are denied access to reproductive healthcare - told with such compassion and delicacy that you cannot help but empathize with and root for Sunshine because the conservative society has failed her
I hope many people get to watch the film because it is both a deeply personal and universal story that casts a light on one of the most pressing crises in the country: teenage pregnancy
And I also hope Sunshine ushers in a healthy and open conversation because women deserve the right to make decisions for themselves
This is the kind of film I’ll be thinking for days kasi ang bigat pero napaka-cathartic panoorin

Sunshine, as a film and as a character, is bold and unwavering
She doesn't preach or ask for pity

The story is clear all through out -- Sunshine has made her decision, and while she seeks understanding, she seeks it only from those who matter, not from the audience and definitely not from the holier-than-thou
While Sunshine embarks on her journey to find answers, we never forget what she is -- a young girl in the Philippines, left to deal with the consequences of an unplanned pregnancy alone

It is so easy to put the blame on women or on impulsive, lustful teenagers, but the film reminds us that in a country where religious biases trump teenage pregnancy and maternal mortality rates, pointing fingers helps no one
The film reminds us that for women and other marginalized sectors, the first line of defense against systemic neglect is community
Brave and unfiltered, I can easily see Sunshine becoming a Filipino classic

To be a woman is to carry quiet storms, but to be one in the Philippines is to brave them with no shelter, judged for bleeding, blamed for surviving and denied the right to choose
Direk Antoinette Jadaone's magnum opus
Maris Racal's finest acting work
And arguably the most important Filipino film of our generation
Heavy raindrops were like meteorites landing on the pockmarked pavements of Manila when we braved two storms to catch the screening of Sunshine

Our tuktuk carried only three passengers: me, my partner, and another man—seven people short of the usual full ride as it had been a week of rain with flooding which meant classes and government work were cancelled
When it rained harder, our driver couldn’t help but mutter Tama na
Gutom na kami
It’s hunger borne out of poverty that limits, if not entirely removes, the access of ordinary Filipinos to watch important films such as Sunshine
Like any other works of art attempting to feature parts and parcels of Philippine society, etched on its tapestry is the signature Manila mayhem: masikip, mabaho, maingay and magulo
But the structure of the film is far from chaotic despite the complicated and challenging subject Direk Antoinette Jadaone took upon herself to flesh out
The stakes were high and indeed pushed the protagonist to do what she thought needs to be done
Her point was clear and warranted no further elaboration
Maris Racal was stellar in her portrayal of an aspiring Olympian who got pregnant at the blossoming of her career as a young athlete
The same can be said about the equally astounding young actress Annika Co who was a perfect foil to Racal’s character
The film, with its shorter than usual run time of barely an hour and a half minutes, didn’t hold back in driving its message, leaving nothing open for interpretation
Towards the end where Sunshine was performing her routine, I thought for a moment that her beaming towards the camera with her majestic ribbon would be the final shot of the film

But when the young Annika was shown watching Sunshine finish gracefully finishing her performance and embracing her when it ended, that was when I realized, gets ko na, that in this narrative, she would have a choice, one that's entirely her own
Direk Tonet has managed to make such a compact film about choice
While choice for women is such a privilege in a conservative country like ours, there’s something powerful in showing that Sunshine made a choice, one that goes against the conventional
While other films of the same topic would leave it to the audience to ponder whether or not the protagonist would choose the controversial choice, Sunshine showed us that yes, she did that
After the end credits have rolled, we were left staring at the black screen, perhaps, feeling fulfilled, weighed upon, or hungrier than ever for films of the same caliber

Sunshine is so monumental for Philippine cinema that it reaffirms one of my aspirations, that one day, Filipinos can have the choice about what films to watch in the cinema every weekend, not choose just either one—satisfying their physiological hunger or fulfilling the hunger of the soul

Perhaps the best Filipino film of the year so far, and an important one at that
“GETS KO NA
”First things first, thank you Direk Antoinette Jadaone for being so brave
Our country badly needs films that dare to confront the cries and injustices our society (esp women) continue to face
Sunshine is a soft, aching plea for change
It’s a quiet but urgent cry for body autonomy, for choice, for justice
And it’s not just about one woman’s pain — it’s rooted in something deeper: a system that has long failed us, most esp women, in this country
Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine begins with control
With poise, with the perfect arabesque, and with the precision of a gymnast that is ready for the next move
But as the film moves along, the tension in the stillness builds up and begins to show
Behind the clean flow and rhythm of theribbon, the rehearsed elegance of the body is still pushed to their limit
Sunshine feels like a cruel misdirection, but the contrast is exactly the point that womanhood needs
In a country where abortion is still illegal without exceptions, Sunshine doesn’t just tell the story of a young woman’s crisis
It captures a quiet violence of expectation, the pressure to remain graceful even when they are under a system that does not allow women to fail, to choose, or even to speak freely

In the Philippines, the Revised Penal Code punishes abortion with imprisonment, while access to safe and legal procedures remains out of reach for most women, especially those who are young and unfortunate
Punishment because of abortion with imprisonment, and this legal stance is reinforced by deeply rooted religious conservatism
It is not just illegal—it is unthinkable
The stigma runs deep, and the silence surrounding it is even deeper
According to the Center for Reproductive Rights (2023), thousands of women are forced into this silence every year
Estimated around 1
1 million Filipino women induce abortion annually
About 1,000 of Filipinas die each year from abortion-related complications, and over 100,000are hospitalized due to unsafe procedures
These numbers are not just statistics, they are lives of the young, scared, and the unheard
Sunshine puts that reality front and center, but does so without shouting
It doesn’t force emotion, it lets it build naturally
This film follows Sunshine as she navigates through the aftermath of a missed period, a distracted boyfriend, and a society that offers no legal, safe, or accessible options
She’s left to carry the weight of a decision she didn’t choose, in a system that treats her body like public property
Sunshine (played by Maris Racal) is a kind character with stillness that feels like a resistance
Her performance is tight, contained, and filled with the kind of fear that is quiet and does not seek and beg for sympathy
A character with a facade that represents many generations of women where they mask all of their feelings and hold on to the thought that “this too shall pass”
She is not trying to explain herself, she is simply trying to breathe and move in a world that keeps on closing in
Racal does not rely on big breakdowns or dramatic lines
She holds her ground even when that ground is crumbling beneath her
Every look, every breath, feels calibrated
Like someone preparing for a landing they know they might not even survive
What makes the performance even more powerful is how familiar Sunshine feels
She is notwritten as an extraordinary character
She is a regular young woman, navigating school, relationships, and the uncertainty of early adulthood
She could be any girl from any province, any city, any university
That ordinariness is important
Because it reminds us that this story isnot rare
It is not fiction
It is the quiet, constant reality of so many young women in this country who are forced to navigate the consequences of a decision they didn’t even get to make
Jadaone doesn’t push for spectacle
The film sits with silence and discomfort
No overdramatization and overexplanation

Her braveness has a place in Philippine Cinema as this take and storytelling of hers about abortion in a world where systems and institutions are fallingshort, the quiet resistance of Sunshine speaks volume
Instead of turning the film into a message movie, Jadaone chooses to linger
She doesn’t try to solve anything
She doesn’t pretend that resolution is possible
And that’s what makes Sunshine hit even harder
The film doesn’t just show the problem, it lets us sit in it
It allows discomfort to stretch across the screen without rushing to ease it
That discomfort mirrors what many women feel in real life
The shame
The fear
The confusion
The silence that comes not from peace, but from pressure
It also explores the feelings through visuals
Pao Orendain, the Cinematographer of the film captures the feel of the City of Manila
How it is familiar inside the streets, but also how suffocating it is
The noise pollution that is made by the vehicles, the streets filled with conversations, and the trains rattling as it passes by
The way they captured it, Manila is just another place where it forces the characters to move carefully, just like any other people who lives, visits, and goes to Manila to reclaim life
The streets hum with life, but not always with warmth
The camera observes from a distance, never forcing perspective but always aware of the space Sunshine must navigate
What makes Sunshine stand out is that it never asks permission to tell this story
It does not frame abortion as a debate, or as an issue that needs to be justified
It centers the experience without apology
In doing so, it offers a kind of cinematic resistance that feels rare in Philippine cinema
Jadaone’s choice to tell this story without moralizing, without preaching, without forcing catharsis, gives it more weight than any dramatic scene ever could
And in a country that still debates whether women should have that right, Sunshine lands, not perfectly, but with all the force of someone who has had enough
Someone who knows she deserves more
And that is enough to shake the ground beneath her, even if no one else is watching
Like a gymnast mid-tumble, it shows how much strength it takes just to survive a fall
And sometimes, survival is the bravest routine of all
Gets na gets kita, Sunshine
This review features some spoilers
In local cinema, as with mainstream media, there’s a dearth of films tackling abortion
12 Weeks, Anna Isabelle Matutina’s Cinemalaya feature debut, was the latest attempt I could recall, or at least one that had something useful to say

At the same time, a comprehensive sexuality education integrated at all education levels (separate from the education department’s sex ed order), as proposed in the anti-teenage pregnancy bill, has been under fire from the country’s conservative population
Into this frantic context emerges Sunshine, the latest indie darling from writer-director Antoinette Jadaone
The sole Philippine entry in the Centrepiece section of the 2024 Toronto International Film Festival, the film finally comes home

It’s making its local premiere exclusively at SM cinemas, after touring the international film fest circuit to critical renown, including the Crystal Bear for Best Film at this year’s Berlin International Film Festival
But make no mistake, as the picture refuses to be singled out as an “abortion film,” a descriptor so sweeping and limiting that it is seen only vis-à-vis morality
Jadaone finds new ammo with which to make sense of the polarizing topic: gymnastics
(The film’s TIFF world premiere, in fact, came at the heels of gymnast Carlos Yulo’s double Olympic gold in Paris
)The sports drama unfolds through the title character, played by Maris Racal, a young gymnast whose preparation for national tryouts is upended after discovering she’s pregnant

Refusing to compromise her shot at Olympic glory, with her useless boyfriend (Elijah Canlas) almost instantly ditching her, Sunshine resorts to illegal abortifacients offered by Manila’s underbelly, where she runs into an enigmatic young girl (Annika Go) bent on tracking her every move and policing her every decision
Soon, she internalizes biblical shame
Sunshine follows Jadaone’s feminist inclinations

Her directorial debut Six Degrees of Separation from Lilia Cuntapay (2011), is a raw mockumentary that doubles as a compelling paean to the titular screen bit actress, whose name is nearly synonymous with Philippine horror but has largely remained underappreciated

In Never Not Love You (2018), Nadine Lustre’s Joanne is a breadwinner who trades a long-awaited job promotion in Manila for a fraught chance to begin anew and dream together with her privileged boyfriend in London, only to wrestle with the punishing economics of romance
Fan Girl (2020) explores the dark side of being a superfan through a female character who’s a proxy for the film’s articulation about the psychology of idle worship in a nation forever beholden to it
Shortcomings of these movies aside, Jadaone insists on narratives that do not treat and present the female gaze as though it’s self-explanatory
The director often edges toward gray areas and destabilizing standpoints, whether or not they wind up humorous, fascinating, schmaltzy, or troubling
Whereas Jadaone’s previous movies are attuned to the conventions of their respective genres, Sunshine offers something new to the director’s dramaturgical defaults
The film is an intersection of neorealism and magical realism

It trains the camera on Manila’s grime, decay, and nonstop noise, embracing its outcasts and harsh truths (the Lino Brocka comparisons are inevitable), just as it punctuates the gritty reality with a magical invocation via the imaginary friend that trails Sunshine

“Media literacy” would tell you that the spectral presence is a representation of the internal-external friction the heroine deals with; fetus in the flesh and the body that refuses to carry it; the back-and-forth between morality and pragmatism
(Jadaone, in an interview with Filmmaker Magazine, revealed she was inspired by the imaginary character in Taika Waititi’s 2019 satirical drama Jojo Rabbit

) But beyond this, the make-believe figure is a surrogate for the conservative, pro-life fraction of the audience, with the director opting to engage in the subject matter’s complexity instead of comfortably locating the film in an echo chamber

While the narrative device could prove as an apparent play at sympathy, indulging in a “will she, won’t she” kind of thinking (surface-level reading could also suggest that women seeking abortion are deluded, ridiculous as that implication might sound), it also offers access to the broader violence disguised as “conscience” that puts women, regardless of gender identities, at a disadvantage

If anything, Sunshine is less about the act of abortion itself than about the systems that encourage women to settle for dehumanizing rights already decided for them by a patriarchal few, systems that prohibit them from dreaming, and tell them that to dream only means more labor, nothing more

Sunshine, like Petersen Vargas’ Some Nights I Feel Like Walking (which made its Philippine premiere in June), harnesses the metropolis as a character of its own, instead of reducing it to a mere symbolic backdrop
Whereas Some Nights steeps its urban tale in neon erotica, completely absent of daylight, Sunshine shifts between the city’s diurnal and nocturnal environments

Pao Orendain’s camerawork here chiefly reaps magic from close-ups and interior shots, often framed from the window and dotted by a shaft of light (hence the Brocka sentiments), locating the viewer into the heroine’s intimate yet anxious state
The self-induced abortion scene in the sketchy motel, a sight casually interrupted by frantic railway noise, is particularly visceral that you can almost feel the texture of the image

The camera also draws focus to the irony that permeates Manila’s streets, particularly around the vicinity of Quiapo Church, where makeshift stalls selling figurines, scapulars, and all sorts of religious paraphernalia also offer abortion drugs and quack treatments, just as banners declaring “abortion is murder” remain a typical sighting
In other scenes where Sunshine traverses the cityscape, the visuals are more straightforward
Accompanying the images is a soundscape that immersively mirrors the congestion, exhaustion, and urban din that form part of the DNA of the country’s capital
Jadaone’s script nearly leans on the miserablist

When Sunshine finds an opportunity to pull herself out of the vexing situation, poverty immediately gets in the way, leaving her with no choice but to ask her boyfriend for a meager P5,000 to secure the abortion drug and a cheap motel room to perform the deed herself
Yet even in Manila’s hospitals, the conditions are dire; patients are forced to share beds, and hallways are turned into makeshift wards, crowded by people in need of attention beyond the medical
Rape and casual prostitution also get in the way, as in the case of Menggay (Rhed Bustamante), the pregnant 13-year-old Sunshine comes across in Quiapo
In a highlight moment, Sunshine, livid upon meeting her friend’s abuser, suddenly picks up a beer bottle and whacks it over the man’s head, before sprinting to escape the scene
(Curiously, Jadaone plumbs the politics of self-determination by contrasting Sunshine’s ability to decide for herself with Menggay’s distance from that very sense of agency
) Even the Quiapo vendors selling abortifacients, who some might think merely exploit the desperation of their customers, are also victims who simply don’t earn enough
Unflattering as these depictions are, it’s hard to deny that these aren’t routine realities in the social inferno that is the Philippines
Still, there is humor, whether in a scene that involves a knife interrupting a silly argument, or in another that sees a self-righteous doctor preaching the goodness of the divine
As Sunshine, Racal delivers a performance that would be a disservice to reduce to neat superlatives
It’s a physical portrayal that required the actor to undergo training with national gymnastics coaches for nearly a year
It’s a role that might put her in the center of another controversy after barely surviving the previous one

But just as Sunshine is asked to “drown out the noise” whenever she steps on the mat, Racal distills every layer and emotion into a character that’s simply life-like, almost free from the veil of performance-making
Jadaone once told me that her ideal lead performance is one that “is part of something bigger than herself
” There has not been a more worthy portrayal in local cinema this year
At the same time, the movie functions as a reintroduction to the boundless talent of Jennica Garcia, who plays Sunshine’s elder sister, a single mother trying to keep everything intact
Her portrayal expertly captures what a supporting performance should be—one that has enough screentime to be an emotional anchor for the lead but also generates her own moment
There’s a kind of invisible labor informing the character that Garcia encapsulates with an onscreen presence that always feels grounded and never incidental
Sunshine is hardly a social exposé

What ripples throughout this partly winding urban tale is a ready, fatal fact about the place of women in this eternally eroded nation that we’d rather dismiss as “controversial” or “divisive” because we refuse to listen
The film’s visuals might be artful, but they don’t always convey a pretty picture

It’s no coincidence that the movie’s narrative throughline is the community that Sunshine finds in the women around her: her elder sister, her best friend (Xyriel Manabat), despite her initial inhibitions, her coach (Meryll Soriano), the young Menggay, the compassionate doctor (Angeli Bayani), and even the imaginary friend
Though this sense of solidarity comes at varying degrees, it keeps Sunshine afloat and does not let her think of herself as a monster for terminating an unwanted pregnancy
Once Sunshine nears its final shot, I keep thinking of Fan Girl’s insular ending that succeeds its heroine’s already exhausting journey
I’m glad to learn that our heroine this time does not succumb to sheer epiphany
Here, hope actually feels like a tangible possibility instead of an unwarranted emotional wallop
Sunshine is perhaps not Jadaone’s most definitive work; That Thing Called Tadhana (2014) or Never Not Love You might claim that distinction
But it is her sharpest creation yet
It took a whole lot of research and lived experiences to put this story on the screen
It took a bit of time for the film to make its way back to where it started
It’s a miracle that it even got the go signal to be screened publicly
I can already sense all the hot takes and thinkpieces it will generate
And I can only hope that it will be as meaningful as this
This review appears on PhilSTAR Life in a slightly different version

“Gets ko na

”In this film, we follow Sunshine, a rhythmic gymnast and an Olympic hopeful, as she travels through Manila’s dark, narrow, grimy, and crowded streets and alleys in search of a way to terminate her pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal
There are few parts of this film that really stood out to me because they made elevated the movie and made it more compelling
The first part that I really liked is how the city became a living representation of this country’s oppressive stance against anything pro-abortion
The city allowed us to have something tangible, to be able to relate to Sunshine’s struggles even more
Second, the magical realism aspect is also a highlight for me
Once it finally clicked what Ariana and Annika Co’s characters represented, I was blown away
One common argument of those against abortion is that you are going to kill someone who’s probably gonna be a very important person
And yet, we get Annika Co’s character
Through a very powerful performance we end up caring for this kid

But once you start to realize who she us and who she represents, you start to realize that she’s not just an extension of Sunshine but a representative of all babies born to mothers forced to carry a child
She and these babies are vessels forced to carry the unfulfilled dreams of their mothers
She said something like, “Ang pangarap niya ay ang pangarap ko
” And that line broke me
The argument is always, “We are not fulfilling someone’s potential if we abort them
” but there’s always a failure to acknowledge that forcing someone to bear a child is also not allowing them to fulfill their potential
The last part that stood out to me is Maris Racal’s great performance
She is the movie
Without that performance, this film will fall apart and she delivers
What this film did is humanize a debate that’s usually so contentious it ends up being too one dimensional
It made the debate more accessible to every one
The movie is unflinching and raw
A harsh criticism of a society and culture who despite being always proud of their women, continues to fail them by continuing to enabling oppressive systems that mostly targets women
A big middle finger to a society that still strongly reeks of misogyny
It also an exploration of the country’s broken healthcare system
This film is a celebration of female friendships and sisterhood
The people who helped Sunshine in her journey are women
It forces you to be uncomfortable
It forces you to think and have empathy
This film is highly relevant and should be a required watching for everyone
Probably one of the most important Filipino films ever made
Hope it gets an even wider release

we meet sunshine through her battle of being an olympian
armored by her well-worn asian games shirt and her head held high, she shines the brightest among her peers who also look up to her and what more she can become
her coach knows this too, along with her family and lifelong friend, who would all do everything to make sure she achieves them

perhaps its in the nuance of a story that is deeply feminist and human, but antoinette's jadaone's sunshine is the strongest in its ability to capture the realities of adolescent pregnancy with both gentleness and fierce

portraying (albeit sometimes preaching about, but deservingly so) the world of a filipina girl navigating the weight of expectations and the silence surrounding sexual and reproductive health, the story unfolds as a reflection of what we lack and suffer from

this flaw persists in the lesson of consent that was never taught, contraception never offered, the judgment of clinical service providers, the terrifying possibility of dying alone, and the unbearable strength it takes to push forward anyway, not because you’re fearless, but because you must
as a youth
as a woman
as a human with dreams and rights

the reality today is rough: the philippine government failed to pass its version of the adolescent pregnancy prevention bill in the recent senate, the current curriculum and implementation of the comprehensive sexuality education is in question, and more and more right-wing (ish) groups are mobilizing their funds to hinder the fight even more

but hopefully, with these kind of films made accessible to the public, we will be reminded that abortion happens not just because teenagers are risky or that they have been abuse hence it's justified, but because they have the right to decide for themselves
after all, sunshine's every step and every twirl, carries not just her own hope, but the collective dreams of those who raised her, and fought for her to have this

and in watching her take the mat, we are reminded of every girl who dreams of olympic gold, of becoming president, of curing AIDS, and how urgent it is that we believe in them first before some blob of blood
that we talk to them about things that matter
that we care
because when we do, they shine
