Sunshine Is Every Woman Who Dreams Beyond Her CircumstancesSunshine was not created for the sake of making a statement, nor just triggering a conversation; it was meant to make people feel and understand why abortion happens and how our current system makes them dangerous for women
Sunshine did not need to be pitied or root for, she needed to be understood
The film opens and immediately solidifies Sunshine’s ambition
It is anchored on Sunshine’s eagerness to excel, to achieve, to succeed, to be the best, to be an Olympian
And this ambition is not going anywhere

With every tiptoe that Sunshine stands on—as she throws her pink ribbons and gives in to impulse—she stands tall again, catching the ribbons as if they were always meant to fall in the right places… until they don't
Sunshine’s perfect harmony gets disturbed by her sudden realization that she is pregnant
Antoinette Jadaone’s intentional direction on making some scenes too loud, too chaotic, and far too overwhelming added to the personification of Sunshine’s mind; scrambling, panicking, terrored
It was not just Quiapo’s busy streets, it was also Sunshine’s trembling heart
But in between the anxiety and fear, Sunshine gathers the courage to try making a choice—even amidst the confusion
Sunshine finds out in the harshest way possible that a choice is not an option
She is put in a situation where the only way out is to give in to ‘sinful’ acts, dangerous pills, and death-defying abortion attempts
For a young teenager whose dreams seem too far from where she is, this is the only way
While many expect this decision to become the climax of the movie, Sunshine’s story is far from over
In my understanding, the film explored her conscience through Annika Co’s beautifully done character
It reminded the audience that while women consent to abortion, they are still carrying its moral burden
Annika’s character became an instrument to make women who seek abortion feel human, with human conscience and sensibilities
But it was done with such care, careful enough not to make it counterproductive but rather stuck in the ideology of the system that she grew up in
However, Annika’s character is only a personification of Sunshine’s chaotic mind, making Sunshine her own companion to her dawning journey

This character becomes Sunshine’s comfort in the dangers of her abortion attempts, showing the deeply awful and tragic realities many women face; alone in rotting walls of the city, drowning out the noise, and daring to dream bigger than the spaces they are subjected in
But what makes this movie even more special is that it did not let Sunshine go through it alone
While the movie was an avenue for telling the reality, it also became a source of hope for many women, especially for young ones who will watch it

There will be other women supporting them in their decision, other women who will not judge them for their choices, and other women who will create a safe space for them—at least in ways that they can, in the rotting system we have
Finally, Sunshine does not just urge the system to give women the rights to their own body; it explicitly explains what women go through in the struggles that we speak of
It does not undermine the calls for a systemic change, but it brings you the stories behind why a choice is necessary
It opens you to a narrative that does not just agree to progressive actions, but puts the heart in it
And in between those narratives, the movie reminds us that women are more, that they deserve to take up more space
Women are dreamers, they have ambition, they are complex, cohesive, and compassionate
Women are more than their mistakes, their stories go beyond
And that is the essence of a choice; to let them dream
To free them from the shackles of an already oppressing society
To not dim their light and let them shine, like Sunshine herself
To all the Sunshines out there, you are not alone
Be steadfast on your ambition and dare to dream big
And you take up space even bigger

Sunshine is a brave and powerful film—one that confronts a deeply taboo subject with grace, nuance, and emotional weight, especially within the context of the Philippines’ heavily religious culture
Tonet Jadaone doesn’t pull punches, but she doesn’t sensationalize either
It’s an honest, grounded portrayal of something often swept under the rug
Maris Racal shines in a career-defining performance—raw, vulnerable, and fully committed
This isn’t an easy watch, but it’s a necessary one
And for those who stay with it, it’s deeply rewarding

In many known movies, abortion is commonly narrated as a quest with so much comedic acts, plus some forced shallow arguments to inject drama
But for Sunshine — How the movie depicted purchasing a pregnancy test kit in the Philippines = an act to get humiliated
Sunshine, a teenage Filipina athlete forged to be an Olympian who had an unwanted pregnancy, was the sacrificial being for a story to be told
Sunshine happened in the Philippines, where access to reproductive health services is way harder to have compared to other countries, like in the US and Europe
The country has been enclosed with regressive conservatism, causing talks about sex to still be taboos
Abortion is still illegal as well
The movie happened right smack in the heart of Manila City — Quiapo

It is an area known for a well-known Catholic Church and the surrounding kubols or booths of herbal medicines and potions for all uses — from seducing someone, cursing someone, to inducing abortion (or in Filipino, “pampawala ng kapit ng bata
”) The story, its darkness, and some women’s resort to the said harmful options would not have happened if only proper education and healthcare are available, to be honest
Sunshine was very telling of the struggles of Filipinas
But I think it’s globally reflective as well because it told the following things:1
) Unfair treatment on female athletes: Remember Venus Williams’ pregnancy
She almost died after giving birth, and she was kicked out of the top ranks because she cannot play during recovery
The WNBA players
They just wore shirts last All-Star weekend saying “Pay Us What You Owe Us
” And here, Sunshine, an aspiring Olympian, unintentionally risking her passion and potential bread and butter just because proper help is nowhere in sight
) Violence against women and children: Catcalling, predatory stares, and rape were parts of this movie
The movie did as much as it could to raise awareness that these actions are still apparent and are unfortunate enablers of all things that went downhill for the female characters
Sunshine mirrored reality, especially for us, Filipinas
I hate writing that sentence, but, it’s the truth
————————Technical items I liked:• Rico Blanco’s Challengers-esque film score
The music was so immersive
• Rhetorical characters (which are pretty difficult to execute and usually come out as trying-hard, but they weren’t)• Piolo Pascual and his presence
The audience just gasped as soon as he entered the frame
• Most of all — Maris Racal
Her future is so bright
Pain, so much pain, was expressed by her character
And she did more than enough that the audience would want to stop whatever’s causing her agony
• Gusto Ko Sakin Ka Lang is a banger in a tugstugs jeep ↕If you’re in the Philippines, watch this in any SM Cinema
If you’re outside the Philippines, watch out for more future film festivals
Sunshine has been shown in the Toronto International Film Festival, Berlin International Film Festival, Palm Springs International Film Festival, and many more
Sunshine is more than a film about a teenage gymnast reaching for her olympic dreams
it reflects the struggles, hopes, and quiet battles of countless young girls trying to find light in a world that often dims their shine
Sunshine isn’t just an athlete wearing an asian games shirt holding a pink crane—she is a woman, a sister, a student, a friend, and someone younger girls look up to

set in the noisy, smoggy, and congested streets of Manila, the film doesn’t shy away from the uncomfortable realities many Filipino girls face: teenage pregnancy, poverty, lack of access to healthcare and education, judgment from professionals, and the systemic neglect of women’s rights

ADDENDUM CHAR (i just can’t stop thinking about this movie after like a week) Sunshine is a story of hope entangled in reality’s shadow
I’ve seen this film before—many times
As a student, learning the theoretical aspects of medicine
As an intern, having actual encounters through interviews with women like Sunshine
And as a practicing physician, who trained to become an OB-GYN, completing many incomplete miscarriages—induced or not—removing what’s left of what we call products of conception
Sometimes people call it products of misconception when they’re trying to be funny
This movie didn’t just slap us with the sensitive issue of abortion
It dissected so many layers of issues we need to talk about more often—and pondering them in reality is a mental and moral gymnastics at play

I would love to discuss all of them one by one, but this is a movie review after all, not an essay on the dangers of lacking a solid law to protect our young women from the societal pressures of patriarchy and religion—pressures that push them into life-threatening situations, only to be blamed for doing something they had no real choice about
In short, fuck the system
It’s always been a mental gymnastics for me to decide how to approach situations like this
And this movie is telling me exactly how
Jennica Garcia’s character deeply resonated with me—from the way she calls Sunshine’s name so tenderly, to the way she assures her that she’ll be there no matter what
She reminds us that we all need at least one ate around us who looks after us despite everything
(She literally said, shouted even, BE KIND
)Another character who lingered in my mind was the 14-year-old teenage mother
Shoutout to the team for dressing her in something colorful—a subtle clue to her identity, only revealed later
She was one small character representing thousands of teenage mothers, who are becoming younger as the years go by
She also represented the vulnerable group prone to sexual abuse—the group we have somehow failed to protect
I’d love to dissect each of the characters, but I’ll leave that to you
Instead, I’ll talk about Sunshine (last na, promise)
Maris Racal’s portrayal was a masterclass in character acting
Sunshine is a fearless dreamer, full of dedication and passion to make that dream come true
She perseveres despite her family’s circumstances
She’s also a believer, kind, and someone who truly cares

You see it in the small things—like the way she makes the sign of the cross before her performance, or when she prays fervently in Quiapo Church to ask for guidance or forgiveness on the thing she’s about to do or not to do
And that’s the beauty of this film—it tells you so many things without saying so much
It urges its viewers to talk about them because these are urgent matters
Maybe we’re still far from legalizing abortion, but this movie isn’t just about that
It’s telling us we have so many other issues to tackle
In short, we need to protect the Sunshines—or this world will become darker than it already is
sobrang oa na naiyak ako feeling ko may kipay din ako
I’m fairly easy to please when it comes to films
Give me a solid plot, a bit of laughter, a love story I can root for, and a strong ensemble, and I’m happy
Sunshine delivers all of these, but more importantly, it delivers a quiet, aching kind of truth
The trailer already sets up the premise: an aspiring Olympic gymnast finds herself two months away from the qualifiers, and pregnant
What unfolds is not a cautionary tale, but a necessary, grounded story about the private cost of dreams and the impossible decisions women are often forced to make
This is not a conventional film
At several moments, I found myself crying with Sunshine—because I know there are many women like her
Women who have been in the same position, or still are

In a country where laws continue to deny women the right to make choices about their own bodies, Sunshine handles its subject matter with a kind of restraint and realism that does not demand pity, but insists on empathy
Even if you haven’t experienced what she has, you feel it—because you are human, and perhaps more deeply, because you are a woman
When the credits rolled, it took a while before anyone in the cinema, including myself to get up and leave
There was a heaviness in the room
Everyone sat in silence, letting the weight of the film settle in
Some have described the film as Brocka-esque, and I find that comparison apt
This is Tonette Jadaone’s most powerful work to date
A film that is necessary, timely, and deserving of all our support
I hope more people watch Sunshine and understand this side of womanhood, one that is constantly sidelined in the name of morality and ethics
There is truth, and power, in giving women the right to choose
In letting them take ownership of their own bodies

In 50 years, people will talk about Sunshine in the same breath as Lino Brocka’s, Ishmael Bernal’s, and Marilou Diaz-Abaya’s works
It’s a modern classic - rich in details and symbolism, but sparse and no-nonsense in its storytelling
Perhaps Direk Tonet’s best work to date

There’s a quiet power in Sunshine, one that doesn’t shout its message but lets it settle in your bones

This film is many things: a coming-of-age story, a critique of a broken system, a glimpse into the intimate pain of being a girl in a country where your choices are limited before you’re even allowed to make them
It focuses on the deeply human moments of fear, frustration, and quiet strength as Sunshine navigates an impossible decision in a society that offers her no safe options
Maris Racal delivers her best performance yet, as there’s a stillness to it that makes it all the more heartbreaking
What I really loved is how it doesn’t feel like it’s trying to explain itself and it just presents the reality where religion, poverty, and patriarchy intersect in deeply personal ways
It’s a whole world closing in on a girl who’s just trying to breathe, fighting for her freedom to choose and a right to dream

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine listens
It listens to the silence of shame, the dissonance of faith, and the quiet, aching resolve of a girl who simply wants to choose
It’s the kind of film that our deeply Catholic country isn’t ready for, but desperately needs
That it’s showing in nationwide cinemas—not just tucked in the corners of a progressive film festival—feels like a small act of rebellion in itself

Like Eliza Hittman’s Never Rarely Sometimes Always, a film I often return to when thinking about stories of quiet resistance, Sunshine unfolds with restraint and tenderness, never sensationalizing what is already unbearable

But where Hittman’s film relies on cold urban detachment, Jadaone’s world breathes with a Filipino kind of chaos: loud horns, dim chapels, vendors selling herbal “solutions” beside icons of the Virgin Mary
It’s all there
The hypocrisy, the hush-hush remedies, the weight of sin pressed upon young women’s shoulders before they even understand the language of their own bodies
Maris Racal is astonishing
She carries the film with a performance so grounded, so lived-in, that she often feels less like a character and more like someone we know
A friend
A cousin
A girl on the jeep beside us, clutching a bag, hiding her fear behind a tight grip and a brave face
Her Sunshine is not loud, but she is brave
And perhaps bravery today looks exactly like this: choosing to take control of your life, even when the world tries to stop you
Jadaone’s direction is both intimate and distant, borrowing from the gaze of Brocka but infused with a distinctly feminine grief
We see Sunshine from behind glass, from across alleys, as if we too are complicit in watching but not speaking up
Yet the film never loses its tenderness, even in its political anger
Sunshine is not an easy watch
But it is essential
In a country where reproductive rights are still cloaked in rosaries and stigma, this film asks us not just to look, but to sit, to stay, to listen
It doesn’t beg for permission
It asserts presence
And sometimes, in a nation deafened by doctrine, that’s more than enough

i’ve already seen so many pro-choice films that greatly explore the difficulties of going through an abortion (never rarely something always, happening, etc) but i must say that it feels really different to watch a film like it made in your country

because in the pro-choice films i’ve watched before, they’re usually either set in the old times where abortion was still illegal in their countries or set in a modern setting whereas the female lead needs to travel in other places/states to undergo abortion legally… but in sunshine, it’s set in the modern times or the living conditions of filipino people right now yet there’s still no place to go where abortion is accepted… which speaks a lot about the real life situation for women in our country
women anywhere have to go through a lot to apply *the choice* that they’ve decided on

however, it is much much worse in the philippines as it’s a complete taboo and sometimes it feels like we’ll never see in our lifetime where abortion will finally be legal in the country…… so, it truly is a remarkable feat that we got a pro-choice filipino film now
not only that because it’s directed by one of the most well-known directors, released nationwide, and promoted in mainstream shows and platforms
this film shedded some light to everyone and it was very much needed for every filipino woman out there
thank you direk antoinette, maris racal, and all the amazing women here for sharing the story of sunshine

This film is, at its core, a well-intentioned and emotionally resonant film
It tackles difficult subject matter with sincerity, and for the most part, it does so with grace
However, I found that the inclusion of fantastical or imaginary elements occasionally detracted from the weight of its core issues

While I understand the metaphorical ambition behind these stylistic choices as well as their function in softening the emotional blows with humor or levity, I believe the film is at its most powerful when it forgoes embellishment and leans fully into the raw intensity of its subject matter

In those moments, when it embraces the chaos, the pain, and the emotional urgency it really becomes something far more affecting and memorable, allowing the simplicity it strives for to emerge, though it’s often overshadowed
At times, the dialogue veers into overtly inspirational or didactic terrain, feeling more like affirmations meant to uplift than naturalistic exchanges between characters
It’s clear that the film doesn’t only aim to tell a story, it wants to educate, to empower, to stir social consciousness
Yet in doing so, it sometimes edges closer to the tone of an educational TV movie than a fully realized work of cinema
That’s not a critique of its moral imperative, it’s a film that should be shown in schools but rather an observation about its limitations as a piece of narrative storytelling
The emotional and ideological weight it seeks to carry isn’t always supported by the nuance or complexity that cinematic storytelling demands
What grounds the film and gives it its most enduring power is its emotional core
Maris Racal delivers a performance of quiet strength and vulnerability, anchoring the film with remarkable consistency
Especially compelling is the subplot involving Rhed Bustamante’s character
Without revealing too much, her arc resonated with me more deeply than the central storyline
It was heartbreakingly authentic, subtle, restrained, and profoundly human
In that thread, the film touches something honest and unflinching
I also admired Antoinette Jadaone’s formal restraint in certain key scenes, particularly her choice to mute the sound
In a film so concerned with voice and expression, those pockets of silence carried tremendous weight
They allowed the viewer a moment of stillness, a space for reflection and imbued the film with a haunting quietude that deepened the emotional stakes
That said, the film’s message doesn’t always land with clarity
After a pivotal hospital scene, I overheard two audience members blame the protagonist for her choices, siding with the doctor who confronts her
That reaction, while anecdotal, reveals a significant shortcoming: the narrative may not have sufficiently challenged ingrained prejudices or prompted the kind of empathy it aspired to cultivate

It bravely addresses urgent topics- reproductive rights, bodily autonomy, the realities of being a young woman navigating unjust systems but the film doesn’t always sharpen these into a coherent or persuasive argument
In trying to reach everyone, it occasionally loses the sharpness needed to truly confront
Still, “Sunshine” is a valuable film, one with earnestness, compassion, and purpose
Its flaws are born of ambition: the desire to inspire, to uplift, and to inform all at once
But perhaps empowerment doesn’t always need to be accompanied by joy
Sometimes, it is in the unvarnished confrontation of pain without fantasy, without consolation that we discover our deepest strength

I don’t mean to suggest the film ought to have ended in despair, but rather that its final act, which shifts into metaphor and closes with a success story, might have benefitted from something more grounded, more unresolved or ambiguous
Real life rarely provides a clean arc, and in a film so rooted in truth, the ending felt almost too easy, too neat

To be honest, Sunshine may follow the story of a gymnast, but it's really about the quiet, impossible contortions many women are forced to make just to keep going—physically, emotionally, morally
It’s about the weight of carrying something you didn’t choose, in a world that offers you no real way out
It asks the kind of questions that linger long after the credits roll: How do you hold on to your dreams when your body no longer feels like your own
How do you choose anything at all when every choice comes with shame, fear, or punishment

In a country where abortion is completely outlawed—even in cases of rape or danger to the mother—and where women are taught to suffer silently for the sake of appearances or faith, Sunshine hits differently
It doesn't shout
It doesn't try to shock
It simply tells the truth as it is lived: with quiet pain, with small acts of defiance, and with the kind of strength that often goes unnoticed
This film doesn’t just resist—it listens, it aches, and above all, it stays with you

So so so much empathy in Jadaone’s lens and Racal’s performance — in many scenes I found myself sharing Sunshine’s pain, so when she finds peace in her decision, I couldn’t help but beam with pride too
Sunshine isn’t just a film—it’s a quiet cry from someone who feels stuck, trying to move forward in a world that keeps pulling her back
Tonet Jadaone tells the story with gentle honesty, never shouting, but always making you feel
Maris Racal plays a young gymnast chasing her dream
But life throws her a twist: an unexpected pregnancy
Suddenly, her body—once her source of power—feels like it no longer belongs to her
She’s scared, tired, and unsure what choice feels right
The setting isn’t just Manila—it’s its soul
Busy, sacred, messy
In one scene, she’s buying abortion pills from a street stall, while church bells ring nearby
The contrast is sharp, but real
Sunshine doesn’t tell you what’s right or wrong
It just shows you what’s true
What stayed with me most is how the film feels personal
Like every time I’ve had to choose myself, even when others didn’t understand
It reminded me that courage isn’t loud—it’s the quiet strength to keep going
If you’ve ever felt like you were drowning in expectations, Sunshine reminds you that even in the darkest alleys, there’s a sliver of light
Not because the world is kind—but because you choose to keep walking

Yesterday, I stumbled upon a Twitter post pointing out parallelisms between Jadaone's Sunshine and Brocka's Insiang with how both films' main characters, in at least one scene, were framed behind bars, mirroring their metaphorical imprisonment within gendered norms of their respective social milieus

Indeed, although almost 50 years have passed between the two films, it's an unfortunate reality that women's rights in the Philippines still have a long way to go, with conservative Catholic values hindering its advancement
Both Jadaone and Brocka present us with their titular characters' fractured psyches, trying everything within their limited power to achieve some kind of self-emancipation

Another Twitter post, however, posits that while Jadaone echoes Brocka in some ways, she ultimately diverges from him by virtue of her "woman's instinct" that also augments her narratives with an "added layer

" Obvious gender essentialism and identity politics aside, this is a sentiment that I'm keen on interrogating: what does it actually mean to have a female directorial sensibility, particularly in the vein of Antoinette Jadaone
An easy answer would be to look at the central conflict of Sunshine, that is, unwanted pregnancy, and that Jadaone opts for a female teenager as its main focalizer

I'm pointing this out because trans men and intersex people can also get pregnant hence a pregnancy plot point would not inherently be women-specific (although there would surely be many overlaps), so it's Jadaone's directorial decision to create a female protagonist that imbues the film with intricacies of the female experience---how proceeding with motherhood would be career suicide for an athlete aiming for the Olympics, how Sunshine is constantly berated by self-righteous people she encounters, how society itself was built against female self-determination, and despite all these, how Sunshine finds small pockets of refuge in other women---a friend, a mentor, an inn receptionist, a doctor, an abused prepubescent, a sister---who are empathetic enough to understand her pain and conviction, and to whom she's equally compelled to reciprocate kindness whenever the situation permits

Further, Jadaone digs deeper and finds the Catholic religious institution, itself a remnant of feudalism, as an underlying hegemonic force against women empowerment, so culturally embedded in Philippine society that Sunshine finds it wherever she goes, be it in the drugstore, in the hospital, in the university, in the sport that she loves, even in the man who got her pregnant

Unfortunately, here is also where Jadaone's supposed female sensibility loses steam: religious guilt is so ubiquitous that even she is not aware that it limits her perspective, that instead of finding multiple angles of inquiry she instead chooses to hammer in the same anti-religious (therefore anti-patriarchal) talking point over and over and over again, even to the point of physicalizing the unborn children, a weirdly pro-life creative decision in a film that self-categorizes as pro-choice

Heck, the film just assumes that the audience already knows about the economic facets of being a Filipino athlete so it makes no effort in examining it, nor is it concerned with how Sunshine and her family earn their money (nobody seems to be working
No, those aren't important; just focus on the fact that Sunshine is a woman and that she's oppressed because of it
"Drown out the noise," her coach tells her, but is it really necessary to drown it out if the noise is as repetitively monotonous (albeit still imminently threatening) as Jadaone presented it

My argument is that uncritical admiration for "female sensibility" is as dangerous as the patriarchy it contends with, and that it's the same liberal narrow-sightedness that applauds Jadaone's bravery for tackling taboo gender topics and turns a blind eye to her cowardice in heeding the pro-Palestine boycott of the Berlinale film festival in the same breath; what's the point of female sensibility if it is devoid of anti-fascist solidarity

Perhaps Sunshine is actually a self-surrogate for the lengths Jadaone is willing to go through in pursuit of her career, and we're all just supposed to root for her because it's great that Philippine cinema is acknowledged and praised internationally, everything else be damned

And maybe I'm expecting too much from Jadaone, that I should just accept that her films are self-contained texts that will never reach the same kind of radicalism and depth as Brocka's (which is admittedly a high standard to reach), but deep inside I want to believe that she's capable of bolder, stronger filmic statements

Ganito pala sa Maynila—maingay, mausok, at puno ng pangarap
Sunshine holds up a mirror to Manila's contradictions
There is a sketchy motel that asks for your ID before handing over the keys, as if the system needs to know if you are old enough to make your own decisions
A crowded hospital where pregnant women share beds in the maternity ward, almost as if they are only given a small space in a world they live in
A religious landmark for those seeking miracles, but just outside are street markets selling religious paraphernalia and illegal abortion pills
Maris Racal gives an outstanding performance as Sunshine, a young rhythmic gymnast whose Olympic aspirations are upended by unexpected pregnancy during tryouts
One of the film's striking choices is the inclusion of this magical presence played by Annika Co
To me this character felt like a reflection of the conservative audience inserted into the narrative, a constant presence, watching, whispering, and trying to make sense of Sunshine's decisions
The film closes with the hope that Sunshine, and others like her, might still get the chance to finish their routine and maybe, even become champions of their own lives

Usually, when a film claims to challenge a societal norm, it ends up being either too preachy or barely scratching the surface
But sometimes, a film like Sunshine comes along and delivers on its promise—clear, direct, and most importantly, brave
Not only is this Jadaone’s best film to date, but it’s also her most important
It’s a feminist masterclass in storytelling, evident in how every significant character in the film that supports Sunshine is a woman
And to top it all off, the ending was written to give the character what she truly deserves—even if the harsh realities of our country don't always allow a woman to have that
Even the casting was perfect and clearly intentional—from Maris’s embodiment of Sunshine to Elijah’s portrayal of the privileged Miggy (perfect choice of name, by the way)
Setting the story against the raw backdrop of Manila adds just the right weight to the film’s intention

Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a record-breaking national athlete, but the film fails to show the weight of that achievement
She wears a tank top marked “Asian Games 2018,” and her coach (Meryll Soriano) warns her against complacency: “Balewala lahat ng gold mo sa Asian Games
”Since the Asian Games are held every four years, and Sunshine is about 19 or 20, this suggests she won multiple golds in 2018 — a rare feat
She would be gymnastics royalty, a media darling, likely the most successful Filipina rhythmic gymnast in history
Yet the film doesn’t show her as a public figure
No news clippings, no media buzz, no crowds—just a few kids asking for a selfie
It also focuses mostly on her ribbon routine, barely showing the hoop, ball, or clubs—all key to establishing her as Olympic-level
Sunshine’s decision to abort is quick, and her fears and ambitions are underexplored
The Olympics, in fact, feel more like her coach’s dream—the film tells us this but doesn’t show it
There’s no pressure from a country rooting for her, nor from sponsors who presumably funded her expensive training (which we’re left to assume, since rhythmic gymnastics is an elite sport)
No rival gymnast, no sense of competition, no major stakes, and no real glimpse into the demanding world of elite sport
All this undercuts the tension around her unwanted pregnancy
Jadaone instead spends a chunk of screen time on soapy magical realism
An imaginary, foul-mouthed child follows Sunshine around, mocking her decisions
But instead of adding insight, this character becomes repetitive and irritating
Rhed Bustamante plays another pregnant teen, awkwardly inserted into the plot in an effort to cover too many sides of the abortion debate
But Rhed’s more serious situation makes Sunshine’s dilemma feel shallow—like a story about a girl careless with sex and unwilling to face the consequences
Some visuals in Sunshine hit hard: abortifacients sold beside religious icons outside Quiapo Church—a jab at how the Catholic Church, in practice, is more ritual than moral compass
There’s also a grim motel scene
But these moments can’t save the film
Set in the predominantly Catholic Philippines, where abortion is illegal, Sunshine tries to raise issues around teen pregnancy and reproductive rights, like overcrowded maternity wards
True enough, the Philippines has one of the highest teenage pregnancy rates in Southeast Asia, especially among the poor
But if a film brings this up, it must give some context

The Reproductive Health Law, passed only in 2012, was meant to help—but the Catholic Bishops’ Conference of the Philippines (CBCP) continues to fight tooth and nail against sex education and birth control
The film ignores all this
Instead, it gives us a cartoonish, Bible-thumping doctor and a patriarchal pastor—villains standing in for real problems
We don’t expect to be spoon-fed, but when a film enters controversial ground and hints at bigger issues, it has a duty to avoid shallow symbols
In the end, Sunshine parrots Western slogans like “My body, my choice” without anchoring its stance in the Philippine context
The message feels imported and emotionally flat

Sa panulat at direksiyon ni Antoinette Jadaone, isa itong pelikulang sports drama na umiikot kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na kailangan magpasiya kung ipagpapatuloy o hindi ang pagbubuntis habang papalapit ang kaniyang paglahok sa pambansang paligsahan sa rhythmic gymnastics
Walang tapon sa bawat kuha ng mga eksena, kahit na sa mga background audio nito, sapagkat sumisimbolo ito sa kalagayan ng Pilipina sa ating patriyarkal na lipunan
Nagustuhan ko ang panulat at direksiyon nito dahil sang-ayon sa sinabi ng aking kaibigan, naiparanas nito ang pakiramdam na may isa kang kakilala na kahalintulad ni Sunshine
Bukod dito, naiparamdam nito na kasama ka sa pelikula
Iyong tipong sinubaybayan mo rin ang paglalakbay ni Sunshine sa saanmang sulok ng Maynila
Kaya, makakaugnay at mailalagay mo ang sarili sa kalagayan ng pangunahing tauhan o sa sinuman
Malinis din ang pagkaka-edit ng pelikula sapagkat malinaw sa direktor kung ano ang nais niyang mangyari kay Sunshine
Piling-pili ang mga eksena kaya ang hirap pumili ng pinakamaganda o pinakanagustuhan
Hangang-hanga rin ako disenyong pamproduksyon nito dahil bukod sa ginalugad talaga ang madidilim na espasyo ng Maynila, iniisip ko kung paano sila nakapag-shooting sa ganoong karaming tao
Grabeng blockings niyon
Karapat-dapat talaga na papurihan si Racal sa kaniyang pagganap dito
Tama lamang ang timpla ng iba't ibang emosyon ang ipinamalas niya rito
Ngunit ang pinakanakabibilib sa lahat, magaling din ang mga pantulong na tauhan kaya napalitaw nito ang husay ng pangunahing artista
Ang tinginan nila ni Thea (Xyriel Manabat)
Ang coach na tila pangalawang nanay na si Eden (Meryll Soriano)
Ang misterysong batang babae (Annika Co)
Ang kakampi na si Geleen (Jennica Garcia)
Kahit na ang lokong si Miguel (Elijah Canlas)
May ambag silang lahat upang mapagtibay ang karakterisasyon ni Sunshine at ang husay ni Racal
Ang ganitong pelikula ang nagbibigay ng dahilan kung bakit mahalaga na mayroong CSE at kung bakit kailangan mapag-usapan at mapag-isipan muli ang legal at siyentipikong pagpapalaglag
Babae man o lalaki, kahit na ang LGBTQIA+, binibigyan tayo nito ng awtoridad sa ating katawan

Sunshine presents a two-pronged takeoff on putting forth a controversial subject it aims to transfigure into a discourse
It’s gritty yet poignant, a dichotomy facilitated by careful restraint in its direction, intricate cinematography, and Maris Racal’s stellar performance
The film deflects clichés observed in Filipino melodramas that often rely on overly oppressive emotional tropes and techniques
Most notably, it veers away from positioning religion or the Church as a central source of female agency

Instead, it presents it as an androcentric institution where permission for a woman’s reproductive health decisions must be sought, implying a strong assertion of control and dominance over women’s bodies

Set against the backdrop of bustling, grunge-textured Manila, the camera takes a remarkable grasp on the parallelisms and minutiae of everyday life in the cruel city: a crowded train moving across the metro juxtaposed against a dreary room in Avenida; an abortifacient vendor sitting by a display of Mary Magdalene busts she sells in Quiapo; a tight-knit community devoid of love and empathy for a child
The film refuses to paint the gaps and seams of a faulty society in broad strokes
Sunshine is delicately crafted and measured
It deeply delves into the nuances and detailed complexities of living in a Christian society that has, ironically and deliberately, chosen to position women’s rights on the periphery
It taps into female solidarity as a form of agency and collective resistance, offering both an idealistic and pragmatic antithesis to the marginalization they have long been experiencing
Reminiscent of Antoinette Jadaone’s pre-studio works such as Plano (2004) and Saling Pusa (2006), Sunshine feels like a beautiful work of personal musings
It is honest, outrageous, yet tender—marking one of her greatest directorial masterpieces
a narrative film that tackles relevant issues in the philippines: reproductive health, abortion, poverty, misogyny, etc
Perfect casting
Beautifully written
I think it's safe to say by now that Antoinette Jadaone is one of the greats of Philippine Cinema
And not just of now, but of all time

The still-young filmmaker, who cut her teeth on quirky indie comedies ( Six Degrees of Lilya Cuntapay, Beauty in a Bottle) soon became the new queen of Pinoy Romantic Comedies, resulting in an 8-films-in-5-years streak that included classics like That Thing Called Tadhana, Never Not Love You and Alone/Together
Then in 2020, something changed
At the height of the pandemic, Tonet released Fan Girl -- an unflinching, searing commentary on celebrity worship, toxic masculinity and patriarchal oppression in the Philippines
It not only won all the major awards during that year's MMFF, but was also the highest-grossing film for that year
This makes Tonet somewhat of a unicorn: a writer/director who can make socially relevant, intelligent cinema but at the same time kill it at the box office
This feat is especially astounding in a year when zero films have actually made money
And so that six-year streak turned into a five-year absence, and wisely so
Tonet channeled her creative juices towards other roles and mediums: television, streaming, producing
I'm a big believer in taking care of one's filmography, and she's doing just that
And as fans we have finally been rewarded
Hello, Sunshine
Sunshine follows a slew of, and there's no non-blunt way to put it, abortion movies that have come to the fore in the 2020s
You have the US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always and France's L'Événement
All films follow the internal struggle and loneliness that women face when going through the abortion process
Of the three, Sunshine is the most powerful for one simple reason: it's set in the Philippines
And while it hits home because it is home, the oppression, hypocrisy and outright strangeness of the system makes this abortion story unique

It's a country where you can find ads for abortives just buy typing in "abortion" in your instagram search terms, where a vendor of Catholic paraphernalia situated outside a church will also peddle Cytotec, where a doctor who saves your life will also give you a 5-minute telling-to once you're well enough to listen
It's a country where self-righteous sanctimonium has endangered millions of young women's lives
Sunshine is pro-choice, but it's also pro-life
It never tries to turn away from the consequences and the trauma women go through when making this decision
And it shows us what could have been, never cheapening the lives that were lost
These layers, the emotional depth with which Tonet imbues Sunshine, are what sets it apart
It's a very thought provoking film, but it aims straight for the heart
I've spent all this time singing Tonet's praises, but of course Sunshine wouldn't be Sunshine without the brilliant Maris Racal
I meant it when I said that Maris is a generational talent: a true actress with genuine love for the craft who just also happens to be incredibly popular
She breathes so much life and attitude into Sunshine that she really feels like a friend
Someone you're rooting for, someone whose pain you understand
It's a very important film, but don't let its importance weigh you down
End of the day, like all of Tonet's films, it's a story well told with characters you genuinely care about
Sunshine is now showing in all SM Malls
Please do go out and catch it right away

Sunshine explores the balance beam of morality, tipping between the push to reclaim bodily autonomy and the pull of Catholic guilt

It’s interesting how the film’s key scenes are set in the dark, sketchy streets of Quiapo — a reflection of how young Filipinas navigate the lifelong, generational burden of taking control of our own bodies, while still trying to stay in line with the same dark and sketchy standards set by the very society that claims to protect us from it

It was Jadaone’s courage that popped in my head when the title card flashed, a very Filipina name that connotes brightness and warmth — two things the film was not intended for, two things the titular character was deprived of

Sunshine is a story of every Sunshine, a Filipino woman vulnerable to systemic injustice and oppression; a story no one could have been told better than a Filipino woman herself — and a fearless and intelligent one at that
From reproductive health and general health care system to conservatism, Jadaone’s care and spirit championed
Her personification of one’s conscience was beautifully done
I sobbed through the last 15 minutes
True-to-life darkness in the country executed from the literal streets to the contexts of quality of life through Orendain’s realism
There’s a harrowing frame in the movie that ticked all my boxes as a fan of dark cinematography
I bled in the dark with Sunshine right there

This film boasts a talented bundle of actresses: Meryll Soriano, Annika Co, Xyriel Manabat, Jennica Garcia, with Maris Racal tying the ribbon, flexing her acting muscles across different tones and needs
Well-written and well-directed performances with standouts coming from Garcia, Co, and Racal

“Bakit ka ba takbo nang takbo
Mahirap yan
Tumatakbo tapos di alam kung saan pupunta
”i faintly remember this video explaining the absence of young prodigies in the film industry
because unlike athletes, the field doesn’t merely rely on one’s prime to succeed
instead, it honors the individual’s maturity, discernment, and time spent in understanding life
this is what i felt in Direk Tonet’s recent slew of films
since Fan Girl (2020), it feels like she’s found her voice¹
informed, empowered, and deeply understanding

with her latest offering, Sunshine, i have to applaud her for having the guts to tell such a delicate story, a sensitive subject matter—in a predominantly Catholic country where abortion is illegal, no less

Sunshine’s charm lies in showing the grim reality of the city, the sheer obliviousness of the night, the secret alliance of the system and culture continually perpetuating harsh conditions for women and their bodies

it’s an incisive picture for us to empathize with the Sunshines of this world, with their dreams at the palm of their hands but their backs against the wall—deprived of freedom, options, and utmost support
and don’t you find it endearing that the ensemble that helped Sunshine’s reckoning are all women
from her gymnastics coach, the motel receptionist, her estranged bestfriend, the healthcare professional, and, of course, her loving sister²
watching Sunshine is important to open the discussion and continue the conversation on women’s bodily autonomy
and maybe it all starts with an understanding, a mutual agreement, and someone who will say “Gets kita
” like a heartfelt acknowledgment
___¹ one could argue it’s already burgeoning since Never Not Love You (2018)² Jennica Garcia the artist that you are

"Sunshine" is not just the greatest Filipino movie I've seen but one of the most important Filipino films of all-time
This film deals with controversial topics in our society, abortion and teen pregnancy
A week of national tryout for the gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal) finds out that she's pregnant
Conflicts arise as she has to decide what to do next
In between life and dreams, what's the most significant between the two
The film is unconventional at best
This is not your usual and average Filipino drama you'll see
It's a character study about a teenager who is on the down side of her life
We follow her journey through this life and see a glimpse of her life dealing with her problem
Maris Racal defines this film as Sunshine
Her acting here is brilliant
She's perfect for this role
Jennica Garcia surprised me
Her character as Sunshine 's sister marks
What she said to Sunshine near the ending, though it's common, is like a punch to tears
I ended up loving her character
Jennica Garcia deserves an award for being the best supporting actress for this role
Another cast that standout is Rhed Bustamante and Xyriel Manabat both deserve a recognition for their role
Blurring between reality and fantasy, mostly this film is realistic in portraying the whole theme thanks to Direk Antoinette Jadaone directions
Also, the cinematography is the best
Overall, "Sunshine" is a women's movie
It's timely, affecting and brave to its theme
It doesn't spoon feed
It will make you immersed and think
It's worth an experience
This is a rare Filipino movie I've seen
I'm glad and proud watching this in cinema
After watching "Sunshine", it leaves me with a question, "Is abortion a choice if your greatest dream will compromise
Antoinette Jadaone's most polished work yet since NEVER NOT LOVE YOU
With a very strong social commentary on unwanted pregnancy and abortion, Jadaone navigates the pain and heartbreak of a woman in the person of Maris Racal as SUNSHINE
A gymnast aiming for Olympics but the conflict arise when she got pregnant
With her electrifying performance a shoo-in already for the next award derby Maris is deserving of all the future trophies that will be bestowed to her
Maris Racal and Annika Co are both fantastic
SUNSHINE is what we need during bad times

Interesting na rhythmic gymnastics ang sports ni Sunshine (Maris Racal)

Hindi ito kilala sa ating bansa pero kitang-kita sa sports na ito na kailangan ng marinading determinasyon at disiplina hindi lamang sa larangan ng sports dito sa Pilipinas pati na rin sa paghahanda sa paglaban sa Olympics
Kaya naman ng mabuntis si Sunshine ay naharap siya sa isang desisyong babago sa kanyang buhay at sa mga tao sa paligid niya
Ilan sa mga isyu na nilatag ng pelikula ay ang kakulangan ng sex education at accessibility ng legal abortion sa Pilipinas dahil na rin sa konserbatibong paniniwala
Idagdag pa ang kulang na suporta ng gobyerno pagdating sa ating atleta tulad na lamang sa eksenang sila pa mismo ng pamilya niya ang naghanda ng kanyang isusuot sa Olympics
Religious hypocrisy din ang kinokompronta ng pelikula tulad sa eksenang giniguilt trip ng isang sarado Katoliko na OB GYNE at muli ring pang-guilt trip sa kanya ng pastor na ama ni Miggy kay Sunshine
Si Miggy ay pastor kid na nakabuntis sa dalaga

Hindi na rin naman bago ang pagtalakay ng abortion sa Pilipinas sa pelikulang Pilipino dahil nariyan ang "High School Scandal" (1982) sa direksyon ni Gil Portes at "Hinugot sa Langit" (1985) na pinagbidahan ni Maricel Soriano at dinirek ni Ishmael Bernal
Ang kagandahan ng pelikula ay babaeng filmmaker ang lumikha at alam niya ang nadarama at pinagdadaanan mapa-pisikal, emosyonal at sikolohikal ng kapwa babae
Napakahusay ni Maris Racal sa pelikulang ito
Ang laking tulong ng cinematog kasi 'yun ang nag-set ng tone at mood ng pelikula over-all
Somewhat reminded of "Gusto kita with all my hypothalamus" pagdating sa cinematog

Piolo Pascual
However, Piolo’s character, as Pastor Jaime could’ve been explained and discovered more, and not pressed in a few minute exposure
What stood out in the film were Maris, Jennica, Annika, and “Ariana”‘s portrayal
Also, Sunshine, due to her juvenile age, can be prone to misconception and misinformation

In a predominantly Catholic country wherein proper sex education and proper healthcare system are nowhere to be found, and practices are dictated by religion and morality, relying on social media platforms as search engines would mean that she’s susceptible to wrong notions of her reality, which may lead her to resort to the sudden decisions that she make
The debate between religion and choice is long-going in the Philippine context

If the international audiences accepted this film with open arms, it’s about time that the Philippines does the same, and the film’s message would transgress to those without an open mind and for those who are unawakened with the harsh realities that most “Sunshine” faces

This did not intend to resolve anything, cos we have been seeing this in real life and in the news

But this was a good reminder that after all these headlines, after all the movies that tackled the same story, and after all the social media awareness, IS IT’S STILL A PERSISTING PROBLEM FOR MANY FILIPINO CHILDREN AND WOMEN
That we have still yet to save these women, that our authorities still don’t care, and these women are still in danger

Ito ang ibig kong sabihin kapag sinasabi kong may problematic pattern sa ilang pelikula
Layunin nito ay marahil ipakita ang pinakamasalimuot na kalagayan ng ating lipunan, subalit nauuwi lagi sa paggamit ng trauma at karahasan bilang device lamang
Sa paraang ito, yumuyugto ang kawalan ng respeto sa lived experiences ng mga biktima
Sunshine, however, is not that kind of film
Sa halip na pagsamantalahan ang lunan ng karanasan ng mga kababaihan, pinili ng pelikula na maging mapanagot
It is a story about women, in a world that constantly tries to pin them and to deny them full autonomy and diginity for themselves
Naging maingat at makatao si Direk Tonet sa treatment niya rito sa Sunshine
Hindi niya sinensationalize ang karahasan, bagkus ginawa ito nang may paggalang
Inilantad ang katotohanan pero hindi iniwan sa dulo ang mga biktima at maging ang mga manonood
In this film, we see a woman who is brave
A woman who insists on choosing for herself
A woman who, despite everything, claims her shine
To Sunshine, and to many sunshines out there: ang sinag ninyo ay magmumula sa inyo lamang
Hindi ito hinihiram, hindi ito ibinibigay, sa inyo ito at sa inyo lamang
Kasi gaano man kadilim ang lipunan sa atin, women will always be the brightest
Film got me walking around deep in thought after
That was raw, painful, and beautiful
Just like being a mother and also choosing not to be one

Nauso na sa mga Pinoy viewers na hihintayin na lang nila sa Netflix yung mga pelikulang Pilipino
Para raw makatipid
Pero karamihan sa kanila, willing gumastos kapag Western superhero movie ang papanoorin
Gets naman din kasi nga may escapism kapag sinasalba ni Superman o ng Fantastic Four ang New York City kumpara sa mga realist stories sa Pilipinas
Bat nga naman kailangan ng malaking screen para lang makitang nag-aaway si Dingdong Dantes at Charo Santos
Pero please, panoorin niyo ang mga pelikulang Pilipino sa big screen, lalo na yung may magandang istorya na maaaring magbigay-linaw pa sa mga isyu
Tulad na lang ng Sunshine ni Antoinette Jadaone

Tungkol ito kay Sunshine (Maris Racal) na naghahanap ng paaran na magpa-abort dahil sa napakaraming rason: hindi planado ang kanyang pagbubuntis, ayaw siyang panagutan ng nakabuntis sa kanya, ayaw na siyang samahan ng kanyang kaibigan, pagtsi-tsismisan siya, at mauudlot ang kanyang pangarap na maging Olympian
Sa dami ng kanyang rason, simple lang naman ang kanyang dahilan: ayaw pa niya maging nanay
Ito ang unang Pinoy film na napanood ko na talagang sinusulong ang karapatan ng babae para sa kanyang katawan
At sa dami ng pinagdaanan ni Sunshine, kahit na may reservations ka sa isyu ng abortion, gugustuhin mong matupad ang gusto ng ating bida

Ramdam na ramdam ko kay Maris ang mga dinadalang problema ni Sunshine hindi lamang bilang isang aspiring Olympian kundi ang isang pagiging babae sa Pilipinas kung saan malakas ang impluwensya ng Catholic values sa ating mga batas
Intersectional din ang pagtalakay ni Jadaone sa isyu ng abortion sa Sunshine
Hindi ito basta-bastang women's rights na nakita natin sa Western media tulad ng Barbie (2024) at Sex Education (2019-2023)
Hindi itinanggi o dinemonize ng pelikula ang Catholic guilt pero hinimay ito sa pamamagitan ng pag-humanize nito sa anyo ng batang babae na sumusunod kay Sunshine (Annika Co)
Ang ganda ng chemistry nina Maris at Annika at ramdam mong iisa lang talaga sila
So, bakit nga ba dapat panoorin ang Sunshine sa sinehan imbes na hintayin sa Netflix o ano mang streaming service
Napakalalim ng isyu ng aborsyon at women's rights na dapat bigyan ito ng full attention
Pag naman nanonood tayo sa streaming service, may tendency tayong mag-check ng phone
Pero hindi dapat tayo ma-distract habang pinapanood natin si Sunshine
Pag naman sobrang intimidating yung scene, pwede nating i-pause
Pero sa mga ganitong storya, dapat hindi ito pina-pause
Ma-disturb dapat tayo sa ganitong kwento

Ang tunay na sining ay nagsasalamin sa totoong pangyayari sa buhay, at ang pelikulang ito, ang pelikulang Sunshine, ay nagsisilbing patunay na buhay na buhay ang sining nating mga Pilipino
A HORROR FILM FOR FILIPINAS AS WE WATCH THE PORTRAYAL OF OUR HELPLESSNESS AND LACK OF CHOICES REGARDING OUR BODIES, OUR LIVES
Women are frequently placed in situations where they feel they have no choices due to the regressive and harsh judgment of society regarding our rights, particularly our right to safe healthcare
Sunshine, as a whole, has stood firm in its mission, showing why such story is important, as women continue to endure the repercussions of societal choices that place us in jeopardy

This film is undoubtedly one of those that was treated with so much care, showing little to no romanticization of the anger and struggles the characters faced, and most importantly, it did not conform to conservative ideologies
Maris Racal is definitely an actress to keep an eye on; her artistry and commitment to her craft shine through in this film
She certainly delivered one of the most valiant depictions of women in cinema, and it felt just right for her to bring the character of Sunshine to life
And of course, Antoinette Jadaone, who consistently brings depth and authenticity to her female characters, has done it again
As many have said, while anyone can create sociopolitical films, having women write and direct them adds a special touch that connects us to our shared struggles
Jadaone knows exactly how to write her female characters, and there’s nothing more beautiful than a woman who values the lives, journeys, successes, and struggles of her fellow women
Ultimately, as the film shows, it’s women who always end up caring for one another

May we live in a lifetime where abortion is decriminalized and seen as a fundamental aspect of healthcare for every woman, ensuring that no woman ever has to confront death or risk her life due to circumstances that leave her with no choice
ABANTE BABAE

Dreams carry a powerful force—one that can drive people beyond the bounds of their morals

In the film Sunshine, this force is embodied by a young gymnast, whose ambition, fueled by society’s expectations of fame, pushes her to the edge—physically, psychologically, and morally—as she struggles with the weight of success and an unplanned pregnancy

Surrounding her are characters who reflect and intensify this tension: a doctor torn between personal ethics and the responsibility of helping an abortion patient; a street vendor selling both faith and death, caught in her own contradictions; a friend navigating the rift between her parents’ choices and her own agency; and a coach who, in relentlessly pushing her to break physical limits, unknowingly drives her toward moral collapse

The film offers a counterpoint through the voice of a child—a quiet yet powerful presence that serves as both an echo of the gymnast’s inner conscience and a projection of the expectations society imposes on her
This voice becomes a haunting reminder of who she is and who she is expected to be, grounding her in an innate moral compass even as she’s pulled deeper into chaos, anxiety, and confusion
Sunshine presents a world where the pursuit of dreams comes at a cost, and where ambition blurs the lines between resilience and ruin

I like any movie that utilizes metaphors to emphasize the severity of a situation

I think Annika's character was such an important part of the movie—despite others saying it downplayed the severity of the situation since it was a whimsical concept—since it brought contrast as well as a different but important point of view in such a controversial topic

5/5I think this is one of those films that I will not just 100% get—not because it was badly written or executed—rather, it is such a lived experience (even phenomenological) that is scathing, intense, and too real
But Jadaone & Maris Racal (and the whole ensemble
) made this film so empathetic, bold, and brave to actually tackle and make you realize what the social reality is
The collective Filipino religious trauma, poverty, crime, the lack of accessible healthcare—it's all encompassing with Sunshine's experience (and to all Filipinas as well)

How does a young woman endure a life filled with “faithfuls” who feel morally superior to judge and ridicule her choices in a society riddled with antiquated beliefs, further magnified by patriarchal politics where men can walk away without responsibilities and consequences
How do you thrive when institutions that are supposed to protect you are trying to pin you down
Maris Racal shines as the titular character Sunshine, hindi sumosobra o kinukulang, raw, honest, perfectly capturing a young woman in turmoil while trying to show a facade that everything is okay
She is supported by an amazing cast: Annika Co, Elijah Canlas, Xyrel Manabat, Piolo Pascual, Rhed Bustamante, and the most affecting performance of Jennica Garcia
This film captures the gritty essence of Manila without being patronizing or didactic
Each frame is filled with ironies: abortion drugs sold beside a church, a repeated shot of split windows showing dreams, chaos, judgement, and slivers of kindness

One shot in particular shows Sunshine rehearsing at home, on the split side are young people probably coming home from a fun night, kasi bata lang naman si Sunshine and she is willing to sacrifice everything for her dreams, at napakarami pang tulad niya, lahat sila hindi napapakinggan
Listen, read, learn, resist until every woman has autonomy over her body
Drown out the noises, lift your head, close your eyes, and let your light pull you through
“gets mo na ‘ko
” id like to believe that the kid was a depiction of sunshine’s conscience and its such a powerful statement to put out there — that sunshine didnt have anyone to convince but herself
that its okay as long as the choice was hers and not anyone else’s, especially in a society that often robs women the decision to make a choice in the first place

and despite the loud and often guilt-ridden noises that paralleled the packed and polluted streets of manila, it contested the catholic and cis-heteropatriarchal belief that the sole purpose of womanhood is motherhood and to choose to become someone else is to sin
but sunshine wouldn’t have come through all odds if it weren’t also for the women in her life that chose to show up for her
the only thing more powerful than the dangers that women are constantly subjected to, are the embrace of fellow women who just understand it
sunshine didn’t even have to utter a single word, her silence, both in her vulnerable and fearless moments, was heard
the quiet glances between her and thea, reassuring her that she is seen
her sister’s arms reaching out to her in bed, making her presence known and reminding sunshine that she’d never be alone, the gentle squeeze of menggay’s hands to let her know she’s safe
they all heard and seen each other, and having someone who’s willing to carry and share your burden with is enough for everything else to be bearable

Sunshine tells the story of a 19-year-old gymnast pursuing her dream of making it to the national team to compete in the SEA Games and eventually, the Olympics until a life-altering event changes everything
Ito marahil ang isa sa pinakamahalagang pelikulang Pilipino ngayong taon, o baka pati na rin sa buong dekada
Hindi ito nagpaligoy-ligoy sa layunin nitong maglahad ng katotohanan masakit man ito o hindi
Unang tumatak sa akin ang pangalang Antonette Jadaone noong napanood ko ang That Thing Called Tadhana
Mula noon, sinusubaybayan ko na ang kanyang mga pelikula maging ito man ay romcom, crime, psychological, o political
Siya at si Direk Dan Villegas ay palaging may tatak: may kirot, may kurot, at higit sa lahat, may lalim

Ang Sunshine ay isang napapanahong pelikula na nagsisilbing mitsa para sa mahahalagang diskusyon: ang kalagayan ng mga atleta sa bansa, ang sistemang pangkalusugan at pang-edukasyon, pananampalataya, gender roles, at higit sa lahat, ang karapatan ng kababaihan sa sariling katawan
Madalas nating marinig: “Ang anak ay biyaya
” Pero kailan nga ba ito nagiging biyaya
Kailan naman ito nagiging pasanin
Ang isang pagbubuntis ba sa murang edad ay dapat tawaging biyaya, lalo na kung ito ay dumating sa panahong hindi pa handa ang isang babae
O isa itong uri ng sumpa, bunga ng sistemang mapanghusga
Hindi laging pisikal ang pang-aabuso sa kababaihan
Minsan, ito ay nasa anyo ng mga ideolohiyang pinipilit ipalunok sa kanila
Kapag inagaw mo ang kakayahan nilang magdesisyon para sa sarili nilang katawan, para sa kinabukasan nila, para sa mga pangarap nila, iyon ay anyo ng pang-aabuso
Wala nang mas akmang gumanap bilang Sunshine kundi si Maris Racal
Ang kanyang pagganap ay puno ng puso’t tapang mula sa kanyang mga sulyap, bawat paghinga, hanggang sa mga katahimikan niya sa ilang eksena
Nararamdaman mo ang kanyang sakit, pangarap, at takot
Isa ito sa mga pinakamahusay na performance ng isang aktres sa kasalukuyang panahon

Ang buong ensemble cast ay maingat na pinili mula kina Elijah Canlas, Meryll Soriano, Jennica Garcia, Annika Co, Rhed Bustamante, Xyriel Manabat hanggang sa mga may limitadong eksena ngunit tumatak: Juan Miguel Garcia, Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, at Piolo Pascual
Bawat karakter ay may silbi sa masalimuot ngunit malinaw na salaysay ni Sunshine
Ang pelikulang ito ay malakas, matapang, at mapanghamon
Hindi ito madaling kalimutan
Hindi kami agad nakatayo matapos ang closing credits hindi dahil baka may post-credit scene kundi dahil ninanamnam pa namin ang bigat ng mensahe nito
Sa huli, isang malaking saludo kay Direk Tonet Jadaone
Maraming salamat sa liwanag at lakas ng Sunshine
Sa panahong maraming gustong manahimik, pinili mong magsalita
Mabuhay ka, Direk
Rating:  (5/5 - unanimous)

Sunshine (2025, Project 8 Projects)I acknowledge that there are a lot of things in life I take for granted as a cisgender man
In Antoinette Jadaone’s new film, Sunshine, she presents a flawed yet heartbreaking tale on the female cost of pregnancy

In the film, we follow nineteen-year-old Sunshine, who has dedicated most of her life, along with the support of her sister who was also a former gymnast, in rhythmic gymnastics and her pursuit to enter the Philippine team for the Olympics
However, several weeks before the National tryouts, Sunshine discovers that she got pregnant after a recent sexual encounter with her boyfriend
Stepping out of the theater, I realized how it’s so hard to be a woman, not just in the Philippines but in general

And pregnancy, one of the human experiences that only a cisgender woman can experience, and how much it impacts on their health, emotions, and even their dreams or aspirations - especially when it happens completely unplanned

All of these are further amplified in the situation here in the Philippines where sexual education is still not a priority, access to quality maternal care is expensive, and role of religion to beset unfair expectations towards women
Despite having a strong message, there are things in Sunshine that I wish had been improved on

I must admit I felt a bit cheated out because the movie was initially hyped as a sports movie focusing on gymnastics - the same way Rookie did for volleyball, but in the end was more of a character drama that whose lead character is a gymnast

I wish that Jadaone delved deeper on Sunshine’s motivations on why gymnastics is important to her because at how the story was written, Sunshine could’ve played any sport and the story would remain the same

Before I get called out, I know the movie’s true intention is a commentary on the state of female reproductive health in the Philippines, but I felt like it was just a missed opportunity to highlight the state of female sports in the Philippines, particularly gymnastics because Filipino sports movies are so rare

I also felt like that the script could’ve been tightened up a bit as the elements of magical realism introduced in the story (without going too much in spoiler territory) didn’t land as much in terms of story logic
As a follow-up to her lead starring role in 2023 movie Marupok AF, Maris Racal continues to be one of the promising actresses of her generation
And in Sunshine, she delivers one of her career best performances so far, especially at lengths her character goes through and in the dedication to train of the gymnastics segments of the story
Overall, Sunshine is not an easy watch because it doesn’t mince the hard truths of how it is living as a woman in the Philippines

And now with with the ongoing female reproductive health and sexual education discussion in the Philippines, Antoinette Jadaone offers a strong message on why it is imperative that protections for women’s health should be passed, and why the movie Sunshine deserves your time and your attention
However, irony that this movie can only be seen by a limited number of people because of its R16 rating as well as the unfair cinema practices in the Philippines, makes this even more frustrating

ANIMA ceased to exist last July 31, 2024, and this film is the last project that was ever produced by the company to be released

I’ve spent the past year trying to find meaning in such a swift demise — after all, most people prefer to go out with a bang; and I felt like we went out with the most sad, unceremonious accordion noise
But I’m glad that, a year later, Sunshine came out, a film that all things considered, is so bold and so loud and so strong in what it wants to say
Leave it to Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal not only to craft such a severe, yet truthful and empathetic tale, but also to rally a community to see this film
It makes me feel like we went out with a bellow, and all of our pains, struggles, and heartache with our sudden departure was heard somewhere, somehow
ANIMA was where I really grew into my own as a marketer, a coworker, and as a person
I’ll miss it dearly, but will cherish the memories forever
I’m happy Sunshine is shining brightly for us

Maris Racal delivers her most visceral performance to date — raw, quiet, devastating, Annika Co brings subtle intensity as Sunshine’s confidante, brimming with quiet guilt and Jennica Garcia anchors the story with maternal grit and emotional weight

Courage bleeds through every performance; this film demands to be seen a brutal, unflinching portrayal of abortion, rape, and systemic neglect in Philippine society every silence in the film speaks louder than dialogue; breath and ambient sound shape the mood Jadaone’s direction refuses easy comfort — every frame dares you to feel gritty visuals and handheld camera work ground the story in realism Sunshine isn’t just a movie — it’s a mirror, a gut-punch, a reckoningfavorite scene: the "mata-mata" scene of xyril and maris

Philippine cinema is very much alive, and a woman is our flag-bearer
As a cisgender male who calls himself a feminist, I'll never fully understand what it's like to be a woman in this country
This film, however, gave me the feeling of walking in their shoes
Every step was a courageous move toward something that could later become a matter of life and death
The story was written in a very deliberate manner, with the cinematography strengthening the narrative…
an underrated beauty of cinema is how it can invite one into a suspended state of reality
for a brief and borrowed hour or two, our story pauses to make space for someone else’s
sunshine (2024) is one of those rare films that honors the lending of time not with surprise and spectacle, but with empathy as its goal and medium for exploration
and the language of empathy in sunshine settles in slowly, almost bodily

aptly named, the movie seeps through the senses like the quiet force of nature: it casts a harsh light on the grayed and shadowed alleys of manila, where sins and prayers blur into one cruel cacophony
it burns with familiarity when we recognize sunshine, the girl, in our own world
she sits beside us in overcrowded jeepneys, gets scolded like us in hospital beds, walks among us on streets of quiapo that shame and steal a strip of dignity
with the same light, the film reaches for the sunshine within us - the ones who dream and persist, who dare hold our potential as promises
there are sunshines among us held tightly by sisters, while some sunshines are held up only as stubborns who flicker through the dark
yet herein lands the most transcendent part of the film: it peddles no moral lesson or pedantic sermon
all that it offers is an invitation to bear witness to sunshine, as she moves to the rhythm of a music only she can hear and pushes against the gravity of choices forced upon her
the film doesn’t seek answers; it simply asks for understanding

in its own sober way, it holds out hope that when the borrowed time is up, may we not only remember every sunshine who flies and rises, but also the ones who fall and return, until we see how every ground that meets her, holds her, or traps her, as she labors to birth her becoming, is also the same one we own

Truly a landmark film
We are introduced to Sunshine through her warming up with other student-athletes and performing her routine for the upcoming Olympic team tryouts
Viewers can tell that her prowess and national team member status is a mix of talent and hard work, that even when she messes up halfway through, it doesn't make her any less of a great gymnast
When she first finds out that she is pregnant, the camera focuses on her hands tremble

But she immediately acts on it – searching for suspicious dealers for pills, telling the boy that knocked her up, and going to church to pray that the Lord takes away the being forming in her womb – even when we see glimpses of her trying not to lose her composure in the humid streets of Manila
The film shows and justifies Sunshine's reasons for wanting an abortion, even if the means available in the Philippines will harm her
She has dreams that can't be put on hold, and she clearly is a young girl with mannerisms and tendencies deemed "immature" – factors that do not make her fit to be a mother
But in a scene wherein she talks to a pastor (played by Piolo Pascual, who made everyone in my cinema gasp) that promises financial support throughout her pregnancy and motherhood, she rejects it
"Ayoko maging nanay," she says, plain and simple
That was my favorite part of the film, because it felt cathartic to hear it
Although Sunshine had good reasons for the choices she makes, we must not need to have justified, valid, and layered reasons for wanting an abortion
Some of us do not want to be mothers and undergo the medical complications that come with carrying a child, just because

The body of the story may be about Sunshine, but its soul revolves around Menggay
From the moment the official trailer dropped, Sunshine instantly captured my interest
I’ve been waiting ever since for the chance to see it and after months of anticipation, I finally did
And now, I can say this without hesitation: I have nothing but praises for the film
More than just well-made, Sunshine is a brave and necessary work
It’s a film that demands to be seen — not only because of Maris Racal’s powerful performance, but because of how urgent and relevant its message is in today’s world
Unlike other films that leave you in feel-good state when the credits roll, Sunshine leaves you with questions — difficult, uncomfortable questions that deserve to be brought into the open
What if women had better options
What if men received the same public scrutiny when it comes to unwanted pregnancies
What if we had a healthcare and justice system that actually protects girls like Menggay
What if we dared to talk about abortion in a way that invites honest, compassionate, and informed discussion
This is where the film finds its power
When Menggay’s story arc unfolds, that’s when Sunshine cements its message, it stops being just a film and starts becoming a mirror to reality
Because this is for the countless Menggays out there — young girls with no real choices
Mga batang gaya niya
Isang 13-anyos na tinanggalan ng karapatan ng mismong sariling pamilya
And the painful truth is: there are far too many Menggays in our country
Deprived of opportunities
Denied the chance to choose a safer path forward
Watching this film taught me to become more open-minded
It urged me to weigh both the pros and cons of abortion more critically, and to consider how we can use art as a tool for education and awareness
In the end, Sunshine is not just a film — it’s a challenge
A challenge to our government to craft better, more inclusive campaigns
Ones that don’t just resonate with the intellectuals but reach the grassroots, where change is most needed

After two decades in the industry, Antoinette Jadaone has cemented her capacity to bend, direct, and write with different genres — the deconstruction of ekstras with Lilia Cuntapay, the ironic and hilarious takedown of cosmetic surgery industry with Belo-approved meta-comedy “Beauty in a Bottle,” and the dialogue-driven romantic hugot dramas with ‘Tadhana
” Without a doubt, Jadaone stands as one of the most vital voices in Philippine filmmaking today, consistently challenging conventions and pushing Filipino Cinema forward
In all her films, one thing that’s notable she's put women's voices at the forefront
She has since taken a pandemic pause after Fan Girl, but this has also led to her researching and diving deep into her most recent film, Sunshine
The film follows a student gymnast, Sunshine (Maris Racal), who discovers she’s pregnant just as she’s about to compete for the SEA Games
The film takes a surreal turn when she encounters a kid/ alter ego appears in crisis moments, reflecting her inner turmoil as she faces societal judgment
Throughout the film, Sunshine’s emotional arc—marked by anguish, desperation, and vulnerability—lays bare the reality where women’s access to safe choices is morally questioned and legally denied
This taboo isolates her: abandoned by friends and her partner, judged by doctors, and pressured by her coach to give up her dreams
Social stigma is one, but the films also highlights how poverty and consequently, sexual miseducation put into question the dignity of women
To be able to choose freely, is too high of a cost for Sunshine who has to deal with its social, financial, and legal repercussions
The film understands how for women in the fringes there’s little to no choice
The film is not without hope
Her sister, who’s a single mother, grounds Sunshine
Her alter ego serves as emotional salve during her many crises
And she also chances upon an underaged girl months into her pregnancy who reflects and echoes her experiences
In each of them, Jadaone realizes Sunshine’s future: to be a single mother, carry her pregnancy to term, and have a daughter
The film effectively wrestles with the nuances of her situation: to choose her dreams or be with a child
Ironically, Sunshine occasionally stumbles under the weight of its many themes: its surreal elements and side characters threaten to overshadow Sunshine’s emotional arc
It makes one wonder how better the film would have been had it just been, as the film title suggested, about Sunshine
Nevertheless, the film is a showcase of Jadaone’s confident vision
There’s this wonderful scene in the film of a maternity ward that just for brief moment became a community for pregnant women and mothers helping and supporting one another
It epitomizes the warmth that carries Sunshine forward: from isolation to solidarity, and from uncertainty to self-understanding
Parting with her past, she talks to her alter ego hoping she’d understand
They hug
To be understood that’s just what Sunshine needed

Alam kong napakahalaga ng pelikulang ito sa kababaihan pero ang hiling ko ay sana mas maraming kalalakihan ang makapanood nito
Ang misogyny at patriyarka ay mga problemang dulot naming mga lalaki
Matibay ang paniniwala kong kami ang dapat may pinakamalaking ambag sa pagbubuwag ng mga ito
Dapat kami ang nagpepenitensya
Pero hindi ganito ang realidad
Mga babae tulad ni Sunshine, Menggay, at ang maraming babae sa pelikulang ito ang bumabaka at nagdurusa sa ilalim ng huwad na sistema
Tila habambuhay silang nagpepenitensya para sa isang kasalanang hindi matubos-tubos kahit pa anong gawin nila—ang kasalanan ng pagiging babae
Mahusay ang pagpapakita ng Sunshine sa iba't ibang impyernong dinaranas ng kababaihan: personal, panlipunan, pisikal, mental, pinansyal, sekswal, at, higit sa lahat, pulitikal
Ramdam ito sa bawat eksena kung saan galit, pag-aalala, at pagod ang namamayagpag sa mga linya, ekspresyon, imahe, at tunog

Pati nga mismo ang kalagayan nito bilang pelikula ay isang impyerno rin: ang masalimuot na danas nina Direk Tonet sa paghahanap ng distributor, ang katotohanang madalang abutin ng mga ganitong pelikula ang mainstream consciousness ng mga Pilipno, ang mabilis na pagliit ng bilang ng mga sinehan na nagpapalabas nito, at ang nagbabadyang diskurso na tiyak na magiging mapaghati
Samakatuwid, ang pelikula mismo ay dumaan at patuloy na dadaan sa impyernong ginawa ng patriyarka
Ipinapakita ng Sunshine na mula noon hanggang ngayon, kababaihan ang umaako sa responsibilidad na hamunin at buwagin ang patriyarka
Kaya sana mapanood ito ng mas marami pang lalaki, lalo na kung hindi pa sila mulat sa realidad ng kababaihan, mga batang ina, at mga biktima ng sekswal na karahasan
Tayong mga lalaki ang nag-imbento at nakikinabang sa patriyarka
Tayo ang may kasalanan, tayo ang dapat magpenitensya

i knew i had to watch this before this film disappears off the face of the earth like gitling did
