sunshine (2025) had no metaphors and subtle parallelisms: it screams that a woman’s autonomy is her own
a very straight-forward, well-thought of, and a passionate piece about how a woman was made to struggle the moment she was born by the system and how it’s designed to take away her ownnes
this is true for everywhere else in the world; but much more significant in the context of a third world country such as the philippines
abortion is a controversial topic in the country, to say the least
it is seen as a violation to the sanctity of life—a sin to remove a clump of cell in a human body
swayed by the biblical texts and the catholic church, abortion is illegal in the country
but for women like sunshine and mary grace, the law does little to stop the reality: it only pushes them to do the act in shadows, where the only option is unsafe and risky

the religious references throughout the film were palpable: from the jeepney that sunshine rode to quiapo bearing the sign that says “gift of God” to sunshine’s physical manifestation of her conscience in the form of her would-be child—which shows an inner conflict between her faith and survival
these references do not seem disrespectful but rather an emphasis on how deeply stitched sunshine’s struggle to catholicism is
it’s a critique on how the bible is weaponized to police a woman’s choices and her bodily autonomy
i want to make a point on the healthcare system too which the film really did a good job criticizing: with all its faults, the healthcare system is biased against women
the lack of access to safe procedures, institutional neglect, and moral policing (made by professionals, mind you) leave women like sunshine and mary grace with nowhere to turn
the lack of quality healthcare in the country is so normalized that it leaves everyone no dignified options to address even their basic needs
a perfect film that paints intersectionality so well: women from different sectors, despite having the same oppressor, face different realities
it did not sensationalize abortion but it gave the audience another angle to look at it from; in a perspective that’s raw and honest
i was crying at the end (#that scene) because in spite all this, she prevailed
a woman, in a system that set her up to fail, survived and lived to achieve her dreams
overall, sunshine (2025) was hopeful, important, and full of courage
an important film that must be seen by everyone (and more importantly, by women)
maris racal, you are a generational talent, you deserve all the flowers AND jennica garcia, this piece’s hidden gem, you have mothered on a scale no one has ever had before
it is easy to get drowned in the noise
thank you, sunshine, for believing in your dreams and being loud about them

This movie had balls
It tackled one of the most taboo things in Filipjno culture; abortion

Few films manage to hold intensity, tenderness, and truth all at once-but Sunshine does
It was a brave story of strength, love, and kindness
Yet it was also sharp, honest in its portrayal of the harsh realities young Filipina women often endure: the limits imposed on their bodies, their choices, their futures
And still, it was warm
It never allowed you to drown in despair
Instead, it held you with care, gently reminding you that even in the most shadowed and uncertain places, light still finds its way in
Just like its title, Sunshine felt like light breaking through, like a quiet kind of hope that chooses to stay
Sunshine’s strength lies on its strong messaging
It confronts the audience— yes, what you heard was right
Maternity wards are in terrible conditions
A lot of R*pe and incest victims are of that age
Bigotry and victim-blaming play a huge part in our society
Antoinette Jadaone doesn’t tiptoe or walk around with her message: she is loud, angry, and knows where she stands
Her direction is both observational and sympathetic, allowing the audience to feel for Sunshine and feel helpless in situations out of our control
Despite all of these, it’s an incredibly hopeful movie about choice
Maris Racal is radiant and fantastic, and Jennica Garcia is the heart of the film

The chaotic rhythm of life
Spoilers ahead
Bold and controversial, writer-director Antoinette Jadaone continues her non-romantic-comedy streak with another compelling and dark subject matter through "SUNSHINE"
Gracing the screen is the titular character, played by Maris Racal in her career-best performance, who finds out she's pregnant while she prepares for her Olympic-qualifying event
Trouble ensues, dream and ambition crash
Teenage pregnancy and women conditions take front and center as the film gives voice to the usual silenced of the society
Jadaone may have placed rhythmic gymnastics in the background but it excellently serves as a metaphorical tool to describe the ebb and flow of Sunshine's life
We see her struggles pitted against conservativism and arguable morality in a country where religion and patriarchy rule and shackle
Through magic realism where we are introduced to two young players who abruptly show up mid-scenes, the film gets a rich layer on how our lead navigates her perilous journey
They channel the moral compass though at times their appearances and comedic flair tend to be uneven and out of timing

Racal, with her sharp strength and vulnerability, is utterly commendable but so is her supporting cast - Jennica Garcia and Meryl Soriano as her strong-willed yet nurturing older sister and coach respectively, Annika Co as her unborn child manifestation (an unpredictable plot twist that eventually made sense), and even the cameos from Madeleine Nicolas, Angeli Bayani, Angie Castrence, Elijah Canlas, and Piolo Pascual fulfill their impressive character actor repertoire
Some arcs and scenes could have been fleshed out because it's got a premise worth exploring but the Philippine censorship may have played its upper hand to prevent the film's full bloom

In the same vein of "4 Months, 3 Weeks, 2 Days", "Never Rarely Sometimes Always", and "Happening", it may not be everyone's cup of tea due to its hefty topic and open-endedness but it's a delight to see an important Filipino film that fearlessly opens the conversation to empower women more on making their own reproductive choices, even with the deafening noise and outdated discourse
5/5, folks

Winner of The Crystal Bear Award in the Generation 14plus category at the 75th Berlinale - Berlin International Film Festival, "SUNSHINE" is now exclusively playing in SM Cinemas, rated R-16 without cuts

Been eyeing this film since last year
Fortunately enough, I was able to watch this yesterday with my Mom
In the midst of darkness and rain, we looked for Sunshine
It adds surrealism without sacrificing its groundedness
Remember crying in a few scenes just because of how real it felt and then that sudden realization hits me, and I remember — nangyayari talaga siya sa totoong buhay yet it's inadequately addressed

Alienated, discriminated, and hidden behind idols and symbols stained with shame like the Sunshines and Menggays who are forced to comply with the rules set by a patriarchal, hypocritical, conservative society
I think this film won't force you to agree with its message but it challenges our morals and belief system
Above all, it only asks to be understood
There's multiple shades of womanhood that's not confined within a black and white backdrop
And it's good that we start and continue to talk about it
Overall, this film isn't just about abortion — it's a critique on society, politics, and feminism
As well as a call for women's accessible reproductive healthcare

Before I even entered the cinema, prepared na aq mag cry cry
I saw the trailer, the interviews, and the podcasts so I was bracing myself for emotional confrontations and intense family drama pero wala so what really made me cry was how real everything felt
The way Sunshine just tried to carry on, the way Jennica quietly supported her, and the way the story showed how painfully human this situation is
There was so much honesty in how it was told
Pogi din ni Papa P
As a woman who has experienced a teen pregnancy scare before, I saw parts of myself in Sunshine
That helpless feeling, the fear of not knowing what to do, the shame, and the silence around it… It was all too familiar
I also have friends who’ve gone through it for real
They shared their stories, and as I watched the film, I could see their experiences mirrored by Sunshine
Maris Racal is amazing as Sunshine
Everything about her performance was convincing, from the way she moved to the way she spoke (pero direk kita yung face ng double ni Sunshine ha )
She really looked like a young athlete from a struggling family, someone whose life revolved around discipline and dreams until it all came crashing down

I’ve seen Maris in different roles before, like in Incognito, where she played this aircon ex-military girly na mukhang ginagawang pangbahay ang gucci, it’s rlly impressive how she completely transforms into Kanal Sunshine bc she doesn’t just act the part, she becomes it
Jennica also stood out for me
As Sunshine’s Ate, her presence was comforting throughout the film
She had this motherly vibe that felt very natural
I liked how the film gave her character depth without spelling everything out
You could tell that her love for Sunshine came from a place of experience, like she had her own quiet struggles too
Galing din ni Annika
Even the supporting casts delivered
The manghihilot, the abortion pill seller, the doctors and the people Sunshine met along the way weren’t just fillers
Their performances felt soooooo real, and they matched the tone of the film so well
I didn’t feel like I was watching actors, I felt like I was watching people actually living through these moments
Sa ibang indie films, I cringe when I hear characters cursing because it feels like the writers are just slapping random tangina words trying too hard to sound edgy or cool
But here, everything made sense
The dialogue flowed naturally
The curse words weren’t just for shock, they felt earned u know
One of the scenes that stayed with me was in the motel
It was quiet, then the sound of a train passing by filled the background
That sound stuck with me
It gave the scene so much weight
It felt like the world outside was moving forward, while Sunshine was stuck in a moment where everything felt uncertain
That kind of sound detail is the kind of thing I really appreciate
As someone na working din sa field, I couldn’t help but notice the small design details
Sunshine’s costumes were on point, from her jerseys na may ibat ibang year (aminin, pambahay natin mga intrams shirt ) to the athletic tapes on her body, to her bag full of pins and cute hair clips
Those little choices made feel convincing talaga
She looked like an actual teen athlete, not just someone pretending to be one
The scene in the church was another standout
She didn’t even go inside
She stayed outside and prayed, and that choice said so much
It was symbolic
It showed how distant she probably felt from her faith or how unworthy she thought she was in that moment
That kind of framing really hit me
I also appreciated the sound design
Instead of dramatic bg music, they focused ambient sounds
It gave everything a grounded feeling
It was like I was right there with her, experiencing everything in real time
The pacing was perfect
There were no awkward pauses, no scenes that felt unnecessary
Sa ibang movies, may moments na napapa-phone lang ako hahahah Every second mattered
Every moment added layers to the story
Even the locations were smartly chosen
They weren’t overly stylized
They felt like real places people actually live in and go through things in
Award ka talaga Sunshine

Sobrang fitting na sunshine ang title ng pelikulang ito dahil katulad ni sunshine, may tapang, puso, at pagkakakilanlan ang pelikula

Matapang dahil bilang predominantly catholic country na sobrang na ka-angkla ang paniniwala, mga desisyon, at disposisyon sa buhay sa kung ano ang tama at mali sa bibliya, isang malaking hakbang ang ipakitang tumaliwas sa nakaugalian at kinalakihang ideya ng kung ano ang “tama”

Matapang dahil sa mundo at sa bansang sobrang patriyarkal na nag c-cater lamang sa kalalakihan, walang pag-uubling pinakita na wala dapat may ibang may karapatan sa katawan at kapakanan ng isang babae kung hindi sila lamang

Matapang kasi ilegal ang aborsyon sa pilipinas at imoral ang tingin sa mga taong gustong gawin ‘to pero walang tako’t na ipinakita na katulad ni sunshine, may mga babeng hindi ginusto at gustong maging ina at dapat ay may karapatan silang mamili
May puso kasi naguumapaw sa pagmamahal ang pelikula
Pagmamahal ng kapatid, kaibigan, mentor
At higit sa lahat ang pagmamahal sa kapwa babae
Ang pagmamahal na ipinakita ni sunshine kay menggay, ang pagmamahal na pinakita ni doctora helena sa kanilang dalawa
Masakit in a way pero sobrang gandang isipin na women will always have each other’s back at the end of the day
Walang titindig para sa isang babae nang lubos kung hindi babae lamang rin
Ngunit ang nangibabaw rito ay ang pagmamahal ni sunshine sa sarili niya at sa kanyang mga pangarap
May doubts si sunshine bilang isang babae, bilang isang katoliko
Kaya nga ilang beses natin siya nakitang nagdasal eh at kaya na rin nag e-exist ang karakter ni annika co
Siya yung nagsilbing physical form ng nagsalong upbringing at inhibitions ni sunshine pero at the end of the day, nanaig pa rin ang pagmamahal niya sa pangarap niya
Ang ganda, sobrang ganda
May pagkakakilanlan kasi sobrang pinoy na pinoy ‘tong pelikulang ito
Mula sa kung paano pinakita yung ingay at gulo ng maynila, hanggang sa dynamics ng magkakapatid sa pamilyang pilipino
Pati kung paano nabubuhay ang mga babae sa bansang bulok ang reproductive health system at hindi tanggap ang pagiging sexual nila

Since childhood, she has dreamed of qualifying for the Olympics
But now, she faces a life-changing dilemma: she’s pregnant
Antoinette Jadaone’s film follows Sunshine’s journey by reflecting her through the women around her
There’s the little girl who silently follows her in the streets, questioning her every decision
There’s her older sister Geleen, once an athlete too, whose own dreams were interrupted by an early pregnancy
There’s Coach Eden, who’s trained her since she was…

THISSS IS CINEMAAAA U GUYS (YAS, edited w/ a short commentary)what i love about sunshine is it never tries to sell the idea that motherhood is innate, pure, or noble
instead, it asks the real question paano kung ayaw talaga
and it’s so bold to center that lalo na sa context ng pilipinas where everything about being a woman is reduced to sacrifice
we’re raised to believe na ang katawan natin ay para sa pamilya, para sa pananampalataya, para sa kinabukasan ng iba
never para sa sarili
kaya sobrang rare and sobrang radical makakita ng pelikula na nagsasabing "hindi mo kailangang gustuhin
hindi mo kailangang magpaka-martir
”sunshine understands na abortion is not some abstract “debate” about morality
it’s lived
it’s embodied
it’s desperate
and it doesn’t look away from that
it shows us what women are actually left with when they’re denied safe and legal options
instructions sa papel, gamot na walang label, pangambang baka mamatay ka sa proseso
it doesn’t sensationalize it, but it doesn’t sanitize it either
and that’s where the power lies
the film knows the violence doesn’t start when a woman decides to abort
it starts when the state tells her she can’t
when even in the face of trauma, poverty, or kahit simpleng “hindi ko kaya" o "ayoko," the answer is always “wala tayong magagawa
" sunshine sits with that anger
nire-recognize niya na ang lack of choice ay isa lang sa napakaraming anyo o mukha ng systemic violence
patunay ito of how the law protects an imagined morality while punishing the actual living woman
and yes, this film is very aware that class makes all the difference
hindi lahat may access to private clinics or doctors willing to take the risk
karamihan, kung hindi lahat, gaya sa pelikula ay sa quiapo ang bagsak
o kaya naman hilot
'yung iba wala talagang means & are forced to be victims of the way laws, culture, and religion collude to trap women into roles they never asked for
and that matters
because the way we talk about abortion in this country is always so detached from those realities
laging hypothetical
laging abstract
laging nakadikit sa spiritual na paniniwala
but sunshine shows that for many women, hindi lang siya tungkol sa pagkakaroon ng choice o sa moralidad kundi buhay at kaligtasan din nila mismo
literal na tinatanggalan sila ng basic human rights

ang sarap himayin ng pelikulaaa especially 'yung subplot tungkol doon sa 13-yr old girl tapos isampal 'yun sa mukha ng mga taong hindi magawang ilabas ang sarili nila sa personal nilang mga baluktot na paninindigan
ig the best part for me is how sunshine never tries to justify
likeee it doesn’t go “look, she had no choice,” or “she’s a victim, kaya understandable
” no
it says na kahit may support ka, kahit privilege ka, kahit hindi ka biktima, may karapatan kang pumili
and that, for me, is what makes it a GREAT feminist film
hindi siya nakikiusap sa audience na intindihin si sunshine
it tells you, plainly, na she owes you nothing
and maybe the most haunting part of this film is how it visualizes the weight of that decision
hindi bilang guilt or punishment but as memory
the film doesn’t erase the what-if
it shows you that even when a choice is right, it doesn’t come clean or easy
and that doesn’t make it wrong

A sunshine of hope in the dark, conservative alleys of Manila
This is a film that tackles what we Filipinos mostly shame women for: abortion
In this film, we see how the patriarchal society has a chokehold on our women
Men continue to crush the dreams of women, whether through abandoning them (ehem Miggy), ruining them (ehem Bobot), and deciding for their future (ehem Pastor Jaime)
But not Sunshine
Despite everything, she persisted
She never gave up
Her trials and eventual triumphs gave a nice contrast to the setting: the dark alleyways of Quiapo
In the desolate streets, there she is continuing to shine
And can I just say, sobrang galing ni Maris
She really did justice in portraying the character
Additionally, I’d also like to commend Annika Co in her portrayal of the bata
Superb, she has potential
Her character is like an annoying voice of reason for Sunshine
Pero grabe, naluha ako in the end sa scene nilang dalawa
And Rhed Bustamante too as Mary Grace
Despite a short screen time, I felt that she was the soul of the movie
Through her, we saw how Sunshine comes to realize her fight for her dreams
Mary Grace was the bridge that Sunshine crossed to eventually come to her decision of persisting with her goals
I also liked how the women in the film supported each other
Thea, despite her mother not allowing her to hang out with Sunshine, showed up in the end
Coach Eden, who helped Sunshine realize her dreams
Her sister Geleen, who strongly supported her in every way
This film is an ode to women, and tackles an issue that should really be talked about more
PEAK PHILIPPINE CINEMA

Sunshine tried to open a discussion about a topic rarely talked about in the Philippines -- and in that aspect, I think it was already a success
For it to be played in Philippine cinemas is already a win for the film, on top of the other awards it has received abroad

In terms of the technical aspects, I liked how the film showed the beauty of Manila despite its flaws, how graceful rhythmic gymnastics look like despite being a tough sport, and how the venues mostly used in the film had enough space needed despite being cramped
Story-wise, I like how it tackled the problems of the Philippines in terms of reproductive health, but also showed the pro of being a mother -- or at least having a mother figure by your side
However, while I understand why Sunshine made that decision, I think it somehow lacked that oomph on why she was eventually convinced to do IT
What happened after THE TALK
Still, I believe Sunshine should be watched by many
Sunshine shows that one may be in a dark situation, but if you stand your ground and believe in what's best for you, then you know how or where to find the light

A lot has already been said about this film—timely, important, brave
Sunshine is not great just because it tackles abortion, it welcomely invites us to be with its titular character
Every scene we are with her, and no scene is wasted
We know she got big dreams, and it's all she's ever known
We feel her despair, anger, and the facade through her smile
We see her make bad choices, but we understand why
I've seen a similar film in 2020, US's Never Rarely Sometimes Always
What sets Sunshine apart is it is set in the Philippines, a predominantly Catholic country
From the moment Sunshines wants to know about her status, judgment has already been cast upon her
People around her treat her as if she's some sort of contagious disease
Institutions, who are supposed to provide help, condemns her and gives a long-ass speech as if they're god
Yet, she finds a glimpse of hope in the most unlikely of places
Direk Tonet has proven to be one of the most versatile and essential modern directors in the Philippines
From her indie roots to her modern take of romcoms, she consistently has made semi-blockbuster memorable Filipino films
In her shift to sociopolitical drama, which already started in Fan Girl (2020), her voice as a female writer-director is clearer than ever
Hearing the germ of idea for this film got me intrigued, inspired from Jojo Rabbit (2019)
At first, I was skeptical of this borrowed plot device, but it completely won me over and elevated the film in the end
Manila is captured as pure as it is
The score is played at the right moments, and so did pure silence
And of course, Maris Racal, the heart of this film
A year of training and research for the character paid off
She is Sunshine through and through
Her in that motel scene is raw and chilling to say the least
All the supporting actors and bit roles are just as great and gives life to Sunshine's world
Jennica Garcia may have a few lines, but her performance especially in that scene with Maris is one to be remembered for, especially for teenage mothers
A surprising yet worthy appearance comes from Rhed Bustamante, whose minor role made a huge impact on me—I cried
Sunshine is such a lightning in a bottle kind of Filipino film
Who would have thought that a great indie pinoy film about abortion is getting this high amount of traction and success
One's hope is for this to create discussion among us and to move the needle systemically for girls like Sunshine
(And as a cinephile, I hope more films like this get produced and be seen by Filipinos, because Philippine Cinema has always been alive

It is refreshing to see such a brave filmmaker like Antoinette Jadaone take on such a taboo topic as this, and despite its obvious flaws, there is so much to be celebrated about "Sunshine"

Her depiction of realist Manila within a predominantly Catholic albeit judgmental Philippines is strikingly affecting, and the first half of this in particular is a worthy showcase of great filmmaking
The plot device did take me out of the film from time to time, and I do not think it was necessary nor was it effective
Yet, what more can you ask for when you have such a riveting turn from Maris Racal, who puts forward a performance for the ages
Those around her are also excellent, particularly Jennica Garcia, who embodies so much heart and emotion in the little scenes that she is in
Could this have been a better film
But is it one that is worth seeing
[Watched at SM Mall of Asia cinemas]
“drown out the noise
”easier said than done when the noise is everything
the streets of Maynila
the train
the coach
the prayers
the stares
the guilt
Sunshine isn’t just a film about a girl with Olympic dreams and an unplanned pregnancy
it’s about how loud the world gets when you’re no longer allowed to dream
the kind of noise that follows you into cramped maternity wards, judgmental glances, and conversations that aren’t even about you, but your body
it’s claustrophobic — not just visually, but emotionally
the tight shots mimic how it feels to be backed into a corner: by family, religion, institutions, and the echo of “what will people say
” that never stops ringing
there’s no space to move
no time to think
just pressure
this is a strong film
one that dares to confront the Philippines’ obsession with purity, shame, and control
it pulls back the curtain on a country where reproductive health is taboo
it also shows the quiet fear around abortion — how it’s never really said out loud, but always there, hiding under the surface
a real choice that girls are never allowed to make
where the system will preach “life is sacred,” but give you a plastic chair in an overcrowded ward and leave you to figure it out alone
sure, it plays it safe sometimes — there are parts where you wish it pushed a little more
but it still says a lot, even in quiet moments
Sunshine doesn’t claim to have all the answers
but it knows the questions that need to be asked
about bodily autonomy
about access to care
about what it really means to grow up in a place that punishes girls for being girls

Watching Sunshine wasn’t just watching a movie
Parang I was sitting beside a woman, listening to her story ng tahimik lang, pero sobrang bigat
It’s not easy to watch, but that’s exactly why it felt so real
What hit me the most was how the film didn’t try to be loud or preachy
The film doesn’t try to romanticize or a free promotion for abortion
It just let the silence do the work
Minsan iyak lang, minsan wala talagang salita
That makes it more powerful
Hindi ito simpleng kwento
It’s about pain, dreams, and mga choices na hindi talaga madaling pagpilian
Pero I have to say, may parts na medyo kulang for me
Sana mas dark yung cinematography, like Khalel 15 — gritty and raw
Lastly, hindi ito movie para sa lahat
But still, Sunshine gives us something real
And if you’re willing to sit with it and really listen, then you’ll see a side of womanhood na madalas tinatago
A woman who refuses to ruled by their own body, choices and dreams is something powerful and bravery

Mula pa lang sa trailer, alam ko na—hindi ko puwedeng palampasin ang pelikulang ito
Direk Tonet ‘yan, eh
May tiwala ako sa kakayahan niyang gawing matula ang trahedya, at gawing tahimik pero mabigat ang mga sigaw ng kababaihan sa lipunang laging inuuna ang hiya kaysa sa hustisya
Isa sa mga personal na dahilan kung bakit ako nanood ay dahil gusto kong unawain—hindi man buo, pero kahit konti—kung ano ang dinadala ng isang babaeng katulad ni Sunshine
Bilang isang assigned male at birth, pero hindi ganap na komportable sa label na iyon, alam kong may distansya sa pagitan namin ni Sunshine
Pero iyon mismo ang dahilan kung bakit ako nanahimik sa sinehan
Tumigil akong mag-analisa, at hayaan ang pelikula na magsalita para sa sarili nito
Hindi ko kailangang maging babae para makiramay
Pero gusto kong makiramdam
At dito, sa pelikulang ito, nagtagumpay akong maramdaman si Sunshine—ang kanyang pagkalito, galit, at takot—na para bang sarili kong laman-loob ang kinikiskis ng eksena
At sa prosesong iyon, nadama ko si Sunshine—ang pagkalito niya na hindi simpleng pagkaligaw, kundi paglalakad sa isang landas na sinabihan siyang bawal
Ang galit niyang hindi mapagsigawan, at ang takot niyang hindi inamin, pero nandoon sa bawat kumpas ng katawan niya
Maris Racal didn’t just play Sunshine—she inhabited her
She carried her, as if every scene weighed heavily on her spine, even when she stood upright
May mga eksena na walang dialogue pero mas mabigat pa sa sigawan
At doon ko nakita ang mastery ni Maris bilang aktres: ang kakayahang magsalita gamit ang pananahimik
Nakakatawang may nagsabi raw sa likod ng kamera na “haggard” siya habang nagsu-shoot
I laughed—not because it’s funny, but because it’s too real
Ganito talaga ang hitsura ng kabataang babae na araw-araw tinatanggihan ang mundo, pero hindi puwedeng mapagod
May mga Sunshine sa Quiapo, sa mga post sa Reddit, sa mga comments na deleted, sa mga babae sa jeep na tahimik lang pero may bitbit na kwento
And it takes a film like Sunshine to remind us: they are not voiceless
We just haven’t been listening
Unang tingin kay Annika, iisipin mong comic relief siya
Isang batang gumugulo sa eksena, parang pang-balanse sa bigat ng naratibo
Pero habang tumatagal, na-realize kong siya pala ang pinakamatining sa lahat
Hindi siya ordinaryong karakter—siya ang konsensya ni Sunshine
Hindi ang moralistic kind, but the invasive kind
Yung konsensyang hindi laging tama o mali, kundi nagtatanong: “Nasaan ka na
” “Handa ka ba
” “Ito ba ang gusto mong piliin
” At dahil hindi laging consistent ang paglitaw niya—minsan parang guni-guni, minsan parang totoo—mas naging epektibo siya
Kasi hindi ba ganoon din ang konsensya
It creeps in when you're alone
It arrives uninvited
In a country where abortion is taboo, Annika becomes more than a person—she’s a presence
A question
A symbol of possibility and loss, but not in a way that condemns
She’s not there to judge Sunshine, but to make us feel what it means to carry a choice you can’t share with anyone
Sa isang bansang ang moralidad ay naka-template mula sa pulpito, ang pagkakaroon ng karakter tulad ni Annika is radical
Hindi siya plot device
Isa siyang reimaginasyon ng konsensya—hindi para ipahiya ang babae, kundi ipaalala kung gaano kabigat ang dalahin sa lipunang pilit silang pinatatahimik
Ang Sunshine ay hindi pelikulang pro-choice dahil gusto nitong makipagtalo
Hindi rin ito pelikula tungkol sa abortion dahil gusto nitong mag-skandalo
Ito ay pelikula tungkol sa karapatan
Sa kakayahang pumili, kahit pa masakit ang pagpiling iyon
Sunshine doesn’t celebrate abortion—it honors the courage to face it
Sa lipunang ang kababaihan ay kailangang laging malinis, laging mabait, laging matino, heto ang isang pelikulang nagsasabing: ang katawan mo ay hindi kasalanan
Ang pagpili mo ay hindi dapat katumbas ng pagkapako
Maraming salamat, Direk Tonet
Salamat sa hindi pag-ikot sa ligtas na naratibo
Salamat sa pagbibigay ng boses sa katahimikan
Salamat sa paghubog ng pelikulang hindi lang para sa kababaihan, kundi para sa lahat ng gustong matutong makinig
Bilang isang lalaki na walang MATRES, pero may malasakit sa mga may isa, ramdam ko ang urgency ng kwento
Sunshine is not a perfect film—but it is a vital one
And in a country that rarely gives women room to speak, a film like this doesn’t just feel brave
It feels necessary
" Drown out the noise
"This line in the Sunshine struck me after watching the film
Noise is considered as a plot device in the film literally and figuratively
I like how the background music or the noise from the background is used to set the tone and mood of the film especially in scenes where Sunshine is walking or riding a jeep home
Noise in the film can also represent the doubts that fill her while practicing and self-righteous religious people who judge her actions throughout the film
The film is about a gymnast who plans to join the tryouts for the Olympics
However, she receives a result that is unexpectedly pregnant which can hinder her chances in getting in
Maris Racal is great in her role as Sunshine and I think that she embodies the role of a gymnast especially since she tried gymnastics to prepare for her role
There were scenes that were remarkable for me such as when she tries to hit a the mirror of a car after her boyfriend (played by Elijah Canlas) doesn't take responsibility for her pregnancy
I also loved the supporting characters as well
Despite their small roles, they made a mark for me
For instance, Jennica Garcia was impressive in her scenes with Maris Racal as her older sister
You can feel that she defends and protects her sister and stay by her side especially during her revelation that she is pregnant
Xyriel Manabat is no surprise for me since I admire her acting skills since she was a child actress
She is great as Sunshine's best friend
Annika Co, an upcoming child actress, is a scene stealer where she acts as a conscience to Sunshine
She is charming and witty in her role and I think the twist made sense to me in one scene
In addition to it being a sports drama, this film also tackled the themes of women's choice and abortion
These topics are considered sensitive and taboo in a dominant Catholic and conservative society
As a man, this film moved me and realize how hard it is to be a woman in a society wherethey are judged for having an autonomy in their body
In a third world country, healthcare is considered a privilege especially for the poor
Because of abortion being considered illegal and immoral, women are forced to resort to unsafe practices which can endanger them

It is shown in the film and I think it's interesting that it depicted two doctors: one which discriminates women because of her religious bias and one which tried to understand and helped another character in the film who turned to abortion
It's a sad reality, but I'm glad that this film will open conversations about themes like these
Overall, I find Sunshine an impressive film
I think this is Antonette Jadaone's best film so far
It's my second film that I've seen in cinemas and I'm grateful to witness it in the big screen because it is worth the watch there with its immersive experience
I was definitely looking forward to it since it's rare to watch a sports film which centers around gymnastics and it has been shown in film festivals abroad
I was worried that it won't be shown here because of how controversial it would be because of the stand of the Catholic Church and other religious sectors regarding abortion
I guess more people are more open-minded towards the topics unlike before
Aside from the acting, what I found compelling in the film is the cinematography and scoring which adds tension and mood to the it
Despite its limited release and pitted against two superhero films during its premiere, I really hope more people will get a chance to watch this movie
Even if it shows the harsh realities of life and in sports, I agree with other film critics that it also shows hope

No doubt my favorite Jadaone film, Sunshine is not only an important work of art in a cultural context, but an objectively beautiful, clean and concise narrative work

What I mean is not a single frame is wasted, or given up for style points - every decision of performance, framing and pace is made to serve the story, to make us empathize with Sunshine, to feel what she feels
Woman vs the institution - the clarity of this theme is just so powerful, yet we’re brought into Sunshine’s world through masterful camerawork that just feels honest
There’s a shot I love, where Sunshine is framed inside a window (in her room then in a motel), and the chaos of the city goes on about her, uncaring and apathetic to her situation
That’s the whole movie - the slow-burning horror that she is being shunned by society, cramped into tiny spaces trying to survive

It made me cringe to hear the chants of “Pilipinas” by the crowd in her performance at the end (the sad reality of Filipino athletes, unsupported in training yet celebrated in victory)Maris Racal’s best performance
The care and dedication she brought to the role should be applauded
Everyone else in the movie is so dialed in too, a subtle superpower of Direk Tonet’s ear for relatable acting and dialogue
Also love the Pastor P appearance, who brings such an important discussion into the public consciousness
The ultimate boss level: God & practicality vs the woman’s decision
Instant classic
“Sunshine” gripped my soul and left me hollow with unease
the first ten minutes we follow Sunshine as she drifts aimlessly through the restless streets of Manila, and that’s how the entire film feels
yes, it’s sending a message, but watching her spiral felt almost voyeuristic, as if we were witnessing something intimate and illegal
no propaganda, just raw, heartbreaking truth
and as much as i hate comparing directors, the rawness of each frame felt deeply “Brocka” but captured through the tenderness and gaze of a woman
at the film’s core is Maris Racal, exceptional in her quiet nuance, supported beautifully by Jennica Garcia
this film will linger with me for days
it’s about the cruelty of the world, the ache of aspirations, the fragile hope for a better life, and, ultimately, a woman’s choice
And at the center of it all, I love when a woman chooses herself

sobrang halaga sa akin ng sunshine dahil hindi lang karapatan ng kababaihan ang buhat nitong adbokasiya, kung hindi pati na rin ang karapatan ng kabataan na madalas isinasantabi lang sa usapin ng reproductive health
kung ang tema ay tungkol sa pagiging pro-choice lang, magwowork pa rin naman yung kwento kung young adult o di kaya’y isang full grown woman si sunshine
pero siya ay isang teenager—bata sa mata ng batas at babae sa mata ng lipunan
eventually, titignan na rin siya bilang isang babae na lang dulot ng kanyang pagkabuntis, na para bang nawawala agad ang pagkabata porket may dinadalang bata
doble ang pasan ng teenage pregnancy, dahil bilang bata o babae man, wala silang say sa sarili nilang katawan
kulang pa ang impormasyon at rekurso kapag kailangan na nila, making them even more vulnerable sa panganib
tulad ni sunshine, marami ang natutukso sa mga ilegal at nakamamatay na paraan para lang ipaglaban ang karapatan nila sa sariling katawan, dahil wala silang natatanggap na anumang uri ng suporta
mas pinahahalagahan ng lipunan ang buhay na namumuo pa lang sa sinapupunan kesa ang buhay na nariyan na

kaya bukod sa panawagan para sa legal na proteksyon sa autonomy ng kababaihan at dekalidad na healthcare system, lumilitaw rin sa pelikula ang agarang pangangailangan natin para sa comprehensive sex education na siyang magpoprovide ng necessary and appropriate resources sa mga bata tungkol sa sex, contraception, consent, at iba pang mga kaugnay na bagay na gagabay sa kanila para tahakin ito nang ligtas at malay
sana ipalabas pa ito sa mas malawak na audience huhu kelangan to ipakilala at idiin sa consciousness ng mga pilipino ngayon din

“Sunshine” is more than a film, it is a visceral, unflinching portrait of womanhood in the Philippines

It gives voice not only to the silenced narratives about teenage pregnancy and abortion, but also to the layered realities of how Filipinas live, dream, suffer, and survive amid the relentless chaos of urban life
It dares to confront uncomfortable truths
The cinematography is superb
Every shot is meticulously composed to convey the oppressive density of Manila
The stress is not just seen, it is felt
Salamat, direk Tonet
This is a big contribution to the success of Philippine cinema

many reasons why i absolutely loved this movie: 1) watched it w someone who is very dear to me (hi angel if you’re seeing this)2) the actors3) the story it tells 4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHok now lets go point by point starting at no

hoping the people reading this dont think im intellectualizing my review or whatever bc i just have a lot of thoughts and i couldnt sleep so im writing this now…2) actorsits lined up with amazing, talented actors so it’s absolutely a no-brainer that they would all deliver their lines stunningly
however, each character brought out such vivid emotions that i believe only their respective actor/actress could bring out
props to the casting director and direk jadaone for this
i first give my flowers to elijah canlas and piolo pascual
honestly believe that no other pair of actors could portray this father-son, catholic tandem better
elijah weirdly embodies the annoying, conyo, gago actor really well, while piolo is no stranger to playing a overt Catholic
i also am all praise for xyriel, meryll, and jennica
the women in the film who, in a world that is cruel, chose to be kind, especially to Sunshine

i praise jennica especially because with every line recited, you can feel her character’s exhaustion of having to give up their dreams and forcing themselves to accept their reality in an unforgiving society, as if she had a choice
of course, annika co is also a standout star here
though a rookie in the industry, i loved seeing her on the big screen
lastly, maris
no one can play Sunshine but Maris Racal
i fear i have to make a separate review on her solely
i hope she bags many, many awards because she deserves it
3) the story it tellsthe story of Sunshine is one that I, as a woman, have encountered many times

while post-debrief, i recounted the amount of times i was told a former schoolmate of mine became a teenage mother, and i thought about all of the dreams they had to give up simply because they had no choice
even in this film, Sunshine’s reality painted her to have little to no choice at all
while it’s not a new narrative, it’s a narrative that’s stuck in the past—in traditional, old, conservative Philippine society, which is why movies like Sunshine feel so refreshing
it strives to go beyond what society is now

4) what this film means for the future of abortion and RH in the PHthe fact that a film like this was produced and is being shown during a time where, globally, conservatism is on the rise and the Philippines is nowhere close to even considering the decriminalization of abortion, is already something revolutionary in itself
hopefully, this movie opens more doors to more discussions on abortion and bodily autonomy

i really have lots of respect for direk tonette and Maris for being at the forefront of what could be the beginning of the creation of a bigger platform for many women across the country to speak about autonomy and choice
Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas
Ang hirap maging babae sa bansang ito
dami kong iniyak
galing ni maris grabe
it’s worth mentioning that other than the discussion of women’s bodily autonomy, there is also solidarity observed with the female characters within the story
and i like how it is handled not in a romanticized or villainized manner, but of compassion and empathy
i like that
i hope this movie opens the minds of those who wish or are curious to watch the film
teka lang
let me process my thoughts

manila in its barest, philippine societal system in its most oppressive on women, patriarchy in its sharpest teeth clenched tightly on women leaving them bloody (literally and figuratively), long held religious beliefs in its firmest grip leaving many more regressive, and most of all love and support system in its purest and most tender

i keep wondering by the end about the women who weren’t given the privilege to choose, those like mary grace, those who never had the support they needed when faced with the same dilemma, those who’ve braved the use of unconventional means of abortion and may have almost died or indeed died
i wonder of their dreams, of their autonomy, of the life they have to face

and this is a reality lived by many women in the philippines, that despite the film leaving on a positive note, i just cant help but think: this world isn’t built for women to thrive, instead it’s a world where they have to fight tooth and nail just to survive, and in the film, to just get the basic need of a choice over their body
a world crafted where men’s needs and wants are at the forefront, and where women would have to beg to even be considered

about manila
about how quiapo has its own pulse
about commuting
about the air in your ponytail in the jeepney
about motel rooms
about pleasure in the darkness, for cheap, coerced, manipulative f*cks
about the repercussions of said f*cks

about motherhood

the ribbons you twirled and ripped
the jerseys you wore until they were worn out
the maternity clothes in your shopping cart
but what choice do you have

in a system that is made for you to break, slowly, agonizingly
in places of pity and shame, how do you rise
in breaking glass windows and cages, who cheers you on
in places where the sun is scarce and the skies are dark, who forges your shine
I love my mother so much
For me, she’s the best woman in the world - the only woman I love with all my heart
I enjoy Filipino films because of her influence - she loved classic Filipino films
She loved Sharon Cuneta
She loved Aldub
But I recently learned that she once dreamed of becoming a flight stewardess - a dream I never knew she had
I only learned about this and other stories of the woman I thought I knew when her sister shared them with us during a visit this year
That’s when the realization sank in, I knew my mom, but not the little girl she used to be - the one with so many dreams
A probinsyana with this dream of going around the world
But she had me (I'm the eldest) when she was eighteen
She said she never regretted itBut I remember when I was young, she drowned herself with alcohol almost every day
Now, I understand
She never had a choice
I'm happy that she is my mother

This film got me because I hope my mom had a choice at that time
I loved her so much, but I hope in her next life, she chooses her dreams

SUNSHINE advances itself as a film about bodily autonomy in a nation that denies its very terminology, yet it does so through the insulated idiom of psychological realism rather than the concretised mapping of the material conditions that make autonomy, abortion, and girlhood existentially precarious
We are immersed in affect, but the structure underpinning these sensations is left either ambient or altogether unrendered
Yes, the pharmacy exists as a moral space and the hospital as carceral, but where is the livelihood
Who funds the training
What does it mean, materially, to be a 19-year-old athlete—and an international one, at that—with no visible labouring parent and no bread line to back it up

Abortion is outlawed in the Philippines because it preserves state-church power and results in the reproductive labour of the poor as exploitable and their agency criminal, but to bracket class from the narrative—in a context where economic vulnerability is the foremost determinant of reproductive injustice—is consequential
Instead, the endless deferral into mood, while expressive, is in itself a seductive alibi for political disengagement

I understand that this is a film of interiority—that the point is to reflect Sunshine’s constrained perceptual field—but her interiority is a response to economic realities that the film chooses to elude, and when the audience is asked to interpolate systemic weight from ambience without any clear depiction of how deprivation functions, what we get is an abstraction that parades as empathy, and from that abstraction, other evasions proliferate: the neoliberal myth of the meritocratic athlete, whose suffering must be understood as psychological strain rather than as infrastructural abandonment; the convenient fiction that ambition alone propels a body through state-sponsored regimes without subsidy or the material realities the film forgoes

To abstract oppression into psychic distress then, while refusing its logistical origins, is to risk reproducing the same symbolic economy the Church relies upon: one in which the body is meaningful only as a metaphor and a vessel onto which morality is projected

This aesthetic disposition of interiority is of course obviously a structure inherited from the exportable idiom of European festival realism where the trauma of the Filipina is depicted legibly for the global North

From this perspective, it would make sense that the institutions that manufacture her precarity are rendered as emotional rather than historical, inviting the audience to feel with her but never to account—but by doing so, what emerges is not so much a Filipino film but a Filipino offering: an artefact of pain rendered in tones familiar to jurors abroad, a choice that aligns seamlessly with both (1) Jadaone’s career pivot into the international circuit, having premiered the film at Berlinale and TIFF, and (2) the film’s own final sequence: Sunshine performing her routine at the SEA games before a panel of foreign adjudicators, body taut and calibrated for approval by those who will never understand the weight of what she forfeited to arrive there

By naming these two parallels do we metabolise the rage of a system into something palatable and interpretable, and since both Jadaone and Sunshine must contort to be seen, in being seen, they are asked to become less what they mean

Perhaps the question is not whether SUNSHINE fails as a film or recedes as an offering, but whether it was ever permitted the autonomy to be anything else—whether within the landscape of Philippine cinema, where funding is precarious, distribution systems anaemic, and state culture support present only for the films that do not threaten it, a film like SUNSHINE must already enter the frame pre-legibilised and pre-digested, its rage ironed out for export

This is, after all, by the admission of its own producer Bianca Balbuena, a film that delayed its domestic release in order ‘to premiere in top festivals [around] the world to create noise and curiosity’, with the implication that only through international approval could the film attain enough value to justify its own existence at home
Thus, to resist the very circuit that enables its existence is impossible, but recognising this sharpens our understanding of the conditions under which those evasions occur
What we must ask, then, is what kind of complicity we are willing to forgive in a nation that punishes truth so severely that even its cinema must contort just to be heard

The silence in the cinema was deafening
[SM City Sta
Mesa — Cinema 4]
Quiapo has always felt like a contradiction
It's a district that thrives on both holiness and hustle, tradition and survival, all crammed into claustrophobic, identical alleyways
At its heart stands a towering church, surrounded by vendors selling everything: street food, religious images, herbal medicines, fake documents, sex toys, and abortion kits – pamparegla
The irony writes itself
And yet, that's where people are forced to go when they're desperate
Like Sunshine
Sunshine (Maris Racal) is a gymnast on the rise who discovers she's pregnant before a major competition – just as her future starts to tighten around her
The plot is simple, but never small
What unfolds is a slow, steady panic of a young woman trying to figure things out in a country that offers her no real choices
You feel the weight that she's carrying, not just in her silence, but in her body
She's holding so much in, almost willing it all to be a fever dream
But beneath that restraint is a quiet rage — in her posture, in her breath, in the way she fights to keep it all together
The movie doesn't try to frame anything as heroic or tragic, and that's what makes it powerful
What stood out most to me was how angry, how fearless, it allows itself to be
It simmers
Controlled, but with crushing intensity
This is Direk Tonet's best work to date
It's her most honest and her most focused
And you can tell she did this with immense care
The love is in the details

You must also imagine the lives of all other Sunshines out there whose stories remain unheard and unseen

alam ko rin kung paano siya tinitignan ng lipunan, ng batas, ng sistemang matagal nang hindi pumapanig sa kababaihan
isang sistemang feudal, patriyarkal, mapanghusga

alam ko rin na hindi dapat tinitingnan ang aborsyon sa lente ng kasalanan o krimen, na para bang awtomatikong mali ang pagpili, at masama ang pumipili
pero ang hindi ko alam, ang hindi ko kailanman mararanasan sa ganap na paraan, ay kung ano ang pakiramdam
ang bumangon araw-araw dala ang bigat ng isang desisyong walang tama sa paningin ng lahat
ang labanan hindi lang ang sarili mong konsensya, kundi ang mundong hindi kailanman kinilala ang pinagdadaanan mo, ang takot mo, ang dahilan mo

at yun ang pinaramdam sa akin ng Sunshine
and i think that's where Sunshine really succeeds
it doesn’t glorify
it doesn’t argue
it simply shows
it gives us a glimpse
into a life of a young woman, into her choice, into her pain, and the kind of quiet strength we rarely talk about
gusto lang talaga ng pelikula magkuwento tungkol sa isang babae
ang dami kong gustong himayin
but if there’s one thing that stayed with me, it’s this: Sunshine gives voice to stories we rarely hear
and maybe we avoid them kasi nga masakit
kasi hindi tanggap ng kultura at sistemang kinalakihan natin
but that’s exactly why they need to be told
what makes the film powerful is how intentional it is
every frame, every silence, every turn it didn’t take
lahat may dahilan
it could’ve been more clever
it could’ve been more dramatic
pero hindi siya nagpakitang gilas
instead, ginamit niya ‘yung simplicity para tumama
para magpa-reflect
para magpa-isip
what i appreciated most was that it didn’t force me to take a side
it didn’t try to tell me which choice was right, no matter what sunshine ended up deciding
it just asked me to listen
to sit with sunshine
to be there with her
even when things were loud & messy, even when she herself didn’t know what to do
and sometimes, that’s all people need
not answers
just space
and empathy

Sobrang ganda ng paghandle ng movie na ‘to sa topic niya, lalo na sa bansang ‘to na sobrang sensitibo ng mga ganitong usapan kahit na hindi na naman sa ibang bansa, kaya malakas yung respeto ko sa lahat ng involved sa paggawa nito, lalo na si direk Jadaone, kasi kailangan natin ng mga pelikula katulad nito para makasimula ng pag-uusap at pagbabago sa bansang ‘to
Ang daming taong tumutol at humamon sa konsensya ni Sunshine sa iba’t ibang paraan, pagkontra sa kanya gamit ang relihiyon, ang batas, ang pera, ang kalalakihan, at iba pa
Kada sulok ng Pilipinas may matatamaan, kasama na yung nakaupo sa likod ko, at dapat lang
Ang pelikulang ito ay tunay na isang sikat ng araw
Tumatagos ang sinag
Totoo siya sa pakiramdam
Dahil totoo nga siya
Totoo si Sunshine
Matatanaw mo lang siya kapag binigyan mo ng oras ang sarili mong huminto at pansinin ang paligid
Saka mo mapagtatanto: kasama natin siya sa bawat hakbang ng kasalukuyan
Kahit sa gabi
Kahit pa sa gitna ng unos
Isa siyang payak na reyalidad—nararamdaman sa dulo ng mga daliri
Parang singaw sa paligid; halos masamyo mo sa hangin
Ganyan siya kasinsid
Ganyan siya humihingi ng pansin
Patuloy siyang lumulusot kahit sa pinakamasisikip at pinakatahimik na puwang ng kaingayan
Siya ang bumabati sa bawat umaga
At kahit sa gabi’t hapon, may iniwang peklat—mga bakas na, sa paglaon, bumubuo ng mas malaking larawan
Larawang pumupukaw sa atin tungkol sa mga madalas itinatanggi, pinatatahimik, isinasantabi
Mga bagay na totoo, at tunay namang nangyayari—ngunit ikinukubli
Tila bawal
Tila tabu
Ngunit sila pala ang tunay na bumubuo sa bilog, ngunit nananatiling hindi kinikilala sa tatsulok ng lipunan
At ang tanging hangarin ni Sunshine: na maging isa ka sa “atin
Gets ko si Sunshine
Gets namin siya
Sana, gets din siya ng iba

“My body, my choice
” But is it really when your options of what you can do with it is stuck in a country overtaken by religion and politics stuck in the medieval times
Sunshine falls under one of my most favorite genres: social commentary by simply showing girls just trying to live
You can see throughout the film that she’s just a girl
Asking Miggy for money, asking for help when she needs, acts on her impulse, has dreams and goals, using twitter and Reddit for research (#real), etc
She knows she can’t take care of a whole ass child right now, all she can (and she should) do is to chase her dreams and make a career out of it
Though you can also see that Sunshine doesn’t really hate the kid
She takes care of her the way she can– giving her money to get home, looking for her when she’s lost, protects her from adult themes (drinking, abortion, etc)
So her decision at the end, it’s not because she hates the kid, it’s because she loves herself
With the limited choices she had, she made the most out of her youth And what’s so wrong with that
With being just a girl

Hindi ko masisisi ang mga nagsasabing may kulang sa mensahe, pero para sa akin ay isang malaking hakbang na ang paglikha ng ganitong uri ng pelikula para mapag-usapan at maipaglaban pa lalo ang reproduktibong karapatan ng mga kababaihan
Idagdag mo pa ang kahusayan nina Maris Racal at Jennica Garcia, doon pa lámang ay deserve nang maipagmalaki ang pelikulang ito
Direk Tonet knows exactly when to let silence speak, when to drown out the noise, and when to let emotions simmer
In Sunshine, she invites us into Sunshine’s mental and bodily struggles, but leaves just enough space for the character’s autonomy and our own
While some films impose what should or shouldn’t be, Sunshine deliberately resists the impulse to moralize— and does so with intention
Instead, it evokes
It urges us to feel and think through its subtlety
Jadaone’s placement of Sunshine’s body within the harshness of Manila is a political act
To know Sunshine, then, is to know the spaces that both suffocate and shelter her
The film doesn’t offer easy answers (or any at all), but that’s precisely what makes it resonate and linger

A damning portrait of a misogynistic society and how the smallest acts of kindness become beacons of hope
Antoinette Jadaone's empathetic direction and writing is precise, harrowing, and sensitive, capturing its protagonist's defiant spirit against all odds
Maris Racal is flawless as the titular character, portraying Sunshine's turmoil - both internal and external - with stirring rawness
Jennica Garcia is likewise deeply moving as Sunshine's ally and compass, a performance rich with history and life
Shout-out to Paolo Orendain's austere cinematography, Eero Yves Francisco's oppressive production design, Benjamin Tolentino's laser-sharp editing, and Vincent Villa's absorbing sound design
This film is fully realized from top to bottom and you feel it in every moment
This better be the Philippines' official submission for Best International Feature Film at the #Oscars

The film confronts the harsh realities of teenage pregnancy, abortion, and even the challenges faced by athletes in the Philippines
With abortion being illegal here in the Philippines, many women resort to dangerous methods that put their lives at risk
The movie also highlights how men often evade accountability for such situations, leaving women to bear the heavy burden alone
It sheds light on the prevalent issue of unwanted pregnancies, a reality that is sadly common here
The film emphasizes the powerful influence of religion in shaping societal norms
Overall, it’s a bold and honest portrayal of women's struggles, particularly in a country deeply shaped by religion and patriarchal values
Kudos to Maris Racal and Antoinette Jadaone

I was lucky enough to be an extra for this film prior to knowing what it was about, upon seeing the trailer, I knew this was going to be special
Maris Racal truly gives one of the best performances I’ve seen in a long time
She is able to express pain (both physical and internal) in ways that make me writhe with her
I don’t think I’ve wanted to hug a woman through my screen like this in a while
And wow
Annika is a star in the making
She impressed me so much in this, especially in the scene where they head to the hospital
It’s definitely a scene that will stick with me for a long time
Jennica’s performance also stuck with me (as a panganay~)Manila is presented so cruel, yet so kind in those moments where Sunshine finds help
I’ve seen a couple of other films talking about abortion in the Philippines (Hinugot sa Langit and 12 Weeks specifically), but I think this one struck me the most
I found this to be extremely nuanced, the presence of the kids and their roles in Sunshine’s life really made me think
I’m still not a hundred percent sure how I feel about their presence, but I appreciate that it made Sunshine’s plight something to really think about
I also appreciated the ending, I think we often see a remorseful side post-abortion for female characters here
But I’m glad we get to see someone who gets to move on and continue to dream, to live
I also thought about the other women I’ve heard about going through similar situations
With how much the world seems to be going backwards, I really hope this piece makes people think about women’s right more here
No one should have to suffer

watched this movie at a new cinema
new environment & new everything
no connection to the movie at all but i really felt the need to watch this masterpiece asap
so i got out, alone & motivated to push through everything i had set out for the day
my expectations were not disappointed as the movie delivers such a strong message towards the harsh audience which is the Filipino society
everything about the Philippines' secular practices to its contradictions that are laid by the patriarchal nature of the country—it was cruelly portrayed in the movie transparently
that's what i loved about everything that had transpired in the hour and hour-half time i sat in my seat

everything was in color too—something our country is quite known for; though maris racal had played the role of Sunshine, her character had pretty much went through the storms of what seemed to be an unplanned pregnancy that would become her hindrance in achieving her dreams
something women would always give up once motherhood would grip them by the toes
sad but true, tragic but a reality
yet this film assures women all around that carrying a child—or not, should not be something that would hinder us from reaching for the stars
every scene reminds us, the audience, how motherhood is a gift (unplanned or not), and its something we should carefully discern of before accepting such a blessing
sunshine knows this, she knows it too well to give her baby the life she does not deserve, if they was born with a mother not mature enough to handle the challenges of maternity
moreover, sunshine knew her dreams
her lifetime dream
God knows how much she desired the big stage
as said by Doc Helena, our God is a forgiving god; the statement echoes towards the ending as sunshine weighed out her choices
it was not a matter of letting something go, it was a matter of reaching for something that was always there
ika nga, talent is equally distributed, but opportunity is not; and for sunshine, she grabbed the chance
gripped it hard
never letting it out of her touch
and ceased it like it was her last chance—it was
i loved this movie too much
social class, reproductive rights, healthcare, religion, mixed with the right amount of comedy all married into one thought-provoking film

It's decent to say the least, it's a Jadaone movie for Jadaone fans

But that's the thing, it's myopic that it themes and logic of the narrative presented is as only limited as the filmmaker's worldview to say the least, or rather it is limited to how Jadaone sees the subject matter in regards to abortion and having an agency which is told in such a simplistic way, lacking that empathy and how objective it is

However, I commend the script to call out against the prejudiced perception but that's how it is, it did not hold accountable to it, and while Sunshine had conviction to make her decision in the end, and matters in her own hands, it didn't feel unearned to be honest
Like who is Sunshine to the audience, as a main character

Why do the audience should root for her, I think the screenplay failed to make its audience care and thank god Maris Racal made it somehow work because she did put effort to act in those dramatic scenes and it shows she's into that role, kudos for putting an extra work on gymnastic scenes
But in some light hearted scenes, it felt like she didn't convey those emotions that at times it felt monotone
She could've shown a more human and relatable side of Sunshine
It didn't helped that the runtime could've expanded or improve some things that were lacking, but overall the film did ok
Lastly, I have a message to those who are invoking Brocka's name or likening it to the film or the filmmaker: "keep his name out of your mouth

there is no doubt that i would love this film effortlessly because the direk tonet jadaone formula never fails in empowering women in their strongest moments; and even more so in their struggles in the fucked up reality of living in a third world country where they are robbed of their freedom to choose

i loved all the little details in sunshine’s home; the subtle reference to problematic people supporting fascists and corrupt politicians; and the way the city of manila is captured in all of its colors, filth, and beauty—showing us familiar roads and alleyways, reminding us of the vibrancy and dullness of the thousands of lives that passed us by
but what struck me the most is the irony of abortion pills being illegally sold where you can buy a statue of Sto
Niño, an image of the Child Jesus who was born from an unplanned pregnancy (albeit God-willed and wholeheartedly accepted by Mary if you’re Catholic)
because much like this visual, i do believe that devotion to God and the right to choose for yourself are not mutually exclusive
if you’re using your belief to shun others instead of understanding them, then you’re not living up to your faith
i’ve said it before in past movie reviews—to me, unsafe abortions are the most horrific thing you can show your audience and i’ve seen two other films before, one more vivid than the other
but this one in sunshine is the most painful and depressing
hihilingin mo talaga na sana walang babae sa mundo ang makaranas nito

ang pinakamahirap lunukin na katotohanan ay mayroon at mayroong mga babaeng makakaranas nito kung hindi magkakaroon ng maayos na sex education sa ating mga paaralan at hanggat walang access ang lahat sa reproductive health at safe abortions sa bansa
saludo ako sa tapang mo, direk tonet, to show something no other director of today is not afraid to do so
naniniwala akong ang kababaihan ang pinagmulan ng mundo

kaya maraming salamat sa pelikulang ito dahil nabigyan ng spotlight hindi lang ang mga babaeng tulad ni sunshine at ni mary grace, pero pati na rin ang mga babaeng tulad ng ate ni sunshine, kaibigan niyang si thea, ang kanyang coach eden, si doctor helena, at pati na rin ang babaeng bantay sa avenida inn na walang pag-aatubiling tumulong sa kanya
this is womanhood, ika nga
marahil para sa’yo, ang mga babaeng ito ay iyong ina, ate, kapatid, pinsan, kaibigan o kasintahan
pero isa lang ang sigurado, may mga babae sa buhay nating nagsisilbing kakampi natin sa araw-araw at dapat lang silang bigyang-pugay at pasalamatan
(please stop reading at this point if you don’t want spoilers for the ending
)at first, i thought annika’s character is sunshine’s manifestation of her younger self or her inner child that serves as her conscience in every decision she makes
but when we’re introduced to ariana, it’s finally clear to me that they were sunshine’s manifestation of the unborn babies from her and mary grace’s unwanted pregnancies
this is why that “gets ko na” scene is so powerful
because after relentlessly asking for forgiveness from God for reasons she couldn’t fully understand, she finally forgives herself for choosing herself and her dreams
minsan ay may ni-repost si direk sa twitter and it is all about the paths our mothers did not take when they chose to love us instead
when i read that, i just cried
obviously, i am thankful my mama chose me but honestly, i would’ve understood if she didn’t

what a film indeed
I can already imagine the discourse once marelease to sa VOD
First of all, I think it is so bold of Jadaone to come up with a concept that is so simplistic yet so real and full of grit despite the subject’s thematic weight
Abortion remains to be a debatable matter in the Philippines and opinions are always highly polarized among liberals and conservatives

Despite the country’s right-wing political ideologies, there are still calls from progressive groups urging the government to legislate better constitutions on health and reproductive rights for the benefit of those who need it most
Sunshine happens to be one of these people
Sunshine is a dedicated gymnast and an aspiring Olympian
With only a few weeks left to polish and brush up on her routine, she suddenly found herself in a bind that put her faith, morals, and self-worth to the test
The film doesn’t let us stay in a hopeful frame of mind; rather, it propels us to empathize with the character and question whatever is wrong and fucked up with the system
When Sunshine found out she was pregnant, her first instinct was to get rid of it
Pray it away
End it even if it means drowning in a cycle of self-destructive behaviors
It was clear from the very start she didn’t want to push through and she held onto that
I guess that’s as far as I can go for now so as to not give away too much of the plot

I watched this alone sa sinehan kanina and as soon as the credits rolled, i overheard someone sa likod ko saying na ‘bitin’ daw, and i totally get the sentiment that maybe for some people medyo half-baked or kulang ang storya
But sometimes, films don’t have to be loud in order to hit the right spots
With its very straightforward premise and message, I think Sunshine deserves the amount of hype it’s getting
The sports industry is already overwhelmingly taxing and having to face added burdens brought about by unwanted pregnancy can be way more damaging than one can fathom

Sunshine is not a film that will convince you to change your moral and political convictions; rather, it clings to the little hope of making the audience understand that the dilemma Sunshine had to face isn’t something that exists only in the reel world, but something that is very much present in the real world—in a society where bodily autonomy often comes at a social cost

Above all else, one thing’s clear is we really need better and safer reproductive laws in the Philippines so women wouldn’t have to go through under-the-table practices that put their lives on the brink of death
However, with the current political climate, i guess it’s realistic to assume we’re still a little far off
But with films like Sunshine, I’d like to think there’s still an ounce of hope for our country to perhaps embrace ideals that give primacy to women’s autonomy and rights, at the very least

”I think Sunshine is Direk Tonet’s best work yet
It is simplistic, raw, and bothering but it is wrapped in a cute pink ribbons that seeks to hide the harsh truths women in our society face
The bits of humor at times give audiences a space to laugh and forget how heavy the message of the film is and then it just hits you with its narrative and the core message behind it
My favorite scene was the conversation between Ariana and Bata, it was both pro life and pro choice which may be a hard thing to pull off but the team did it effortlessly
I loved how raw and unfiltered it is and how it became a eureka moment for the other audiences
I am in no way fit to write a long ass review about the them of the film because stories like these are rooted in everyday struggles of women in such violent and patriarchal society
I loved the film but I would love more hearing how women react and talk about this film, sila ang tanging nararapat na magexpound lalo nito at naka supporta lang ako
This movie surprised on how well-made it is from start to finish

Habang nasa kalagitnaan ng pelikula, nasabi ko na lamang sa sarili ko, “Para saan ba talaga ‘tong pelikula na ‘to
Ano bang point nito
” Yun pala, ako lang ang hindi agad naka-gets
Ang fucked up lang kasi isipin kung yung bata ay literal na physical manifestation ng nasa tiyan ni Sunshine, parang anim na taong gulang na anyo ng dapat sana’y magiging anak
Mas fucked up pa kasi kinokonsensya niya si Sunshine (tinawag siyang murderer)
Pero later on na-realize ko: hindi siya totoong bata, kundi visual representation lang ng internal conflict ni Sunshine
Siya yung konsensya
Siya yung maliit na boses sa loob
Siya rin si Sunshine
Kaya hindi talaga tungkol sa journey ni Sunshine sa pag-abot ng mga pangarap niya ang pelikula
Mas tungkol ito sa batang karakter—na hindi rin pala talaga bata—at sa mas malawak na karanasang pangkababaihan
Kasi sa totoo lang, ang kwento ng abortion ay hindi tungkol sa bata
Ito ay tungkol kay Sunshine
Sa mga babae
Sa mga may katawan
Sa mga may kakayahang magdesisyon para sa sarili nila
Maganda naman ang ending
Medyo parang Modess commercial nga lang (charot)
Pero kung tatanungin ako, feeling ko may kulang
Bilang manonood, hindi ko gaanong naramdaman ang bigat ng emosyon
Kulang sa lalim
Kulang sa hugot
Pero nabawi naman sa pagganap ng mga aktor—walang tapon, mahusay ang lahat
Isang halimbawa ng kakulangan sa emotional connection para sa akin ay yung eksenang umiiyak si Sunshine sa loob ng inn habang isinasagawa ang abortion
Malapit na akong bumigay nun, ramdam na ramdam ko na, pero biglang nag-cut to a shot from outside the window of her emoting and yung maingay na traffic
Aesthetic, oo
Maganda, pero di ko gusto
Parang sinampal ako pabalik sa reyalidad na, “Hoy, hindi ka kasama sa kwento
” Saksi ka lang
I don’t know about you guys, but I don’t like that
Favorite scene ko siguro ay yung early scene sa pelikula, yung umiiyak si Sunshine sa jeep
Maingay sa simula, tapos unti-unting tumahimik habang nakatutok lang ang lente sa kanya
Ang galing nun
Ang ganda
In addition, siksik sa intensyon ang mga detalye—katulad ng painting sa unahan ng jeep na may nakasulat na “Gift from God
” Hala siya, eh di ikaw na ang tumanggap
(charot)Anyways, ang dami kong nasabi
Pero ngayon na lang naman ‘to
Ang galing ni Maris
At isang malaking middle finger sa mga mahilig makialam sa buhay ng iba—lalo na’t hindi naman hinihingi ang opinyon nila
Wala rin namang ambag
Oo, may ambagan

Beyond how brilliant Sunshine is, this film reminded me once again why cinema matters in shaping and inspiring a better society
It has the power to connect, to spark meaningful conversations, and to heal
The film doesn't ask you to take a side or change your stance, instead it offers perspective
It doesn't scream any agenda on you, instead it quietly holds your hand and asks you to listen
This film made me realize just how unfair this world can be to women
It is hard enough to be a woman, even more so to be a woman in the Philippines
As a man, it opened my eyes around struggles I'm privileged not to face, but must learn to understand
Sunshine champions women with deep care and honesty, and Tonet Jadaone continues to be one of the most important voices in Philippine cinema today
I can't wait to see what she creates next
Maris Racal portrayed Sunshine with such precision and depth
Her fears and pain simmer just beneath the surface, yet she keeps moving-focused, trying to hold herself together-trying to drown out the noise as she fights to choose what's best for her
Top 3 scenes that stirred the audience at our local theater:1
The preachy doctor scene 2
Rhed Bustamante’s pregnancy reveal 3
The “Ate” scene between Jennica and Maris

A perspective from a young woman's struggle towards her dreams in Urban Manila
Handle delicate and sensitive timely issues-abortion and #ProChoice
The juxtaposition of society and women's struggle
How each scenes will straight out of reality
Your social support will vary and how public space are intermingle of ideas

Each realities matter yet beliefs they hurt-from a Conservative Christian Obgyne female doctor who cannot fathom how a young woman would not want to give birth, to a female Quiapo vendor selling abortifacients in front of a Church, to a dear sister who raised her both siblings who will love her no matter what (Jennica's performance here is so superb, I almost cry), to a 13 year old girl who been raped because by a family member, and finally Maris Racal's Sunshine who undergo making a decision, a choice--that is so hard and required ethics, but understandably absorbed into her role, how every woman in the Philippines simply existing is so exhausting
But also how the patriarchy compels women as their biggest supporter draping the country's public health that hurt and judge women for their choice, to the point of penalizing them as criminals
Sunshine is realism, carefully managed and lay out how women needs always to advocate for their own choice and bodily autonomy

This kind of film is what the whole Philippines has to watch
It is an eye-opener that sparks significant discussion in terms of how Filipinos perceive situations in a traditional and conservative way
I definitely loved how it tackled this controversy while focusing on Sunshine’s dream, which represents many teenage girls that suffered from unwanted pregnancies
In this hour-and-a-half film, it did highlight the majority belief yet also countered it in different narratives
Despite being so interested in pre-watching the film, I still didn’t expect how the film has featured many symbols and situations that Filipinos have to realize
I get so emotional about how the storyline has approached this issue, and I hope to see more of this in our country
Maris Racal is the right actress for the role
The way she played Sunshine was so natural and raw
Her delivery of lines, the body language, the expressions—everything was on point
She made Sunshine as the character that many can easily relate to
The casting was amazing, as were the cinematography, color grading, music scoring, and the flow
Definitely Direk Antoinette Jadaone’s best

Antoinette Jadaone unleashes a kind of ferocity in this film that's very much needed from a mainstream voice in our sociopolitical age
The choices made throughout the narrative leave a powerful message that stay with you long after you walk out of the theater
It demands your attention, and it demands that you listen

Sunshine feels like a film that will define a new age in Philippine cinema, not for its technical marvel, but for ushering in a bravery in writing that may just be what's missing from our industry's identity
I might even reckon it to the likes of the Brockas, Bernals, de Leons, or the Diaz-Abayas of the world
Please, catch it in cinemas if you can

This movie is brave in tackling a very delicate issue, but at times, it tries too hard to deliver its message
It needed more grit and heart, and less aesthetics and preachiness
The bit with the pregnant teenage girl felt like a random device, which is unfortunate given the weight it carried on the film's plot
Still, I like how it tried to take on subjects like incest, poor maternal health, Catholic guilt
It works well when it shows its heart -- the tender moments between sisters, the heartbreaking text message to a friend before a risky decision
Maris Racal is good, and the supporting cast also deserves a lot of praise (the Quiapo vendor was great)

1st watch
i have so many thoughts and feelings for this film
but it’s just a great film, hands down
throughout, we see sunshine behind and through bars and whenever we see her beyond it, her choices feel cathartic (like dasurv masiraan ng kotse
dasurv mabasagan ng beer sa ulo
) i found the hospital scenes to be the hard-hitting ones since there are so much to unpack

like either way, you’re trapped—trapped alongside the many other women who are forced to share hospital beds in public health centers/clinics/hospitals or either, you end up fighting for your life when the abortifacients don’t work
given the structures around us, the choices we are given do not serve us nor empower us, which then make these other options more enticing
despite this dreary reality, i found myself being emotional during the final sequence
sunshine finds herself free in gymnastics and that’s what she gets to do and she gets to drown out the noise
and that’s all what we’re advocating for, for women to have the choice
