what we can hope for, perhaps, is the exploration of more nuanced stories like sunshine’s to be seen and heard

The movie that will haunt you after watching
Sunshine isn’t loud, but it leaves a lasting echo
Her silence feel heavier than words
As she searches the streets of Manila for a way out, we feel every step, the desperation, the shame, the unbearable weight of decisions no one should face alone
What haunts you isn’t what’s said, but what isn’t
The film never preaches, but it unsettles
You don’t just watch it, you carry it with you
Sunshine doesn’t end with answers
It ends with a breath held in your chest

sunshine sheds light on the complexities yet unity within the different relationships that girls have with other women
sobrang daming expectations na hinihingi sa atin at iba rin ang pagod dahil dito
maris perfectly embodies the character of sunshine, who stayed true to her dreams until the end, despite the multiple challenges she faced to get there
this film was very, very raw and the execution perfectly delivered the message it wanted to reach the audience

i love you sunshine <3
the irony of the super christian ob-gyne treating sunshine like a child (say thank you papa jesus) while also expecting her to carry a child full term
there are lots of ironies in this movie, especially in how sunshine—a girl, barely a woman herself—is treated
“what if the child you’re carrying is the next president of the philippines
” but what about sunshine’s dreams
must those dreams end when motherhood begins
whose dreams and potential are more important
sunshine the movie doesn’t answer these questions outright, leaving you to chew on them instead and come to your own conclusions
at the start, i found the narrative device of the child as a manifestation of sunshine’s guilt a little too on-the-nose, but the pay-off in the ending made it worth it
as the ending says: gets ko nabut the best parts of sunshine are when it dwells on the almost fantastical ridiculousness of manila—not just the place, but also the people

details like the abortifacient vendor using the money sunshine gave her to “bless” her holy figurines or the santo niños looming over their whole transaction or dangerous illegal abortions followed by scenes of overflowing maternity wards
the movie passes no judgement on these scenes but merely offers them up for observation: here is manila in all it’s messy glory
it’s the perfect backdrop for sunshine’s series of bad choices
(and also reminiscent of lino brocka’s film style which i absolutely ate up)

Siguro nasabi na ang halos lahat ng magagandang aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine, pero may isang bagay talaga ang tumatak sa akin: ang ilaw
Hindi ko alam kung sinadya man ito, pero napansin ko kung paanong ginagamit ang ilaw upang i-spot si Sunshine
Sa bawat eksenang naggi-gymnastics siya, ramdam mo ang goals at motivation ng karakter niya
Tunay nga na siya si Sunshine, siya ang liwanag
Ang bawat eksena sa loob ng training court ay nagmistulang higaan ng dilaw na liwanag, puno ng pangarap, dedikasyon, at pag-asa
Pero sa tuwing lalabas siya ng gym, sa tuwing aalis siya sa mundo ng gymnastics, unti-unting dumidilim ang paligid
Ang bahay nila, na nasa gitna ng nakakasulasok na usok ng Maynila
Ang pampublikong ospital na kalunos-lunos ang itsura
Ang mga kalsada ay madilim, makulimlim, nakakalunod ang ilaw
Habang bumabalot ang dilim, makikita sa mukha ni Sunshine, lalo na sa kanyang mga mata, ang pagnanais niyang kumawala
Parang sinasabi ng mga mata niya, ayaw ko ng ganito
Ayaw niya ng dilim
Ayaw niyang masakal ng mundong nasa labas ng kanyang pangarap
Siguro ang pelikulang ito ay hindi lang tungkol sa abortion
Isa rin itong kwento ng mga batang babaeng may pangarap
Kung paanong nililimitahan ng lipunan ang kakayahan nilang abutin ang mga pangarap nila
Kung paanong pinangungunahan at dinidiktahan ang mga desisyon nila kung ano ang “tama” o “mali” habang sabay na pinipigilan silang lumipad nang malaya
Ang dami ko nang nasabi, pero grabe, wala talaga akong masabi sa galing mo, Maris
Ang husay mo, sobra
At ikaw naman, Direk Tonet, ang tindi mo
Dati, pinapakinggan ko lang yung opinyion mo tungkol sa abortion sa AWKP, tapos ngayon, pelikula na siya
Kwento na siya
At hindi lang basta kwento, kwentong siguradong magpapasimula ng usapan, diskurso, at ingay

Antapang ng movie na ito
Likha ng kababaihan para sa kapwa kababaihan
Sa dami ng opinyon ng mga tao lalo na kapag tungkol sa katawan ng babae, iba ang ginawa ng Sunshine
Hindi ito dumaan sa maingay na diskusyon o pakikipagtalo
Tahimik lang siya, dala dala ang katotohanang hindi kayang ipaliwanag ng statistics, relihiyon o moralidad
Hindi siya ginawa para kumbinsihin ka o pasayahin ka
Ginawa siya para ipakita kung ano talaga ang nangyayari, at maramdaman mo kung gaano ito kabigat
Kwento sya ng libo-libong babae na tahimik lang, pero araw-araw may dalang mabigat na desisyon
Yung tipong kahit gusto mong may makausap, mas nauuna pa rin yung kaba kasi madalas, ang sumasalubong hindi pag-unawa kundi panghuhusga
Ang Sunshine ay paalala na hindi lahat ng sakit ay may eksenang iyakan
minsan, nasa katahimikan ng paglalakad pauwi, sa paghawak sa tiyan, sa pag-iwas ng tingin, sa pagbitbit ng bigat na hindi mo pwedeng ibahagi kahit kanino
Hindi ito pelikulang dapat lang mapanood, pelikula ito na dapat pakinggan
Dahil sa mundo kung saan ang babae’y madalas pinagdidiskitahan, ang Sunshine ay isang matapang na bulong: ‘Pakinggan mo naman kami

I LOVE THIS SO MUCH  two things: (1) you already know my gripe with movies nowadays being too self-aware, esp when making commentary on social issues (e
through infodump dialogues and/or in-your-face monologues)
given the themes of this movie, i was initially scared that this'll end up having the same issue— but THANK GOD that wasn't the case here
this one actually took the effort to situate us in Sunshine's shoes
it knew how to convey Sunshine's story by fleshing out the world that she lives in, by showing how she relates to others, by showing us the things she does not do and does not say
this movie knows how to practice restraint
that's how it managed to really make Sunshine shine :D(2) i love that this movie makes a very decisive stance on abortion, without having uhhhh such a cold attitude towards children

like, never once did Sunshine change her mind about having an abortion, and this movie also made several strong cases about how motherhood disadvantages/endangers women— but it also makes it clear that the problem is not
the babies/children
in fact the children are also victims here, as shown in Ariana's case
instead of being shown as ~the problem~ pa nga, this movie instead shows us that children may symbolize hope and companionship and possibilities
the unwanted pregnancy made life difficult for both Menggay and Ariana— but wasn't it Ariana, still, who stood up for Menggay
what Sunshine went through throughout the entire film was difficult and isolating— but she wasn't exactly alone, was she
hindi man niya gusto 'yung bata, there was a part of her that sought comfort from the possibility of the child's companionship
i think it's just human nature, yenno, to seek connections from others when going through a difficult time

and when you live in a society where you can't disclose all these troubles to anyone, not even to those closest to you— whose companionship can you seek, if not your own flesh that's taking shape into another life
sino pa ba ang mas makakaintindi sa 'yo kundi ang sarili mong laman at dugo

yeah in practice that may not be true LOL kaya nga ipinaabort pa rin ni Sunshine eh xD kahit anong "romantic" ng notion na susuportahan ka ng anak mo anuman ang pangarap mo, that's practically impossible when its very existence is what could hinder you from reaching them lol
pero ayun nga, it's the difficulty of the situation and our human vulnerabilities that add nuance to these discussions
—some pro-choice people (and i know they mean well naman) like to claim that abortion is ok because it's just getting rid of some soulless clumps of tissue anyway
and i guess that's scientifically true
but if fetuses are rly just soulless clumps of tissue then why are we so afraid of pregnancy at all
why do we want to do abortions as early as possible
I MEAN LIKE, it's silly to keep dismissing the possibility of actual growing life when discussing these things
and the fact that Sunshine Did Not Do That makes this movie good and relevant and real and special and a must-must-must-must watch
i love this movie <33 i hope more people get to see it

Ramdam mong may tiwala siya sa manonood

Malinaw kung ano ang tinutumbok ng pelikula, at 'yon ang isa sa pinakamalakas nitong punto
Alam niya kung anong gusto niyang sabihin, pero hindi ka niya dinidiktahan kung paano mo ito tatanggapin
Binibigyan ka ng sapat na puwang para makaramdam, magtanong, at magnilay
Sa panahon ngayon na maraming pelikula ang kailangang sumigaw para marinig, ang Sunshine ay bumulong lang—pero 'yung bulong, dala-dala mo pa rin hanggang paglabas ng sinehan

Sunshine offers something refreshing and different in Philippine cinema—and honestly, we need more stories like this
It’s bold, necessary, and deserves to be talked about
Kailangan natin ng mga kwentong totoo—‘yung nagpapakita ng realidad ng pamumuhay sa bansa natin
Under the direction of Antoinette Jadaone, Sunshine goes beyond being just a story about sports or dreams
It’s a story about womanhood in the Philippines—isang bansang deeply rooted sa religion, conservatism, at kung saan ang mga usaping tulad ng abortion ay nananatiling taboo
But the film’s message resonates far beyond our borders
It reflects the reality of so many women around the world
The film speaks so much truth about the lived experiences of countless women, and saludo talaga ako sa tapang ng mga gumawa nito
In these times, it takes guts to tell a story like this
Sunshine, as a character, represents those who dare to dream, and more importantly, those who dare to choose for themselves
The film is a powerful reminder that you have the right to carve your own path
Lalo na sa isang bansa na madalas i-demonize ang mga choices ng kababaihan, ng LGBTQ+ community, o kahit sinong pumipili para sa sarili nila

no one tells you how alone it feels
to carry something you didnt ask for
to suffer in silence because your pain is inconvenient, because your choices are not yours
sunshine didnt just show that
it made me remember it
it made me feel it again
i watched it twice
and both times, it hurt in the same places
but it also touched something soft in me
a reminder im not the only one whos ever felt this way
her name was sunshine
but nothing about her story was light
and maybe thats the point—women are expected to shine, even when everything inside is collapsing
she made bad choices
but what choices do we really have, when the world makes decisions for our bodies before we even know how they work
what choice does a girl have when the world punishes her for not being ready, and punishes her again for trying to survive it
when the system has failed us already when they have decided that bearing a baby is a demand and not a choice
and i felt seen
in all the things i was too scared to say out loud
the hiding
the pain you cant tell your mother about
the googling
the not knowing where to get pills, or how to afford them
the fear of your own body, and the shame of not understanding it
ang hirap maging babae
lalo na sa bansang pilit kang pinatatahimik
and still—there was warmth
there was sunshine
because somehow, this film made me feel less alone
because stories like this remind us that we are not alone
that our pain is not isolated
that someone out there is watching too, and feeling seen
that is what sunshine gave me
a relieving and painful kind of light
that not everything has to be healed, sometimes it just has to be shared

I think what felt most important to me about this film is that the sensitivities considered in writing this story ensured that reality was still being shown
It showed respect for the people direk was able to interview, and it showed disdain for the culture we perpetuate in the guise of religion and culture
It calls for the audience to see the effects of the choices they ask of others
It calls for empathy for the victims and what they have to go through and give up — their dreams, their childhood, their life
And it calls for disgust for the old ways of thinking, and possibly our skewed views on morality
And in these hard times, how proper support from the people around you can allow you to make decisions for yourself and not because of what others will think
Something that most people do not readily have in our society
Every moment of this film has emphasized a deep-rooted societal problem that was asking to be seen
And kudos to direk Tonet for doing so beautifully

While I don’t think this movie is going to convert any pinoy pro-lifers, I also don’t think that’s the movie’s purpose anyway
This movie is so pinoy, or at least in the Manila sense
The city noise, the sweltering heat, all radiating in the background of Sunshine’s journey to get an abortion
I wouldn’t say the movie’s perfect—I have some issues with the use of Sunshine’s motivations as a student athlete being a little flat—but the movie resonates in the parts where it matters
Although Sunshine (2024) advanced the conversation about abortion and body autonomy, one treatment of the film sets the conversation back
Don't get me wrong tho', it effectively presented difficult conversations within an already difficult subject

It doesn't just talk about abortion in the moral sense, but also its nuances—such as abuse and inaccessibility of healthcare, including both financial and policymaking aspects that rob women of the right to appropriate medical procedures
It also gave face to the concept of guilt through the personification of the unborn, embodied by the characters of the unnamed child and Ariana
But that very personification is where exactly the issue starts
The argument for the pro-choice position is the fact that life does not start at conception, but upon delivery
To personify unborn fetuses strengthens the narrative that abortion is murder
"Murderer," as the unnamed child called Sunshine the moment abortion crossed her mind upon knowing that she's pregnant
But how much does this set the conversation back
Not a lot, really
The film did not fail in doing its job
By tackling abortion itself, it already succeeded in sparking conversations such as this one
And that's already a huge step in advancing women's right to accessible healthcare
Let's just hope that we'll get to see more "woke indie films" like Sunshine (2024)
Art, after all, is not solely for its own sake

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine doesn’t waste time
Within ten minutes, we already know what the titular character wants: she doesn’t want this pregnancy
What follows isn’t a mystery or a coming-of-age arc- it’s a fight
We meet Sunshine as she trains for the Olympic gymnastics qualifiers
She’s 19- focused, disciplined, and carrying a dream she’s had and has trained for since she was 10
Then she discovers she’s pregnant
From that moment on, the film never strays from what Sunshine wants: will she be able to get an abortion
Sound design is a big part in every movie and in Sunshine, the sound feels like another character
Before her routines, her coach tells her to “drown out the noise
” But what if you can’t
Sunshine lives by a noisy street
She trains in a chaotic gym
There’s a baby in the house that cries at all hours
Even in a church- where she prays not for guidance, but for forgiveness before attempting to buy an abortion pill- there is no peace
Sound, in this film, becomes symbolic of the constant interference she endures
The noise of judgment, of religion, of expectations- it’s relentless
That judgment bleeds into nearly every interaction she has
The pharmacist gives unsolicited opinions when she buys a pregnancy test
Her best friend’s mother condemned her
In a country where over 90% of the population identifies as Christian and Catholicism dominates public life, the supposed separation of church and state is functionally meaningless
Religion makes the rules

And when Sunshine is rushed to the hospital after complications from taking an abortion pill purchased from a street vendor, the doctor shames her in front of other patients, calling her actions “a sin in the eyes of the Lord
”Sunshine carries everything alone
Her future, once so certain, is now uncertain
If she continues the pregnancy, the nine years she spent training will be for nothing
Her body is already changing
Her coach notices
She can’t train like she used to
Her dream is slipping
And then we meet Mary Grace, a quiet but devastating side character whose story lingers
Their first encounter happens at the same place where Sunshine tries to buy an abortion pill
The second time they meet, Mary Grace tells her she thought her bloated belly was just worms- a line so innocent it crushes you
In that moment, we are reminded: she’s a child
A victim of incestuous rape and we later learn she’s just 13, after she was taken to the hospital for complications when she attempted to get rid of her pregnancy
In a country where sex is taboo and sex education is frowned upon by religious leaders, what hope do girls like Mary Grace-or Sunshine-really have
Maris Racal is outstanding
Her physicality, her posture, her tension even in the quite moments makes her character feel very real
She carries the film with a maturity and vulnerability and it’s undeniably Racal’s best work to date
At just 90 minutes, Sunshine is lean and direct
It doesn’t meander
Just a young girl fighting again and again for her dreams
Sunshine is a masterful depiction of what it means to grow up in a country where women and girls lack the right to choose
Where “I don’t want to be a mother” isn’t considered a valid reason
The film drives this home in its final minutes: the guy responsible for Sunshine’s pregnancy shows up at her house with his pastor father
They assure her they’ll support the baby “every step of the way” until the child turns 18
Sunshine listens, then finally says what she’s been saying all along: she doesn’t want to be a mother
We already know this
We’ve known it since the first ten minutes
But her ex and his father don't, or rather, can't understand it
“That’s not the point
” she yells, and she’s right
The moment others found out she was pregnant, it stopped being about her, but about the baby
They had no regard for her dreams, for her aspirations, and how pregnancy will affect her well-being
It was never about if she'll be supported, it was about whether she's still "allowed" to have what she wants
And in a country that denies girls and women a choice, the cost is often their dreams, their futures, and sometimes, their lives
Sunshine is just one story, but it’s shared by thousands
And unless the law changes, there will always be more Sunshines
Jadaone’s film dares to say that-loudly-even when the world tells her to drown out the noise

Sunshine does not go the way of those brutish Brillante Mendoza social commentary flicks where the end goal is to suffer, and suffer, and suffer
instead it opts to project its demons as an internal problem
That, which works quite splendidly if not for the fact that this is a film supported by a very tepid and uncharacteristic score from Maris Racal's own ex-partner
That being said, the best things about Sunshine actually emanate from its night sequences
It captures wholly the distress, illegality, and dismay of everything to do with abortion, the black market, and whatever Sunshine's problems are adjacent to in reality
Those night scenes seemed straight out of Abbas Kiarostami’s Like Someone in Love

It's actually so apparent by the film's end that everything that does come out of this leads to the most reasonable one: a film that doesn't explicitly preach what to do, save for what its problem is tied to in context
But yeah, that score really does this thing a disservice

sunshine is more than just a story of a girl tortured by the thoughts of bearing a child at such a young age; it is a grounded story surrounded by problems caused by societal pressure towards women and questionable christian morals and beliefs, which also opens up the current state of the country in terms of healthcare and its views on abortion

art has always been meant to provoke, and direk tonet did it so gracefully—like how sunshine performed her routines, but still so raw with scenes depicting medically unsafe abortions during the second half
the cinematography was very pleasing for the eyes
most of the shots used were very effective in laying out the emotional impact of this film, most especially its exterior and tight shots with sunshine being the subject
another directorial choice that caught my attention was its symbolism
notably, the use of bata and ariana as figments of sunshine's imaginations
despite those major choices, i personally liked the subtle and unnoticeable details more because i truly believe that it was those that helped keep the film coherent with its vision
details like added sound bites from the television and radio or the production design of sunshine's house
overall, i love it

”first of all, this movie is so refreshing

it shows the struggles of our main character, sunshine, and goes into depth how unwanted pregnancy can lead to mental and physical problems, the desperation of having limited options and resources, the shame encoded into our heads at birth by religious and societal expectations, and most importantly, it shows the resilience women are forced to do just to simply survive
second of all—i love, love, LOVE how this story is not your typical filipino pro-life propaganda warning

it’s honestly so upsetting how conservative and unprogressive our county is with abortion, but hopefully with this movie, older generations can sympathize with not just sunshine, but also mary grace’s situation

i’m actually so glad sunshine doesn’t force its main character to attach herself to the stigma of “abortion is murder” mindset; but rather, being able to be firm and push through with her decision—knowing that she’s not ready to be a mother—and doing what’s right for her (and the baby), without the influence of her boyfriend’s opinion, as well as the boyfriend’s father who offered to take care of financial expenses, which is quite rare
another beautiful moment in this movie that i personally love is the sisterhood between sunshine and geleen
geleen’s understanding nature is powerful in itself—that having one person who will love you and guide you despite everything you’re facing can make your way in life a little easier
knowing that you have someone to lean on in times like this is so fortunate, cause not many filipinas can have that kind of support system
and dr
helena’s help
as someone pursuing medicine, i understand the male doctor’s perspective on how he doesn’t want to loose his license, but with just dr
helena stepping in discreetly, she is incredibly brave
she’s risking her entire life on the line for someone she doesn’t even know, and for me, that’s such a great example of camaraderie between women
although the first doctor that “helped” sunshine was unnecessarily rude
i’m glad geleen stepped in and defended her sister
as a doctor, don’t you have to leave religious talk outside work
what an asshole

overall, i’m so glad that philippine cinema is slowly stepping out of its comfort zone to talk about sensitive topics like these despite half (or even the majority) of the country being against abortion
i hope this movie spreads like wildfire—a wake-up call to break free from patriarchal laws, and the belief that women’s bodies and choices are truly their own

There are films that entertain, and then there are films that hold up a mirror—brutal, honest, and impossible to look away from
Sunshine did that to me
It stripped me raw and left me in quiet reflection long after the screen went black
I saw in Sunshine’s story not just a character, but the collective ache of countless women who’ve had to choose between self-preservation and duty
The central challenge of Sunshine—a young gymnast discovering her pregnancy at the cusp of her Olympic dream—hit me in a visceral way

Not because I’ve ever been pregnant, or aspired to the Olympics, but because I know what it’s like to carry something heavy in silence, to want something for yourself while the world insists you exist for others
Sunshine’s fear, defiance, and quiet longing mirrored the emotional territory I navigate daily: trying to live on my terms in a world that insists I don’t get to choose
My full review here: inthewakeofthings

What I like about Sunshine is this film fully embraced Antoinette Jadaone's artistry as a filmmaker, similar to her magnum opus "Fan Girl"
The luscious colors and shades at the backdrop of a failing city
The grounded surrealism
And Jadaone's honesty in what she wanted to convey in the film

Much like her previous romance films Alone/Together and Never Not Love You, this film grappled with social and economic uncertainty but this time it highlighted Maris Racal's character's struggle to love her passion in gymnastics
It's no surprise Racal acted the hell out of her role, but my flowers are for Jennica Garcia who encapsulated the ghost of Sunshine's what-could-have-been
Sunshine further proves Jadaone is in her prime, and there's so much more she can make in the next years

Late diary entry
It really is true that employment screws the cinephile in us

This is Jadaone's Never Rarely Sometimes Always (2020) mixed with the magical realism of Jojo Rabbit (2020), and Brocka's depiction of Maynila as a harsh, predatory city that traps and exploits the marginalized
There's a night scene that was basically taken from a Brocka handbook, framing, camera movements, dialogue
I love Jadaone's growth as a filmmaker and this project shows how she matured in multiple filmic aspects, but more so on the commendable screenplay
The conversations felt realistic– something a Gen-Z would say in the present context
There's a clever and subtle critiquing done by adding the English-speaking scenes as well
As if they poke fun at the other contradictions in our postcolonial, patriarchal society now

Multiple ironies and contradictions lie in this film—the titular character's name doesn't coincide with her lived experiences, the vendor selling the religious images of Nazareno and Sto Niño also sells the abortion pills, how the people who claim to care for us are so quick to judge if situations do not align with their perspective or morality

Sunshine to me was a thought-provoking way of presenting a very evident issue in our Philippine society, and Jadaone made it brutally honest without lacking the compassion and clarity to bring about this story
I love how hopeful the ending was tbh

I know that this country has been so steeped in religious conservatism that even acknowledging how hopeful that ending was would raise flak—but this movie has done a great deal to create awareness and productive discussions on unwanted pregnancies
Sunshine was a confrontation of our modern maladies, something that very clearly threatens the health and future of women
That's another contradiction in itself, having a government by the people, for the people and yet it chooses to ignore the evident crises of its people
I digress

ILY DIREK TONET
My favorite part of the film is how Sunshine simply does not have any maternal figure in her life
Her mother is literally nowhere
Numerous characters try to act in this woman's place, but all fail in being the figure Sunshine needs
I believe this is why the coach remains a flat character for the entire duration of the plot
Even if she refers to Sunshine as "anak," we never get to see her be a mother to her
The coach is at the center of the conflict, the one person who must never know that she's pregnant
Thus, Sunshine refuses to open up to her coach, refusing to be cared for knowing the consequences
When her coach hears rumors of her pregnancy, there is no comfort in her words when she confronts Sunshine
Instead, all the secretly pregnant teenager receives is a reminder of what is at stake, that she won't get to be on the team
This pushes Sunshine to go back for a stronger round 2 of the pamparegla
Not even Thea's mom can give comfort to the friend of her daughter
She literally does the opposite, ordering Thea to stay away from Sunshine
Even when Sunshine asks the motelkeeper for help, and they reluctantly do so
The elder women place her on a tricycle and leave her to bleed out as the tricycle rushes to the hospital
Then there's the doctor
Sunshine's sister perfectly criticizes her demeanor towards Sunshine
Her sister asks the doctor if she's a relative of theirs or possibly their mother because she's acting like one
Though this might seem like a counter, when you take into account how the doctor cares more about Sunshine apologizing to the Lord and thanking Him rather than Sunshine's well-being, the case falters
Also, her character felt more like a voice of how religion greatly affects the medical field and in turn, women's bodies
The same goes even for the case of Mary Grace, who has been impregnated by her own uncle
While her mother is alive, their relationship is complicated to say the least
Her mother enables the abusive relationship between the uncle and child for money, so that someone else can "take care" of Mary Grace, essentially removing herself from the role of being a mom
I think all this is why her sister is highlighted as a light in her life
She is the closest thing to being a mother in Sunshine's life, caring about her health, whether she goes to school or not, and so on
However, they are sisters at heart
They can only hold each other's hands through life
Her sister does not order her what to do with the baby, instead defends her from the doctor, pays for the bill, and gets her home
They are sisters through and through

Siguro nga’t kailangan lang din naman talaga nating ilagay ang ating sarili sa kanilang mga paa sa para maintindihan ang daing ng bawat isa
Si Sunshine ay isang perspektibong pilit paring tinatalikuran ng nakararami
Hindi sa lahat ng bagay kaya ng mga babaeng lunorin ang mga ingay
Maski ang bata’y kayang intindihin na tao lang din si Sunshine, at kahit babae siya; dapat at karapat-dapat siyang magkaroon ng karapatang mamili
Mahal na mahal kita, Sunshine
Literal na absolute cinema
Manila is rich with history, and within its walls are cracks that harbors scandalous yet important narrative we are too ashamed to tell
And unfortunately, Sunshine, in essence, represents the face of this cruel fate — the very victim of society's refusal to address issues that are relevant yet alarming
And through the film's course, we see Quiapo as this undeniable haven of hypocrisy, a place of contradicting morals, the very product of poverty and its people trying to survive and make ends meet
Jadaone somehow manages to tap into the very surface of these stories rather creatively, without missing a beat and has a stark vision of what the film should be about
At times I feel like the film is a literal outcry for help
Every character here is a representation of that and is the result of what's wrong with the system in general
This paired with Racal's impressive performance strengthens the film's core message
Simply put, Jadaone's work is not a prententious flick that uses sensitive subject matter for mere views but rather an impactful affair that successfully champions itself as a vessel for awareness

Overall, the film is resonating with me, a powerful testament that the film transcends genders and in itself is a beautiful feat because it lets you see and viscerally feel Sunshine, and witness her journey to self-forgiveness and inner peace

Ang palabas na may nilalamang iba't ibang karanasan patungkol sa usapin na pinalitaw sa kwento— aborsyon
Marahil hindi ito laging napag-uusapan, dahil bakit
Kasi nakakulong sa isipang mali ang magpalaglag, mali dahil pumapatay ng inosenteng sanggol sa sinapupunan
Hindi naiisip ang sitwasyon ng ina, at ng magiging anak kung sakali mang ipanganak
Sinasawalang kakayahan na magdesisyon ang bawat babae para sakanilang katawan, kung ano ang gusto nila, kung ano ang satinging tama
Ipinakita rito na hindi madali ang desisyon
Ipinakita rin dito ang mga matitibay na rason para hindi ituloy ang panganganak— pangarap
Sana lahat ay ma-gets ang desisyon ni Sunshine, katulad ng pag-intindi ng bata sakanya
"Gets ko na
The entire time I was watching, I felt like I couldn't breathe
It's claustrophobic and suffocating, just like how Sunshine herself feels
You feel her world slowly closing in on her, invisible walls tightening around her in every frame
The camera doesn't let you breathe, and neither does the sound
Manila's noise is constant, overwhelming, and disorienting, especially for a gymnast who needs focus and silence to thrive
Sunshine is literally and figuratively trapped in tight spaces, cramped jeepneys, crowded streets, the overbearing sound of trains passing by, judgmental stares, and high expectations
Visually and sonically, it captures how isolating and terrifying it is to carry a burden like hers in a society that is less than kind toward women
(Btw, just to put it out there, the cinematography and colors in this film are GORGEOUS
) In almost every film that tackles women's issues in the Philippines, you'll find this line repeated in many reviews here in Letterboxd: "Ang hirap maging babae
At lalong mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas
" It's because it's true
Every day, women here continue to fight for autonomy, for safety, for the right to choose themselves

We live in a deeply patriarchal and religious society that expects women to always put others first—especially family, be it their parents, siblings, or children—and shames them whenever something bad happens to them as if they brought it upon themselves
Society never asks the men who take advantage of women simply existing to change, rather it expects women to quietly endure
Bakit kailangang babae ang palaging mag-adjust
I appreciated how the film showed moments of solidarity between women, but it's sad how that's not always the case in real life
Exceptional performances from the entire cast, especially Maris Racal, who is tremendous in the titular role

From the start, she's completely convincing as an elite athlete and future Olympian: disciplined, focused, and has no room for error, as both her dreams and the dreams of others rest heavily on her shoulders
But it's in moments where Sunshine wrestles with fear, guilt, and inner conflict that Maris truly shines
She captures and presents the character's vulnerability so well
Also, as someone who always adored Jennica Garcia since her GMA days, I absolutely loved watching her quiet and subtle acting as Sunshine's sister
I said in my first review of Fan Girl that I hoped Direk Tonet would make an even braver film, and she did
Sunshine focuses and dives deep into the themes it introduces and stands firm in its critique—something that I felt was somehow lacking in Fan Girl
While some moments didn't always work for me and the magical realism elements sometimes took me out, I understand the choice
Part of me wishes it stayed more grounded and direct, but the “Gets ko na” scene near the end hit so hard that I stopped minding altogether
It's a great, important film and I hope it helps open up more discourse on women's reproductive rights in the country
Go see it in cinemas when you can

After making waves at the Toronto Film Festival last year and winning a Crystal Bear at the Berlin Film Festival early this year, #SunshineMovie finally comes home to the Philippines
Starring Maris Racal in a powerful lead performance, the film follows Sunshine Francisco, a decorated gymnast whose Olympic dreams are threatened when she unexpectedly becomes pregnant
She must choose between her ambitions and the responsibilities suddenly placed on her — all while navigating a society that dictates what women should and shouldn’t do with their bodies
Directed by Antoinette Jadaone, the film doesn’t shy away from the hard questions — ones that should be answered by the Church, the government, the educational system, and most crucially, parents
Why is premarital sex and reproductive health still taboo in 2025
Why does society police women’s choices about their bodies
Why can’t we provide options for victims of abuse
These questions linger long after the credits roll
Maris Racal gives a career-defining performance — fragile yet defiant — as a young woman trying to stay strong while breaking under immense pressure
Aside from her acting, her gymnastics scenes are highly commendable, a testament to her dedication to the role
Jennica Garcia gives a quietly affecting turn as her older sister, shining in key emotional scenes
Child actor Annika Co, making her debut, is a revelation — a true scene-stealer with star potential
Former child star Rhed Bustamante will touch your heart & churn your stomach
Piolo Pascual also appears in a poignant special role
Manila, chaotic and contradictory, plays more than just a backdrop — it becomes an extension of Sunshine’s journey
From historic churches to narrow alleyways, she searches for clarity, strength, and hope, beautifully captured & lighted by ace cinematographer Pao Orendain
Sunshine is bold, relevant, and deeply moving
It’s a call to conversation, to empathy, and to change
Super highly recommended
Now showing exclusively at SM Cinemas nationwide — don’t miss it
This movie is so satisfying to watch because it empathizes with its main character, sunshine, a young gymnast training for the olympics who happened to have an unwanted pregnancy
Young women like her are figures often shunned in popular philippine media and well, society so it’s refreshing to see someone like her in a sympathetic light

Abortion is such a taboo topic in this country so i very much appreciate the relentless uncovering of the different failures of the government and society with regards to women’s reproductive health and rights
Props to Maris for fearlessly embodying the role
Abortion is healthcare
It should be a choice accessible to anyone that wants it

It doesn’t have to be earned which is why I do find the imaginary kid representing sunshine’s conscience or the possible “kid” she might bear in the future unnecessary and redundant in the face of all the other oppressive opinions surrounding her
If the goal was to voice her inner worries, it wasn’t needed, it was already felt and would’ve been better shown some other way

If the goal was to voice the external conservative audience’s thoughts, then it wasn’t needed as well because they’re already thinking it, the film should’ve been secure with putting its faith on Sunshine alone
She’s a woman and she has dreams and having a baby is not part of that
She has value still for just the fact of being a person
I guess it just rubbed me the wrong way
It’s a very beautiful film nonetheless, shining best in its moments of truth and courage

this is such an important piece of art—for women, from women, as women—especially in the context of the reality of being a filipina living in the philippines
the whole runtime genuinely felt like i was watching a piece of philippine cinema history unfold
i’ve never been so emotionally compelled, invested, and moved over a piece of (ph) film (for quite some time now)
this is what real cinema should be
the weight and power it bears in emphasizing the ills of society, directing empathy, progressing toward solutions
from the opening sequence of the routine, the editing and cinematography of this movie shines
quickly pacing up to the story’s compelling conflict, maris’ gripping performance hooks you into a spiraling anxiety
that immediate catholic guilt was just perfect in its timing and execution, you can’t help but greatly appreciate how well thought-out this specifically was

as she walks through the streets of metro manila aimlessly and frantically all throughout in different parts of the story, it mirrors a striking resemblance of a guarded uneasiness that we women all fear that something bad might happen to us in the streets; it’s a fight for our lives everyday

it’s also so bold of a creative decision to figuratively humanize the unborn that at first, suspiciously could have gone wrong in one mishandling of the story but eventually paid off in working favorably by ticking the (filipinos’) tendency for sentimentality—especially with an even darker subplot
the casual inhumane reality the common filipino endures

Ang iniluha ko naman talaga kasi sobrang bigat sa puso knowing how raw and authentic this has been, especially with the fact that a lot of women, even girls, actually experience this, na this just goes way beyond the screen but is a sad reality of some
Being a woman will always be both a blessing and a curse, most likely when it comes to fertility, because often it will always be tied down to a woman's worth
Being a mom takes a lot of courage, for it requires a lot of sacrifices, dedicating your whole life to a child you've conceived for 9 months

It makes you appreciate motherhood and admire the women who dream to be a mother who is capable of giving unconditional love and a good life in a sense na they are willing to do everything for their child
But the truth is not everyone wants to be a mother, and society must learn to respect this kasi it is genuinely for the betterment of everyone, most likely for the child itself

Kasi being a mom is such a huge responsibility that most aren't even ready for, and a lot of other factors, such as teenage and unwanted pregnancy and being a victim of sexual abuse, contribute to the decision of termination of the child

People often tend to overlook it and deem it as something so negative, but what they fail to see is how this decision will always come from the place of love and care for themselves as well as the baby kasi genuinely I think it is more cruel to continue things you don't even want in the first place 'cause both the child and the parent would only suffer physically, emotionally, and psychologically

Also, I hate how women are expected to sacrifice their own dreams, aspirations, and life itself like it's so unfair how men could easily get away with anything, while the the women will be the ones to suffer, be condemned, and be villainized for things that they both did naman

Accidental pregnancy — are women in our country truly given a choice
Fear, dread, societal pressure, and the struggle for autonomy — Sunshine tells the story of a young woman full of dreams, now standing at a crossroads because of an unplanned teenage pregnancy
What is the right choice for her
Should she listen to the voices urging her to preserve a life she does not want, even at the cost of her dreams
Or should she listen to herself — to her ambitions, her desires, and her right to choose her own future
Motherhood or success
Why must women be forced to choose

This movie might raise a lot of eyebrows here in a predominantly Catholic country like ours, and it might even stir a few uncomfortable conversations
But I think that’s why it matters
What resonates with me most as a woman is how Sunshine powerfully captures a young Filipina’s agency
Despite growing up in a harsh world, she refuses to let her circumstances define her or dictate her future, thanks to the strength and support of the women around her

It speaks volumes about the kind of society we’ve built, the choices we’re forced to make, and how survival, especially for women like me, is not just a quiet resistance, but a brave act of believing in and shaping the future in our own terms
Still showing in SM cinemas nationwide

We’ve always known that the custom of films is that they should be written from the heart,but with ‘Sunshine,’ the beating organ was not a place, it had gained limbs, put on a leotard, then graced the stage itself—that heart is Maris

The film mirrors how a good-for-nothing man only reaps a fleeting pleasure from an intercourse while pain is all that is left of and might be rooted in a woman forever and how a female that chooses and decides for her own body are condemned by her very own sex
I also appreciate how film celebrates the innate wisdom of children :’))Tribulations don’t kindly pick a certain period in our lives, we will be found unarmed in them any time
It is also vague how long its adversities will delay our dreams—but what is sure is that they can never end them
I encourage everyone to see ‘Sunshine

’ It is undebatable that we expose ourselves to brutally honest discourses about womanhood, safe sex, and reproductive health in the Philippines, dahil sa pagmamalasakit nag-uumpisa ang ating laban na mabuo ang isang mapagpalaya at ligtas na mundo para sa kababaihan—para sa lahat

“The unborn” are a convenient group of people to advocate for

They never make demands of you; they are morally uncomplicated, unlike the incarcerated, addicted, or the chronically poor; they don’t resent your condescension or complain that you are not politically correct; unlike widows, they don’t ask you to question patriarchy; unlike orphans, they don’t need money, education, or childcare; unlike aliens, they don’t bring all that racial, cultural, and religious baggage that you dislike; they allow you to feel good about yourself without any work at creating or maintaining relationships; and when they are born, you can forget about them, because they cease to be unborn

You can love the unborn and advocate for them without substantially challenging your own wealth, power, or privilege, without re-imagining social structures, apologizing, or making reparations to anyone
They are, in short, the perfect people to love if you want to claim you love Jesus, but actually dislike people who breathe
The sick
The poor
All the groups that are specifically mentioned in the Bible
They all get thrown under the bus for the unborn
– David Barnhart

sunshine is a film by Tonet Jadaone
context is very important because if you have seen jadaone’s films (That Thing Called Tadhana, Fangirl, Alone Together among others) then you will know this is HER film
you feel it in every frame
the writing
the direction & performances
there’s no voyeurism here
no moralizing
just truth
honest, specific, sometimes messy truth about what it’s like to be a woman in this country
not in the headlines, not in theory, but in the streets, in health centers, in quiet conversations with friends who are too afraid to say what they really need
maris racal delivers the performance of her life
she holds back when she needs to
she breaks in silence
she carries every scene with restraint, sensitivity & precision
she becomes sunshine
and it’s the kind of performance that demands to be remembered
the ensemble is just as grounded
jennica garcia, thea, the kid: each one brings something real to the table
nothing is forced
they don’t play characters
they play people you’ve probably met
maybe they remind you of someone you know
maybe they remind you of you
what makes sunshine work is not the acting or the direction but the refusal to look away
the film doesnt hide behind a metaphor
it gives us a manila that feels exactly like the one we move through
where pamparegla is sold outside churches
where motels won’t let you in if you’re alone
where grieving teenagers are all around but they have kept it in because no one has dared say “you’re safe here
” from my POV, the film takes a narrative risk
there’s a device that briefly pulls you out of the realism it builds so well
but it sticks the landing
because what matters is that you never stop feeling for these women
and that you leave the theater asking why stories like theirs still feel unsafe to tell
i’ve had my own sunshines, close friends, a relative, a classmate
women who needed care, not judgment
watching this film felt like watching them again
and all i could think was, “please, let her be safe
”this film deserves a seat in our national conversations
not just in cinema panels, but in health committees, in policy rooms, in the offices of people who still think there is a valid excuse to deny access to care
one of the most necessary films of the year

This is a brave and essential film that dives into the tough reality of an unplanned pregnancy in a country where abortion is illegal
Maris Racal gives a raw, powerful performance as Sunshine, a young gymnast whose dreams are at risk, leading her to desperate, illegal options

The movie smartly uses Quiapo's setting, showing its mix of strong religious faith and hidden illicit acts, highlighting the difficult truth about women's reproductive freedom and how religion and judgment impact their lives
It's an honest look at a situation often ignored, pushing viewers to understand the hard choices women face when personal control over their bodies conflicts with strong beliefs

Most relevant Filipino film of the 21st century
alam niyo yung feeling na pagkatapos manood ng pelikula tungkol sa struggles ng modern women, o ng kababaihan in general, parang may nagaalab na galit sa loob mo
ganon na ganon ako
tipong hindi lang galit na umiiyak sa tahimik, kundi galit na kumakabog, galit na gusto mong isigaw, gusto mong may baguhin
galit ako sa sistema
galit ako sa kung paano itrato ang mga babae — na parang katawan lang, na parang obligasyon nilang tiisin, magparaya, manahimik
galit ako sa mga bulok na paniniwala na tinuro sa atin at patuloy pa ring pinaniniwalaan
galit ako sa tradisyon na sinasanto kahit matagal nang nakakasakit
galit ako sa mga mata na mapanghusga, sa mga bibig na laging may masasabi pag babae ang gumagalaw
galit ako sa mundo nyeta
pero itong galit na 'to, hindi to galit na mauupos lang
hindi to galit na lilipas pagkauwi
ito yung klase ng galit na may pinaghuhugutan — may direksyon, may laman, may pagmamahal
galit na gustong ipaglaban ang kapwa
galit na may layuning itama ang mali
ganito yung pinaramdam sakin ni direk tonet ngayon
ramdam mo na hindi lang siya nagdidirect eh
nagsisisigaw siya sa pamamagitan ng pelikula
pero sa halip na sumakit ang tenga mo, sa puso siya tumatama
at si maris, grabe
ibang klase, walang duda
sobrang galing niya mag-embody ng role, ang effortless pero ang lalim
habang pinapanood ko siya, hindi ko na siya nakita bilang artista eh
she felt like someone i knew
a friend
a neighbor
a stranger na napadaan pero dala ang bigat ng buong mundo sa katawan niya
dama mo sa kanya yung lapot, yung pagod, yung hagard, pero higit sa lahat — yung dignidad
yung tahimik pero matapang na dignidad
at ang mas masakit, 21st century na, pero kailan ba talaga matatapos ang pag-ccrucify sa mga babae
bakit pag babae ang may choice — sa katawan niya, sa sex, sa pagiging ina — bigla tayong nagiging moral police
gets ko, some people will say, "eh pinili niya makipag-sex
" oo, pero bakit sa panahong ito, ang pagbili ng condom, ang pag-access sa contraception, ang simpleng pagtanong tungkol sa pts, ay parang kasalanan
bakit parang kahit anong piliin ng babae, mali pa rin
at sa kaso ni red, bakit parang hindi pa rin siya pinapayagang mamili kung anong gagawin niya sa sarili niyang katawan
bakit parang laging may kapalit, laging may parusa, laging may kapwa babae pa nga na una sa paghusga
ang ironic, diba
ang daming takot sa sex education, sa reproductive rights, pero hindi takot manghusga
the more we condemn, the more we isolate women
at kapag nagiisa na sila, dun nagsisimula ang desperation — dun sila mapipilitang hanapin ang mga opsyon na mas delikado, mas tahimik, mas mapanganib
sana makita ng mga tao na hindi lahat ng babae na nabubuntis ay handang maging ina
hindi lahat ng katawan ay handang magdala
hindi lahat ng buhay ay handang isuko ang sariling pangarap para lang maging ina
at hindi ito dahil masama silang tao — kundi dahil may sarili silang timeline
sana yung mga taong galit na galit sa konsepto ng "choice" ay matutong makinig
choice is not evil
choice is freedom
and freedom is humanity
sana maging wake-up call itong pelikula na ang kababaihan ay hindi lang tagapagdala ng buhay — may mga buhay din silang gustong buuin para sa sarili nila
at kung alam nila sa puso nila na hindi pa sila handa, hindi natin sila dapat pilitin
hindi natin sila dapat husgahan
hindi natin sila dapat ipako sa krus
punyeta talaga ang sistema, pero hindi ibig sabihin wala na tayong magagawa

Mahal na mahal kita, Sunshine

“the filipino women and the curse of catholic guilt” despite popular western belief where early stages of pregnancy are just lump of cells and does not count as a human being, this is where pro-choice comes in and protest women’s autonomy through the lens of science
in our nation this is not a strong argument as this doesn’t penetrate the teachings of the catholic/christian church where flesh is flesh and the act of aborting a lump of cells is murder

now this is where sunshine and the jojo rabbitesque kid brave depiction contradicts with the filipino pro-life argument “future president” and the what ifs of the future child, despite some view this representation as counter productive it actually stands for how much catholic guilt and patriarchal values is imbued from the moment we are born, that’s why no matter how we view ourselves as progressive, modern, and forward, the filipino women still struggle with their autonomy over their body and choices where they face at the mercy of unwanted consequences

that’s why i admire how brave “sunshine” depict the lump of cells as a hallucinatory unborn child where it grounds how filipino culture views it and turns it as a film creative force to show how women no matter the circumstance should have complete autonomy over their body, not in an overly liberal way where everything is muddled in the gray area but as an acceptance that we live in a society where women are still tied to patriarchal reproductive roles and system wherein we disguise feminist liberalism as matriarchal
with abortion still illegal in our country, teenage and unplanned pregnancy a national problem, and contraceptives a taboo subject

this is a film that offers understanding, empathy, and compassion to sunshines out there that are resorting to unsafe, life threatening, and “illegal” ways that society calls bad choices but what is “bad” when it is the only choice they have

lastly i cannot complete this write up without mentioning the lino brocka, i love how it shows manila as a character with its noise, chaos, and decay through the familiar seams of avenida and quiapo with its religious interplay of choice (accessibility to unsafe preganancy pills) and solace of a religious power it holds
maris racal stellar performance will forever hold her in the filipino cinema history as sunshine, as how nora aunor is bona, and hilda koronel is insiang
i really really hope more people watch this and be a strong catalyst of change for reproductive rights as it is core a healthcare and human rights

Now let’s talk about the performances
First sequence pa lang, it’s apparent that Maris Racal studied the role
Inakap niya at binigyan niya ng kaluluwa yung karakter
Hindi siya bumitaw hanggang final sequence
She had a lot of silent moments in the film and those were the most powerful
Nakakabingi yung katahimikan na halos hinahabol ko na rin yung hininga ko minsan
Jennica Garcia’s character, on the other hand, though it’s just a supporting role, is one of the main highlights throughout
Yung kahit minimal lang yung dialogues niya, tignan mo lang siya sa mga mata niya, maiintindihan mo sya

Your role as an audience member is to listen
The rest is for you to reflect upon on your own

” — tears
almost immediately
a lot of issues were tackled so gracefully and with sensitivity in this film, whilst not necessarily favoring any particular side
the scene where sunshine asks for forgiveness at quiapo church, the same church where she was desperate to find abortion methods, shows how two conflicting views on abortion can be felt at once
also liked how it depicted the pressure of being an athlete, of maintaining your weight, and of the unrelenting need to train despite your life pretty much falling apart

if there’s anything i want to praise, it’s the way the film portrayed the role of women supporting one another, from the protagonist, her sister, her coach, the doctor, down to the innkeeper that rushed her to the hospital

the worst takes in this film were from men (no surprise there) who didn’t even bother asking sunshine how she felt (because in our incredibly conservative & patriarchal society, women are nothing more than their childbearing abilities lmao)
ultimately, the only valid opinions on a woman’s body & whether or not she should undergo abortion should be hers & hers alone

Gift of God
“Naiintindihan mo na ba ‘ko
”“Gets ko na
”i grew up in a somehow conservative and very religious household
i was taught by my elders that abortion is murder
full stop — that no reason could ever justify the taking of a “human life
”i never questioned this belief
until i grew up and learned about the social conditions that surround my imperfect — almost dysfunctional — family
dumating na sa punto na palagi ko nang tinatanong kung bakit nga ba pinili pa akong ipanganak ng nanay ko
tinawag ko ang sarili ko na isang kasalanan
isang aksidente, hindi sinasadya
eventually, i started to question my own views
my mother didn’t have a choice
but what if she did
what if her religion did not instill fear onto her — did not make her choose between her dream of living in the US and…me
what if she was given the right to make autonomous decisions for her own body and for herself
the importance of the sanctity of life has long been asserted in, what seems to be, an unending discussion on the controversial topic of abortion
these endless queries led me to enlightening myself to a greater picture of things
THAT criminalizing abortion is a NEGLECT to women’s rights
up until this day, women’s health and bodies have been continuously politicized by society
bago natin ituring na isang krimen ang abortion, we first need to view this on a sociopolitical lens
bakit nga ba maraming mga babae ang nagpapalaglag
what i loved about this film is how it portrayed Sunshine’s story in the most raw and harshest way possible
direk jadaone, a WOMAN director (yes kailangan iempahsize to), saw Sunshine as a human being — a young woman who FEELS, who DREAMS big for herself
not as a criminal but as a real woman with real human flesh with the right to her own life
even Manila didn’t feel like a foreign place as a Batangueña
the entire film was real, we were all living in the same society as Sunshine’s
hindi ito pawang fiction lang
totoo si Sunshine
she is every young woman who had to choose between herself and a life she does not want for herself
she is also every young mom who had to choose between the same things
she is every young woman who is held back by what today’s society deems as morally upright based on outdated religious doctrines
she is every young woman who was denied proper healthcare, every young woman who was denied their choices and rights
she is every young woman who was neglected by a corrupt system that politicizes on women’s health and bodies
thank you, direk jadaone for introducing us to Sunshine
and to my mother, i hope you know that i would’ve understood you the same way Bata understood Sunshine

i sat at the best seat in the cinema (in the middle
) and love how tastefully beautiful it is visually and sound wisethe visuals remind me of lino brocka + tsai ming liang meets in quiapo, manila
the place itself becomes a character, those shots of sunshine wandering through the urban chaos tell us so much
especially that scene in the cheap hotel near morayta, when the train passes by and it’s like the city is holding her pain, witnessing everything, maybe even screaming alongside her
the way they use sound here is incredible, and almost throughout the film too, like the noise (and sunshine trying to ‘drown’ them out) becomes part of her headspace, you know
the city breathes with her loneliness

the city is even ‘her’though i find the jojo rabbit inspiration kinda out of place with what the movie already has going for it, maybe it’s just jadaone’s style of directing, trying to move away from brocka’s straight realism into something more surreal, but it doesn’t really work for me since this story needs that grounded feel
still, i appreciate that they didn’t just simplify everything
i personally think films should capture the messy (nuance
) when dealing with complex topic like thisbut overall i think this is really tight and visually gorgeous
my favorite part is when sunshine just whacks that creep with the suitcase
what an improvement from her previous film where the character just called the police lol
this is how you try to attempt a feminist lens in a movie, especially this one, the character arc trying to ‘break’ from the ‘setup’ of the reality they are set in
like them trying to pull a fourth wall break, but internally, if that makes sense

Aspiring Olympian Sunshine's (Maris Racal) world suddenly turned upside down after she realizes that she is pregnant
This is by far the most beautiful and bravest Filipino film I've watched
There is an important topic that needs to be discussed after watching the film
And we need to sit down and talk about it
Loved the whole technical aspect of the show
Cinematography was on point (go Pao
The gritty Quiapo was a whole character in itself
The bustling city echoes the fear and confusion in Sunshine's mind, yet amidst all the chaos - she is alone
Rico Blanco's music radiated organically throughout the film
Both silent and scored scenes touched feelings and intensified emotions
Maris Racal cemented her status as one of the great actors of her generation
No need to look pretty as long as she delivers the right emotions that her character calls for
And damn, Jennica Garcia
She fuckin' deserves an award
Take it, take it
Especially that last scene (spoiler ahead
) where she's the only one who's crying among the cheering crowd
My heart tore to pieces
Special mention to Annika Co who amused me with her natural acting chops
For a kid to deliver that, she's definitely a hot talent to watch out for
And of course, Direk Tonet
Been a fan of Antoinette Jadaone since That Thing Called Tadhana (and yeah, as a ka-eme, AWKP) and damn she really is one strong voice in this industry
Her writing, strengthened by her directing, sends out a clear message to her audience
Sunshine is an example - subtle yet painfully direct in one
After the 7pm screening in SM North last Monday, she came to answer a few questions and what struck me the most is her sharing about her most favorite part of writing - REVISING
For a professional writer like her, it is very humbling and inspiring to hear that
And her body of work definitely shows how great they are due to the notes, lessons and heart she puts to her stories

Seen @SM North EDSA Cinema 6 w/Post-Show Q&A and Pagpag Session w/Direk Antoinette Jadaone FANTASTIC SUNSHINE 2/2“Gets ko na
” I still recall that time back in high school when we were taught the morality of abortion in Religion class

I was a scholar at a conservative Catholic all-boys school, and although I wasn’t religious (nor did I ever practice Catholicism on paper), its discussions almost shaped my beliefs on the subject matter
What I did not know was that those beliefs were tied with several factors besides religion such as patriarchy and conservatism
That was before the pandemic, and since then, my viewpoints have stirred away from every close-minded and male-led influence those so-called teachings had
Yet, I still find it unfair that I don’t have to go through those experiences that women go through in this patriarchal society, including that of Sunshine
Critics were not kidding about the Lino Brocka comparisons to Sunshine, yet this has that unique female perspective that elevates its authenticity
The film is straight-forward, and in doing so, it is raw, visceral, and brutally honest
It takes its viewers through an experience rather than dictate or spoonfeed, and it rarely shies away from its reality

From the milieu alone — from the shitty healthcare system, to the sheer lack of contraceptives (if you could find them, they’re very expensive), ignorant, privileged boyfriend, and to the conservative religious doctors and rapist relatives — we are already shown that this is not a world suitable for Sunshine and for women like her who are struck with unwanted pregnancies
Because that’s the truth of our nation
Because this is not a country that favors the oppressed

As the famous saying goes, “Mahirap maging babae, pero mas mahirap maging babae sa Pilipinas,” (“It’s impossible to be a woman, but it’s more impossible to be a woman living in the Philippines,”) and that couldn’t be reflected better in this film
Sunshine seeks to reclaim autonomy over her own body, which every woman deserves so but is seldom granted that right
Despite the latter being true, we still see Sunshine do everything she could to get that abortion, even if it means having to spend an unreasonable amount of money just to do so
Some may say that her story is inspiring, but it’s tragic how inspiration is confused with disturbance
This is a story that’s supposed to shed light on the fact of the matter because this is one of many issues in the country that have to be addressed, especially within our own government
Even its production design and cinematography that go hand-in-hand highlight how constrictive this place is for those who are forced to go through such uncomfortable, unasked experiences
Much of the film’s raw emotions would not have been as impactful without Maris Racal
Her acting and performance here are simply generational and incomparable
She may be known for her more comedic roles (and pure wit and vibes in interviews), but her role of Sunshine brings out her more vulnerable side that is just as raw as the attitude of the film itself
Among the more underrated performances is Jennica Garcia, who levels up with Maris Racal’s natural performance but brings a distinct, yet supportive dynamic
Child actor Annika is also great and is secretly the one who makes some of the more emotional scenes, especially those towards the end, work so well
In addition, Meryll Soriano stands out, as do Elijah Canlas, Rhed Bustamante, Xyriel Manabat, Piolo Pascual, and Angeli Bayani – even if the latter two only show up in one scene each

Some ongoing debate had sparked since its release here with regards to the weaving of the children subplot into the story, and while it did have its risks, for better or worse, it still cannot be disregarded how brave Antoinette Jadaone and Maris Racal are for telling this kind of story
Perhaps it could have been subtler, but in a country like ours, it was necessary to have been told through a more straightforward direction without being too preachy
There have been a handful of films out there that tackle abortion and unwanted pregnancies, but what makes Sunshine stand out is the mere fact that it is set in the Philippines

We are one of the last few countries to have abortion illegal as we are rooted in traditions influenced by the patriarchy and religion that treat it as an immoral, evil doing and as a taboo simply because, to them, the youth are “being irresponsible

” Sunshine never puts the blame on its titular character for its consequential catalyst, and through its depiction of such a life in this country, instead, asks us to question our reality: Did the youth fail us for exploring a natural part of ourselves, or did the adults fail them by placing and enabling all these barriers as mere punishment substituted by the words of “a lesson” or “a teaching”

That’s what makes Sunshine scary: The simple fact that it’s set in the Philippines; that women with unwanted pregnancies have to navigate through these stupid barriers, but it also ends with hope for a better future where women are allowed to make choices for their own body
In fact, we must also be reminded of this saying: “No uterus, no opinion
” Such a timely film that is raw and honest with its sensitive topic that must be talked about because so many women have had experiences like that of Sunshine
Seeing this at one of the many screenings with Q&A and audience sharing truly added to its communal experience

Direk Tonet always mentions how the film is no longer hers but ours now that we have seen it, and you could clearly see and feel it as the credits rolled, with some women opening up about once being a Sunshine or their parents giving birth to them at such an early age
It reminds you that those experiences are real and are still happening to other women underground up to now

It’s also amazing to see an eye-opening drama such as this fill up the theaters more than it did for Fantastic Four (which made for such a whiplash of a double-feature for me because it tackles the opposite theme to Sunshine)
It goes without saying that those who say that Philippine Cinema is nothing compared to Hollywood films should shut up and watch this in cinemas

Oh, and legalize and decriminalize abortion in the Philippines now

“gets ko na
I have always disliked how people compare other Filipino cities to Metro Manila, specifically Cebu City
Because they always go for the most shallow differences and often time the most hypocritical
Every city in the Philippines, and for the most part the world, has traffic, hot weather, trashy streets, muggers, and poor air quality, not just Metro Manila
This frustrates me because there IS a tangible difference between Manila and other cities, it's just that a city's identity is more spiritual in essence

The churches in Cebu City won't have vendors selling abortion pills, nor will doctors in Davao City berate you moments after caring for you after you nearly died from an attempted abortion, but in Manila they do
It's a city of people getting by, it's why you go to Manila, and a deep understanding among everyone that that's what they're all trying to do, just get by
Every year my favorite Filipino movie to come out pass by me until the next year, I think this is the first time that's changed

the film hits too close to home for me
sunshine is suffocating, and maybe that's a directorial choice
it hits in the most uncomfortable and painful parts of me at times
it resonates with every woman who has to determine a better choice out of two shitty choices: one that might shackle her freedom or one that may free her but haunt her at the same time
it makes you feel rage at systemic failures which birth a backward society that villifies women for their lapses of judgment--damned if they do, damned if they don't
sunshine is linear in its plot

it never really takes you out of sunshine's head, so you see how raw everything is, how immature she is, how she's desperate and breaking apart but trying to keep it together, and how she's just a kid who fucked up
the film works because of this approach, albeit some plot devices are too on the nose--making them iffy and questionable, and may have muddled the film's stance
there are obvious plot holes, little details that could have enriched the world-building were overlooked
some subplots lack depth, but the performances made me look past on these things, in a sense that it was pleasant enough to watch for me
not for everyone, but everyone should be part of the discussion
jadaone's films are usually hits-or-misses for me, but sunshine is one of her better ones
the message may be clear and hopeful, but real life presents a much darker truth: for most women, there are no olympics and dreams to hold on to
in reality, we still have a long way to go in paving for a more humane society for filipino women

here's to working towards a future where women are not shamed for reclaiming their agency, and where their indiscretions are not berated and ridiculed, but treated with proper education and compassion

" That moment broke me

"sunshine" delves deeply into prevalent social realities and dares to question long-standing traditional systems
but what struck me most was how it thoughtfully explored women’s bodily autonomy, weaving it into a narrative that felt both natural and unforced
the lead's inner turmoil exists in the gray areas—a subtle moral dilemma, especially when prioritizing autonomy challenges societal expectations
this raises critical questions: how does sunshine’s obligation to herself impact the broader community
and what roles do the people around her play in shaping or reinforcing these expectations

i honestly wished there was more screen time, yet in the moments it was given, it still managed to leave a profound message about women's reproductive rights—one that lingers and quietly settles in your mind

“Sunshine” tackles urgent and relevant issues that are at the core of the current public health system in the Philippines
The film confronts the alarming rise in teenage pregnancies, a problem often worsen by a lack of sex education
It bravely addresses women's rights to choose, challenging the patriarchy that continues to influence societal norms in the country
The film's powerful message is that women have the right to be anything they want to be
They should have the final say over their bodies, their dreams, their choices, and their lives
No one should ever dictate who they are or what they can become
"Sunshine" makes a compelling case that a woman's decisions are her own, and outside opinions, particularly from men, are irrelevant
It is a story that empowers women, giving them a VOICE to be HEARD and a presence to be SEEN
"Sunshine" is raw, relevant, and a catalyst for important conversations
It is not just a film; it is a reflection of the struggles faced by countless women
The movie fearlessly asks difficult questions and forces viewers to confront uncomfortable truths
It's a story that deserves to be discussed by everyone, because Sunshine is more than just a character—she is a symbol of HOPE and COURAGE
Maris Racal's portrayal of Sunshine is the best
She perfectly captures the reality of a woman's struggle and the immense difficulty of navigating life in this world
The supporting cast is equally remarkable
Jennica Garcia and Annika Co deliver powerful performances that are essential to the film's impact
Every cast in this film was remarkable
A big big thank you to Direk Tonet Jadaone for her bravery and boldness in telling this story
Your work is consistently admirable because you don't just make films; you spark meaningful conversations that resonate long after the credits roll

against the backdrop of the sticky, restless, and noisy streets of manila, Sunshine becomes a suffocating experience
a formidable display of how patriarchy is insidious
even the reactions of the women around sunshine are outcomes of its thinking, sometimes its intentional, sometimes unaware
the judgement and unsolicited advice are concealed as concern and even sunshine herself isn’t free from it
it is literally manifested as an imaginary child that echoes her guilt, pressure, and the moral burden thats placed upon her
There are moments where its subtexts are parallel to Ernaux’s memoir Happening, which is visceral in its honesty about seeking abortion in 60s France, a time where it was illegal there
But Sunshine is dangerously current

Abortion remains illegal in the country because religion and patriarchy is deeply etched that it is indistinguishable from moral law (yet pamparegla pills in quiapo sit on the same shelves as statues of the infant jesus and still our agency must somehow exist in conflict with holiness
) in the final act, Sunshine’s choice is physically expressed through a routine
her movements make it seem her body is being wrapped in ribbons, constricted and suffocating, but as she continues, the bindings are loosened and ultimately released
the film’s profundity lies in its portrayal of abortion not as something easy nor devoid of consequences
it is contradicting: physically and emotionally excruciating but undeniably life saving
I cried three times while watching Sunshine, and I cried the hardest during this particular scene
It’s when Pastor Jaime and Miggy visit Sunshine’s house to discuss her future

Instead of asking how Sunshine is feeling in that moment, Pastor Jaime immediately begins outlining plans like offering maternal and healthcare coverage for her and the baby, and even proposing an educational fund up to college for the child
This scene highlights another tragedy that women face in a patriarchal society

Sunshine is an important film—one that Filipinos shouldn’t miss
It’s not the strongest film, but it’s certainly worth discussing
In fact, it currently tops my list of Filipino movies this year
And that’s precisely why I feel a sense of disappointment
At the very least, I wish it had resonated more deeply
It had the potential to delve further into its realism, but instead, it chose to spoon-feed every emotional beat, leaving little room for quiet reflection
While I understand why Jadaone took this direction, I can’t say it worked for me
Personally, I wasn’t fully sold on the use of children as a narrative device
The way the film delivers its message too overtly makes the subplot involving the 13-year-old feel disconnected and distracting
The child character might have been more effective as a symbolic presence, her inner voice, her conscience
Had it stayed that way, rather than taking the more problematic route of literally giving life to unborn children, as in Ariana’s case, the film might have delivered a far more powerful impact
Still, there was a moment near the end, a line that marked a turning point of understanding and acceptance, where freedom was finally felt from guilt
That scene alone earned the film a 9 out of 10 from me
