The OB admitting section was, and still is, one of the busiest parts of the hospital I worked in as an intern
It had been renovated prior to my first duty there, and it would be renovated once again after I'd left
Both of those renovations were done in part to address a persistent issue: that the place never runs out of patients
Every day, and especially on Mondays and Fridays, the admitting section would take in a significant number of expectant mothers with all sorts of conditions
Some would be giving birth for the first time
Some were veterans who were familiar to the staff working there, giving birth like clockwork every year
Some had serious conditions alongside their pregnancies that made giving birth extremely complicated, to the point where their current state posed a significant risk for death while giving birth
Nevertheless, they would slowly fill up the adjacent labor and delivery room, often two to three mothers to a stretcher
On very busy days the stretchers would run out, and the labor room would be filled with mothers settling down wherever they could, mostly on the cold, tiled floor

I remembered those days in the admitting section when I saw Antoinette Jadaone's latest film, Sunshine, about a young gymnast (Maris Racal) who gets pregnant right before a very important event that might lead to the SEA games and eventually the Olympics
Sunshine doesn't have any qualms about making the decision as she immediately gets to work trying to find an abortifacient to terminate the unwanted pregnancy
This process is not made easy
Miggy (Elijah Canlas), the man who impregnated Sunshine, wants nothing to do with her after learning of her pregnancy
He doesn't even tell her to have an abortion directly, only saying that 'she knows what to do

' Getting medical help is equally difficult, and intersects gender with class: medical treatment is expensive (despite the fact that state sponsored healthcare should be financially accessible) and as abortion is still illegal in the Philippines, people resort to black markets to seek the care they need
Once in a while, the OB admitting section will receive a patient who has lost her child
Miscarriages are common, and often they are spontaneous
Once, a mother of a stillborn child asked me if the cries in the next room were her child's, when I knew the infant was lying in a box, ready to be given to back to their parents
Then there are the other kinds of patients, ones who made a choice like Sunshine
They all had their reasons; this was a conscious and informed decision
After a while you know it when they come in
Sometimes the doctor would come in and tell them that what they did was illegal, some would even threaten to call the police
Nothing ever came of it; they were empty threats - often to 'scare' them into not making that decision again
It always made me uncomfortable
To be born a woman is to be born into violence, into a world where the odds are stacked against you
Sunshine is not the first film to depict this violence - films like Rae Red's Babae at Baril (2019) and Jadaone's own Fan Girl (2020) are two examples

They show what a deeply patriarchal society creates: people like Miggy and a certain other character near the end, people who I interpreted as not exactly archetypal or allegorical towards the structures that created them, but as the inevitable products of it
But unlike those two films that I mentioned earlier, Sunshine feels far more indignant, full of anger that Fan Girl lacked, and drawing towards a different conclusion compared to Babae at Baril
Quiapo has been a backdrop for many a Filipino film, and here it is a sanctuary of sorts
It is here where Sunshine goes to find the solution to her problems
Ironically draped in religious imagery, it both embodies the faith it represents (as a source of refuge for those who are in need) and as something that stands against its tenets
Sunshine is a film about choices: the choice to live one's own dream, the choice to live freely as the best person you can be
Sunshine's sister Geleen (Jennica Garcia) coaches Sunshine as she practices in their shared home
Certain background elements (thanks to the film's excellent production design) hint that Geleen, too, was once an aspiring gymnast, whose dreams ended with a baby
If she had the choice, would she have lived a different life
It shows as well in Geleen's character, and Garcia gives a standout performance as her
Finally, that idea of "refuge" may not refer to Quiapo, but something else entirely
Throughout the film there are many people, both seen and unseen, who help Sunshine in her quest
"Ipagdadasal ko kayo," a hilot tells Sunshine after they bring a child to the hospital who made the same choice
"Mag-ingat ka," another one tells Sunshine as she sets off
A sympathetic medical professional gives a knowing look
Every doctor has a story like it: in one of my last rotations at the labor room, a patient walked in nervously in the robe the hospital supplied her
It was a very busy day, and pregnant women overflowed on the stretchers and sat on the floor
She had no business being here: she looked no older than 14, and she should be going to school and playing with friends, not in the last stages of giving birth
Suffice it to say, this pregnancy was not her choice
If she had the choice like Sunshine did, would she be here
On the other hand, the point of the film for me is not whether one makes one choice over the other, but that people like Sunshine and that kid has the ability to choose in the first place
Because the labor and delivery room should be semi-sterile, companions (in this case, the kid's very worried mother) are not allowed in
But the rest of the mothers in that labor room heard us taking the medical history and heard her story
The other expectant mothers gave the kid their blankets, talked to and comforted her, up until she gave birth
Everyone was that kid's mother that day
In a world where you are denied agency, where one is subjected to violence from birth, the least women can do is find refuge in each other

Maris and the rest of the cast were perfectly chosen for the film, with each character making a meaningful contribution to the plot
Maliban sa acting and galing galing din ni maris sa mismong mga gymnast performances niya
To be honest, I initially found Sunshine disturbing and lacking in many parts
It felt like the film held back, especially in its screenplay and pacing
But as I reflected more on it, I realized that might have been the point—although many of the scenes were commendably filmed, the film wasn’t trying to entertain; it was trying to confront
Maliban sa mismong tema ng storya, sobrang daming iba pang paghihirap na danas ng lipunan natin na mismo ako ay hindi aware ang naipakita sa pelikula
The rawness and silence I initially perceived as weaknesses were actually reflections of Sunshine herself—caught between the pressures of gymnastics and the weight of her misfortunes
In that light, I came to see that her quietness was powerful and already served as the message

The film was created not just to tell Sunshine’s story, but to help us recognize the many "Sunshines" around us—especially in the Philippines, where abortion remains heavily stigmatized due to political control and religious conservatism
Sunshine challenges us to understand their pain and see their urgent need for help
I truly hope that someday, those in power will recognize that safe and legal abortion is not just a debate—it’s a right every Filipina deserves to have

Sunshine fue una experiencia bastante sorprendente dentro del contexto del cine mainstream filipino moderno

Saliéndose del margen seguro y cómodo que tiene acostumbradas a las masas a la complacencia social retratada en un romanticismo casi cínico de la pobreza y la glorificación del poder y la influencia, además de la necesidad por rectitud religiosa

La cinta, desarrollándose sin teatralidad ni grandes despliegues telenoveleros de drama, entiende perfectamente que la sobriedad y sequedad de la realidad filipina de la clase baja no necesita endulzantes para trabajar de manera efectiva y cortante en pantalla

La cinematografía es excelente, el ritmo es perfecto y las tomas se toman todo el tiempo necesario para declarar visualmente sus ideas, además de que la dirección si bien denota algunos rastros y pequeños momentos de la desconexión farandulera moderna del voyerismo cínico que nos fuerza a sentir lastima por la pobreza, no cae totalmente en ello, demostrando mucha fuerza y entendimiento la gran parte del tiempo

sunshine explored important and sensitive topics that are not only necessary for filipino audience to see but also essential to open dialogues and conversations, to shed light on and ultimately to spark change especially on things that are often labeled as taboo in a conservative and retrogressive country like the philippines
the film does not impose, it only depicts the struggles of the character
it shows her grit, resilience and her power to decide for herself
sunshine is a beautiful portrayal of a woman’s ability to choose and her autonomy to determine her fate
despite the living ironies she’s confronted with, she remains hopeful, that she could still follow her dreams and that she could rule over her life against all odds
she doesn’t have to conform

sunshine does not necessarily promote pre-marital sex or abortion
it goes beyond issues of healthcare and reproductive health
it advocates empathy and compassion to the sunshines of the world
it allows us to understand the complexities and the silent pains and plights women go through and why there’s a need for them to have access to safe and equitable options

set the scene
modern-day manila, a city equally bound by the abundance of opportunity as it is bound by the abundance of consequence
sunshine is a dreamer tied to the goal of becoming an olympian
she is told to drown out the noise while she lives a life enclosed by it
she gets pregnant by a good for nothing conyo elijah canlas and is told that her poverty-stricken ass should carry the burden of aborting the baby

and of all places, she finds herself in quiapo, manila’s catholic landmark, praying to Jesus as she repeatedly journeys through the downtown in her search for the most effective pills while surrounded by statues of Mary, her conscience carrying the loudest whispers that deem her a murderer, echoed by the church she sought forgiveness in—and the very God she prays to
there exists an assumption about the matriarchal philippines, a country that holds its female sensibilities to the highest regard in the same way it adores Mary

yet as we are exposed to our society’s deepest cancers, the mask of matriarchy only rings true for as long as it submits to the role of patriarchy and as a result, we are a nation of contradictions because of this reality
only in the philippines you can see a catholic girl pocketing abortion pills in a church
sunshine is no Mary, and manila is no matriarchy
her conscience rides through a push and pull with the conservative ideals she was brought upon
her best friend briefly ditches her out of familial pressure
her ex’s family (hi papa p) barges in their house to own up to the mistake
sunshine’s life is filled to the brim with contradiction

in spite of this, even with her lack of maturity and the ever-so demanding backdrop of a patriarchal manila, there remains glimmers of hope, her own thriving matriarchy within the small space she can truly call her own
an environment not bound by fluctuating contradiction, but by the permanence of choice
Generational performance from Maris Racal, beyond proud to have her and this film representing our country on the world stage

"Ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya
" This line, spoken by the child, sums up the entire film
It’s simple, heartfelt, and my favorite line
People may have their own interpretations, but this is how I personally understood it
Sunshine has an older sister, Ate Geleen, played by Jennica Garcia
Ate Geleen was once a gymnast, just like Sunshine
But now, she takes care of her child
The film doesn’t say it outright, but it’s clear that Ate Geleen gave up her dreams and career to raise her baby
Why did she give it all up
We don't know
But maybe it’s because she’s the eldest daughter — the one expected to take care of her siblings, the one who is supposed to work harder, sacrifice more, and carry the heaviest weight
Mahirap maging babae, lalo na kung ikaw ang panganay na anak ng pamilya
Maybe that’s also the very reason why she’s so supportive of Sunshine’s decision — to have an abortion, to chase her dreams, and to not follow in her footsteps
Ate Geleen knows exactly what it’s like to give up everything, and she doesn’t want her younger sister to carry the same burden she did
The movie ended with Ate Geleen proudly looking at Sunshine while holding her baby
Dahil ang pangarap ni Sunshine ay siya ring pangarap ni Ate Geleen na hindi niya natupad

let me just say na MARIS RACAL IS SUCH AN AMAZING ACTRESS
totoong haggard nga siya (lol), pero ‘yung haggardness niya, that actually added to everything
you can see the pain, the exhaustion, and the heaviness in every scene—it all felt so real
grabe, nakakamangha talaga siyang panoorin
sobrang husay niya, and because of that, sunshine didn’t feel like a film at all—it felt like someone letting you into her world
it felt like sunshine was sitting beside me, telling her story, and all i could do was listen and feel everything
from the very beginning, klaro na kay sunshine kung ano ang gusto niya
hindi ang maging nanay, kundi ang makasali sa Philippines' national gymnastics team
but the world she lives in kept pushing her into a corner
this film tackled more than just abortion—it exposed how cruel the system is to women, lalo na sa pilipinas
it showed the weight of religious beliefs forced onto our bodies, the cycle of abuse, and the daily injustices women face just for existing
napakahirap maging babae sa pilipinas tangina
lahat ng lalaki sa pelikula—si miggy, 'yung tito ni menggay, si tatay ni miggy, pati ‘yung doktor—lahat sila, galit na galit ako
bakit babae lagi ang kailangang mag-sakripisyo
bakit babae ang kailangang mag-adjust, magpatawad, magtiis
putangina talaga
and yet, these characters weren’t exaggerated
they were too real
which makes it even more terrifying—kasi alam nating totoo ‘to
it happens
it’s still happening
what haunted me most were menggay’s scenes
dun talaga ako tuluyang naiyak
ang sakit sakit
gusto ko siyang yakapin, gusto ko siyang ipagtanggol
bata pa lang siya pero pasan na niya 'yung bigat ng mundong hindi naman niya kasalanan
sana sa lahat ng menggay, may sunshine sa buhay nila
and then there was anikka
nung una, akala ko multo siya o guni-guni lang
pero habang tumatagal, i realized—she was sunshine’s imaginary child
or maybe her younger self
or both
she represents so much: a lost dream, a piece of sunshine
kaya ‘yung eksena sa dulo, when anikka said “gets ko na,” it wasn’t just her talking—it was also sunshine finally accepting her own decision
grabe ‘yung iyak ko dun
that should be enough
a woman’s choice should be enough
the film also showed that women, at our best, are each other’s safe space
si coach, si doktora, yung kaibigan, most especially ‘yung ate niya—lahat sila, may dalang simpatya
yung presence nila nagsasabing “nandito ako
” yung scene na tumabi yung ate niya sa higaan sobrang nakakalungkot panoorin
it reminded me that the first place we should feel supported is at home
buti na lang at nandiyan ang ate ni sunshine dahil minsan sapat na ‘yung maramdaman mong hindi ka nag-iisasunshine isn’t just a movie
it’s a wake-up call
it asks us to reflect—bakit tayo mabilis humusga
bakit kulang ang pag-unawa
and most of all, bakit kailangang maging matatag ang babae para lang mabuhay nang payapa
sunshine is a beautiful, heartbreaking, and necessary film
hindi lang siya basta panoorin
kailangan mo siyang damdamin

gets ko naSo many still don’t understand, but it’s enough that some do
This film is brave—fearlessly made, carefully thought out, and clearly crafted from the heart
When I watched it, all I wanted to do was hold Sunshine—hold every Sunshine out there who I know is carrying the weight of this harsh, terrifying society
I still can’t get over the fact that this was shown in Philippine cinemas because, finally, it got the visibility it truly deserves
This is the kind of film the world should see

When I finished watching it, I already knew the state and how our society would portray abortion and how it was always deemed evil and inhumane but after seeing this film, I felt a sense of relief that finally, a film about women, about abortion, about its effects, not just mentally but physically, and how sometimes, we really just have to understand, for who are we to judge someone who really is just fighting to live through and view women in a way that they should be, respected
Even the supporting characters—especially Jennica Garcia—were brilliant
I felt her love for her sister so deeply

Even when Sunshine thought the world had turned its back on her, her sister’s presence was a constant reminder that someone was still there, always beside her, fully aware of the struggles she faced—struggles made heavier because she’s a woman
Also a huge role that was portrayed by Rhed Bustamante
Just, wow
It was a story meant to be told and written
It isn't just fiction it's currently happening today and that's why it should be a story that needed to be shed light on
It was tragic, painful to look at but it was real, all of it, and that's what makes it a story worth telling
And Maris Racal—what a phenomenal actress
Her cries pierce right through you
Her frustration, her courage, her strength as a woman—all of it shines through
In Sunshine, I saw her desperation, her bravery, her womanhood, and her relentless grasp on her dreams, refusing to let them slip away
Maris and Direk Tonet knew exactly what they wanted to tell their audience, and I’m so glad they did it with such courage
They gave voice to women like Sunshine—women who are still too afraid to scream their truths
I hope this film becomes a beacon for people like Sunshine, the way she brings life to every twirl of her ribbon and every movement of her body to the rhythm
There are so many like her still hidden in the shadows of fear and guilt
And yes, we all know that in the Philippines, some mindsets are hard to change—but does it have to stop there
Will we allow people like Sunshine to remain caged by a judgmental society
Maybe for now, it’s hard
But because of this film, women like Sunshine can finally catch a glimpse of hope

Start of my love for Philippine cinema this 2025
Honestly, 3
5 stars for the movie overall, but here's extra 0
5 star for the super random cameo that was also somehow super on the nose
It's such a good bit that amuses me to no end
I'd rate the movie higher if not for a plot device that felt completely unnecessary and at times distracting
Take it away, and it won't even change anything about the movie
Every time they employed this plot device, it was just so unnecessary and distracting
The movie also squeezed in too many "unwanted pregnancy" tropes that it risked being too bloated story-wise
Think of an "unwanted pregancy" trope, it's there

They stop short of it being too bloated at the expense of the story (and you have to give it to Antoinette Jadaone for this balancing act), though I still spent a good chunk of the movie wondering how many more tropes were coming
Still the movie is brave, and is made so much better for its bravery
It does not shy away from the realities faced by so many women in this country when it comes to maternal health
It tackled head-on the heavily religious overtones that tends to dominate the conversations around this topic
It shows the ironic juxtaposition of abortion pills being sold next to religious artifacts
But most importantly, it does not get preachy
It does not feel like it is patronizing the audience about what should be in each scene that squeezes your heart, it just shows it
But also Jennica Garcia steals the show in every scene is in
Maris Racal deserves the accolades she's getting for carrying the movie so steadily as its lead and with everything asked of her for the character
But Jennica Garcia just commands every scene even she doesn't say a word
And every scene these two have together was really gold-medal worthy
powerful and rawmaris and the entire team did an incredible job

if this shares anything with films from ph cinema's golden age, it is a strong thesis statement about manila
a lot has changed since we have moved from one marcos to another, but the power sunshine holds is to choose the one thing that has endured -- belief
driven by ambition, comforted but oppressed by religion, and deceived by folk medicine, sunshine's situation is a product of the convictions of those around her
fact and fiction are difficult to distinguish from her perspective
whether the effectivity of unregulated medication or the potential of an unborn child, a pregnant woman has to deal with the gradient of reality that is muddled by a conservative environment
importantly, sunshine is not a product of circumstance, but an active agent in negotiating her place amid all of it
i have my gripes with the main plot device of her possible unborn children, but i also feel open to interpretations that explain them
this is going to be an important filipino film and its artistry is probably secondary to how it might change views
“hindi sapat na ang babae ay maging ina lamang; dapat din siyang maging aktibong bahagi ng pagbabago ng lipunan
”Lualhati Bautistaas a huge believer in “only make art if you have something to say,” jadaone really has something to say
this movie is probably one of the most important filipino films ever made
the sad truth is, it does not exaggerate any details, this is simply the reality of our patriarchal society
but the film’s strength lies not only in its message but also in how it perfectly captures its setting

the movie itself is something that the majority of filipino filmmakers should study, a lino brocka-esque portrayal of the grit of manila: the familiar filipino home interiors, the choice of clothes, the 300 pesos motels, the guilt-tripping sermon from conservative boomers, the religious imagery
every detail, even the smalles rings true and is authentically filipino
this is something that elevates it far above many other modern filipino films
also,  ABORTION IS HEALTHCARE

i didn’t know na the simple “gets ko na” line will have me almost crying sa sinehan
oa na kung oa pero GETS NA GETS KO
it lands because the whole film builds up to it, this idea that women are constantly being misunderstood, questioned, doubted
and then one woman looks at another, sees her pain, and simply says, “gets ko na
” that’s the most powerful kind of solidarity
not saving someone
not preaching to them
just understanding them
the female relationships were the heart of it
hindi romantic love ang source of salvation dito
women helping women, women understanding women, yun ang lifeline ni sunshine
and that, to me, is what makes the movie not just brave, but also beautiful
one of the boldest things sunshine did was not moralize
a lesser film might’ve gone down the typical route— punishing the character for her sins, forcing her into regret, or ending with her back in the cycle of poverty because she “deserved” it
sunshine rejects that
it gives her space to want more, unapologetically
that is, in itself, revolutionary kasi sanay tayong makita ang kababaihan na laging martyr, laging nagpapaubaya, laging umiiyak sa ending habang umaandar ang jeep, but here
we get a girl who simply chooses her self
and that should never have to be a radical act but in our context, it is
because we glorify mothers, “ilaw ng tahanan,” “walang katulad ang pagmamahal ng ina”, pero the moment a woman says that she's not ready for the role, she’s shamed
our culture wants motherhood without giving women the right to choose it

It’s been a while since I last watched a movie alone
I actually asked my partner first if it was okay to watch Sunshine without him—he’s not really into Filipino films, and I totally respect that
But something about this movie pulled me in
And I’m glad I watched it
Sunshine shook me
It’s not just a film—it’s a mirror of what’s really happening around us
It hit hard, especially thinking about those who’ve gone through abuse—women, children, even the ones who never had the courage to speak up
Sure, there were a few funny scenes—maybe to ease the weight of the story—but the truth behind it stays
It’s heavy, it’s real, and it’s heartbreaking
We can’t just look away anymore
These kids and young women who’ve lived through this kind of nightmare… they need to be seen, heard, and protected
Because maybe—we are their last hope
And that means something

This film truly moved me—it powerfully portrays the harsh reality of the Philippines’ current stance on abortion
The line “gets ko na” struck me deeply; it’s both empowering and eye-opening
Every woman in the country should see this, as it sheds light on the difficult experiences many go through
The story is raw, relevant and it is worth talking about
It’s a bold feminist film that reminds us we all sunshine in our own unique ways and we continue to wait for sunshine
Every woman has the right to make decisions about her body and her future
Thank you so much, Direk Tonet, for creating this important piece

Sunshine sa Kuko ng MaynilaKasama ng mga pelikulang may “maynila” sa titulo na kamakailan ko lang napanood, bukod sa pagpupunit ng bandila ng konserbatibong paniniwala na nagmula sa kristiyanismo, pinapakita din ng Sunshine ang siyudad ng Maynila sa gabi—kung saan imbes na pag-asa, sumpa ang pangunahing kaluluwa na hinihinga’t tinitiis ng mga mamamayan

Sa labas ng simbahan makikita ang mga illegal na medesinang pampalaglag na nagsisilbi bilang pagasa para sa maraming kababaihan marahil ang institusyon sa harapan ng mga tindahang ito, ang simbahan, ang may kapangyarihan kahit na sabihing progresibo na ang mga paniniwala ng tao

Sa isang eksena, si Sunshine ay nagbuwis buhay sa isang masikip na motel sa Avenida, dala dala ang boteng pampalaglag, nagdudugo, nanghihingalo palabas habang patuloy ang pagtakbo ng LRT, at nagising nalang sa ospital, puno ng mga babaeng tinitiis ang hindi makataong pampublikong pasilidad
Halos 500 teenager ang nagiging ina araw araw
Kung legal lamang ang pagpapalaglag, ang mga numerong ito’y mababawasan
Isa sa may pinaka mabigat na istorya ay ang karakter ni Rhed Bustamante na si Menggay, isang 13 taong gulang na binuntis ng kaniyang tito
Kaniyang sinusundan si Sunshine at ibang mga babae, upang humingi ng pampalaglag
Nililibot niya ang Maynila na may tiyang di nararapat para sa isang dalaga
Tulad ni Sunshine, si Menggay ay pinadala rin sa ospital
Ngunit di natin siyang nakitang gumising
Ang pelikula ni Jadaone ay paniguradong titignan ng mga iskolar bilang “classic” makalipas ang ilang taon, tulad ng Manila by Night at Maynila Sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag
Isa sa mga susi ng pagtatagumpay ng storyang ito ay naiintindihan nito ang mga karakter na kinekwento bilang mga tao at hindi lamang teksto
Madaling tapusin ang mga pelikulang may realismo sa trahedya ngunit hindi pinili ni Jadaone ang direksyong iyon
Ang titulong “Sunshine” ay sumisimbolo rin sa diwa ng Pilipino—madalas masiyahin at nakakahanap pa rin ng ilaw sa madidilim na eskenita, matatatag (o resilient)
Dahil tayo’y kilala sa ganitong paraan, madali tayong abusuhin ng ating gobyerno
Labag raw sa batas ng diyos ang pagpapalaglag ng bata ngunit sa ganitong pagiisip, sa pagproprotekta ng mga hindi pa naisisilang, pinapatay ang ating mga kababaihan

Ngunit isa sa mga ipinakita sa pelikulang ito ay ang mga babae na nakikiramay kay Sunshine, kahit man ito’y makulit na bata, o kapatid na nagsilbing nanay, o kahit mga babae sa post maternal ward na nakakaintindi ng sakit na nadarama ng karakter ni Maris Racal at ang mga Sunshine sa Pilipinas

Mahaba pa ang magiging lakbay patungo sa bansang kayang tumanggap na isang karapatan ng babae ang awtonomiya ng kaniyang katawan, ngunit sa pelikulang ito, at sa pagdami ng mga manonood, nagkakaroon ng espayo upang magbukas ang mga usaping tinuturing “taboo”
tight hugs, for all of the sunshines out there

In every movie, I like to believe that there’s at least a little advocacy screaming through every minute
In this case, it’s the consideration of legalizing abortion in the Philippines
Maraming mga hindi kayang bumuhay ng anak, mga hindi kayang sustentahan ang isang tao, at mga taong sinamantala lamang
Even with these reasons, is it still not right to consider abortion
One might counter, “Pwede mo namang ipaalaga sa kamag-anak o sa mga magulang
” But the truth is: life is much more complex than that
It is so much more complicated because there are cases like this in real life, where the only family they have is their siblings
Some only have themselves
…Hays, basta abstinence talaga dapat guys

An eye-opener
This is Maris’ best
to live in a society where your most personal decisions are controlled by external forces and outdated structures… it’s exhausting
after watching the film today, i found myself deep in thought as i left the cinema
it was so real and raw
like, genuinely, an eye-opener
the film just beautifully, but also painfully, shows how interconnected everything is
your sex education, or lack thereof, impacts your healthcare system access, your personal moral compass, and of course, your dreams and your passion
it really hit home how incredibly hard it is to be a woman especially here in the philippines, with all our deeply ingrained religious beliefs, particularly around topics like abortion

it’s just so disheartening to hear all the harsh opinions and these strong pushes for anti-abortion laws, especially when they come from people who aren't personally dealing with those difficult, life-altering situations
it’s so easy for some to just state an anti-abortion stance, but the reality for a woman wrestling with such a complex decision is so much more nuanced and personal
you hear it all the time: choosing to terminate a pregnancy is selfish
but then i genuinely wonder, isn't it also selfish to bring a child into the world if you're not fully ready, or if you're uncertain about the future that motherhood brings
in a country that can be so conservative, we really, really need a broader, more compassionate discussion
we need to figure out how to support women and their choices, whatever they may be
not all women want to be mothers
not all women want to be impregnated
even i, personally, don't want to be a mother
and that's okay
it’s time we should be open to talking about these topics, really opening up our minds, and stop letting our religious beliefs completely go into our way of empathy and understanding
this movie just amplified that for me
ang galing galing mo, maris

an anecdote that nobody asked for: i vividly remember my sixth grade homeroom class, sinabihan kami ng adviser namin na mali magpalaglag, kasi “hindi mo matatama ang isang pagkakamali sa paggawa ng isa pang pagkakamali”
it’s been engrained in our heads and taught to us that abortion is wrong
i didn’t even have the time back then to question it kasi ‘yun yung sinasabi ng lahat ng adults around me, and eto na yung tinuturo sa atin even at a young age
having a film like Sunshine is so important, it sparks a conversation that we couldn’t have before because it was such a taboo topic

pati nung tinabihan ni jennica si maris sa kama, the sisterly bond was something i didn’t see coming kuhang kuha talaga ako watched this in cinemas with my tita, who’s like a mother to me
it meant a lot that i got to experience it with her :)

although i already knew what the premise of the movie was, sobrang emotional pa rin nung dating nung intro sakin
it opened with Sunshine performing her gymnastics routine almost flawlessly tapos maya-maya, it was immediately revealed that she was pregnant
knowing all this beforehand didn't lessen the impact of the intro scene for me - my heart broke for her all the same
living in an extremely conservative country with an extremely poor healthcare system is a nightmare especially for people like Sunshine
where the only choices are to carry on with the pregnancy or risk going through an unsafe abortion - she will get judged either way
another thing that i liked was the kid's character
she can be interpreted in many ways - some say she is Sunshine's what if but i interpreted her as Sunshine's conscience
in the early parts of the movie, she was discouraging Sunshine from going through with her plan but eventually came at peace with Sunshine's decisions by the end of the movie
for me, she was also a manifestation of Catholic guilt - something that most of us carry since we grew up in a religious country
the things she says to Sunshine is exactly the kind of thoughts you would think of when deciding on something that is against the principles you grew up with

surely, this movie will become something that starts a discussion on the sensitive topics it tackled - para sa mga taong nagdadawang-isip pa sa pagiging pro-choice, sa mga taong sinsubukang intindihin yung mga pro-choice, at para sa mga taong katulad ni Sunshine

“Saan ka pupunta
”—Di ko alam
“Mahirap ’yan
Tumatakbo at hindi alam kung saan ang pupuntahan
”These words pierce through the screen because they echo the confusion and helplessness felt by so many young women who were never taught what to do, only what not to become

The film refuses to sensationalize and instead, it exposes how a girl’s so-called mistake (often rooted not in her choices but in a partner’s negligence or acts of abuse) can lead to an avalanche of lost dreams, happiness, and possibility
Sunshine becomes every girl who was failed by sex education, every young woman silenced by stigma, and every teenager blamed instead of held
Running beneath the narrative is a critique of the Philippine healthcare system
Sunshine does not receive proper maternal support
She is not offered structured care, options, or safe counseling
Instead, she moves through her pregnancy in silence guided only by whispered advice, black market pills, and the cold gaze of people
Clinics do not offer refuge, hospitals feel clinical in the worst way
Emotionally vacant
Healthcare here is not healing but a trauma repackaged as procedure
What I find striking is how the film threads the idea of stigma into the structure itself
It’s the system
How fear, silence, and judgment strip away any chance for recovery, much less dignity
And this is where Sunshine dares to challenge its viewers
The existence of this movie forces a confrontation
Sunshine doesn’t preach, but it demands to be seen
It tells the story of a girl who chose herself
In a world that expected her to stop, she kept going, and that choice changed everything
“Naiintindihan mo na ba ako
”—Gets ko na
high school pregnancy, big dreams, and a whole future ahead

Definitely one of the most important Filipino films of this generation
Sunshine is a bold and compelling story about when passion collides with unforeseen circumstances
Delivering a powerful performance, Maris Racal gives light to Sunshine, a bright and hopeful teen gymnast whose Olympic dreams come crashing down after an unplanned pregnancy
While the film is beautiful aesthetically, it’s also dark and grim as it not only deals with a controversial subject matter, but is also an accurate reflection of Philippine culture and society
I love stories that involve moral dillemas — stories that make the character choose between two conflicting moral values
This is the case for Sunshine, whose choice is either to abort her baby to reach her Olympic dream, a goal she’s dreamt of in years; or keep the baby as this is deemed the morally right thing to do

Set in the Philippine context, one of the most religious countries in the world, that is one of the hardest dilemmas to have, and I thought the film gave justice to what Maris’ character had to go through
Maris deserves her props for this as well
She was an acting powerhouse, delivering and making the audience feel everything she was going through right out of the screen
It seemed like she trained legitimately for all the stunts, too
All these efforts made the film much more impactful and grounded
Visually, this is what I imagined the City of Manila is like on film
The city, while beautiful to look at, lying beneath it feels like a sense of grime and moral corruption, which blended well with the film’s theme
But aside from a couple of narrative choices made, I really liked this film
Sunshine, while beautiful, is also a haunting reminder of the everyday struggle of the common Filipino
A Filipino who has goals and dreams but is blindsided by forces beyond their control but chooses to push through
It’s an empowering film that I think will leave its mark for years to come
Every choice in cinematography, production, writing, etc
feels all so delicately planned together to build itself into a single cohesive message on the state of reproductive health in the Philippines

Even just the choice of Sunshine being a gymnast- a sport that is known to affect women's menstrual cycles, which explains why Sunshine didn't consider pregnancy in the first place- proves the care and attention direk Tonet placed on every aspect of the film
The ending however, did leave me to wish more in terms of understanding the aftermath of Sunshine's abortion
Filipino society's marites culture and religious evangelism no less is bound to have an effect on Sunshine's life and that was something I wished to see her persevere through post-abortion
but I do also respect the need to end Sunshine's story on a more hopeful note, as that message of sheer hope and optimism is probably more important than portraying an already familiar reality

For Every Woman (Para sa bawat Babae) It’s hard to fully grasp what women go through in our society, what more if you’re living in a country like the Philippines, where there aren’t enough laws to protect women’s rights
This movie is a wake-up call, an eye-opener, a voice for the voiceless women
It sheds light on major issues we often sweep under the rug like, sexual assault, teenage pregnancy, public healthcare, poverty, child abuse, and most especially, abortion
These are real, painful realities in the Philippines and we need to talk about them
We need tangible solutions
We need action from our government
As for the cast, whoever handled the casting, hats off
Every single actor in this film delivered
No weak links
Maris Racal completely embodied Sunshine
It wasn’t Maris I saw on screen, it was Sunshine
I know she’s getting a lot of praise for her impeccable, flawless acting here, and she absolutely deserves it
But let me also talk about Annika Co and Jennica Garcia
Annika was incredible in this film
From funny to irritating to heartbreaking, she nailed every single scene
She held her own alongside veteran actors, and that’s not easy dude
And Jennica Garcia
Her eyes, that “mata-mata acting”
In one confrontation scene where she barely had lines, her eyes told the whole story, you could feel out of the screen that she’d do anything for Sunshine
She’s the older sister we all deserve
And the rest of the cast, Elijah Canlas, Xyriel Manabat, Meryll Soriano, Ar-Yuh-Nuh (JM), Rhed Bustamante and the others
damn, perfection
They ate and left no crumbs, mothered
This film serves rawness
It’s honest (the Quiapo, to searching from Reddit, X, FB)
It almost feels like a documentary film type
From the gritty shots of Manila’s streets to the realness of the lines, these are the same things we hear in actual situations like this
The script cuts deep
The weight of each line… it’s crushing, full of heavy emotions

Major kudos to Direk Antoinette Jadaone for creating films that reflect the harsh realities of life in the Philippines, especially the realities that women face, the never-ending battle against a society that dictates what a woman should do with her body, the shame, the guilt, and the silence they’re forced to carry
I hope more films like this are made, films like Pamilya Ordinaryo, Birdshot, and now, this
This film deserves AWARDS
I’m also amazed by the cinematography, the color grading, the symbolism of the two children, the sound (especially the NATSOT from Manila, ang lala beh, it really adds so much depth to every scene)
This movie will make you laugh, cry, and feel pain
But above all, it stirs the mind and hits the heart, also it carries a message that matters
Message that needs to be heard, seen, and acted upon
The story arc is solidddd
The ending
Not abrupt, not lacking, it was just right
Perfectly right
To every Sunshine out there “gets na namin kayo
” Compassion shouldn’t depend on religion, gender, or social status
These aren’t just stories
This is real life
And we need bold, brave storytellers to bring these realities to light
Highly recommended

Sunshine is often considered a drama film by many who have seen it
However, I see it as a lowkey dystopian body horror film
Being a film about the effects of the Philippine's abortion ban, it displays the nation as a dystopian society that cares very little for the women living in it
The Philippine State callously disregards women's human rights and bodily autonomy with an overwhelming religious zeal, combined with a deadly dose of patriarchal rule
Posters proclaim abortion…

One of the most impactful aspects of the film is how it portrays the internal conflict of Sunshine, the mother

You know, I was a child of unwanted pregnancy too
So are my siblings
Like Sunshine, my mom had dreams
Like Sunshine, my mom was striving for better living
Like Miggy, my father was the more financially capable
Like Miggy, my father was useless about it [pregnancy]
Though, my mother couldn't do anything
She still had me— and my ate; and my younger 2 siblings
I wish she had a choice, or even knew that there are options more than just acceptance
Maybe, she could have lived her dreams
It hurts me that I lived on and carried on in my father's care (and even my dad lived unbothered); meanwhile, my mother still suffers in poverty
She is always dead worried about us, and about how she can even carry herself at the age of 40
I hope this film helps people realize Sunshine humanizes all Filipino women who endure such a heavy living— heavy dreams, heavy hearts, and heavy standards
I hope Sunshine becomes the gateway to opening discussions which let women choose and live, especially against how we had been dictated
I hope every Sunshine is given their flowers, and given the warmest hugs

"Drown out the noise
"I watched this film just hours before I turned twenty (teenage graduate)
After a year of waiting for it to be released here in the Philippines, I can say—it was absolutely worth it
What makes it so powerful is its courage to open the conversation about abortion and reproductive health in a deeply religious country like ours
It doesn't hold back
As a society, we need to be more open to the realities women face, and ask ourselves what we can do collectively, especially what the government can and should do
"Mahirap maging babae, lalo na dito sa Pinas"
The film is raw and relevant
Sunshine is real
Her character struck a chord, and I saw glimpses of my past classmates and friends in the struggles of Maris Racal and Rhed Bustamante’s roles
The film tackles poor awareness and lack of access to health facilities, while also confronting religious beliefs and cultural norms head-on
It really centers on abortion—not to promote it, but to open the conversation, especially for conservative audiences
It is still a taboo and personally, I hold a progressive stand on abortion, and seeing it presented this way felt affirming
I also loved the use of symbolism—from the “Gift of God” jeepney that Sunshine rides on her way to Quiapo, to her choosing not to enter the church even while seeking God’s guidance
Those subtle moments say so much
I admire how it ends with the strong message that women own their bodies and have the right to choose and decide—whether or not it goes against religious or cultural expectations
This film is more than a story, it’s a tool
A voice
A reflection of many who share the same experiences as Sunshine
And I truly hope the government will soon shed light on this issue and give women access to safe and free abortion procedures

Antoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine is an absolute cinematic gut-punch
Sunshine, the titular character played by Maris Racal, is on her way to Olympic glory, her dreams already in the bag
It takes a missed period and a couple of pink lines to veer her off-course
And just like that, she crashes headlong into a society that’s dead set on denying women their bodily autonomy
Racal’s performance is where the film’s soul resides
She embodies Sunshine with a physicality and emotional depth that’s fully felt from start to finish
Her sobs are painful to watch, but she’s given some respite she can hold onto: the comradeship among women
Jennica Garcia’s Geleen, Sunshine’s older sister, is a particular standout
Fittingly, Jadaone is not soft around the edges, and the film is unflinching in its message
Yet Sunshine never feels preachy or didactic
Because, to be fair, there’s really no neat, easy, and one-size-fits-all resolution for women like Sunshine
But ultimately, it does pull back the curtain and invites you into a conversation, rather than passing judgment
sabi ng coach ni Sunshine, “yung iniisip mo, ilang araw lang yan

” pertaining to her dream of representing her country in the olympics

Hindi nagmintis ang “Sunshine,” sa direksyon ni Antoinette Jadaone, sa pagsuong sa panganib na kaakibat ng paggiit ng kababaihan sa kanilang autonomiya sa sariling katawan at kalayaan mula sa pananamantala
Batid ng pelikula na ang karapatan sa aborsyon ang tanging daan ng bidang si Sunshine Francisco tungo sa kanyang pangarap na makalundag sa Olympics

Ngunit sa paglalarawan sa paghihirap ni Sunshine bilang isang abstraksiyong siya lamang ang humaharap, naisantabi ang pagkakataong maging paanyaya ang pelikula upang bulatlatin ang panlipunang estruktura sa likod ng kanyang pagdurusa
Hindi rin tuluyang tumagos palabas ng sinehan ang tindig na itinanghal nito para sa kababaihan

Sa kabila ng panawagang boykot bilang pagtutol sa henosidyo ng Israel sa Gaza, lumahok ang pelikula sa Berlin International Film Festival 2025 at indirektang nakisangkot sa panlulupig ng kababaihan kapalit ng Kanluraning balidasyon

Sa tulak ng lokal na suporta, na-extend ang pagpapalabas ng “Sunshine” sa mga sinehan—patunay na posible ang tagumpay ng pelikula nang hindi kinakalakal ang sarili sa mga institusyong may kamay sa karahasan
Basahin ang buong rebyu dito

: This fricking movie made me realize that being informed is one thing, but seeing and feeling the experience is another
Fear and self-interest
The two powerful drives of men according to Napoleon

But Sunshine is a woman— a gymnast, one of the few sports considered most feminine—one of those burning out athletes who lives by flexibility, by bending yourself in all possible corners to become this perfect beautiful being
So yes, maybe she was driven by fear and love for gymnastics, but why not

Her panic walks bending through eskinitas, the close ups on Maris’ expressive eyes unyielding despite the fear, and the overwhelming passionate Filipino noise shiver through the gritty scene of Manila and it feeds us, the audience, a rhythmic choreography of the most tender experience of a woman
Manila succumbs her, a fragile thin young girl on the verge of losing it all
And I fucking loved and consumed it

I love it too much I felt the giddiness through the tips of my fingers when the first scene at Quiapo entered, Sunshine in panic crying inside the jeep, and the first thing I thought was, “putangina si Julio ng Maynila sa Kuko ng Liwanag

”Yes maybe Sunshine enjoyed doing it with Miggy, and maybe seen the near death process of getting rid of it through Mary Grace, felt the catholic guilt, and that maybe her drive to success is to disregard what could be (motherhood) but still, ultimately still, tender is the flesh of a woman who wants to be in life
Like Julio (my shayla), tender is the flesh that holds all possibilities in life
The difference is, the tragedy of Brocka’s Julio is the absence of grounded support systems
Sunshine became her own because of the people and the women in her life who understood and grieved with her
Ito ang kasagutan sa katanungang paano naging kapantay Lino Brocka, Ishmael, Mario O’Hara si Dir

i absolutely love how nuanced this is
how it took into consideration filipino contexts in discussing such a sensitive topic
i love the cinematography, absolutely stunning
captured the vibe of living in the busy and harmful streets of manila
discussed this with my gf but i find the heavy incorporation of religion in this quite integral to the story
while westerners may be able to discuss about abortion more openly, filipinos whose lives revolve around religion, are not at all the same
we were taught at an early age that religion is the absolute law, and we must follow every rule made in the name of religion
and so, the guilt sunshine carries throughout the film is heavier than ever, because not only was she dealing with the judgment of others, she was also dealing with the judgment of God, “The Father
” And, surprisingly enough, I find the presence of the child important
At first, she bothered me a bit, how she accused shine of being a murderer, stopped shine from her attempts at abortion
She’s the superego, the guilt that follows shine everywhere
But also, she’s a part of sunshine, hence her line “Pangarap ko ang pangarap niya
” (non verbatim) and so, she too, wishes to see sunshine succeed
Her running to sunshine after her final performance and saying “gets ko na” was her way of easing shine’s guilt
After all, as people love to give life to everyone’s unborn child, then I guess this once, I too, shall make use of that

And she was willing to trade the loss of her life for sunshine’s happiness, because she will always be a part of sunshine

Sunshine affected me deeply
The film explored women’s autonomy with so much honesty, and the characters’ struggles and victories felt incredibly real
I loved how it showed the layered challenges that come with unwanted pregnancies and the emotional, physical, and social weight women carry
The story treated its themes with grace and intelligence, and I truly believe it deserves a wide audience
One of the most powerful elements came from Sunshine’s relationship with her sister
Watching the difficulty of her sister’s life, especially the reality of raising a child, shaped her own decision
It felt like she saw her future in that picture, a future filled with sacrifices and dreams placed on hold
That glimpse alone said so much about choice, survival, and the pressure placed on women
The film also opened an entire landscape of conversations
Misogyny, women’s choices, abortion, body autonomy, laws, healthcare, and the quiet burdens carried by women in this country
These are everyday truths, yet they rarely reach the screen with this level of sincerity
I crave more stories with this courage, stories that explore mature themes with depth and curiosity
This film touched many important ideas and left me eager for even richer layers
Symbolism filled the entire narrative, and I loved how each detail carried emotional weight
I could spend an entire afternoon unpacking everything
One scene stays with me the most
The motel sequence
The stillness, the rumble of the train, her actions, and the aftermath created a breathtaking moment
That scene captured the danger of doing something unfamiliar to one’s body and the immense pressure created by law and religion
It felt intense, raw, and beautifully crafted
And the presence of the kid as her guilty conscience completed the emotional arc in such a striking way
It felt like a final haunting reminder of everything she carried
What I love the most of this film is the face-on paradoxes that unfortunately reflects the reality
You see a doctor, who is supposed to save lives regardless, ignore a teenager because she took pills
You see the main character fully knowing the consequences of her actions but most people around her thinks she should do this or that
And you see pro-life always insisting that the aborted children could be someone great, but never giving a glance to those…

this is a film that shows several harsh realities that many young women face every day

it tackles sensitive yet crucial issues such as unplanned pregnancy, illegal abortion, sexual assault committed by a family member, the heavy influence of religion on decision-making, and how one snap can completely shatter a young person’s future
these themes are not exaggerated; they are painful and real
“Mahirap maging babae, mas lalo na babae sa Pilipinas
”the film drop a reality line about women especially here in the philippines
this resonates the lived experiences of countless young women who grew up navigating a society that often blames them first before offering help
the movie also embodied the noises—the noise of judgment from society, the noise of broken dreams, and the noise coming from people who desperately need help but have nowhere to turn
it speaks out that the loudest sound isn’t the chaos of Manila’s streets, but the silent cries of countless helpless women
the film exposes the flaws in our cultural, social, and institutional systems, making it easy to see where we are lacking the most
the scene showing the overcrowded OB department in a public hospital was somehow alarming
it’s chaotic, understaffed, and overcrowded—yet this reflects reality
it reveals how instead of creating long-term solutions, government tend to simply acknowledge the issue or, worse, disregard it
the systems remain weak and unresponsive
beyond all of these social issues, the film also shows how dreams can easily collapse under the weight of societal pressure
this makes the film more than just a film—it becomes a moviefied reflection of the everyday struggles of filipino youth, especially young women who are forced to grow up too fast
overall, the movie sunshine is a wake-up call
it’s a call for empathy, understanding, and meaningful change

Where she just keeps hitting her stomach with bare hand hoping it’d kill the baby or the approach of bringing in surrealism (or mythology) to show the unborn kids’ connection and interactions with their yet to give birth Mom had made it much more harder for us to come over it
Hypothetically speaking, “If I ever get a girl child I’d call her Sunshine” Coming from rural India, I guess without much realisation I had recently developed a more liking towards Asian cinemas
It makes me feel more connected and more personal
Not just with the main characters but each and every moving and non-moving, told and untold, shown and hidden subjects in every single frame
What is worse than living in a country that has outdated laws/systems/infrastructure
Having no one to share your suffering with
Sunshine only gained clarity when she felt supported by her older sister - that at the end of the day, she gets to have control and the final say to whatever her decision is

Giving agency to the people whose decisions will only affect them anyway sounds so simple since you can apply it to almost anything, but once abortion is mentioned, suddenly some people want to control the decisions of other people
Religion is obviously at the forefront of this topic
People forget that their religion is based on faith, not objective truth
It is still crazy to me that we live in an age where you could educate yourself, yet some of us still blindly choose to follow a random book that was written by a random person thousands of years ago
Kudos to Jadaone and team for making this important and (unfortunately) still relevant film

All I can say is that this film is undeniably brave—brave enough to tackle a timely and controversial issue within a country shaped by religious beliefs, societal judgment, and limited access to healthcare

For Sunshine, the act of making a decision carries extraordinary weight, as she becomes fully aware of the consequences that she will have to faceI appreciate that the filmmakers not only showed how Sunshine arrived at her decision, but also place emphasis on why she makes it
The narrative thoughtfully explores the influences, pressures, and circumstances that frame her choices, allowing the audience to understand her on a deeper level

The film effectively captures the bleak realities and unfiltered rawness of Manila, which it is easy for me to say “gets ko na”—to agree with certain moments and empathize with Sunshine’s actions, precisely because the film enables us to feel the gravity of her experiences
This work is a feat for Filipino cinema
I hope more Filipino filmmakers continue to produce films that spark meaningful conversation and illuminate social realities capable of influencing society
Kudos to the cast, director, producers, and entire crew for this compelling piece of storytelling

Isang yakap sa lahat ng Sunshine
Hindi lang tungkol sa kung ano ang pinipili mo, kundi kung bakit mo kailangang pumili
The film reminds us that while we argue about what's right and wrong, may mga taong bitbit ang bigat ng mundong hindi natin kailanman mararamdaman
And those people have to make decisions that sometimes are not acceptable to norms or beliefs
But Maris Racal delivers a story of a girl na hindi humihingi ng sympathy kundi karapatan
Karapatan na mamili
Karapatan na magpatuloy
Karapatan na mangarap
For me, it's not just a simple talk tungkol sa abortion; it’s about access, fairness, and acknowledging na hindi tayo pare-pareho ng laban
We don’t have to personally want what Sunshine wants
Pero we must understand why she has to fight for it
Kung bakit may mga oportunidad na dapat bukas para sa lahat kahit na hindi natin ito kailangan
Kung hindi mo gets kung bakit may kailangang pumili, maybe you are privileged enough na hindi mo pa kailangan mamili
And that’s exactly why we must always choose compassion

i have so many thoughts about this movie so i might just make edits
also i only got to watch it now kasi kakarelease lang sa netflix first i just wanted to applaud the use of background noises

i think im so used to movies relying on ‘noise cancellation’ that the background sounds were so instantly noticeable for me, and i understood it as something integral to the plot na ‘sunshine’s story is just one sound among many’, and thinking about how noisy these public spaces are (quiapo, avenida) parang ang liit tignan ng buhay ni sunshine tuloy

and it’s so real that society tends to overlook the lives of these women where they’re commonly diminished into statistics or cautionary talesi can even argue that in some instances, like sunshine praying outside the quiapo church or secretly talking to the pamparegla seller, is a ‘background noise’ in itself
naingayan ako sa mga scenes na yun to the point where the dialogue was just blending with the background noise

it really says a lot about how these stories are just among us, and it’s so devastating to think that something as serious as this matter (something hindering of one’s ambitions and with the capacity of changing the direction of one’s life) blends so well with noise we consider every-day and mundanesecond, this movie really touched my pathos  given my positionality as a woman

I had the chance to watch this at JAFF 2025
The plot twist is simple, but the message is powerful
The film highlights issues of sexual harassment and sexual violence involving minors
At JAFF, the director shared a little about how sexual issues are still considered taboo in the Philippines, and how the film also touches on the topic of abortion

Listening to the director speak at JAFF about the impact of this film, several discussions regarding cases of sexual harassment and violence in the Philippines have begun to open up, even if only slightly
According to him, this film has helped pave the way for filmmakers there to create similar works, which are still relatively rare

I didn’t expect how emotional this film would make me feel — to the point that it got me all teary-eyed
"Sunshine" is one of those films that stirs something inside: It makes you see, it makes you feel, it makes you realize, and it makes you understand
Itong "Sunshine" ay hindi lang basta-bastang pelikula gaya ng iba, dahil sa malalim at mabigat nitong mensahe
Sunshine, the girl with big dreams who got pregnant too early
Mary Grace, a child neglected by her own Mother, and was raped and impregnated by her Uncle — these characters aren’t purely fictional; they reflect real-life problems that many have faced
Iilan lamang ang sitwasyon nina Sunshine at Mary Grace sa maraming dahilan kung bakit sang-ayon ako sa Abortion o Pro-choice
Abortion isn’t murder; it’s healthcare — this is a strong and profound message in the film
"Sunshine" is a film that goes beyond entertainment; it also functions as an eye-opener

“Naiintindihan mo bako
”“Gets ko na

”Gets ko na/naiintindihan ko are the words na lagi kong sinasabi sa mama ko but in so many different situations, the child and sunshine’s similarity to us is that, laging nabibring up sa usapan naming mag-ina yung mga what ifs ko for her as her daughter, what she could’ve been if she chose herself years ago

Hindi ko naiintindihan, are the words na lagi kong sagot kada ang response niya sakin ay “kasi ikaw ang buhay ko”, kasi ang kapalit nun sakin ay yung mga responsibilidad na maging mas matalino, mas magaling, na hindi option ang pumalpak, especially when it comes to decisions
Sabi ko, hindi ko naiintindihan kasi sayang
Lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, lahat ng mga narating ko ngayon, dapat siya na yun, o mas higit pa kung nilakasan niya lang loob niya
Ika nga, in this world we can’t always get all that we want, kaya sa kabila ng bawa’t hindi ko maintindihan, siya ring may katapat na naiintindihan ko

Gets ko na, hindi pala na sayang, dahil siya din naman ang lahat ng kung ano ako ngayon, dahil dun palang sa pinili niya ako para maging anak niya, kahit pa na may kapalit iyong mga responsibilidad hindi lang para sakin kundi para din sa kaniya, dun palang sa araw na yun, isang matapang na pagpasya din ang ginawa niya para piliin na kaming dalawa ang magkakampi sa bawat laban na haharapin namin
Gets ko na, na hindi lang sakin to mahirap, na masyado ring mahirap itong mundong ito para sa kaniya, kaya’t ano pa’t para dumagdag pa ako sa mga kalaban niya

I feel like most daughters shares this same sentiments and dreams for their mothers of wanting them to choose themselves even if it means not having the chance to be born in this world, and that’s what makes me love this movie
It comforted me to have the perception of making that dream come true for my own mom
It showed the depth of the understanding between the mother and their child especially their daughters
Just when we thought it’s already deep, it could get more deeper

Worth the year long wait, brilliant film and really cements Antoinette Jadaone as an Auteur of Philippine Cinema
I think what I found so strikingly sad about this is that, fourteen years removed from the Philippines (more than half of my life
); I try to tread carefully when I talk about Manila, the people and their struggles
I don't think that my incredibly sheltered memory of the place would hold as much cultural weight than that of a local, and yet fourteen years later Manila is still
And if I am brought to tears by this, I wonder about the grief carried by generations of young women failed by a dated system
In all her films, what Jadaone ultimately wants, or rather demands for her female protagonists, is Space
Space to exist safely and choose freely

To break women out of crowded public maternity wards with shared beds, obsolete facilities, abject doctors (with their religious biases), and to bring them into the clearing of their dreams, the main-stage gymnasium, the Olympics
mahirap talaga umiyak pag may kasama
“Ayoko maging nanay
Hindi ko ipapanganak ‘to dahil hindi ako ready maging nanay
” / English: I don’t want to be a mother
I won’t give birth to this child because I’m not ready to become a mother
Abortion is illegal in the Philippines, heck even being pro-choice here is looked down upon
Yet, motherhood is an expected life trajectory for many Filipino women, that is if you marry at the “right age” and have more than 1 child at the “right time”
So what choice do women have if they are pregnant under different circumstances
For a country that claims to be collectivist (pakikipagkapwa tao mindset ang dapat pinapairal, etc
), how can this principle become a universal behavior for most when its own government continues to throw its own citizens under the bus
Every dire problem that needs to be addressed can be traced back to how fucked Filipinos are by their government
Whatever rhetoric the Spaniards spread about Filipinos being “lazy” is still used today by the rich and powerful, their basis why the Philippines continues to be poor

The Reproductive Health Law faced a long legislative battle just to get passed, and it still took two years for the law to be fully accessible for the public
When your prospects are so thin, people will do anything to get what they want, even if it costs their life
That is a hard pill to swallow for a lot of Filipinos
At the end of the day, Filipinos are treated as just mere statistics in politics

Sunshine (2024) looks soft, warm, almost gentle on the surface
the colors cradle you, the scenes feel tender, and at first, you think it is comforting
but beneath all of that warmth carries a weight that is impossible to ignore
it is about abortion in the Philippines, where it is illegal, and labeled as “blasphemous,” “disgraceful,” and judged above the lives it affects
the film does not shy away from showing how cruel reality can be
people, even doctors, prioritize morality over humanity, ignoring the pain, the fear, and the uncertainty of the woman at the center
it shows a woman whose future and potential clash with society’s judgment
the unknown girl who follows Sunshine feels like a younger version of herself
she is the part of Sunshine that believes abortion is wrong, the part that cannot yet grasp the weight of a life lived on someone else’s terms
and yet, by the end, she mutters, “gets ko na
” she sees that Sunshine’s life is not a simple question of right and wrong
she feels the burden Sunshine carries, the life she cannot give without losing herself
she recognizes how much was left for Sunshine to live, how much potential to burn bright, and how pregnancy would have dimmed it
she senses the life that should have belonged to Sunshine alone
the realization does not absolve, it recognizes the choices forced upon someone who should have been free to live her life on her own terms
that recognition shatters you more than any argument, any moral lesson ever could
watching this film, you feel everything at once
the warmth of the colors, the softness of the scenes, the love in small gestures, and then the ache, the rage, the grief that lingers because the world can be cruel, unfair, unfeeling
Sunshine is about life that is too heavy for the judgment of others
it is about the potential snuffed out when morality is chosen over empathy
it is about understanding, even when the world cannot
it is gentle, devastating, and necessary
it will stay with you long after the credits roll
Sunshine is soft to watch, hard to forget, and brutally honest about the ways society fails those who need understanding the most
it will make you feel what it is to live, to choose, to survive, and to understand when understanding is all that remains

Jadaone’s works, so I was so excited for this one considering all the positive reviews and attention it got all over social media

Though it’s a Filipino film, the issues it brings up feel very close to home for my country—we’re part of the same Southeast Asian family, after all
The story is poignant and deeply relatable, especially the short subplot about Mary
I couldn’t stop thinking about all the other “Marys” out there who are sexually abused by their own relatives, trapped in a vicious cycle with no real options
Let alone healing the trauma—they don’t even know where to begin
And then there’s Sunshine
True to her name, she becomes the light in the darkness, taking responsibility for what happened even though she never wanted to become a mother yet

“kasalanan sa mata ng diyos”is abortion a sin
people will answer this differently because morality in the philippines is rarely personal
it is inherited by religion, tradition, and the weight of everyone watching
for many, the word “abortion” automatically activates the label of sin, as if life were a simple moral equation and suffering didn’t count as part of the formula
for others, it is a decision carved out of fear, pressure, and survival, made in the middle of circumstances that no outsider fully understands
kung ginahasa ka, kasalanan pa rin ba ang pagpapalaglag sa bata
if your answer is yes, then your moral compass is calibrated more by dogma than empathy, and your worldview is as rigid as the doctrine you inherited without questioning
conservatism in the philippines is not subtle
it is soaked into daily life, in families, in pulpits, reinforced by laws that pretend neutrality but are shaped by centuries of religious influence
sa bansa natin, halos lahat ng desisyon ng babae ay may kasamang mata ng lipunan na handang humusga, tama
abortion becomes more than a medical choice; it becomes a cultural crime, a symbol that people weaponize even when they know nothing about the life behind the decision
the environment itself—manila’s density, poverty, inequality, survivalism—creates conditions where choices are never purely “moral
” what do you expect from a city where half the population is just trying to get through the day
when you strip away the labels, the question of sin becomes less religious and more philosophical
sin implies intent, malice, or moral wrongdoing
abortion, for many, is none of these
if you’d ask me i’d say that, it is not an act of cruelty
it is a response to reality, a calculated survival decision shaped by pressure that most people never experience
kung hindi mo kailanman naramdaman ang desperasyon ng isang taong walang mapuntahan, anong karapatan mong magsabing mali ang pinili niya

reducing abortion to “sin” ignores everything: economic instability, trauma, lack of support systems, inaccessible healthcare, fear of judgment, and the sheer brutality of living in a country that demands endurance but offers nothing in return
the real discussion is not about moral purity but about environment
what context shaped the choice
what access to resources existed
what physical, emotional, and social risks will the woman face
people prefer judgment over understanding because judgment feels easier
introspection requires effort, and compassion requires complexity—two things society often avoids
if morality is measured by harm done, abortion may not be a sin at all
it may be a reflection of a society that fails its people so deeply that they must make decisions the world refuses to understand
sa totoo lang, mas madali para sa lipunan na manisi kaysa kumilala ng sistematikong pagkukulang
we condemn individuals because it distracts us from confronting the bigger failure—the environment that gave them no safe path
the real sin might not be in the act of abortion but in the society that makes someone carry the weight alone
a society that romanticizes suffering, worships conformity, and punishes anyone who chooses survival over tradition
a society that has the audacity to moralize while refusing to provide support, empathy, or alternatives

"Do you understand me
""I get it"Jadaone's Sunshine portrays the raw, harrowing, and excruciating journey of a young gymnast who found out that she is pregnant, just months before Olympics qualifiers

The emotional turmoil that sends her into a downward spiral ghastly encapsulates the prevalent issue of teenage and accidental pregnancies in the Philippines and how public's notions that are grounded from bigotry, conservatism, and outdated values can negatively imbue the minds of these helpless women

The fragments of Sunshine's psyche of children also deepened the already thematically layered piece where it now provides the protagonist a whole new outlook whether she should carry on with the pregnancy or terminate it
What I really love about it is the film stays grounded to its footing and steadily focuses on putting the audience in Sunshine's lens
The last act with the kid is a top-notch and probably the most heartwarming scene in the whole film
Maris Racal's impeccable performance also puts the cherry on top where the in-depth introspect of a young woman that is going down the rabbit hole won't be solidified without her
Overall, Sunshine may just bring a new sunshine in the modern era of Philippine cinema

This movie really captured the whole idea of “what if my parents chased their dreams instead of having me

” The film shows how teenage pregnancy and child sexual abuse really happen not just because of irresponsible boyfriends who don’t use protection, but also because it can come from anyone and i mean ANYONE
your own dad, uncle, cousin, friend, or partner
Its eye-opening how teen pregnancy has become so normalized in the phillipines of ages 13 to 18
And to my mom who had dreams too, until she found out she was pregnant with me, she was torn a real 50/50 on whether to keep me or not
She chose to keep me and eventually married my dad
Sometimes I can’t help wondering what her life could’ve been if she pursued her own dreams
Honestly, I’d want her to be happy, even if that meant I wouldn’t exist
The movie’s meaning and message really hit me deeply

Abortion ban only bans safe abortion
Sunshine is a feat for Philippine cinema
It tackles a topic most are scared to produce and it was written WELL
Yes, without the poverty porn or political porn most films of ours subtexts
There are characters that are REAL
Not written to tell unjustly-unrelated issues but to support the story itself
And so, characters that are in poverty aren’t written to convey another message, rather to stand with what the film is about in the first place
This film is easily the one of the best written films of all time in our history
Not only does it tell a beautiful picture of a character undergoing such a life-turning “accident” but how it tells it psychologically, and powerfully
It never let go of what it portrays nor does it settle for a scene that would bring in viewers, it’s written SO realistically that you’d forget it’s a movie

A quick one to point out is Sunshine texting her bestfriend, at the time she needs support the most, even if she’s disappointed for losing contact with her, she still texts out of fear, and that’s something i’m sure plenty of people have done
Those text messages are so real, raw and incredibly well-written too
The whole story is an absolute masterclass of writing a film straightforwardly without losing the essence of what it is

It’s a display of perfect world-building, from the story of her boyfriend, the realistic response from him to the story of the tindera, who without building a relationship, completely makes sense of the film
Even built a subtext of a no nonsense coach that adds to fear, support, motive and regret of the main character
I can tell you all about the beautiful writing but this would be too long
Let’s get to the cinematography
Well, it’s good
Definitely better than most films, it’s quite obvious that certain camera works and shots aren’t just to finish the scene but is chosen to look good while portraying a scene nicely
There’s a lot of cues that whispers visually, like how she prays with bars infront of her, evoking the feeling of our character not FEELING or BEING welcome inside the church
Shot-selections like those sre essential and quite reliable to make a scene impactful so i’m incredibly proud they excerted better effort to make this film the best it could possibly be
Wouldn’t say it’s a strong suit, but this fil is definitely visually well-made
I’ve always seen Maris Racal as a great actress before this, now she’s PHENOMENAL one and is one of the best in the industry right now
The talent to portray talent and skill alone, is something most actors/actresses not only have the chance to audition for BUT absolutely nails from the first to the last second of the film
There’s a Piolo Pascual jumpscare here, Elijah Canlas KILLS it AGAIN AND AGAIN AND AGAIN
Sunshine is great, it’s amazingly told through emotions and a bit of a psychologically present engagement to allow interpretations of viewers be as wide as it can
