Sunshine is one of those rare Filipino films that refuses to look away

Instead of sugarcoating or romanticizing the world its characters inhabit, it confronts the audience with the uncomfortable truths we collectively sidestep—the toxic mindsets we inherit, the social issues we normalize, and the moral rigidity we mistake for virtue
What makes the film remarkable is its honesty
It acknowledges how deeply ingrained complacency is in our culture, how we often witness injustice, misogyny, or dysfunction and simply shrug, labeling it as “ganun talaga
” Sunshine exposes that mentality for what it is: a quiet violence that enables suffering
The film does not preach; it simply presents the weight of these realities with clarity and emotional intelligence, letting the audience feel the consequences of silence and inaction
Its commentary on anti-abortion attitudes is especially bold for Philippine cinema
Rather than reducing the debate to dogma or melodrama, the film shows how anti-abortion rhetoric becomes a peril for women; not just physically, but emotionally, socially, and economically
It reveals how denying reproductive autonomy restricts their futures, limits their ambitions, and punishes them for choices men are rarely held accountable for
Sunshine portrays this with nuance: the internal conflict, the fear of judgment, the systemic lack of support, and the complete absence of safe options
The film understands that this isn’t just a “moral issue”—it’s a structural one, tied to poverty, misogyny, and societal expectations about what women owe to the world
Ultimately, Sunshine is more than a movie; it’s a critique of the culture that raised us
It forces us to ask why we maintain harmful traditions, why morality is weaponized against women, and why we accept inequality as a norm
Its power lies in its refusal to let the audience remain comfortable, and in reminding us that the first step toward progress is learning to confront what we’ve been taught to ignore
nearly cried but remembered my rage for men
Films like this make me realize how great the potential of the PH film industry is when it comes to storytelling, creativity, and taking risks
Sunshine proves exactly that
Ang tapang ng pelikulang ‘to, not just in the execution, but sa choice of subject matter
Makamasa, madaling kapitan, and at the same time, a real eye-opener
From start to finish, ramdam mo yung puso at bigat ng kuwento, and yet ang linis ng pagkakadala
Maris Racal shines in a way that’s both raw and controlled; she gives a performance that stays with you long after the credits roll
Jennica Garcia is equally powerful, grabe yung presence niya, every scene hits (we all need a family member like her
Together, they carry the emotional core of the film so well na hindi mo mapigilang maapektuhan like ALL I CAN SAY IS I REALLY LOVE WOMEN SM
But above all, very important yung conversation na binubuksan ng Sunshine
Abortion is a difficult, nuanced topic—one that should be openly discussed not just within families, but within our society and government
And I firmly believe na choosing yourself first, your success, your safety, your future matters just as much
AND, women should be able to decide for themselves: their body, their rules
This isn't a simple issue, and the film treats it with the depth and humanity it deserves
Sunshine is indeed a courageous and a necessary film that everyone should watch

For a teenage gymnast, carrying a baby to term really does completely remove that path as a possibility for her life—that dream just gets immediately destroyed, in a way that (obviously) won’t happen for the baby’s father, and it’s why it’s so essential to this film’s success that Jadaone so skillfully captures the tactile and practical *reality* of Sunshine’s body in the gymnastic scenes: that body, with its graceful and athletic movements, that she has spent her entire life molding for this sole purpose of Olympic gold, and it will go away, permanently, if she doesn’t have an abortion
I also think Jadaone does a good job of avoiding deck-stacking
Yes, the pro-life nurse who castigates Sunshine is portrayed as a witch, but the saleswoman who gives her the abortifacients is also shown to be a greedy haggler herself

And while the two male figures pressuring her to have the baby (her boyfriend and her boyfriend’s father) both make specious and insincere cases, it is again to Jadaone’s credit that she cast two dynamic male performers for these roles (Elijah Canlas and Pio Pascual—whom I didn’t recognize in a straight-up “Dad” role, after decades playing the heart-throb
)…this is one of those reviews where in the process of writing it I’ve realized I liked the movie a lot more than I thought I did while the credits were rolling

One of the biggest factors holding back the Philippines from being as progressive as our neighboring countries like China and Japan is our deep entanglement with religion—Christianity, in particular
As much as faith shapes our culture, it also becomes a hindrance to national progress when religious beliefs are imposed on matters that should prioritize the welfare and rights of all citizens

Imagine how much better our society could be if we allowed personal freedoms and evidence-based policies to guide our decisions, instead of insisting on religious doctrine as the standard for everyone
The movie portrayed this reality so powerfully

It addressed so many issues in one narrative—how women are often the ones who suffer the most under a misogynistic system, how men can easily walk away from responsibilities while women cannot, and how horrifying it is that young girls, even minors, can be raped and then forced to bear a child
These are the consequences of a society that refuses to give women full autonomy over their own bodies
I truly hope more people come to realize the importance of allowing women to make decisions for themselves by legalizing abortion
Every woman deserves the right to choose what happens to her own body
Despite the heaviness of the story, I’m glad that Sunshine still managed to pursue the dream she longed for, proving that resilience can still bloom even in the harshest circumstances

I may be on the unpopular side of this: I want to love this so badly but for some reason, I can't help to mull-on & pinpoint some details lacked for me and thought it needed more revising story-wise
I am not hating on this
In fact, I actually like several parts of the movie

I think it's fair to say (and undeniably so) that this is an important and a refreshing story on what's the take of abortion & body autonomy here in the Philippines and I do appreciate this movie for that

(I added the half star plus because it still is an important movie)I want to love this movie (but only like it) because I thought it obviously have such a great potential to be "a great movie" on most aspects
What holds me back is the writing, story-wise
It started really strong and direct to the point which I really liked
By the next part, we'd see a little girl who follows Sunshine

At first it seems to me that it could be her inner child or her unborn future child so it confused me a bit (most especially on the part where Sunshine was rushed to the hospital, we'd see a blood on her crotch area as well)
This device they used provided a bit of comic relief in the movie which I thought is cute and actually can be an effective way to delve deeper sentimentally because its so personal
However, I came to learn (through online reading) that she is indeed her unborn future child (bc of Ariana disappearing)

To be honest, I couldn't finalize my thoughts on this whether I like it or not because with that in mind, the mix message does confuse some a bit on whether or not it's a "pro-life" but I guess that could also be the point that it is complicated
Afterall, Sunshine did kept coming back to the church scenes and this can represent a lot of women who faces/d the same situation
I just thought the movie might have to clarify in telling that message

I also much prefer her being Sunshine's inner child (which could be a "tangible" reminder on what the whole movie is all about, Sunshine taking control of her own life and the dream of being a national athlete ever since she's a child)

But the line "Gets ko na" have such a great impact on people because of its "casualness" but its the words that has a really heavy weight on it that I thought is effective to pull people's heartstrings in
Another aspect of the movie that kinda lacked for me which is, I think a big part of it: I want to see how much Sunshine wants it by seeing her own training to be a gymnast
What does she do every day as a training athlete
How does she balance everything in her life-- being a sister/aunt/student/friend/a woman in general while also being a training athlete
What do you to do train as a gymnast
How heavy does it weigh on her that she's truly doing every thing she can to be in olympics and be a great gymnast, what does it look like
I wished she saw that a bit (even just in a montage) before or during the moment she found out she got pregnant
I want to see her really work hard and see how much blood, sweat, and tears and really feel and see that "goddamn it i want this so bad" and not just tell it
I guess what I want to say is that I want more training scenes too because I am also interested in watching gymnasts do their thing haha
I also thought that by the 3/4 part of the movie where we do meet Ariana is kinda took a different turn for the movie

I am not sure if it is necessary that we meet another kid (Ariana, not Mary Grace) and that maybe without that, they could still end up getting the same storyline/result (though don't get me wrong, I did like Ariana, i think she's fab)

It also didn't do much impact on Sunshine's decision but rather it does prove how fucked up it is that this happen in reality and how shitty it is again that we don't have much (legal and safe, known) access to women's sexual and reproductive health services, let alone being a woman/person who's forced into something they aren't ready to be/never wanted be in the first place
More so, the visuals and cinematography, can't deny that it is beautiful, that's a given
Acting is amazing, no notes no doubt

A little predictable on emphasizing on the Manila landscape and scenery although it is still beautiful to look at (especially considering to people haven't been to Manila/Philippines, at least they'd get the gist of it even though its not all picturesque all the time)
I especially appreciate the movie getting in deep and showing the grim & messy ways of taking different methods of abortion
I thought its very important to see how harrowing and fucking hard/harsh/unfair/dangerous it is that women have to/had no choice to do experiences like these

I only wished that they showed the method of when Sunshine made an appointment for that Doctor Helena because maybe it could also show that abortion could also have safe and harmless way that would make people feel less wary and scared of it and maybe even talk about it
With all that, in conclusion I think I do like this movie
It is an important movie to exists especially at our modern times, it's long overdue that we finally talk about this here in our country
I hope we keep talking about it because it is necessary for us we want to keep fighting for women's rights
I don't love it but I do like it and I appreciate it for what it did

htmlAntoinette Jadaone’s Sunshine has been one of our most anticipated local releases of the year and it does not disappoint
Emotionally charged and socially resonant, the film tackles teen pregnancy and the realities of limited reproductive rights in the Philippines with honesty and empathy
While it may not offer clear-cut moral answers, Sunshine succeeds in revealing the real and painful stakes of becoming a young mother tackling equally both sides of the moral coin
National gymnast Sunshine (Maris Racal) has always dreamed of competing in the Olympics
With qualifiers fast approaching, she pushes her body to its limits until she suddenly faints during training
What she assumes is exhaustion from her intense regimen and strict diet turns out to be something far more life-altering: she is pregnant

At only 19 and with her lifelong dream on the line, Sunshine faces a bitter decision: keep the child and lose her final chance at the Olympics, or pursue an illegal abortion and grapple with the moral and emotional fallout
As expected, Sunshine doesn’t shy away from tough conversations
Its central dilemma is painfully relatable, regardless of where you stand on the right to choose in a predominantly Catholic country
Maris Racal is a revelation, delivering a nuanced and deeply human performance as a young athlete forced to confront consequences that will shape the rest of her life
And while we won’t spoil where the story ultimately lands, the film takes a definitive stance without betraying the complexity of its subject matter
It was a balancing act handled with notable care
What elevates Sunshine further is how vividly it captures the societal pressures and chaotic realities of Philippine society when it comes to the right to choose
The judgment, the ironies, the lack of support systems, everything feels painfully authentic and grounded
Where the film stumbles slightly is in its more fantastical elements
Though the intent behind these sequences is clear, they often feel out of place and not fully integrated into the narrative, appearing more convenient than cohesive

Still, Sunshine is a compelling and important watch and not only for Maris Racal’s standout performance but for its bold and compassionate exploration of an issue that remains deeply relevant in modern Philippine society
It’s a film that provokes and ultimately shines

felt this film deeply in my soul bc: count 1: im a woman in a predominantly conservative country count 2: ive had a pregnancy scare count 3: same financial situation as sunshine count 4: film set in the areas i frequent

this feels very similar to brocka in that it portrays manila as a city full of hardship and loneliness that can leave you so disillusioned and alienated; and where hope and humanity exist on the fringes of it

it's a working-class story with working-class sentiments that fully takes on its own identity because jadaone is able to portray such familar elements in a way that feel completely isolating; the interiors of jeepneys, tricycles, shabby motels, clinics — everything feels so alien

which, i guess, offers many people unfamiliar with what these woman go through a much-needed perspective on the importance of dignity and bodily autonomy and how violent, horrible men try to take that away from many women

i think it's also worth noting that religion and patriarchy play such a prominent role here in oppression; jadaone laser-focused on placing religious beliefs and preconceived notions about abortion in the spotlight, all the more affected by teenage pregnancy and how religion has kind of shaped the way many filipinos treat abortion as something so taboo and inhuman that they completely forget how it affects the mother

and it's brought to life by a really incredible maris racal; shaped by all the adversity — the kind of performance that requires you to bare your soul to the audience, to beg them to see the humanity behind the people suffering from religious oppression, and why access to abortion services — even in a heavily catholic country — is of utmost importance
a film Filipinos may not be ready for…but need

Women in the Philippines continue to grapple with deeply rooted issues such as teenage pregnancy which is made even more complex by the country’s predominantly Catholic identity

The moral codes and expectations instilled in us from childhood often determine whether society views abortion as a sinful act or a necessary choice, and this cultural tension becomes the silent force shaping many young women’s lives
In the film, Maris Racal embodies this struggle with striking emotional clarity

She carries the weight of a decision that no young woman should have to make alone: the impossible choice between holding on to her dream of becoming an Olympian or confronting the life-altering reality of an unexpected pregnancy
Her performance is powerful not because it dramatizes the dilemma, but because it mirrors the experiences of countless Filipinas whose voices are often dismissed or shamed into silence
What elevates the film is how it frames her situation not as a moral failure, but as a human story: one shaped by fear, hope, societal pressure, and the search for agency

Through Racal’s nuanced portrayal, the narrative exposes the cultural contradictions we live with: a society that celebrates the achievements of young women yet imposes rigid expectations on their bodies and choices
The film invites the audience to move beyond judgment and recognize the quiet courage required to stand at the crossroads of identity, aspiration, and responsibility

In grounding a personal crisis within the broader context of Philippine social norms, the film becomes more than a character study; it becomes a commentary on how we, as a society, often fail to extend empathy to young women navigating impossible circumstances
And in that sense, Maris does not just act the role; she embodies a truth many are too uncomfortable to confront

What makes Sunshine haunt me is how real it feels — not just as a story of a gymnast’s dream, but as a raw, painful portrait of what it means to be young, afraid, and fighting when everything seems stacked against you
The moment the truth sinks in — that this girl, brimming with hope and ambition, is now carrying a life she never asked for — the world she built starts cracking
Maris Racal gives a performance that doesn’t feel like acting — even when she’s silent, you feel every tremor of fear, every doubt, every moment she prays for a different ending
The film doesn’t paint shades of grey — it throws you into a world where choices are dangerous, and every door seems closed
And the way the city closes in around her — tight alleys, cold clinics, judgmental stares, desperation disguised as quiet — Sunshine doesn’t just tell a story
It burrows underneath your skin and refuses to leave
This film isn’t easy or comfortable, but it’s needed — for the stories it refuses to sanitize, for the voices it pulls from the shadows, and for the courage it asks from us to look
If you think you know pain, you might not until you watch Sunshine

The whole movie revolves around that and we get to be introduced to the characters and the environment around her that is essential and will influence the choice she will make

Here we get to see a real picture even though the story is fictional, as filipinos you could almost grasp the realness out of this film and say, this is the REALITY but we don't have to embrace it, WE HAVE TO CHANGE IT
As a man, I always believed that i am no position to speak about what women should and shouldn't do about their bodies, but will absolutely support the concept of abortion
When we speak about abortion in a country that is like the Philippines, that is so centered on religion, abortion becomes a taboo, illegal and unethical
We also see these professionals, government leaders that support this kind of ideology that abortion is bad blah blah blah
This film is a great commentary and an eye opener to what young women and women in general what they go through, and that abortion should become an option for all women in our society

I will just make it clear that i think this film is not pro abortion or anti life, without directly stating it, the film focuses on making better decisions, the importance of protection, sex is more common than we think which is ironic in the Philippines that is so religious but that’s ok, this country just needs proper education and thats it

In spite of her past controversies, Maris Racal's performance in this film is the very reason why she remains in the spotlight
Her acting as Sunshine is spectacular

The story requires someone who is capable of letting the viewers feel the heaviness of her pain, the agony, and the hope of standing up for yourself and for what you want, and she made us feel all of that

And though I may not completely agree with everything that's pointed out here, I really admire Jadaone's attempt and bravery at addressing such a taboo topic, not just in the Philippines but the rest of the world
Being prayerful and always going to church do not give us the right to see ourselves as being more morally upright than others

When you put all of that aside, Sunshine is just a teenager who regretfully made a mistake and who made a decision for herself, stood up for what she wanted, and spared the child from the resentment of a mom from being robbed of her own dreams, and of leading her to what could possibly be a miserable life
She knows she could be ridiculed for that decision, but she lived according to her own terms anyway
And we know that in the end, she is happy, and that's all that matters
You’d know toxic pinoy kasama mo if they were rooting against Sunshine the whole time
This movie reminds us that whether u choose the dream or the child, a woman always carries a profound loss

The film Sunshine (2024) resonated with me because it honestly depicts how unforgiving reality can be
It shows how quickly people judge young women, often before they even have a chance to breathe or ask for help
The film also makes painfully clear how the lack of reproductive rights pushes women toward risky, sometimes dangerous choices
You can almost feel Sunshine being boxed in on all sides, not because she did anything wrong, but because society refuses to give her real options
Women in the Philippines face judgment, limited choices, and immense pressure around pregnancy
And the film makes a point I strongly agree with: no government or religious institution should dictate what a woman does with her body
Those decisions belong to the person living that reality, not to people watching from a distance
Sunshine made the right choice
Sobrang taboo sa Pilipinas ang usapang abortion, pero at least the child didn’t grow up feeling guilty or resenting their mother for what might have happened if they hadn’t been born
It’s better for a child to know they were truly wanted, rather than feeling like the product of someone else’s dilemma
Constantly being told they’re a blessing can’t replace the sense of being genuinely chosen

each represented their dreams, clinging to whatever little piece of themselves the world hasn’t taken away

Maris Racal anxiously walks through the streets and markets of Quiapo, looking for a way out in the form of illegal drugs hidden beside statues of Mama Mary

Sunshine knows what she wants —to be on the Olympic stage, but the world around her from the kid who knocked her up, to the saleslady who's "helping" her, to her sister who also got pregnant, may have different opinions
Sunshine stops by the church, pleading for clarity but also possibly for forgiveness and absolution
But a ghost in the form a kid that calls her a "murderer" haunts her the most, popping in and out like a conscience
She was nervously waiting to see what Sunshine would finally decide, and so was I

"gets ko na"that line literally sent me into the abyss
going into the film, i was so confused about the little girl following sunshine
i thought she was sunshine’s inner child, like a guide through the mess, reminding her who she was and what she actually wanted
but when they introduced ariana, the kid that “bata” playmate during that night, everything started clicking
then the incident happened
mary grace (rhed bustamante) tried to get an abortion, and her baby died
when we saw ariana recognize mary grace, and then later, at the hospital, the nurse announced the baby didn’t make it… ariana just disappeared
that’s when it hit me: ariana and bata was supposed to represent the baby, their baby
it felt ironic at first because you’re torn between “should i feel bad
” and “should i feel sad about the literal premise of the film
” but then bata said to sunshine, “gets ko na,” and the whole film just punched my soul
maris racal is easily one of the best actresses of this generation, and sunshine proves that
the film is raw, very indie pinoy cinema vibes, and it works
it also doesn’t shy away from the heavy stuff, like how brutal the philippines can be when judging teenage pregnancy and abortion
the shame, the gossip, the pressure to “keep it,” the lack of safe spaces… the film shows how hard it is for girls to make choices about their own bodies when everyone feels entitled to comment
i just kinda wish they explored sunshine being a public athlete more, like the public eye, the rumors, the judgment she’d face online and her community as the time goes by
the ending showing her making it to the sea games was nice, but i feel like addressing the backlash and the pressure could’ve made the story even stronger
overall: great film
beautiful, painful, and honest

Well done
I have a lot of feelings to share about this beautiful and heartbreaking film
Truly a big eye-opener to many Filipinos
Women carry a biological physical pain we are given the moment we are born
Period, childbirth, postpartum, etc
But we also carry the pain this world and men cause
The pain men should be held accountable for
Emotional labour, cultural and religious expectations, rape, pregnancy, forms of abuse, etc
It's like our suffering is pre-written, pre-approved, and expected
And yet the world still has all the audacity to treat us as if we're lesser, fragile, dramatic, overreacting
I think I will never be able to understand the logic of a world that demands strength from women and then punishes us for being strong
Like Sunshine and Menggay, a lot of women out there don't have choices
A lot of women are already deprived of basic rights before they even learn to speak
But then again, society still keeps finding new ways to take more from them
The hypocrisy of the Filipinos in this film is also insane but couldn’t be more well depicted
(It’s actually so much worse in real life
) Filipinos will praise God with one hand and strip women of autonomy with the other
Anti-abortion because “God said so,” but silent about abuse, poverty, rape cases, or the girls forced into motherhood long before they even have the chance to understand themselves
They defend unborn children better than they defend the living women who have to endure the burden of carrying them
Because if they don’t, you will judge them
You will shame them
How is that love
How is that morality
Abortion is criminalized, but sexual abuse cases get dismissed
It’s exhausting
It’s enraging
To all of the Sunshines out there, gets na gets ko kayong lahat
The world keeps underestimating and shaming us, but here we are, still standing, still surviving
To end this, I want to share that one monologue in Fleabag that came back to me after watching this film and inspired my entire review:"Women are born with pain built in
It's our physical destiny—period pains, sore boobs, childbirth
We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives
Men don't
They have to seek it out
They invent all these gods and demons so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own
And then they create wars so they can feel things and touch each other and when there aren't any wars they can play rugby
We have it all going on in here, inside
We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years, and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens
The menopause comes
The fucking menopause comes and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world
Yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you're free
No longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts
You're just a person
i am not crying, you are

It was true when they said that this was a brave film

To be one of the first films in pinoy cinema to explore a pro-choice and an unwanted pregnancy narrative is indeed brave, especially when you know the Philippines’ socio-political and religious climate around topics regarding sex, female desires, pregnancy, bodily autonomy, and parenthood
There were unfortunately some parts of the film that felt like they didn’t work
I’m not sure but Sunshine’s decision to abort felt too quick
And her dream to be an Olympian felt underexplored and more of her coach’s
We’re told rather than shown that it was hers
The inclusion of Annika Co whose character can be interpreted as Sunshine’s subconscious/ego or unborn child or whatnot sometimes felt irritating to watch (sorry not sorry)
But I guess to reach more towards a predominantly Filipino audience and to highlight Sunshine still being a (teen) child who’s forced to confront the consequences of her choices by a child: worked
I don’t know

Not to mention that it felt a little silly to include two other characters, where one was another pregnant teen girl, that lowkey felt like their stories were being shoved down to the audience’s throats
And in the end, felt shallow
I just think that I hoped they showed more of the technicalities of her being an athlete
Rhythmic gymnastics is considered an elite sport
And when you consider it in the Philippine context – the film didn’t really show what was at stake of being an athlete in this sport

The film’s strong aspects are definitely on the score, cinematography (particularly to highlight the corners of Manila as this chaotic, packed, and cruel city), and of course: Maris’ performance as Sunshine
There were scenes that hit hard and heavy
The irony of abortion drugs sold and found in the street outside a church
The motel scene to show Sunshine’s quiet desperation
Her final rehearsal for her routine before her “gets ko na” scene with Annika (where I cried unfort bcz luteal phase duh)

The film does show you a glimpse of the unforgiving reality of what many Filipino women go through everyday: teenage pregnancy, overcrowded and underfunded public hospitals, and the lack of comprehensive sexuality education about sexuality and sexual and reproductive health
It lacked, sure
But I guess, for pinoy cinema to start tackling difficult topics such as this: it’s a start

i’ve known sunshines in my life - a co-worker, a co-worker’s sister, close friends, and old classmates back home
and it’s just sad just how much they were under scrutiny for, for something they should have total control over
it infuriates me even further to realize that back home, abortions are not accessible, and are illegal even
oftentimes the women are frowned upon because of our country’s conservative and religious culture, they face shame and judgement first before they can even get to decide of their own autonomy
meanwhile, the men that are responsible can get to walk away from all scrutiny just because it’s not theirs to hold and carry
to all the sunshines that we know, get to know and may not know yet, they deserve to talk about these things openly, not in secret, not in shame
sunshine reminds us that we definitely have a long way to go
yet a little empathy can go a long way

I don't remember where I first heard of it, but the idea has always stayed with me: for every abortion, miscarriage, or infertility, if a women desires to be a mother, it will come to her at the right time—in one form or another
And I think this film beautifully echoes hints of that belief
The part where Sunshine asks the little girl, "Naiintindihan mo na ba ako
" And the child replies, "Gets ko na," feels like a simple, but so profound of an exchange of words
It feels like a hand that's gently soothing a wound she's been carrying all this time
A wound that asked to be seen with the nuances that came with it, not the fantasies the society chooses to blind themselves with
Another thing that stood out to me abt this film is how it challenges the viewers to confront the expectations forced onto women simply for existing
Not with judgement, but with a silence that understands what it means to be human
I just love that this film respects women's choices
It doesn't force a message or a narrative that motherhood is the only path to walk through once it enters in a woman's life
Instead, it says that your life, dreams, and timing are all yours regardless of what everyone thinks nor says abt it
Because to be a mother means to be ready mentally, physically, and financially
Love alone isn't enough to carry a life, just a majority of its suffering

I loved it to bits
The Philippines has always been against abortions due to its religious nature, so I love that this is the kind of film that will spark conversations about the said controversial yet necessary topic
I for one can never fully give my stance since I am religious but also because I am not a woman
I've always believed that the woman is the one that should decide on what to do with an unwanted pregnancy
So, to see pros and cons of wanting to abort a child as well as choosing to go through abortion was quite engaging and I understand things more now
To see the horrors of using illegal ways of abortion was eye-opening, in all honesty
The film did a fantastic job of showcasing these issues, as the message was loud, clear and perfect
I'd say that my only issue with this film is that I wish the story was more fleshed out in a way
Also, it was blatantly obvious that the mysterious (and annoying, mind you) little girl was Sunshine's supposed daughter
I would've honestly preferred it if it wasn't made obvious

First Letterboxd essay — I had an itch to scratch so bad with this one
Also medyo late, crammer kasi year-end na :) Right off the bat, I knew how reviews of this film would look like
At hindi naman nagkamali
This film is highly praised, receiving remarks such as masterpiece, brave, and a stepping stone
Yet to my surprise, a few share the same sentiments I had, thoughts that were brewing in me while watching Sunshine
Kaya rin ang hirap buuin ng review na ito (bukod sa hindi naman talaga ako nag-eessay sa plataporma na ito), kasi ayoko maging echo lamang
Anyways, just for the sake of sharing kahit onti:(1) I agree that the supposed personified child is, safe to say, contradictory
Kahit may explanation si Direk Jadaone, it still felt conflicting and made the film unsure of itself
(2) The introduction of some characters felt out of place
In some aspect parang chess yan, character placement and arcs matter, so the player must be aware of their moves
(3) The slap in the face commentary on religion felt overdone
Sayang ang parts and points na pwede pang mahimay
Oh diba, dami niyang sinasabi
But in all honesty, I really felt the need to essay the hell out of this review
Mahalaga sa akin ang usapang SRH at syempre mahalaga rin sa akin na maging diskurso ito
And dahil diyan, here’s a point I feel no one else has raised
Personally, it felt like under-researched ang pelikula
Mababaw pa ang na-capture nitong realidad ng abortion at ang hirap na nadadanas ng kababaihan sa kalusugan
These are things you would know agad with one simple search on Reddit
Gets ba
(Lol) And to think na mas layered and complex pa dapat ito sa sitwasyon ni Sunshine, as a student-athlete with financial instability
Sayang lang, ano
Syempre may good points din ang Sunshine sa pananaw ko
Visually, it did its thing
Acting, no doubt, great talents, especially Maris and Jennica
The fact that I watched this with my parents and that they were genuinely interested and concerned about the film is a good point
Sa dulo naman, baka expectations ko rin ang rason kaya ko ito naisip
From here on, sana hindi laging hanggang unang bato lang
Here’s to hoping na makahakbang at makausad na tayo

Society claims to protect the “unborn child,” yet the conversation often leaves out the women whose bodies, health, and futures are directly involved
It feels unsettling to watch how easily society dismisses the experiences of women, as if their lives become secondary the moment they become pregnant
I can’t ignore how deeply this connects to the patriarchal norms I’ve grown up seeing
From subtle expectations to outright judgment, there is a long history of controlling women’s bodies and decisions

The shame placed on those who consider or seek abortion is not just personal; it is cultural and religious, embedded in systems that teach us to shame and question women’s choices instead of supporting them
This made us more aware of how easily society turns compassion into condemnation when it comes to reproductive health

at gaya ng ate mo at ng bata, kakampi mo rin ako, Sunshine
WHAT A BEAUTIFUL BEAUTIFUL FILM
hindi ko alam kung anong mas mabigat habang pinapanood ko Sunshine — yung katahimikan ng mga babaeng walang mapagsabihan, o yung ingay ng mundong ang bilis humusga pero ang bagal tumulong
Jadaone films always stab softly, pero ito
Parang dahan-dahang hinihiwa yung dibdib, layer by layer, para ipakita yung takot, pangarap, at kahihiyang matagal nang nakatago sa ilalim ng “ok lang ako

”this is the kind of film na hindi mo papanoorin para gumaan ang loob mo, papanoorin mo siya para maalala kung gaano kabigat mabuhay bilang babae sa bansang ayaw umamin na may mali sa sistemang sinasamba nito
Sunshine doesn’t preach
it just stands there, raw and trembling, asking the kind of questions we’re trained to avoid:Paano ka pipili kung lahat ng choice mo ay kasalanan sa mata ng iba
Paano ka lalaban kung mismong katawan mo ang pinaparusahan
Maris Racal is devastating in ways na hindi loud pero lumalalim
hindi siya yung tipikal na dramatic heroine — she’s simply a girl suspended between a dream and a reality that keeps shrinking her choices
her silence says more than any monologue could
every frame feels like a confession: hesitant, trembling, pero totoo
and what struck me most wasn’t the gymnastics, or even the central issue of abortion
it was the ache between who we want to become and what our circumstances force us to be
nakakapagod maging babae sa Pilipinas — laging may moral lesson, laging monitored, laging may takot na isang maling galaw lang, tapos na ang lahat
parang ang liit liit ng mundo mo kahit ang laki laki ng pangarap mo
Sunshine doesn’t romanticize any of this
walang sermon, walang cinematic gloss
just a raw, unfiltered look at how dreams bruise under a society na mas mabilis manghusga kaysa umintindi
the film’s imperfections — the loose ends, the uneven metaphors, the sometimes rushed stakes — oddly work in its favor
because real life isn’t clean
hindi linear ang trauma
hindi laging malinaw ang choice
and maybe that’s the point: that we’re all navigating a world built not on empathy, but on fear and control
in the end, Sunshine feels less like a movie and more like a mirror — one that forces you to sit with the darkness until you finally admit na masakit talaga ang liwanag
it’s an eye-opener not because it shocks, but because it whispers truths we’ve mastered the art of ignoring
a film worth watching, not because it entertains, but because it confronts
because it nudges you to look beyond the screen and into the world we built… and ask, Bakit ganito
And more importantly — hanggang kailan
k lang galing niya

Sunshine touched on some of the most sensitive and difficult struggle of being a woman
especially in the Philippines
One of which is the inaccessibility to women-friendly environments, may it be in your household, in public, at the hospital, at school
And when I say women-friendly, it's the support for the emotional and mental consequences, and physical choices for oneself
We suffer consequences that are beyond our own control but when we decide how to deal with it, our surroundings tend to vilify us for our choices
But Sunshine shows us that we are in charge of our own choices however we like it
We know our bodies, our dreams, our capacities the best

Antoinette jadaone’s SUNSHINE is powerful , poignant, beautiful, and yet heartbreaking which showcases the crisis of young age pregnancy, the taboo and the shame comes with it, hypocrisy of society and being resilient and standing up for yourself and for your dreams over anyone
It’s not a fairytale, but a hard hitting truth
There is no ending to this cycle of shame for women who are bred in this macho-feudal society, how religion and social taboos remain a bottleneck than a savior
But the movie overcomes those things so bravely and leads a courageous path to tell women to take their rights in their own hands
I really loved the idea of her imaginative child being with her all the time, giving her strength, and emotional support and that final moment between those two is tear jerking
What most people think it was a sad ending, but actually it was not, it was an inspiring ending which reaffirms that every woman should have the right to make a decision for herself

this film is a deeply realistic exploration of what it means to be a woman in the philippines—a country where patriarchy, tradition, religion, and economic pressure converge in ways that make womanhood both exhausting and precarious
Importantly, the film is not a pro-life statement, nor does it romanticize suffering or prescribe motherhood as a moral imperative
instead, it shows that the choices women face are complex, constrained, and often invisible to those who hold power
it also addresses the ways women navigate survival under these pressures
it shows that women are often responsible for both care work and emotional labor without recognition or support

the everyday reality of harassment, unsafe streets, economic vulnerability, and social judgment creates conditions in which reproductive choice becomes a deeply personal but politically fraught decision
the film does not moralize these choices; it presents them with nuance, empathy, and a refusal to simplify the stakes into a pro-life narrative

This is a blistering, gut-punching film that doesn’t just ask difficult questions about bodily autonomy and Olympic dreams; it screams them into the humid, chaotic reality of Manila
It’s a brave, essential piece of cinema that confronts the devastating consequences of living in a country where a woman’s control over her own body is perpetually under threat
The cinematography is nothing short of breathtaking and utterly visceral—it’s relentless, trapping us inside Sunshine’s suffocating anxiety

Jadaone uses the oppressive visual texture of Quiapo’s crowded, sweltering streets—a perfect, gritty backdrop—to symbolize the labyrinthine journey of a young woman navigating impossible choices in a system designed to fail her
A massive and well-deserved standing ovation goes to the central performances
Maris Racal is devastating as the titular gymnast, embodying the crushing physical and emotional burden with every strained muscle and every desperate, silent plea
Her performance is a masterclass in controlled despair, capturing the agony of a lifetime of sacrifice being threatened in an instant

She is perfectly complemented by Annika Co’s mesmerizing, eerie, and unrelenting presence as the Kid—an unsettling narrative device that functions as both Sunshine’s internal critic and her desperate conscience
But let’s be real: the film’s rawest emotional hook comes from the shocking failure and apathy of the men around her
Their irresponsibility and sheer lack of accountability form a central, infuriating symbol of the patriarchal society that traps Sunshine
Ang hirap maging babae sa Pilipinas
Every day feels like a battle against a society na paulit-ulit kang nilalagay sa kahon, insisting that your worth begins and ends with motherhood
Fuck the stigma na finoforce ang mga kababaihan into roles they never agreed to—parang automatic default na lang na dapat tahimik, dapat magtiis, dapat magpakamartir
Walang puwang para sa sariling pangarap, sariling katawan, sariling desisyon
Kaya sana mas umingay at mas mapag-usapan ang Reproductive Rights—hindi lang as a “women’s issue” but as a basic human right
This is about giving women the freedom to choose, the safety to seek care without judgment, and the dignity to exist without being shamed or controlled
Hanggang hindi natin tinatalakay nang seryoso ang mga ito, paulit-ulit lang tayo sa cycle ng stigma, trauma, at kawalan ng choices
Being a woman here shouldn't feel like a punishment
It shouldn't demand silence in exchange for survival
And yet, dito sa Pilipinas, ganun pa rin ang realidad—and that’s exactly why conversations like this matter

what makes the film even more powerful is its raw, unflinching portrayal of philippine society
the story exposes how reproductive rights in the country are entangled with religion, shame, and systemic neglect
it shows how a woman's body becomes a public issue the moment it no longer fits moral expectations, and how access to safe, affordable healthcare quickly turns into a privilege instead of a right
ultimately, sunshine champions a woman's right to her body, her choices, and her future—even in a society that constantly takes those away

What stayed with me long after the credits rolled is how Sunshine understands the quiet corners of being young
The ones filled with fear you don’t even have language for yet, and the hope you still hold anyway
The film doesn’t chase shock value; instead, it trusts stillness, letting the soft ache of its characters speak for themselves
And then there’s that storyline about the 13-year-old girl, pregnant because of her own uncle
OH GOD
That shattered me
It’s horrifying, devastating, and the film doesn’t sanitize the truth of it
It shows how violence like that hides inside families, how children are left carrying consequences for sins that were never theirs
I felt so much grief and anger for that kid; it’s the kind of scene that makes you sit there and go quiet because it hurts in a very real way
The film’s exploration of choice, shame, and the pressure to “grow up correctly” hits even harder because of moments like that
It never lectures
It simply shows how heavy it is to carry circumstances shaped by adults who should’ve protected you
Maris Racal delivers an immaculate kind of devastation in this role
There’s a sharpness to every look she gives, a trembling truth in every word, that feels painfully real
She breaks open the character’s longing, lets the fear spill out raw, and turns her strength into something that rises slowly from the wreckage
It’s a performance that destroys you and stays spotless in its honesty
Sunshine is the kind of film that lingers
Soft, bruising, furious when it needs to be, and quietly bright in all the places that matter

A challenging plot to bring to the screen and a harsh and sad reality for many women
The strong hold religion has over the Philippines is especially frustrating
The hospital scene where you would expect empathy from the doctor pissed me off
The pastor and Miggy especially bothered me — Miggy because he’s a little shit and the pastor because his reaction reminded me of my father
Other people can get away with abortion because they have the money so they can just go freely with their lives, but for younger women like Sunshine and Ariana, it’s life or death
Ariana’s situation is especially heavy, something I’ve heard about from people I know
This film is going to bother me for a while
Sunshine (2024) serves as a powerful and eye-opening film, especially for us Filipinos
As someone working in the healthcare field, I believe the movie highlights an important truth: abortion should not be treated as a taboo subject or inherently immoral
Whether we acknowledge it or not, there are women who do not wish to become pregnant or are not ready to become mothers
Criminalizing abortion does not stop it from happening; it merely drives women toward unsafe procedures that place their lives at greater risk
If one personally identifies as pro-life, then one has the choice not to pursue abortion

However, holding that belief does not grant anyone the authority to dictate or restrict what women can do with their own bodies, especially when they do not contribute to the wellbeing of the child these women may be forced to bear
The health, autonomy, and safety of women must remain our priority
It is time to end the stigma surrounding reproductive choices and to uphold the separation of religion and state in policymaking

Ang pelikulang Sunshine ay hindi lang simpleng kwento ng isang babae—isa itong salamin sa maraming isyung matagal nang umiikot sa Pilipinas pero pilit pa ring isinasantabi

Nagawa ng pelikula ito na ilahad ang mga sakit ng sistemang kinabibilangan natin: mula sa pakikibaka ng kababaihan sa kanilang sariling katawan hanggang sa nakakalungkot na estado ng ating healthcare system
Isa sa pinakamalinaw na ipinupukol ng pelikula ay ang isyu ng aborsyon
Ipinapakita ng pelikula kung gaano kahirap ang desisyong hinaharap ng mga kababaihan—lalo na sa bansang halos bawal pag-usapan ang reproductive rights
Nakakahalit dahil hanggang ngayon, marami pa ring kababaihan ang hindi ganap na malaya sa sarili nilang katawan dahil sa malalim na kapit ng konserbatismong relihiyoso
Sa halip na suportahan, hinuhusgahan sila
Sa halip na pakinggan, pinapatahimik
At gaya ng ipinapakita sa pelikula, napipilitang harapin ng mga babae ang mga sitwasyong hindi nila pinili, wala man lang ligtas o legal na option para makaligtas
Kasunod nito, mariing binabangga ng pelikula ang realidad ng ating healthcare system
Hindi na bago ang nakikitang eksena sa ospital: siksikan, kulang sa gamit, at kapos sa espasyo
Dalawa, minsan tatlong ina sa iisang kama—hindi dahil gusto nila, kundi dahil wala talagang mapaglagyan
Ito ang reyalidad na hinaharap ng ordinaryong Pilipino araw-araw, habang ang mga pulitikong may kapangyarihan ay kayang lumipad paabroad para magpagamot sa mas kumpletong pasilidad
Sa kabuuan, nagsilbing boses ang Sunshine para sa mga isyung matagal nang dinidinig ngunit hindi pinakikinggan

A harrowing, claustrophobic, yet essential sprint across Manila streets

The craft here really shines, at just 90 or so minutes the film feels tightly-paced and confidently crafted through Jadaone's masterful direction, yet it still swings wide over several discussions and thoughts over its major theme in an arguably short amount of time

Mind you there's an element here that I'm not the biggest fan of-- I think the film could have actually eliminated it altogether as it feels inelegant especially against the overt realism of the rest of the film
But otherwise it's easy to overlook this compared to how wise the rest of the film is
It culminates in a truly lovely finale that uses simplicity to great, moving effect, especially when juxtaposed to how much noise and haste the rest of the film's heavy atmosphere is
Gets ko na why "Gets ko na" became an easily recognisable, even arguably iconic line from this film
Besides the stellar direction, the rest of the departments here really shine
The camera and production design really stand out here, painting a crowded and cramped world
The performances are simply captivating
Maris Racal truly carries this hefty narrative, but Annika Co really exudes such natural confidence that steals the scene whenever she appears
Ultimately, this really feels like important cinema from simply one of the best Filipino filmmakers out there
Sobrang tapang ng pelikulang 'to
Sobrang tapang ni direk tonet
Sobrang tapang ni Sunshine
Sobrang tapang ng mga kababaihang nagpapatuloy, lumalaban sa mga hamon ng lipunan
Dinala ako ng pelikulang 'to sa kung anong klaseng lipunan ang kailangang harapin ng mga kababaihan araw-araw — lahat ng husga, dikta, at pangungurakot

Wala sa kahit anong batas or salita ng diyos ang makatutulong sa mga taong kagaya ni Sunshine, kung 'di ang maayos na health care system, maayos at tapat na gobyerno, at isang mapagpalayang lipunan — malaya sa kahit anong dikta at husga ng mga taong hindi kailanma'y namroblema sa kanilang kaligtasan kapag maglalakad mag-isa sa madilim na kalsada, sa kanilang kasuotan at pananamit, sa kung anong pananaw ng iba sa kanilang katawan, sa kakayahan makapag-luwal ng anak, sa mga tingin at pagnanasa ng mga mabababang-uri, at sa mga marami pang bagay
Napakaraming aspeto ng pelikulang Sunshine ang paulit-ulit sinasampal sa atin para lang magising sa realidad ang bulok na lipunang 'to
Isa na rito ang pagbibigay sa mga kababaihan ang kalayaang mamili, kalayaang magdesisyon, at kalayaang mangarap, kasama ang proteksyon para sa mga batang katulad ni Mary Grace

Ilang kababaihan at bata pa ba ang kinakailangang maranasan ang hirap nina Sunshine at Mary Grace bago mamulat at umusad ang lipunang sakop pa rin ng makalumang pananaw — mga pananaw na hindi nila alam ay unti-unting ginigilitan at pinapatay ang karapatan, kalayaan, at kakayahan ng mga kababaihan

Ang mga taong tulad nina Bobot, nanay ni Mary Grace, at Miggy ang tunay na lumalabag sa sa utos ng diyos, ang tunay na gumagawa ng krimen, at ang tunay sa nagpapabulok pa sa inuuod na sistema para sa mga kababaihan at bata, hindi ang mga taong tulad ni Sunshine na pinanghahawakan ang karapatan nilang mangarap at magkaroon ng desisyon para sa kanilang sariling katawan
Tangina gaano ba kahirap isipin yon
Napakaganda ng cinematography

Lahat ng baho, usok, lagkit, at sikip ng Maynila; lahat ng mga matang mapanghusga, mga taong makasarili, mga komentong nananakal, at bigat na dala-dala araw-araw ng mga babae at bata, lahat ito ipinakita
Ibang klaseng sining ang ipinakita nina direk tonet, maris, jennica, annika, at sa lahat ng cast ng pelikula
Mahigpit na yakap para sa lahat ng Sunshine na patuloy bumabangon at lumalaban

A disturbingly realistic film that tackles on the disadvantages of living in a country that criminalizes abortion—discouraging women’s bodily autonomy and integrity, huge risks on women’s reproductive health, and so on
It is a dark cinematic film that does not only impress one with its amazing visuals and role portrayal from the cast lineup, but also leaves you pondering on the bold message it screams throughout
Maris Racal is ready for leading roles, and Sunshine gives her everything to work with
It helps that a stellar ensemble of women round out the supporting roles too, with Annika Co haunting her like an undeniable reality

Its plot, certainly a conversation-starter, doesn't all the way succeed with all its creative choices, but it's welcome forward motion for showing that women's choices command respect even if it doesn't fit the ones you decide for yourself
Another thing everyone should agree on is that Antoinette Jadaone has her finger on the pulse of what Filipinos, and the cinephile-going population of the country, need to discuss

hayst ang hirap panoorin :( when you work in healthcare and you know andaming may kwento katulad ni sunshine at mary graceat sana darating rin ang panahon na ang karamihan ay makakasabi ng "gets ko na"
“usapang bata to
bata rin naman ako
”a striking detail that struck me the most is the contrast between the very first time we watch sunshine step onto the mat and the last time she ever does
at first, you hear this deep and intense noise of her drowning the music, her choach’s instructions, and even the sound of her own breathing
and the noise only goes louder and harsher each time we see her practice her routine while she quietly endures the devastating ordeal of attempting to terminate her pregnancy
what started off as a sound to describe her pressure and desperation to reach her olympic dreams, now becomes the sound of her fear, her secrecy, and her grief

this says so much about what it means to be a woman in the philippines: how suffering must be hidden, how autonomy becomes something to apologize for, and how you’re expected to quietly tend to your own wounds you never asked to carry
and sunshine carries her decision with guilt, so much that she looks at the unnamed young girl like she’s staring at every version of her future that never got the chance to choose
but she dreams
she dreams so much
and she dreams for more
and she stands firm, because what’s so wrong about wanting a life that belongs to her
what’s so wrong about refusing to be swallowed by sacrifice
what’s so wrong about refusing to become another woman she didn’t want to be
“gets ko na
”so as we see the last time she practices on the mat, we finally hear the sound of the music, not the deep sound of pressure of fear, but a rhythm that finally belongs to her
the gymnasium is dark, she’s alone and she’s pale, but this is the brightest she has ever looked in the past hour i’ve watched the film
she moves with a softness that feels earnest, like this is the first time her body isn’t performing to impress or survive, only to exist
she dances gracefully, probably the most she ever has, and it’s a moment that shows us that she has unapologetically reclaimed something no one ever thought she deserved: the right to choose herself
and for the first time, she is no longer a girl she’s afraid to be—she is a woman who has already decided

i hope more people watch sunshine (2024) not to criticize women with early and unintended pregnancies, but to meet them with grace and empathy for their fears, their confusion, and their fight to claim what should have always been theirs in the first place—their autonomy, dignity, and right to have access to healthcare without being made to beg for it

“Gets ko na”Pero ang lutong nang mga mura
”Ay nako
Talaga naman ang mga kabataan ngayon hindi na makapagpigil
”Throughout Sunshine, there are several adult figures that do not listen to Sunshine, blinded by either their convictions or Filipino societal norms
They push Sunshine on what she must do: pray, seek forgiveness, give the baby a life, be a mom, and pray
In the adults’ eyes, Sunshine is not a nineteen-year-old Filipina in Manila going to school and practice
To the adults, Sunshine is already a mom
On Saturday, the Filipino noontime show It’s Showtime invited parents with 7 or more children for their game Laro, Laro, Pick
A majority of the contestants were women, and two of the mothers interviewed, Elsa and Rosalie, had 15 and 8 children respectively
Elsa, the 63-year-old woman with 12 living children and 3 deceased children recited the ages of her 12 children from the oldest, 46, to the youngest, 24
The gap between the older ones is 1-2 years apart, while the younger ones are about 2-3 years apart
Elsa confesses how difficult life is for her and her children, spouting how without God she would not be as strong as she is today, living off 300 pesos everyday
When Vice Ganda asked Elsa why she has so many children, Elsa plainly said, “Ehhh di ako marunong mag family planning eh,” inciting some laughter in the audience
Elsa even revealed that the father was absent and had a different family, leaving the Filipina mother and her 12 living children to figure out how to live
The second woman, Rosalie, with 8 children echoed the same sentiments as Elsa

She sells sampaguita every day with no days off at the age of 60 something; her children married and had their children early; the highest level of schooling one of her children attained was high school, but never graduated; her children sell sampaguita with no days off; and she has 19 grandchildren to look after in a home with no roof above their heads
What Sunshine, Elsa, and Rosalie have in common is how the patriarchy confines them to suffocating religious ideals, a corrupt and conservative government, and poor healthcare
What Sunshine does not have in common with the two women is the ignorance in family planning
Sunshine is no one's mother

It should never be a reason to have 7 or more children at an early age, with no means of support financially and emotionally, because it is "God's gift," or because they simply want to experience having children
The favorite catchphrase, "Kase malakas ako, kaya ko to" can only thrive for so long with honesty until oppressors abuse the Filipina determination
Access to sexual education MUST be a right, not a privilege nor a taboo subject

Children do not decide when they want to be born, so there should be conscious efforts to assess if the environment people live in can secure their children's/childrens' future(s), especially in a country like the Philippines
Unfortunately, there are connections to poverty and the lack of interest and access to proper education
There is also the inability for Filipinos in poverty to seek other options, or have the real agency to pursue aspirations

While there is such thing as being irresponsible, Filipino women are a laughingstock in conversations surrounding teen pregnancy and reproductive rights—when realistically—they should have the choice to protect themselves, but are instead ruthlessly flayed off by the very system that commands kindness
[Minor spoilers ahead]Annika Co manifests herself as (what I think) Sunshine's Catholic guilt
We first meet Annika after Sunshine prays outside of Quiapo Church and is about to light a cigarette
Annika appears whenever Sunshine does something that will affect the fetus, and often berates Sunshine for being "bad

" At first, I was hesitant towards the idea of Annika representing Sunshine's potential child, because it can mistakenly support the pro-life argument of murder (which Annika actually yells at Sunshine), until Annika says, "ang pangarap ko ay pangarap niya
" SOBRANG bigat yung line na yan
In a sense, Sunshine and Annika are the same person
Sunshine should be able to pursue her dreams successfully the same way Annika, along with other living and future children, should feel secure enough to be ambitious
The message further builds itself with Ariana, Annika's friend and the 13-year-old girl's potential child
Ariana wants to be the first gay president, but how can they do that in an environment with a r*pist, a neglectful grandmother, and a KID whose choice was stolen
If mothers like Elsa and Rosalie can somehow "get away" with no family planning, how can Sunshine and the 13-year-old girl survive in a Catholic Philippines

The Reproductive Health Law was passed in December 2012, and efforts to educate the masses and distribute contraceptives have improved, yet there is still a high percentage of unintended pregnancies, AIDS rates, and JUSKO PO—ISSUES WITH BUDGETING (source 1),(source 2)

The Philippines will never progress as a nation if objectivity is blocked by the grip the church and the state have on one another, which ultimately and consistently harms Filipinas who give their best yesterday, today, and tomorrow

I am certain that Sunshine is not the first film to be unapologetically bold and loud for the Filipina, but it is certainly the first to make rounds among the casual movie-goers and the general Filipino

It is not a perfect film and such flawed instances are where:- the narrative of Sunshine being an Olympic-level athlete clashes with the lack of popularity shown outside of practice- the cinematography is poetic without a doubt, but the scenes of Sunshine messaging her Coach, Miggy, and Thea isn't synchronized with Sunshine typing on the phone/isn't even her actually texting
If you're going to place emphasis on the quietest scenes, I believe that something as minor as texting should be clean (this was the same quip I had with the controller scene in Anora like c'mon now
)- the cinematography can be too poetic

for example, the shot of Sunshine looking out of her hotel window with the Metro Manila noise juxtaposing her quiet turmoil contributes to Sunshine purposely not drowning out the noise (or the failure to
), but I found it unnecessary because right after she woke up in pain

the juxtaposition felt like it was purely for aesthetics- the Jojo Rabbit esque character of Annika and Ariana was VERY risky (re: pro-life arguments)- maybe it's just me but the film gives you some breathers with comedic aspects in things like "no bad words" and Annika proceeding to say "putangina" which I found myself like "damn girl
" though it makes me wonder if those who do not share the same ideals as me laughed at it the same way the audience laughed at Elsa in Laro Laro Pick
In a not long-winding way, and assuming negatively, if tonal shifts struck the audience as a serious matter and not a reactionary narrative

- the last 3 paragraphs of this review regarding how art can effectively stand by its purposeAng hirap maging isang Sunshine sa Pilipinas, at hindi pinaguusapan kahit eto ang reality ng karamihan ng babae at batang babae
Women can dream for themselves
Women can learn to protect for themselves if there are resources available by sources that make themselves available
Women are strong, but you cannot glorify them to always be strong at the expense of exploitation
Sunshine is many of the first steps in Philippine cinema that can continue the conversation

I hope the film incites action in Filipinos to call out the current and future administration, who, under the guise of a devotee to a forgiving religion, perpetuates being uncritical and whose laziness is a disservice to the Filipino people
And most importantly, may Filipinos denounce the administration's vigor in committing violence against them, and reclaim the autonomy all Filipinos are born with

You can still reach what you want and chase your dreams
Just keep going and keep fighting
As a man, I feel sorry for Sunshine, but believe me, there are many good men in this world better than selfish and stupid men and I learned from this movie how to be a better man
Use protection when you’re doing something intimate, and if you don’t, make sure you can take responsibility for your actions
Live wisely and don’t make rushed decisions
Every choice you make shapes your future
We may not regret our actions in the moment, but we regret them later
And for other men, I want to say this if you have a girlfriend, make sure she’s happy with you
Don’t be rude to her, and don’t ruin her life because of your desires
As a man, I promise myself that I'll be better
I’ll treat women with respect, and I'll never raise my hand when we have problems or arguments

“Gets ko na
”In a country like the Philippines, where everyone has an opinion on your body except you, this film hits a nerve that’s been aching for a long time
The way the film shows her struggle, the shame, the fear, the judgment, the dreams she’s forced to postpone, feels like a mirror held up to countless Filipina girls who had to grow up too fast
You can feel how her choices are never just hers; they’re tied to religion, family, and the weight of “dapat” at “bawal
”But what makes Sunshine beautiful is how it refuses to punish her for wanting more
For wanting herself
When she finally chooses her dreams, finally chooses herself and it doesn’t feel selfish
It feels like survival
Like finally stepping out of a shadow she never asked to stand under
This is a reminder that a woman’s future shouldn’t be treated like a sin
And that the sun doesn’t ask permission to shine… it just does
The best Filipino Film of 2025

what hit me the most was how the film shows society’s pressure without ever yelling at you
the judgement, the shame, the rules you’re supposed to follow — it’s all there, always in the background, shaping every choice she makes

but then there are these tiny moments of kindness, little glimmers of hope, and it’s those moments that make the sadness bearableyou really feel her pain, her confusion, her stubborn spark to survive and keep dreaming, even when everything seems against her

and the story doesn’t give you easy answers — it just lets you sit with the reality of what it’s like to be a girl in a world that doesn’t make it easypero na-realize ko na the girl who follows sunshine and calls her “murderer” is not a real person
she represents the harsh judgment sunshine feels from others and the guilt she carries inside herself
the girl is basically the voice of society telling sunshine she did something wrong, even when the situation is more complicated
she’s also sunshine’s own fear and self-blame turned into a person
in short, the girl is the symbol of the guilt and pressure that keep haunting sunshineyung nasa jeep scene fav ko kasi pinakita na how overwhelmed sunshine is without her having to say a word
while she’s sitting in the jeep, everything around her feels loud, messy, and fast—parang tuloy-tuloy yung mundo habang siya, nakastuck
when she starts crying quietly, it shows how much she’s been holding in for so long
always was and always will be pro-choice

Putangina, hanggang ngayon, ang daming lalaking nag-aakalang may karapatan silang magpasya para sa katawan ng babae
What stays with you long after Sunshine ends is how the film treats every moment as something pulled straight from real Filipino girlhood

You see it in the small, mundane ways Sunshine tries to keep herself together like the way she tightens her jaw during training to hide the panic creeping up her spine, how she forces a neutral expression when adults around her throw judgment disguised as concern and the humiliation of realizing everyone expects her to handle a crisis she never chose
Girls grow up by being punished for becoming women
Sunshine is still a teenager, but the moment her pregnancy becomes known, people start talking to her like she owes them maturity, penance, and accountability she was never taught to carry
When Pastor Jaime steps in, offering moral pressure, you can feel the room closing in on her again
Everyone wants her to be a mother
Everyone thinks they have the right to her future
Despite all that pressure, Sunshine’s refusal hits like a rupture in a system built to control her

[ system log : 001 ]user : haziah | age : 23status : active // processingI liked Sunshine because it speaks volumes about the lack of real sex education among teenagers—how so many are left to navigate consequences without ever being given proper knowledge, guidance, or protection
It shows how quickly people are forced into rigid sides—pro-choice or pro-life—without being allowed the space to exist as confused, scared, and human first
I didn’t like it only because Maris Racal’s acting was phenomenal—raw, restrained, and painfully real—but because the film chose to center understanding instead of judgment
It didn’t sensationalize the situation; it made you sit with it
I liked it because it treated the experience as what it truly is: a life-altering moment that cannot be simplified into slogans, morals, or online arguments
It showed how heavy one decision can feel when the world is already crashing down on you
I liked it because it refuses to make the audience comfortable
It doesn’t beg for sympathy, it doesn’t chase approval, and it doesn’t try to make itself digestible for everyone
And most of all, I liked it because it never tells you what the “right” answer is
It simply lays everything bare and lets you face it on your own
It allows you to choose what to feel, what to believe, and what to carry after the credits roll
Some people say it lacked something—especially in its length—that it should’ve been longer, that it ended too soon
But I don’t agree
I think it had to end exactly where it did
Because some stories aren’t meant to be over-explained
Some experiences don’t offer neat closures
The ending didn’t feel incomplete to me—it felt honest

Women are born with pain built-in
It's our physical destiny: period pains, sore boobs, childbirth, you know
We carry it within ourselves throughout our lives; men don’t
They have to seek it out
They invent all these gods and demons and things, just so they can feel guilty about things, which is something we do very well on our own
And then they create wars, so they can feel things and touch each other
And when there aren’t any wars, they can play rugby
We have it all going on in here inside
We have pain on a cycle for years and years and years and then just when you feel you are making peace with it all, what happens
The menopause comes
The fucking menopause comes, and it is the most wonderful fucking thing in the world
And yes, your entire pelvic floor crumbles and you get fucking hot and no one cares, but then you’re free, no longer a slave, no longer a machine with parts
You’re just a person

i genuinely love this film
it exposes the harsh reality of living in a country dominated by catholic doctrine—where the people around us can be relentlessly cruel, judgmental, and unforgiving

the film tackles abortion with remarkable depth, showing how society instinctively treats it as a sin, a crime, even a form of murder—without ever pausing to consider the woman’s circumstances, pain, or autonomy
sana mapanood ‘to ng lahat, para maintindihan nila na hindi masama ang pagpapalaglag
people forget that there are reasons—real, painful, and valid reasons—why someone would choose it
the storyline of the thirteen-year-old child, impregnated by her uncle, shattered me
it happens in real life
children—literal children—forced to carry pregnancies at the cost of their own safety and future
it’s heartbreaking that instead of being allowed to end the pregnancy for their well-being, many are forced to keep it simply because abortion is illegal
the kid didn’t even know she was pregnant—she only realized when her stomach started to swell
that level of innocence being burdened with trauma feels monstrous
i truly hope our country stops clinging to extreme conservatism and learns to be more open-minded—to understand that these things do happen outside the walls of their moral fantasies
legalize abortion

there is nothing lewd or obscene about knowledge—malisyoso lang ang mga utak ng mga ayaw magturo

"See Greatest Filipino Films Of All TimeSee Jom’s Greatest Films Of All TimeOnce in a while, movies like this will remind us how great Philippine Cinema could be with proper production and marketing
Let's be honest, there are many films like Sunshine out there, produced and marketed independently
The talent of our Filipino directors, writers, and actors is flourishing; it just needs the right hand managing them
Studios surrounding Sunshine took a huge gamble promoting and marketing this movie, because they know how good it is
And it's that fcking good
Sunshine beautifully captures Sunshine, our protagonist, as she battles her way out of an unwanted pregnancy set in the cold city of Manila
This journey was documented with captivating visuals of Sunshine in the gym, in Quiapo, in a motel, etc
On top of this, this is unlike any other dialogue in mainstream Pinoy
The dialogue often has witty layers, purposeful intentions, and emotional punches
Maris Racal delivered a career-defining performance
This is not the same Maris Racal we often see in teleseryes or some other romcom movie
Her performance is an incredible take on such a complex and relatable character
I could nitpick some off details here and there which really bugged me, but I won't talk about it here as I believe that further magnifying this movie's success is what we should do
Sunshine represents every woman, every female, every girl, every lady of any shape or form
It brings up socially relevant topics and issues worthy of discussion
I am most impressed by its bravery to speak all about these, coming from a conservative country
Sunshine, the protagonist, showed bravery in confronting the stigma and the conservative norms
Sunshine, the movie, showed the bravery of promoting and marketing this despite the stigma and the conservative norms
Good movie

Antoinette Jadaone's "Sunshine" is anchored by a stellar lead performance from Maris Racal and a neo-realist perspective on the lack of reproductive rights in the Philippines
The film follows a rhythmic gymnast who dreams of participating in the Olympics, only to find out that she is pregnant
The film explores the difficulties of finding the right medical care for abortion
Racal's performance is impressive, and she is solidly supported by Annika Co, Jennica Garcia, and Meryll Soriano
Jadaone is able to capture the dirt and grime of Manila's urban areas, as well as the outdated beliefs in the country
Reproductive rights for all

The movie did not contain any surprise elements whatsoever — rather, it depicted the realities that Filipino women endure, especially when it comes to pregnancy and abortion
Seeing individuals like Sunshine and Mary Grace deal with the outcomes they did not choose is devastating
It's awful that they had to put their own lives in danger to reclaim their lives
In addition, I detest the notion that women are blamed and criticized while the majority of males who participated in the incident roam free from the consequences
It's horrible how obviously apparent the double standards are
Most of us are aware of the worst-case situations if abortion isn't legalized, and this film accurately depicts the gravity of the situation
If watching this doesn't change your mind about being anti-abortion, I don't know what will
Not everyone is ready to be a mother
Not everyone is capable of being a mother

I truly hope that this movie will continue to inspire empathy and provide better facilities for safe and regulated practices in the country

Literal na daramdamin mo lang yung pelikula and your emotions will be enough for people to understand

Gets na gets ko si Sunshine—from thinking you’re an adult yet feeling like a child; an ambitious girl to a woman on a tightrope; from being alone and criticized by society as a whole to finding your space, your people, your support system despite what people have to say… and ultimately choosing your own peace and happiness—something that is deemed a privilege for women
