SAGOT SA PELIKULANG “SUNSHINE”: HINDI GUGUSTUHIN NG BATA ANG MAMATAY SA ABORSYON KONTRA SA PINAKITA SA PELIKULA----------------------------Paalala: Ito ay dati naming Facebook post na muli naming inilabas dahil nasa Netflix na ang pelikulang "Sunshine
" Para sa nagnanais na malaman kung sino ang "unlikely guide" sa caption, basahin ang post dito
----------------------------Matapos maibalita ang pelikulang “Sunshine” ni Maris Racal, inaasahan ko na ang pagsuporta nito sa aborsyon o ang pagkitil sa anak na nasa sinapupunan ng kanyang ina
Ngunit, ang hindi ko inasahan ay ang huling parte ng pelikula
Hindi ko pinanood ang pelikulang ito ngunit nagbase ako sa buod nito upang malaman kung ano ang naganap [1]
Si Sunshine (Maris Racal) ay naghahanda na sumali sa “gymnastics team” para sa Olympics ngunit nalaman niya na buntis pala siya
Dahil dito, pumunta siya sa Quiapo upang bumili ng pampalaglag
Matapos ng eksenang ito ay makikita na sinusundan siya ng isang batang babae
Iyon pala, ang babaeng ito, na nasa larawan sa post na ito, ay isang “imaginary friend” ni Sunshine
Hindi ko na babanggitin ang gitna ng buod ng kwento ngunit sa huling parte ng pelikula, makikita na si Sunshine ay naghahanda para sa Olympics
Nagpakita muli ang “imaginary friend” na batang babae kay Sunshine
Tinanong ni Sunshine kung nauunawaan ba ng batang babae ang desisyon niya
Matapos nito, pinakita ng batang babae na tinatanggap niya at niyakap niya na may luha sa mata si Sunshine
Ang “plot twist” dito ay ang “imaginary friend” na ito ay ang anak ni Sunshine na namatay dahil sa aborsyon
Sa imahinasyon ni Sunshine, tinanggap ng kanyang anak ang desisyon ni Sunshine na patayin siya sa sinapupunan

Tila ba tinuturo ng pelikulang ito, hindi lang na dapat gawing ligal ang pagpili ng tao na patayin ang anak sa sinapupunan ng ina, kundi gugustuhin ng isang bata na mamatay na lamang sa aborsyon kaysa ang mabuhay dahil sa benepisyo na matatanggap ng nanay kung pinatay na lang ang kanyang anak
Nakakalungkot dahil sobrang sama ng moralidad na ipinapalaganap ng pelikulang ito
Dahil dito, nais ko lang ipakita kung ano ang sinabi ng mga taong nakaligtas sa tangkang aborsyon
Hindi sa lahat ng pagkakataon ay namamatay ang mga anak na pinapalaglag
Dahil dito, mahalaga na makita ang kanilang perspektibo sa usapin ng aborsyon matapos silang makaligtas dito
Sabi ni Linda Swayn na nakaligtas sa aborsyon ngunit nagkaroon ng problema sa kanyang bungo dahil sa bawal na gamot na ginamit sa pampalaglag,"The greatest gift I have received is life
God has given me the greatest gift of life [2]

"Ito naman ang mababasa sa buhay ni Charlie Rousseau, isang tagapagsalita sa radyo sa Canada, na nakaligtas ng aborsyon na nagdulot upang mabuhay siyang putol ang braso at dalawang binti,“She wants to continue with her dream to work and live remotely, and see the world [3]

"Makikita naman natin na lagi nanaginip ng masama si Kimberly na maaaring parte ng kanyang masamang alaala sa tangkang pagpatay sa kanya,“For as long as I can remember, I would have a recurring nightmare
I could feel it coming, as if someone was coming to kill me
Somehow I knew it was going to kill me
It was terrifying
When I was 15 years old, I woke from the nightmare screaming and crying [4]
"Ngayon, huwag muna natin isipin ang aborsyon kundi ang bagong silang na sanggol
Tama ba na patayin sila para hindi maapektuhan ang pangarap ng kanyang nanay
Sa tingin ba natin, sasabihin ng sanggol na tama ang desisyon ng kanyang ina na patayin siya
Malamang ay hindi
Ito rin ang ating rason sa pagtanggol sa buhay ng lahat, lalo na ng mga bata na walang kakayahan ipagtanggol ang kanilang sarili
Galing mismo sa boses ng mga nakaligtas ng aborsyon na alam nila kung gaano ito kasama at gaano kaganda ang buhay
Walang bata ang gugustuhin na sila ay patayin
Itigil na sana nila ang kasinungalingang ipinapalaganap sa pelikulang ito

Maris Racal and Jennica Garcia are two of this generation’s finest actresses, in my opinion

this isn’t really a film about mistakes
well, at least for me
it’s a film about the quiet burdens women carry—those moments when the world expects you to stay composed while everything inside you is breaking apart
what stayed with me wasn’t the plot itself, but the feeling of watching a girl stand at the edge of her dreams while life keeps pulling her in directions she never asked for
there is a particular kind of loneliness here that Filipinas know too well: the pressure to be strong, the fear of being judged, the lack of safe spaces to fall apart
The film captures that ache, the way society can be quick to moralize but slow to understand
For me, it felt like looking at a reflection of a system we’ve all quietly learned to navigate: the whispers, the shame, the institutions that pretend to help but rarely do
Yet in those heavy moments, you still see a girl trying to choose herself, even when the world insists she shouldn’t
it’s messy, raw, and painfully familiar… and that’s why it felt less like watching a film and more like remembering something you wish you could forget

ito, seryoso na at skl ko lang din this anecdote of mine
i remember being a transferee in sixth grade when i was suddenly forced into an intra-school debate tournament
one of the motions i had was about the legalization of abortion and i was placed in the opposing team
i vividly remember kung paano ako naging mulat sa topic na ‘to and i thought to myself, “oo nga, ‘no
bakit nga ba bawal
” i honestly had a hard time countering the government side’s points, so i just ended up focusing on my own arguments (without saying any rebuttals) instead — buti leader of the opp
lang ako no’n, lol
our debate teacher, or the madam chair, was very strict about not using the church as a basis when making an argument
but all i could think of then was the bible, i couldn’t think of any other countering argument na pwede kong maibato
and so, if a small-scale school debate tournament prohibits using the church as an argument, why can’t we demand the same from our government
bakit patuloy na iginigiit ang impluwensya ng simbahan sa batas if we supposedly live in a secular state

Sunshine offers a quiet yet affecting exploration of teenage pregnancy and abortion—two issues deeply intertwined with the social and economic realities of our country
What makes the film striking is its simplicity: it doesn’t rely on heavy dramatics, but instead allows its heartfelt moments and grounded storytelling to speak for themselves
I particularly appreciated how the film subtly incorporated supernatural elements
Rather than distracting from the story, these touches added depth and symbolism, making the film feel both intimate and introspective
It’s a creative choice that gives Sunshine a unique emotional texture
As someone who grew up Catholic, I’ve never taken a firm stance on abortion; I’ve mostly remained indifferent or unsure
But this film pushed me to reflect on the bigger picture
It gently raises a painful yet necessary question: Why bring a child into a country that struggles to provide a dignified, nurturing environment for its people
Without forcing a specific viewpoint, Sunshine invites viewers to confront the harsh realities that many young Filipinos face—stories that are often ignored or oversimplified
Overall, Sunshine succeeds not just as a piece of cinema, but as a conversation starter
It lingers with you, urging you to think about compassion, choice, and the societal conditions that shape both
It’s a simple film, but one with a resonance that’s hard to forget

“Drown out the noise
You are Sunshine
”it’s heartbreaking how many young women are going through this right now
abortion in the Philippines is not only illegal, but also so deeply stigmatized that many are forced to carry this burden alone, sometimes risking their own lives through unsafe procedures
the film portrays this reality with such quiet honesty that it sticks with you
the symbolism throughout was also so striking, like the “Gift of God” sign in the jeepney Sunshine rode, or her so-called imaginary friend who could represent her unborn child or her inner child
it was honestly so satisfying watching her stand up for herself against miggy and his father, who’s a pastor
then of course, her breaking the bottle on tito bobot’s head
every mf like him deserves that
the final sequence felt incredibly freeing as well
it was like she was finally free, almost like a release of everything she had been carrying — fear, shame, pressure, expectation

her imaginary friend disappearing can be interpreted that she did push through with the abortion (which parallels the 13 y/o kid and ariana), or as her finally finding peace with whatever choice she made
hopefully, this film gives conservatives some perspective on the immense weight placed on women in these situations, and they’ll finally be able to say, “Gets ko na
” not everyone has the means to raise a child, especially when society is quick to judge
and even if you do have the means, you might simply not be ready because you might still have dreams you want to chase
it’s really tough, and that’s why kindness matters so much
at the end of the day, we shouldn’t be the ones deciding what women should do with their bodies
and yeah, practice safe sex

I hesitated to write a review that delves into the realities women in our country face, because I’m not the person who should be speaking for them
But SUNSHINE is a deeply powerful film
It would’ve been easy for a story like this to sink into pure despair from beginning to end
Yet somehow, the film manages to confront its darkest truths while still carving out a sliver of hope
The performances are extraordinary—raw, fearless, and honest—but they make the film difficult to watch in the best possible way

It exposes how our country refuses to grow, medicine needed for the operation coming from black markets, how it continues to force women into roles far smaller than what they’re capable of, and how it avoids addressing issues that desperately need to be talked about
Women deserve choice
They deserve agency
They deserve that right without question

This film places you in the shoes of a woman who believes her life has been shattered by one reckless decision made by someone she trusted—and then shows, unflinchingly, how our society treats victims
Hopefully, the success of this film reignites the conversation around the importance of being pro-choice and pushes us toward building a better, more humane system
All we hope for is a little sunshine to finally break through

this film doesn't just tell a story; it exposes a system
for that reason, it stands as one of the most important films ever made in the philippines
honestly, it deserves far more attention, discussion, and recognition
include it in school curriculums too if possible
you don't need tearful monologues, or dramatic breakdowns (not that there's anything wrong with them) to understand the full weight of sunshine's situation
the film uses restraint as its sharpest tool
the dim, muted visuals; the overwhelming noise of her environment; the way the camera locks her in the centre of the frame
always boxed in, always between lines
all emphasise how trapped she is by the social and religious stigma, and by a society that refuses to recognise abortion as a woman's right
the blurred backgrounds aren't just aesthetic; they reinforce her disconnection from the world around her
she doesn't have the luxury to care about anything beyond her immediate reality: herself, her dreams, and the looming consequences of every decision she faces
and that is the tragedy, sunshine is a young woman with ambition, yet she navigates a world that is unforgiving
she is asked to seek god's forgiveness for attempting to abort the baby, yet if god is understanding, wouldn't he understand that she is not ready, and that she acted out of necessity
with abortion vilified and access almost impossible, the film illustrates how society corners, isolates, and silences young mothers
not with loud condemnation, but with quiet, crushing inevitability
it is a devastating portrait of how systemic and cultural forces conspire to limit women's autonomy, and a reminder of the human cost of denying choice
one of the most striking elements of the film, for me, is its gendered power dynamic
every character, without exception, imposes his own beliefs onto sunshine
urging her to keep the baby, citing legality, morality, or personal conviction
their "advice" is never about her well-being, it's about controlling her choices
the absence of a single moment where a man asks what she wants is not accidental, it reflects a broader social structure where women's autonomy is secondary to male authority
the women in the film, however, present a more nuanced spectrum
some internalise patriarchal norms and unintentionally reinforce them, but many others recognise sunshine's struggle immediately
they empathise not because they have the answers, but because they understand the emotional, economic, and social burden that falls disproportionately on women
their solidarity is quiet but powerful
a direct contrast to the coercive, dismissive tone of the male characters
the film ultimately critiques how systems built and upheld by men deny women agency, especially around reproductive choices
in a society where institutional and cultural norms consistently silence women, the film shows that women often became each other's only source of validation, understanding, and empowerment
no scene is waster
nothing is filler
every character is intentionally placed, each one shaping or limiting sunshine's decisions in ways that feel painfully real
this is definitely one of the best films i’ve seen this year
It truly left a lasting impression on me, i’m still processing what i just watched
Maris did an incredible job
Applause for the movie not letting the main character birth a child just to suit the palate of conservative filipinos
This is the type of films the Philippines should make more
Finally a movie with substance, relevance, and courage to tell a story despite cultural taboo
This is required and essential
I thought an hour and a half wouldn’t be enough to dig deeper into the journey of Sunshine but it was actually just enough to see all of it

Although, there were unnecessary choices made in the film that I disliked and that I wish were done differently and I wish saw more of Sunshine’s character in the lowest of lows or maybe I’m just greedy
However,Maris Racal is a revelation
And for the Philippines to have such a film like this one that speaks to so many women, even men, in the country
I hope this is a step forward for the country to move progressively and this be a force for politicians to pass that bill
Because after all, films are made to speak out, protest, and to implement change
Lastly, Sunshine is such a huge step towards good filmmaking in the Philippines
We need more films that speak of truth and of society
Stories that need to be heard and not rely too much on fake romance
Though Sunshine isn’t perfect as a film itself, the courage and the amount of truth revealed in an hour and a half are enough to have the voices of so many women be heard

Ang kwento, ang cinematography, ang emosyon

Sobrang raw and realistic from the familiar “jeje” song playing sa jeep pagsakay ni Sunshine, to the 13 yr old na nakaranas ng pang aabuso mula sa kanyang tito (talamak ang kaso ng incest sa pinas, thank u direk for highlighting that)
Sa sobrang realistic pati ang inis ko kuhang kuha ng conservative doctor
Literally had to pause and say “Putangina” pag sabing “Baka yan pala ang magiging future presidente ng Pilipinas or ang makakagamot sa AIDS
”Ang pelikulang ito ay napakatapang
It had the guts to shine a spotlight on a longstanding issue sa bansa na lagi na lang inooverlook
It dare call out and address what Filipinos considered as taboo
And as someone who had a debate with her mom over dinner about abortion, this film is so special to me
“Hindi ka ba kinikilabutan
” were my moms’ exact words but I cannot blame her

Being a country deeply rooted in Christianity, where morals and teachings of the church are deeply ingrained in you ever since you were young, it is actually hard to speak freely about this things without the catholic guilt creeping up on you
Kaya ang laki rin ng significance ng pagdasal muna ni Sunshine before nya gawin
To ask the lord for forgiveness
Plus it doesn’t shy away from showing the state of the country’s public healthcare system
Nakakaputangina lang
Putangina ng gobyerno
Putangina ng sistema kung saan kailangan maging life-threatening situation ang pagpapalaglag
Banning abortion does not end it, it only makes it unsafe for women since it causes them to resort to underground means
And what an irony that one of those means can be found tucked under the shadows of the church (mga ale na nagbebenta ng pamparegla, u carry so much hope for these women)
The very church that condemns it and shuns women who will even consider it
This film is a big step in understanding women’s bodily autonomy
Mas mahalaga pa rin ang buhay ng nagdadalang-tao
Lastly, Annika (the child symbolizing Sunshine’s future child) saying “Gets ko na” at the end is so so dear huhu
Bata pa ang bata para magkabata
She has her whole life ahead of her and god forbid a woman chooses herself and her dreams

kung iisipin, malaya ba maging isang babae
mapagpalaya ba ang manirahan sa ganitong klase ng bansa bilang isang babae
kailan darating yung panahon na hindi na kinakailangang kumilos ng babae sa isang lugar kung saan malayang malaya siyang husgahan dahil sa kaniyang mga desisyon
tuwing kailan mo masasabing malaya ka sa sarili mong bansa; kung nakakulong ka pa rin sa gate ng simbahan, sa ingay ng dyip at tren sa kalsada, sa konsensya mo, sa sarili mo

paano mo aasahang gumalaw ang isang babaeng hindi lang isa o dalawang tao ang "masasagasaan" sa pagtindig sa kaniyang nga karapatan bilang babae—kundi isang buong relehiyon at batas ang haharapin mo na dapat sana ay nangunguna sa pagbibigay sekuridad at protekta sayo
malinaw sa pelikulang ito ang mga problemang nagpahirap kay sunshine, pero higit na mas malinaw ang mga dahilan kung bakit mas lalo itong nahirapan
hindi sana kinakailangang mag-alala ni sunshine sa mga posibilidad na maaaring may maging sagabal sa natatangi nitong pangarap

dito ipinakita na kahit nakatira si sunshine sa lugar kung saan madilim, madumi, maingay, at dikit-dikit ang mga marurupok na bahay ay mayroon pa rin itong isang ate—isang babae, na lagi't lagi niyang ipapaalala na may kakampi pa rin siya sa hinagpis ng buhay

dito ipinakita kung paanong sa kabila ng mga taong maaari mong lapitan sa gitna ng problema ay mapipilitan ka na lamang maglakad nang mabilis at balisa sa quiapo sa takot na may makakita sayo, o di kaya'y mag check in sa isang motel sa pag-asang sa madilim na kwarto ring iyon matatapos lahat ng problema mo

para sa akin, sapat na ang mga eksena sa simbahan at mga rebulto sa harap ng mga pampareglang itinitinda patago upang malinaw na maihatid ang mensaheng nais maparating ng pelikula; na isang malaking sagabal ang mga aspetong isa tayong bansa na karamihan ay mga katoliko, at lahat ng pilipino'y mga hipokritong deboto, at mas may pakielam pa ang mga ito sa mga desisyon ng mga babae para sa kaniyang sarili, kaysa sa kani-kanilang mga buhay
ang pahayag na hindi handa si sunshine maging isang ina ang siyang dapat na tumapos sa lahat ng mga opinyong wala namang maitutulong sa kaniya
ganoon lang sana kasimple ang lahat

pero higit sa mga eksenang nakaangkla sa ating pagiging katoliko ay ang mga doktor, mga propesyonal na edukado, sa pelikula kung saan mas narinig ko pa silang nanghusga kay sunshine kaysa sa sarili nitong konsensya

paano ka nga naman hihiling na sana'y gawin nang legal ang aborsyon sa bansa, kung yung mismong mga pribilehiyo at edukado na mismo ang nagbibigay rason sayo upang mas lalong matakot at panghinaan ng loob
sa mundo na kagaya ng kay sunshine, sino nga ba ang maaari nitong kapitan
hindi ba't mapipilitan ka na lamang tahakin ang landas ng mga naging desisyon ni sunshine

nakakagalit isipin na sa pagtagal ng panahon ay mas lalo lamang dumadami ang mga kaso ng mga babaeng gumagawa ng sariling diskarte para mailaglag ang kanilang mga dinadala; na higit pa sa nagbibigay kapahamakan sa kanila
napakagaling ng eksena niya sa motel; naghihikahos sa pag-asa na mamamatay din yung reyalidad na nagdadalang-tao siya
mistula ko ring personal na nararamdaman yung pisikal na sakit na nagpapadugo sa kaniya
pero tumulo talaga ang mga luha ko nang napagtanto ko yung papel ng karakter dito ni rhed bustamante
hindi matatawaran yung dating ng kuwento niya, dahil nirerepresenta niya ang bawat batang babae na dumanas ng karahasan sa sarili nitong tahanan, mula sa sarili nitong kadugo
sa bawat katagang pagsambit ni coach na "drown out the noise
" ay ang reyalidad na hindi lahat ay katulad ni sunshine—sa bawat pitik ng mga kamay at lambot ng kaniyang katawan ay may kakayahan itong lunurin ang isip sa katahimikan

hindi lahat ng dumanas sa teenage pregnancy ay may kakayahang isarado ang isip sa bawat panghuhusga at pagsabi ng mga tao na, mali iyan, kasalanan iyan, malay pa natin at balang araw ang laman na gusto mong ipalaglag ay ang magiging presidente ng pilipinas

higit sa katotohanang dapat ay nasa lalake ang lahat ng sisi, malaking parte rin ang simbahan, gobyerno, at ang mga taong nakapaligid sayo, kung bakit hindi mo magawan ng desisyon ang sarili mong katawan at kinabukasan
pangarap ko rin ang lahat ng pangarap ng mga sunshine

Hands down, wala akong masabi sa palabas na ‘to
This film reveals everything about the Philippines that we don’t often talk about
Many Filipinos have no choice kasi illegal ang abortion dito, and young women are forced into situations THEY NEVER REALLY WANTED
It shows the harsh reality of how society constantly pressures women into motherhood, ignoring their dreams, their health, and their right to make decisions about their own bodies
The film doesn’t sugarcoat the pain physical, emotional, and mental—that comes with being trapped in a system that refuses to acknowledge their autonomy
What hits the hardest is how normalized this struggle has become, and how many are suffering in silence
Especially the story of rhed bustamante’s character
13 years old nag cacarry na ng baby  a child carrying a child
This is a message to all the people to talk more openly about abortion, to stop victim-blaming, and to hold those useless shitty ass irresponsible men accountable
It’s more than a movie—it’s a wake-up call, a plea for empathy, and a DEMAND for change

SUCH AN IMPORTANT FILM
During these times, we genuinely need more films like this
First, not only does it touch on the struggles of a young woman faced with an unwanted pregnancy
It also shows how easy it is for the men to rid themselves of the responsibility
Miggy DID NOT give a fuck about Sunshine
He wanted her to deal with it herself; he wasn't even going to give her money if she didn't threaten him
It was his fault that she got pregnant, and yet she has to suffer the consequences of their unprotected sex, which he insisted upon
Second, it is very important how this film shows that early/childhood pregnancies are not just because of young people's 'kapabayaan
' More often than not, young girls' pregnancies are results of sexual assault and rape by predators

One thing I like about Sunshine is its brazen risk to center the story on a 19-year old who's made consequentially irresponsible choices

It's a gambit that can easily be -- and, judging by discussions surrounding this movie, has already been -- misconstrued as a lesson on the importance of hammering down our society's puritanical views on sex and reproductive health to set teenage girls straight

That, somehow, Sunshine is a lesson in, as the elders say, "opening your legs for just about anybody"; that she did not listen to the adage is an absolute failing on her part, and its consequences fall rightfully on her shoulders

But here's the tricky bit: Sunshine could very well have been about a mother who could no longer give birth to another, and it would have still been met with the same logic-defying resistance that still places the blame squarely on the woman
Minor gripes include a finicky plot device that, at times, feels jarring and slightly questionable in terms of messaging
But it all feels egregious to say because the urgency of its existence really dwarfs over whatever minor flaws it may have

It also helps that Sunshine carried is so deftly by Maris Racal's and Jennica Garcia's career-defining performances, and a score by Rico Blanco that knows how to restrain and reintroduce itself in all the right moments

Sunshine cracks open a conversation on an obstinately immovable subject, and unflinchingly exposes the grim reality on how our women and girls move about our society, bearing the problems that we could easily find solutions to but which our religious guilt and intolerance constantly shame us into denying

not saying we went through the exact same thing, but generally, the gist of thinking your life is over, or will be if it does happen, because we don’t have a choice in the first place, and are expected to just live with it, is familiar

the amount of mental gymnastics people will spew about “the future of the children,” how they could be “the next inventor of a cure,” while never considering the mother, who has her own ambitions, who has to give birth, raise the child, and provide the system and support for their hypothesis to even happen… it’s all broken-record arguments

these are the usual lines they’ll say, and some of their reactions (doctors, friends, “partners”) really DO HAPPEN irl and it’s proof that the film is heavily based from real experiences, and well researched enough about the actual process people will go through (and went through) for this
here’s to shed light, to inform, and hopefully, to make people more open, thoughtful, and willing to give women the autonomy they deserve

PUTANGINA THIS MOVIE IS SO GOOD
if there is light, kahit konting-konti lang, we chase it—because sometimes that’s the only thing left for women to hold
sunshine (2025) is the kind of film na hindi ka pinapa-wow sa effects or spectacle
instead, it sits beside you quietly, like a friend na alam lahat ng pagod mo kahit hindi mo sinabi
it’s woman-centered in the most unsettling, honest way—walang sugarcoating, walang mythologizing, just the raw truth of being a girl in a country that asks you to endure more than it ever protects
the film strips away the usual softness associated with its title
sunshine isn’t light; she’s a girl trying to survive a world that keeps dimming her

and when the story touches the issue of abortion not being legalized in the Philippines, it doesn’t sensationalize it—pinapakita lang niya ‘yung totoo: na in this country, women are expected to carry consequences alone
that reproductive rights become moral battles instead of health and safety; na the system treats our pain like an inconvenience, our choices like crimes
‘yung internal struggle ni Sunshine—‘yung fear, guilt, confusion, desperation—hindi dahil “mahina siya,” but because society makes women feel cornered by circumstances we never chose
and the film doesn’t villainize her for thinking about her future; it villainizes the world that forces her to justify wanting one
and then there’s Miggy
Miggy is… familiar
not evil, not abusive, just painfully typical
he represents the kind of boyfriend most girls in the philippines know too well—the one who “cares,” but only until it requires accountability
the boy who says “I’m here for you” pero umiilag sa big conversations
the boy who loves you but doesn’t understand the weight you carry because he’s never had to carry anything like it
Miggy is the embodiment of how boys in this country are raised: may freedom without consequence, may opinion without knowledge, may presence without responsibility
his reactions, his avoidance, even his attempts to comfort—they feel real because they’re exactly what so many girls have lived through
boys who think support is just saying “kaya natin ’to” while leaving the actual pain to us
sunshine 2025 becomes a commentary on how women are taught to be accountable for everything—including mistakes that weren’t only theirs—while men are taught to be forgiven for everything
the movie doesn’t hate Miggy; it exposes him
it shows the casualness of male privilege, the way it slips into daily life unnoticed but heavy—always heavy—on our side
and that’s what makes the film hit: it’s not loud, not preachy, not dramatic
it just shows the truth—and the truth is already loud enough
sunshine isn’t a story about brightness; it’s a story about women trying to navigate a world that refuses to make space for their choices, their fears, their bodies, their futures
it’s a film that says:the pain wasn’t yours alone, but somehow, you were the only one expected to carry it
and long after the credits, you’re left with that hurt—the kind that reminds you why we keep fighting for a world where women don’t have to beg for the right to their own lives

Sunshine (2024) is the most needed Filipino film of our generation and the generations to come
Beyond the excellent storytelling and technicalities, the message it conveys in a predominantly Catholic & conservative country is a long-overdue revelation of the reality of women
The film opens conversations for the uncomfortable truth of human nature
This is not just Sunshine's story
This is also the story of every woman and every young girl who face the challenges of being silenced and whose rights are being dictated and stepped on by our society
Maris perfectly portrayed Sunshine as a woman who knows what she wants and realizes the power that she and every other woman should have
The rest of the cast realistically depicted the Filipino society that reflects their morals on the teachings of Christianity
Moreover, the two "imaginary" characters brought life to the film by displaying the faces behind the masked moralities our society tells us
As a child of unwanted birth and as an adoptee, I know deep in my heart how much I advocate for abortion
I will always side with what is just and right; the ability of women to have access to reproductive health and the power of women to make decisions for their own life

Although I have personal reservations about Maris Racal due to past issues, her performance in this film was undeniably amazing
Sunshine is a definite eye-opener regarding religion, stigma, and the taboo surrounding abortion matters here in the Philippines
I genuinely feel for all the women represented by the characters of Sunshine and Rhed
They may have different names, but they share a rough, unfair path: being stigmatized and pressured to conform to religious and misogynistic beliefs about motherhood
They are forced into the role of nurturing a child, often without considering their own agency
I particularly noticed the scene when Miggy and his father confronted Sunshine about her situation
They never once asked her what she wanted
Their "plans" were simply laid out for her to accept without a word, effectively depriving her of choice
This lack of genuine care is what hurts

Furthermore, the film shows how these women are forced to go through dangerous and unhygienic lengths just to pursue their personal dreams, highlighting how their rights as human beings are limited solely because of their CHOICE
I appreciate this film immensely, and it should be talked about more
The tragic reality of Rhed’s character, a 13-year-old victim raped and impregnated by her own uncle, is a situation faced by many
Yet, victims like her are still discriminated against for wanting an abortion

From the very beginning, the film doesn’t sugarcoat anything
It throws you straight into the raw, unfiltered reality of the city
You feel the noise, the chaos, the sense of being overwhelmed, like you’re standing right in the middle of it all
Pero beyond the city’s noise, Sunshine digs into something heavier
It shows the weight of Sunshine’s struggle, the clash between personal pain, religious expectations, and society’s harsh judgment
The movie doesn’t shy away from the reality na hanggang ngayon, ang hirap mag-access ng abortion services sa Pilipinas dahil illegal pa rin ito
It captures how isolating it is to face a problem this heavy, and how hard it is to seek help in a system that refuses to understand
Overall, I like it
i love how the noise of manila mirrors the noise inside sunshine’s own thoughts and decisions
how the kid represents her unborn child
how her sister shows her the reality of becoming a mother
and how the world becomes quiet and peaceful once she finally learns to silence the noise and listen to what she truly wants
all of it builds beautifully to that final scene

A young aspiring teenage Filipino gymnast who everyone looks up to has been selected in the National team to participate in Olympics
Her nightmare begins when she finds out she is pregnant
Her boyfriend wants her to abort
Her best friend disowns her
She hallucinates a small girl chasing her around trying to make her feel guilty
Desperate to pursue her gymnastics career, she buys a product from the local black market
She rents a room in a shady inn, inserts the product and ends up bleeding profusely
She wakes up in an anti abortion clinic to learn that the fetus is still alive
‘Sunshine’ plays out like a horror movie as the characters try to come to terms with their reality
The tension, fear and desperation is palpable
Sunshine’s journey from numb helplessness to a woman who wants to pursue her dreams is truly remarkable
Abortion is illegal in the Philippines under all circumstances, including rape, incest, or when the mother's life is at risk
Black markets of abortifacients thrive near places of worship and street side shops
Hospitals refuse admission and doctors perform secret illegal procedures
Antoinette Jadone’s writing and direction is raw and brutal
The narrative is neither preachy nor claims to know a solution to a complex problem that leaves women without agency
It simply critiques the situation and demands that viewers confront it along with women who are left helpless in front of politics and religion
Maris Racal pours her heart into the titular character and you would feel nothing but compassion and empathy for Sunshine Francisco
Barely ever climbs the mountain it wants to reach

There’s always a thin, trembling line between a patriarchal society and the relentless social construct that insists women still can’t decide for themselves—least of all when it comes to their own bodies
And even if we try to drown out the noise, this film refuses to stay quiet
It hits too hard
It shows the very realities women go through in today’s world
What makes it even bolder is its willingness to be raw, relevant, and unapologetically confrontational in a country where abortion remains illegal
It doesn’t tiptoe
It doesn’t soften its edges
Instead, it stares straight into the contradictions of a culture that claims to protect life while silencing the ones who live it

Visceral, gut-wrenching, and politically relevant
Sunshine is not only a film about resilience, it’s a commentary on the disparity between human systems and human persons
When a system is run by patriarchal standards, women live life isolated or alienated by how she is defined

yung dilemmas of decisions ni sunshine and yung heartbreaking truth about Mary Grace’s pregnancy
13 years old pa lang siya
Yes, 13 years old pa lang siya
The movie refuses to romanticize their situation
instead, it leans into the uncomfortable truths of being a young woman in a society that praises discipline, resilience, and sacrifice yet offers little support when life derails

Director Jadaone shapes the film with a raw, documentary-like honesty: tight shots of silent breakdowns, stripped-down scenes with no dramatic score, and a narrative that mirrors the suffocating pressure placed on young Filipinas navigating taboo choices
Lastly, ang nagustuhan ko talaga sa film na to is the fact na the film didn’t fail to show and acknowledge the other women surrounding sunshine
women who, though not always in the spotlight, embody the many forms of pressure, expectation, and silent resilience that shape the world she moves in
they all carry their own versions of sacrifice: women praised for being disciplined, nurturing, and endlessly strong, yet rarely offered the same support they tirelessly give

Kudos to Direk Tonet, Maris Racal, and the whole team responsible for creating this film, thank you for being brave and casting a light on our nation’s issues often overlooked in fear of the cultural taboo it carries
I would have rated it 5 stars, but the choice to represent Sunshine’s internal conflict with herself through a hallucinated child character doesn’t sit right with me
Jadaone’s direction results in jarring tonal shifts that muddle the film’s emotional center
What was perhaps intended as a bold attempt at cinematic expression to illustrate inner turmoil instead dilutes the stakes, softening the thorniness of the subject matter with a cartoonish detour
It’s an interesting idea but one that never quite coheres with the rest of the film’s pro-choice sensibility
In fact, by personifying an unborn child as a character which speaks and thinks, then Sunshine unintentionally reinforces the very moral framing that anti-abortion rhetoric thrives on
It circles back into the age-old “when does life begin
” debate—a question that continues to paralyze policymaking in the country, even when the conversation should be about autonomy, access, and proper healthcare
The film doesn’t just inherit this moral hang-up; it stages it, frames it, and in doing so, muddies the clarity of its own politics
Though, I will still give my flowers to this movie
It helped brought upon a conversation in our country long overdue and for that I am grateful
I hope it inspires other filmmakers to be bold in the face of a country that chooses to be blind to issues that continue to grow with no solutions in sight

maraming sunshine sa lipunan—na biglaan, takot, at walang lakas ng loob na harapin ang pagiging ina—pero hindi ito usapin na masama ng tao si sunshine kaagad nang dahil lamang sa hindi pa siya handa
a moment of temptation is not enough reason to demand she accept her situation, as forcing a woman into parenthood before she is ready is a far greater mistake
i hope this film opens more eyes and highlights the need to strengthen reproductive rights in our country, recognizing that abortion is a right for all women
men who cause pregnancies rarely face the same scrutiny or shame; women, on the other hand, bear society’s judgment alone
abortion is not always chosen for pleasure—often it is the result of abuse or exploitation
it is heartbreaking that in the philippines, a case of violence against women is reported every 57 minutes
globally, over 30% of women—more than 737 million—experience abuse from partners or non-partners
many feel trapped, unable to leave because they are pregnant and have no right to terminate

in february 2024, save the children urged stronger reproductive rights in the philippines, noting that 35% of filipino girls under 15 became pregnant from 2021 to 2022—clear victims of abuse and exploitation
this is a critical issue that the government must address
women have the right to control their own bodies and make their own choices—regardless of religion, culture, or social pressure
they are often the most vulnerable and left behind in such situations
thank you to sunshine for her courage in standing up for herself and pursuing her dreams, and thank you to the film for portraying these realities

ito yung ingay ng moralidad, ng tsismis, ng relihiyong mabilis magturo pero mabagal magmahal
ito yung ingay ng mga taong hindi naman mabubuhay sa katawan mo pero sila ang pinakamalakas magdikta kung ano ang dapat mong maramdaman, gawin, at piliin
at sa lahat ng ito, isang nineteen-year-old girl ang pasan ang mundo—a girl who should’ve been allowed to dream freely, pero sinasakal na ng lipunang takot sa kababaihang may sariling isip
isang bagay na ramdam mo agad sa pelikula: magkakampi ang mga babae
halos lahat ng karakter ay babae, at karamihan sa kanila may dalang munting piraso ng simpatya
isang kolektibong danas
isang unspoken sisterhood built on the multiple burdens that women carry: being caregivers, dreamers, breadwinners, shock absorbers of society’s cruelty
pero hindi rin romantisado ang pelikula—may mga babaeng kakampi, at may mga babaeng hindi
katulad ng doktor na ultraconservative, na nagpapaalala sa atin ng painful truth: hindi lahat ng babae ay mapagpalaya, at hindi lahat ng babae ay kakampi sa kapwa babae
minsan, ang mismong sistemang umaapi ay umiiral din sa mga babaeng natutong ipasa-pasa ang sakit
pinaka-mahalaga sa lahat: hindi totoong pagiging makasarili ang pagdedesisyon ng babae para sa sarili niyang katawan
kung may isang “gets ko na” moment ang sunshine, ito ‘yon
kung sarili lang niya ang iniisip niya, wala sana tayong ganitong pelikula
wala sana tayong ganitong lalim
pero ang totoo, bawat desisyon niya ay puno ng takot, pagmamahal, at pag-asa—lahat ng bagay na kinalimutan ng lipunan kapag babae ang may kailangan pumili
dito rin pumapasok ang simbolismo ng batang babae—ang unborn child, ang personified conscience
ariana is 13 y/o's own past self, her own fear, her own what-if
lahat ng interaction nila ay nangyayari “sa loob,” sa pinakatahimik na sulok ng isip ng babaeng hinahati ng daigdig
at nung ending, it’s for herself
the hug is acceptance
ang yakap na iyon ay tahimik na paglaya

pero kahit sa mundong pilit nagpapatahimik sa kababaihan, may irony na hindi kayang itago ang pelikula: sa isang konserbatibong lipunan, ang nagbebenta ng religious figures ay siya ring nagbebenta ng abortion pill
ang ob ay bigot
ang bahay ay hindi laging ligtas
ang simbahan ay humuhusga
at ang babae
wala man lang tunay na espasyo para huminga
bakit ang mga lalaki, may opsyon
bakit ang kababaihan, pilit pinapapili pero hindi ginagawaran ng tunay na choice
dito nagiging mas malakas si sunshine
hindi siya martyr
hindi siya sainted victim
she doesn’t just endure—she decides
she chooses herself kahit alam niyang bawat galaw niya may kasamang kurot ng panibagong judgment
she’s not fearless, but she moves anyway
at minsan, iyon na ang pinaka-matapang na pwedeng gawin ng babae sa bansang sobrang hilig kontrolin ang katawan at kinabukasan niya
dedma sa ingay
dedma sa prejudice
kung may pangarap ka, hawakan mo, kahit pa buong mundo pa ang naka abang na magkamali ka
ang sabi ni direk jadaone, ang pagbubuntis ay magbabago sa katawan ni sunshine, sa career niya, sa buong trajectory niya bilang atleta
at totoo—para kay sunshine, ang pregnancy ay literal career suicide
at dito umaalingawngaw ang tanong na gusto talagang ipukpok ng pelikula: bakit ba laging kababaihan ang kinakailangang magsakripisyo ng pangarap
bakit ang freedom ng babae ay laging conditional
kaya oo—decriminalize abortion
kasi ang autonomy ay hindi dapat ipinaglalaban, dapat innate
ang katawan ng babae ay hindi battleground para sa moralidad ng iba
in the end, sunshine reminds you that sometimes the bravest thing a girl can do is to choose herself, quietly, consistently, even when the world says she shouldn’t

⋆˚࿔Especially in the Philippines, society is stacked against women

From secretive clinic visits to hushed conversations with unsympathetic adults— with Sunshine’s journey, you can feel the judgement of a society that constantly polices women’s bodies and their choices
Patriarchy is relentless : they leave it up to the women to pick up the pieces that the men shattered— "Bahala ka na diyan, just get rid of it"

Maris Racal’s performance was exquisite, ramdam mo yung pagod, sakit, and overwhelming suffocation that Sunshine faces as she navigates through making a choice that is supposed to be hers and hers alone
Every flip, every landing, every stretch was a step towards her dreams— the stage, the recognition, the life she has ever envisioned for so long
Sunshine’s journey is not just about survival; it’s about the courage to continue dreaming in a world determined to limit her
Gymnastics wasn’t more than a sport, it was her identity, her sanctuary, the place that gave her hope to keep believing
At the end, pinili niya pangarap niya, despite the fear, the sadness, and the guilt, her decision was a refusal to let anyone dictate her future, to let her stop that dream

First of all, I know that this movie premiered at the 49th Toronto International Film Festival in 2024 and arrived in Philippine cinemas 4 months ago

And now that it finally dropped on Netflix… I hope I’m not too late to say it finally: This movie is powerful Antoinette Jadaone delivers one of her most fearless films yet with ‘’ — a coming-of-age sports drama that hits with quiet power and emotional honesty
Maris Racal plays the titular character, a young gymnast on the road to the Olympics
Her world revolves around discipline, repetition, and the dream of making it to the competition she’s trained her whole life for
But when she discovers she’s pregnant, her perfectly controlled world cracks open
What I loved about the film is how it never sensationalizes her situation
Sunshine’s fear is treated with quiet realism
The movie acknowledges how complicated teenage pregnancy is, especially in a society where abortion, reproductive rights, and bodily autonomy remain heavily stigmatized and often misunderstood
These themes are controversial
And yes, the movie will divide people
But ‘’ refuses to look away from the truth:
Maris is phenomenal here
She carries the entire emotional weight of the story with a performance that feels painfully real

She rarely breaks down on screen, but you think her internal collapse in the smallest expressions — the breath she holds, the way she avoids eye contact, the way she pushes her dream forward while everything else is falling apart

The supporting cast — particularly Jennica Garcia, Meryll Soriano, Rhed Bustamante, and Xyriel Manabat — also elevate the film, each representing a different kind of pressure or support Sunshine faces
And yeah, some male characters in the movie definitely got what they deserved
Jadaone’s direction is quiet, patient, and uncomfortably close — exactly how it should be
The movie lets us follow Sunshine’s anxiety and feel the suffocating pressure she’s under
One of the film’s boldest artistic choices is the recurring appearance of a mysterious girl who seems to follow Sunshine
At first it’s confusing, then a bit eerie, then surprisingly emotional
I won’t spoil anything, but when the film finally reveals who she represents…
It’s symbolic, heartbreaking, and adds a deeper emotional layer to Sunshine’s arc
Beyond the gymnastics, beyond the controversy, Sunshine is really about choice — and how young women often aren’t given the space to empower themselves to make their own choices

The movie conveys important messages: your body is your own; silence can mask the deepest struggles; the pressure to be perfect is harmful; pursuing dreams matters, but so is ensuring one's survival; kindness fosters safety, while judgment breeds fear; and young women need safe spaces
The movie doesn’t push a specific viewpoint — it drives for humanity
Overall, ‘’ is brave, heartbreaking, and painfully relevant
It does not shout — it whispers truths that hit even harder
Indeed, it’s a film that mirrors reality for many young women today, and one that our society needs to see, even if the conversations it starts are uncomfortable
With that being said, I’m going to give this movie…9/10

Where Filipino films trend to historic dramas and at times big explosive bursts of emotion, Sunshine reflects the good and the ugly of Filipino society in the modern times

It is within the same type as the classics like Maynila sa Mga Kuko ng Liwanag, but where it could've easily just copied that same old formula of poverty, crime, and the ugliness that lies beneath the city, the film chooses to explore controversial topics at its heart and anchors it toward really good character dynamics, not to mention where other films center around a male character from the rural side or from the slums, we instead focus on a lady who is faced with a great moral dilemma (in the Filipino perspective, you'll get it) when her dreams are on the verge of being stripped away from her

While watching, I sometimes forget that it is a Filipino film (not to sound derogatory or self-hating btw) because it strays away from tired old cliches other Filipino films do, and while the blueprints of those tropes are present, they are presented in a light that feels more subdued than its usual contemporaries
Also, I do love how the film does respect the audience in choosing not to explain certain things, letting us fill in the gaps
It's a great watch, in my opinion
And I feel that this film should be at the helm of some sort of renaissance for Philippine cinema, where we aren't afraid to speak out and be bold while also making great art out of it

GANDA WTHit cuts deep, revealing the brutal realities of being a woman in a society na hanggang ngayon ay kinakadena pa rin ng patriarchy; mahirap maging babae, lalo na sa pilipinas, at ramdam mo ‘yan sa bawat eksena

its raw honesty, feminist gaze, and unflinching portrayal expose how our culture endlessly polices women’s bodies, choices, and dreams, lalo na when the world expects them to sacrifice habang ang iba ay malayang nakakalakad palayo

by the end, the film leaves you holding both galit and pag-asa, reminding us that kahit ilang bagyo pa, women will still rise — mabagal man, pero matatag, like sunshine breaking through the darkest clouds
Maganda ang Sunshine, napakita ang pagiging taboo ng abortion, teen pregnancy, at kung gaano kakonti ang kontrol ng babae sa sarili nilang katawan sa Pilipinas

raw, quiet, tapang na hindi sumisigaw pero tumatagos

ang ganda ng pagkakahuli sa Manila — yung sikip, yung init, yung ingay, pati yung bigat na hindi mo maipaliwanag
hindi siya romanticized; totoo lang
yung Quiapo scenes
sobrang accurate na parang naamoy mo na yung alinsangan at dasal at pag-asa ng mga taong dumadaan dito para humanap ng solusyon sa problema na hindi sila binibigyan ng choice
and that’s the heart of the film: choice
or the lack of it
bilang kababaihan, ang hirap pag-usapan ng reproductive rights dito sa Pilipinas kasi every conversation is haunted by guilt, religion, and judgment
pero Sunshine manages to hold that tension — yung guilt, yung fear, yung what-if — without punishing the woman at the center of it
this isn’t just a film — it’s a mirror
it asks questions na hindi madali, and refuses to hold your hand para bigyan ka ng sagot
it lets you sit with discomfort
it lets you ask yourself: kung hindi ikaw ang nasa sitwasyon, bakit ikaw ang magdedesisyon
What will you do if your dream is at stake because of one mistake
Sunshine delivers a powerful message about reproductive rights and the need for access to safe and legal abortion
The film shows the current state of healthcare in the Philippines and how this basic necessity has become inaccessible, especially to those living below the poverty line
I like how the film does not romanticize the societal issue of unwanted pregnancy
Instead, it highlights how stigma deeply affects women’s decision-making about their own bodies
It shows how the main character struggles with an internal conflict and debates with her own conscience
While the film clearly presents why abortion should be legalized and recognized as part of healthcare in the Philippines, it also portrays how religion and health often clash
It is true that our country is still in the process of accepting that abortion is a right that should be available to all women
Some might argue that safe sex is the only way to avoid these situations, but we cannot ignore the fact that many women experience sexual abuse, rape, or non-consensual ejaculation during intercourse
Sunshine is not just a film that explains why safe abortion should be legalized; it calls our attention to consider the issue without guilt-tripping women through religion or societal pressure
Women should have the freedom to decide what to do with their own bodies
Marriage or co-parenting should not be treated as a band-aid solution to a lifelong responsibility
These solutions do not apply to everyone, especially to those who do not have the means to support a child
I know we all have different perspectives on this issue, but thinking long-term about the future of our children depends on how ready we truly are to take on this responsibility
Hindi talaga ako binibigo ni direk Jadaone kapag usapang isyu, pakikipagsapalaran, at boses ng kababaihan
Kuhang-kuha rin ang realidad ng Maynila (bigla kong naalala ang Maynila sa mga Kuko ng Liwanag [1975])

Love how the film depicts the harsh reality of what women have to go through just to be able to decide for themselves and their BODIES
This movie really goes to show how making abortion illegal makes it so much harder and dangerous for women
It does not sanctify the value of life since in the first place the life of the woman is endangered
Moreover, I love how Manila gets depicted in this light, it shows the good and bad that comes with the city
It is bad for obvious reasons, the normalized chaos that is happening around it, how every night Sunshine is there, a mayhem ensues
However, I appreciate how Manila became a sanctuary place for her, where we can see how despite the chaos that happens every night, there are bits of humanity that saves her
The girl dun sa hotel, yung tricycle driver, and the 13-year-old girl that she met
Furthermore, I would like to commend the addition of having childrens act as her conscience or the "what if child of hers"
It's a great addition because we can see how in the beginning of the film the girl was literally shouting "murderer" over and over again because in her perspective, her mother is harming her
But in the end when she said "gets ko na", it became a cathartic scene as it finally hits us that it isn't about being irresponsible and selfish ---- rather it is something more than that
The whole line of the girl saying to her friend Ariana that her dream is the same as Sunshine's is a great addition because I think it rings true with reality

As every now and then, when a child hears about the dreams of their parents and how they had to stop it to take care of their children, especially when it comes to Mothers, the child often feels bad and just wished that thier Mom was able to live out their dream first

Lastly, I love the relationship of sunshine and her older sister, the fact that never once pinagalitan o diniktahan ng ate nya sa kung paano nya haharapin yung sitwasyon niya goes to show how much she trusts and love Sunshine

I also love the contrast that all throughout the film there were different sides of the story whether labelling her as a "murderer" o miggy telling her to do what you got to do that once you reached the end scene when her sister just told her "kahit ano maging desisyon mo kampi lang ako sayo" made it soo impactful

Kase in the end yun lang naman ang kailangan niyang marinig, we have seen her face through that circumstance alone with nothing but her conscience, that the moment na sinabi sa kanya yun, it became a relief to her as well as allowed her to finally tell someone or at least cried it out to them na natatakot din siya kase nga bata din siyaa and hindi pa siya ready maging nanay
All in all, the film was a 10 out of 10, and I appreciate how the film wasn't all in the face about what you should believe in and what you shouldn't

It just presents Sunshine's story and her decision which should be acknowledged because hindi dapat humantong sa isang sitwasyon na mas uunahin pa ng isang doktor ang kaniyang lisensya kesa sa buhay ng isang tao dahil lang "nagpalaglag" siya
If you really value life in its essence then we should also acknowledge the life of the person carrying the baby so bakit niyo papabayaan lang na mamatay yung batang 13-year-old
so in conclusion:TANGINAA NG MGA LALAKETANGINA MO MIGGYTANGINA NUNG DOKTORATANGINA NUNG LALAKING DOKTORTANGINA NUNG TITO TANGNIA NUNG WALANG KWENTANG NANAY (
) - di nya deserve matawag na nanay

The concept of birthing a child will never be their problem, it will never even cross their minds

I love how realistic the scenes were when all the pregnant were all together, aiding each other and comforting each other; that is the harsh truth— men will never know the connection us women have with one another

Rhed (Mary Grace) is the exact reason why abortion should be legalized in the Philippines

Gets na gets ko—and I hope many more people will get it, too
This film struck a deep chord with me
Nearly every scene felt like it could happen in real life—and in many cases, it truly does
Abortion is treated like a sin in this godforsaken conservative and dominantly Catholic country
Many people disagree, but it really doesn’t matter whether you agree or not
In the end, the decision should be up to the woman who’s pregnant
We shouldn’t have an opinion—just understanding is enough
After all, it's her body, her life, her future, her choice
That's why I'll always firmly believe that abortion should be legal and safe

There are women—and even girls—who are far too young, forced into pregnancy, still unstable, still trying to build their own lives, and completely unprepared to raise a child while chasing their dreams
Abortion is healthcare, and access to it is a basic reproductive right
This film captures that reality so loudly
It’s loud with the streets of Manila, with people’s judgment, with hypocrisy

You can hear it all so clearly—the way society pushes women toward unreliable and dangerous methods like pamparegla in Quiapo or hilot, simply because abortion is condemned and proper reproductive healthcare is lacking
It’s so fucked up and heartbreaking
Tangina, ang hirap-hirap maging babae sa bansang ’to—sa mundong ’to
'Yung scene na walang filter na ipinakita ang estado ng public hospitals—mga serbisyong galing sa buwis ng tao pero hindi nila kayang ayusin—sobrang sakit panoorin
Sobrang bulok ng sistema natin
And there’s probably something even worse behind it—we are so fucked
So when Sunshine finally went through with the abortion, I felt relieved
For a moment, I was scared she might keep the baby
Bringing a child into the world when you’re not ready—and being forced to give up your own dreams because of it—is one of the most cruel things you can do to yourself and to that child
And that’s exactly why choice matters

Isa sa mga kagandahan ng Sunshine ay ang pagiging tapat nito sa katotohanan
Pinakikita ang katotohanan kung anong meron sa Maynila; masikip, maingay, maputik, at maalikabok
Pamilyar ang ingay
Pamilyar ang tsismisan
Pamilyar ang katolisismo
Pamilyar ang sikip at mahabang pila sa pampublikong ospital
Pamilyar ang sistemang mabagal at madalas walang pakialam
Pamilyar—dahil ipinanganak at lumaki rin ako sa pinakasiksik na bahagi ng Maynila
Pero bilang lalaki, iba ang mundo na ginagalawan ko
Sa gitna ng pelikula, naisip ko: hindi ako pamilyar kung paano ba talaga maging isang babae
Hindi pamilyar ang takot
'Yung takot na hindi ko kailanman mararanasan, pero ramdam ko habang pinapanood si Sunshine
Para sa akin, Sunshine works because it feels lived-in
Alam mong ganito talaga ang Pilipinas
Bansang puno ng pangarap, pero puno rin ng hadlang
At sa gitna ng lahat, nando'n si Sunshine: takot at desperado, pero matapang
Hindi melodrama ang dating
Hindi rin lecture
Mas parang paalala: hindi dapat ganito kabigat ang mundo para sa mga kababaihan

Maris Racal is Sunshine; and Sunshine is womanhood incarnate
Through Sunshine’s story, the film becomes a quiet yet devastating reflection of how our society—and deeply, its systems—continue to fail women
One of the film’s most harrowing moments is the scene where Sunshine rescues Mary Grace after she nearly dies from a self-induced abortion
It is not just a moment of personal crisis; it is a painful exposure of how inaccessible, judgmental, and unsafe our healthcare system remains for women…

I was gonna leave it there but I have thoughts so full steam ahead—Manila is a staple in almost every Filipino film, being the capital and all, but rather than the large city itself— Sunshine specifically captures the essence of Quiapo so well

The bustling markets, the overcrowd and kids begging for alms, and religion is embedded everywhere— whether it be its churches, the posters within the buildings, street stalls selling rebultos and rosaries, or the people themselves

I don't usually care for the setting of the story but I always think it's smart when it actually helps drive the narrative forward, so I find this neat little aspect of the film amusing (also, while we're at it, props to whoever the prod designer is wow)

I watched this at 3AM during a vigil so I had all the time to read other reviews and can I just say, while I understand how it could be viewed as such— I don't think this film was didactic or propaganda
I love films that open conversations and Sunshine opened a lot, but more than the conversations it opened, I love how the center of it has always been women
The heart of Sunshine is Sunshine herself, and Maris Racal definitely gave the performance of a lifetime in this one
The fact that she filmed this the same time as Can't Buy Me Love is insane, talk about range
Also, props to Direk Tonet 'cause I have only watched this film a day before, but it is so dear to my heart

everything moving, heartbreaking, and gut wrenching has already been said about this film so i’ll add my favorite short sequence that left me breathless:sunshine’s attempt at self-induced abortion was at this tiny raggedy inn room; a rule of thirds composition using the windows to divide the shot, sunshine in the rightmost basked in green light, which feels cold and lonely, away from the leftmost corner of the room lit in warm orange light emitting from a small lamp
she’s boxed and contained and helpless, it’s just her carrying the weight of her own problems and decisions
as she slowly carries out the procedure of the abortion, the train rolls by—loud and deafening—like the heavy guilt and grief setting in
she can’t drown out the noise, she’s drowning in the noise of her troubled thoughts
(not great at writing and describing things sry but yeah the inn scenes were the start of my ugly sobbing throughout the movie)

Sunshine is the kind of film that hits quietly but deeply
It shows how hard it is for women in the Philippines to ask for help, and how scary it can be, pero kahit ganun, it reminds us na may karapatan pa rin tayong mangarap
I also liked how it showed the reality of our Olympians here
You can give everything, train like crazy, be so talented, pero minsan hirap ka pa rin mabuhay
Ang bigat pero ang totoo
Sunshine’s character feels real and strong
Hindi perfect, pero may tapang pumili ng sarili niyang future
Even when she had an easier option, pinili pa rin niya yung pangarap niya
I respect that so much
Sana mas maraming babae ang makapili ng sarili nilang path, dreams, and life

waited so long na maging available on digital 'yung movie na 'to and needless to say it was worth the wait because wtf ilang beses ako naiyak from the depiction pa lang ng daily life sa pinas, the customs and norms we have, to the imaginary children representing the "could-have-beens", and also in a way, the girls' own guilt following them with every decision they try to make for a common situation that girls—especially the young ones—suffer through here sa bansa na 'to (not just the pregnancy itself but also the internal battles that come with religious guilt and having dreams beyond what other people would call as "a gift from God")
na-bother lang ako sa texting scenes because ang random ng pag-type sa keyboard, but hindi mo na talaga maiisip 'yon at present sa sobrang daming na-tackle for such a short film
and yet it was done so beautifully
the pacing was SO GOOD and i couldn't help but fall in love with the cinematography, the WRITING, the ACTINGGG because of how natural the lines were delivered
kudos kay direk at pang top 4 films na ata 'to
two takeaways for me dito: there's really no hate like christian love and seeing female solidarity in films will always make me cry
(pwede na 'to i-add sa films about girlhood bcs it would be my fav on the list)

The raw, unflinching exposition of a city filled with contradictions—similarly displaying the distinct patriarchal society overshadowed by the hold that Catholicism has over the views and laws held by the Philippines
It is beautifully shot and the story is even more beautifully represented through the acting
Sunshine’s story is one related to by many women and brings to light so many issues that women are facing
Her story is one of light amongst the dark; befitting her name
